report: Summary: The pathology report describes a pulmonary wedge resection material with a peripheral manifestation of a mucin-forming adenocarcinoma, which is consistent with a peripheral mixed bronchopulmonary adenocarcinoma. The TNM classification based on the samples suggests the tumor is at stage IB, and there are foci of infiltration in the visceral pleura. Immunohistological analysis confirmed the bronchopulmonary origin of the tumor. Further analysis as to the tumor's point origin will follow.

Summary: Peripheral bronchopulmonary adenocarcinoma of the right upper lobe with a mixed histological subtype comprising of a large-cell and clear-cell, solid and acinar component with slight mucin formation. The tumor is primarily located in S3 with extension over the oblique fissure into adjoining segments of S4 and S5. TNM classification based on the material is pT2 pNO pMX R0, stage IB. Resection margin of the bronchus, vessels, and all removed lymph nodes are tumor-free.

Diagnosis: Central to peripheral bronchopulmonary adenocarcinoma of the right lower lobe with papillary and small acinar components, slight mucin formation, and main localization in segments 7 to 9. TNM stage IB (pT2 pN0 pMX R0). The tumor has extended to S4 of the middle lobe, but the resection margin of the bronchus and vessels, as well as all removed and identified lymph nodes, are tumor-free.

Diagnosis: Large undifferentiated mixed large-cell and polymorphocellular adenocarcinoma of the left upper lobe of the lung with a clear-cell appearance and possibility of neuroendocrine differentiation. TNM classification on the basis of this material pT2 pN1 R0, stage IIB. It is likely a primary peripheral carcinoma of the lung that has invaded the overlying visceral pleura to a minimal extent with central bronchopulmonary and hilar lymph node metastases. Other hilus lymph nodes and other lymph nodes removed are tumor-free. Immunohistochemical analysis reveals a high proportion of tumor cells positive for low molecular weight keratins, a small proportion positive for high molecular weight keratins, and relatively high proportion positive for TTF1. The tumor classification of mixed-type adenocarcinoma of the lung is confirmed.

Diagnosis: Intermediate to peripheral well differentiated mixed adenocarcinoma of the left upper lobe of the lung, mainly localized in S1. The carcinoma shows quantities of predominantly luminal mucus and a bronchioloalveolar pattern of spread with a partly pseudopapillary structure here and a small acinar and solid component. The resection surface, the resection margins of the bronchus and vessels (sample 1) and the lymph nodes of samples 2 to 8, are tumor-free. TNM classification (UICC, 7th ed., 2009): pT2a pNO L0 V0 R0, stage IB. C34.1, M8255/3.

A 5.9 cm gliosarcoma with hemorrhage, edema, and extension to the corpus callosum is seen in the left medial frontal lobe. Excisional biopsy and excision of the left frontal brain tumor reveals a neoplastic glial proliferation displaying anaplasia, microvascular cellular proliferation, and areas of necrosis with pseudopalisading. A second glioma infiltrates the marginal tissue in the superior gyrus. MGMT promoter methylation test results are negative for evidence of methylated MGMT promoter. Immunohistochemistry shows heavy liofibrillogenesis in neoplastic cells with GFAP, positive strands, and small minority cells that overexpress the p53 protein. A proliferation index of about 18% is observed in the more active areas. The Snook's reticulum demonstrates heavy reticulin deposition in the spindle, GFAP-negative areas. The neoplasm is characterized as high histological grade glial neoplasm with a sarcomatoid component.

The pathology report is for an excision biopsy of a brain tumor that is consistent with glioblastoma (WHO grade IV), a high-grade glial neoplasm with mitotic activity and extensive necrosis. Immunostaining showed GFAP positivity and keratin negativity, with a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 20 percent. The frozen section diagnosis was confirmed on permanent sections. The report includes the results of various staining methods performed in the laboratory. The sample was determined to be an analyte-specific reagent and not cleared or approved by the FDA for investigational or research purposes. The laboratory is CLIA-certified for high complexity clinical laboratory testing.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: Glioblastoma multiforme in left frontal region. Local meningeal infiltration is present. Nuclear and cytoplasmic pleomorphism, mitotic figures, endothelial proliferation, and necrosis are present. The tumor is a grade 4 astrocytoma. The diagnosis is based on gross and microscopic examinations, including hematoxylin-eosin staining with supplementation of GFAP. The specimen consists of fragments of tissue partly submitted for frozen section diagnosis and partly submitted in cassettes A, B, C, D, and E. The clinical history is the left frontal glioblastoma. The final diagnosis was made by the attending pathologist following the review of all pathology slides.

Pathologic Diagnosis: Two biopsies from the right temporal lobe of the brain show malignant infiltrating gliomas consistent with glioblastoma multiforme. Vascular proliferation is seen in one biopsy and palisading around areas of necrosis is found in the other. Intraoperative diagnosis favored glioblastoma multiforme. The specimens are received in two parts, one of which is frozen for cytologic preparation and frozen section diagnosis while the remaining unfrozen tissue is entirely submitted for diagnosis. The patient has a right temporal ring-enhancing lesion and undergoes biopsy. Diagnosis is based on gross and microscopic examinations by the attending pathologist.

The final diagnosis for a male patient with glioma is a small cell subtype of glioblastoma, located in the left temporal region. The tumor cells have microvascular proliferation, and some areas of necrosis. The tumor is positive for GFAP immunostain, and KI-67 immunostain is positive in scattered cells. Immunostains for SMI31, synaptophysin, and EGFR were used in the evaluation, and FISH for 1p19q is pending. An addendum to the report confirms strong and diffuse positivity for EGFR, supporting the diagnosis of glioblastoma small cell variant. The report also mentions that the specimen submitted contained components considered to be analyte specific reagents (ASR's) that have not been cleared or approved by the FDA. The sample was submitted in four parts, and the gross description of each part is provided.

The report describes a biopsy and removal of a tumor in the right frontal lobe of the brain. The final diagnosis reveals it to be a glioblastoma multiforme, a high-grade glioma, with irregular segments of red-tan, soft tissue ranging from 2.0 X 1.2 X 0.2 cm to 1.8 X 1.7 X 0.6 cm. The tissue was labeled with the patient's name and number and was submitted for intraoperative consultation, frozen analysis, and permanent sections. The report details the specimens submitted (A: RIGHT FRONTAL TUMOR and B: FRONTAL LOBE TUMOR) and their size and shape. Four cassettes (A1, A2, B1, B2) containing sectioned fragments, and B3-B4 containing the remaining tissue were submitted entirely.

The pathology report identifies the presence of glioblastoma multiforme (WHO grade IV) in three different specimens from the right frontal lobe of the brain. The first specimen labeled as "tumor" is composed of multiple irregular fragments of soft tissue and is submitted for frozen section analysis and permanent sections. The second specimen labeled as "B-RF tumor" is composed of multiple soft, irregular, cerebriform tissue fragments and representative sections are submitted in six cassettes. The third specimen labeled as "C-inf WM" is composed of multiple irregular, soft, cerebriform tissue fragments and representative sections are submitted in five cassettes. The microscopic diagnosis confirms the presence of glioblastoma. No further information regarding patient history, treatment plan or clinical findings is provided.

A portion of the 5th, 6th, 7th and 8th ribs, lymph nodes at levels 5, 9, 10 and 11, and the left lung were received for examination. The ribs were unremarkable with hypercellular marrow. Lymph nodes at levels 5, 9, 10, and 11 showed no metastatic carcinoma. The left lower lobe of the lung displayed squamous cell carcinoma and was tightly adhered to the upper lobe. The visceral pleura was free of tumor and margins were clear. Sixteen peribronchial lymph nodes showed no metastatic carcinoma. Ancillary studies showed that the left lung was at pT2N0MX stage.

Clinical History/Diagnosis: Left lung CA. Source of Specimen(s). A: Portion of 6th rib. B: Lymph Node, level 9. C: Lymph Node, level 11. D: Left lung. E: Lymph Node, level 5. F: Lymph Node, level 7. Gross Description: The specimen is received in six parts. Poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma (7 cm) with neuroendocrine features is present in the left upper lobe lung and is negative for chromogranin and synaptophysin and focally positive for CD56. Negative bronchial and vascular margins. No tumor is seen in any of the lymph nodes (0/1 in level 9, 0/1 in level 11, 0/2 in level 5, 0/1 in level 7). Designation of Sections: 4FSA bronchial margin, 4A vascular margin, 4B. hilar nodes, 4C section approximately 5cm from bronchial margin, 4D-4E. additional section hilum, possible peribronchial lymph nodes, 4F-4G. tumor, 4H tumor in relationship to left pleura, 4I uninvolved lung. tissue. Note: The summarized report excludes irrelevant information such as patient name, doctor name, hospital name, reference, treatment plan, and sample size, shape, and weight.

Clinical History/Diagnosis: Lung cancer. Source of Specimen(s): 1. Portion of sixth rib. 2. Level five lymph node. 3. 11L lymph node. 4. 12L lymph node. 5. Left lingula. 6. Level six lymph node. 7. Level seven lymph node. Final Diagnosis: 1. Portion of 6th rib, excision: - Skeletal muscle and bone with no tumor seen. - Normocellular trilineage bone marrow. 2. Level V lymph nodes, excision: - Two of seven lymph nodes with metastatic carcinoma (2/7). 3. XI lymph nodes, excision: - Multiple lymph node fragments (seven of nine) with metastatic carcinoma (7/9). 4. XII lymph nodes, excision: - Three of four fragments with metastatic carcinoma (3/4). 5. Left lingula, resection: - Squamous cell carcinoma, 4.2 cm, poorly differentiated. - Lymphovascular invasion is identified. - Visceral pleura is not involved. - Bronchial margin with no tumor seen. - Vessel margin with carcinoma present but the vessel wall is not involved. - Emphysema. 6. Level VI lymph nodes, excision: - One of eight lymph nodes with metastatic carcinoma (1/8). 7. Level VII lymph nodes, excision: - Eleven lymph nodes with no tumor seen (0/11). Gross Description: Received in seven parts. Source of Tissue: 1. Labeled #1, "portion of 6th rib". Gross Description: Received fresh labeled "portion of 6th rib". It consists of a segment of rib measuring 2.5 x 2 x 1 cm. Representative sections submitted in 1A, following decalcification. 2. Labeled #2, "level 5 lymph nodes". Gross Description: Received fresh labeled "level 5 lymph nodes". It consists of multiple soft black-brown anthracotic lymph nodes measuring from 0.3 up to 1.5 cm in greatest dimension. The lymph nodes are entirely submitted in 2A-2B. Designation of Sections: 2A- multiple small lymph nodes, 2B - one large bisected lymph node. 3. Labeled #3, "11L lymph nodes". Gross Description: Received fresh labeled "11L lymph nodes". It consists of multiple soft black-brown anthracotic lymph nodes measuring from 0.2 up to 2.7 cm in greatest dimension. The lymph nodes are submitted in 3A-3C. Designation of Sections: 3A- multiple small lymph nodes, 3B-3C- one large bisected lymph node. 4. Labeled #4, "12L lymph nodes". Gross Description: Received fresh labeled "12L lymph nodes". It consists of multiple soft black-brown anthracotic lymph nodes measuring from 0.5 up to 1.0 cm in greatest dimension. The lymph nodes are entirely submitted in 4A-4B. Designation of Sections: 4A- two small lymph nodes, 4B- one large bisected lymph node. 5. Labeled #5, "left lingula". Intraoperative Consultation: FS OF BRONCHIAL MARGIN: BRONCHIAL MUCOSA WITH NO TUMOR SEEN; TUMOR PRESENT IN THE PERIBRONCHIAL TISSUE. Gross Description: Received fresh labeled "left lingula". It consists of a lobe of lung weighing 114 grams and measuring 15 x 8 x 5 cm. The pleura is gray-tan and smooth. The specimen is sectioned to reveal an ill-defined, firm black-brown ill-defined mass measuring 4.2 x 3.5 x 3.5 cm and located approximately 0.5 cm from the closest bronchial and vascular margins. The tumor appears to infiltrate the bronchus. The remaining lung parenchyma is red-brown, congested with no other masses present. Also received in the same container is an additional wedge of lung measuring 8.5 x 5 x 2.5 cm with two attached stapled margins measuring from 7.5 up to 8 cm in greatest dimension. The wedge is sectioned to reveal a homogeneous, soft red-brown congested cut surface with no masses present. The bronchial margin is entirely frozen in 5FS. Additional random section of the remainder of the specimen is submitted in 5A-5F. Designation of Sections: 5FS- frozen section bronchial margin, 5A- vascular margins, 5B-5C- tumor in relation to bronchus, 5D-5E- tumor with adjacent uninvolved parenchyma, 5F- additional wedge of lung received in same container. Source of Tissue: 6. Labeled #6, "level 6 lymph nodes". Gross Description: Received fresh labeled "level 6 lymph nodes". It consists of multiple soft black-brown anthracotic lymph nodes measuring from 0.2 up to 0.9 cm in greatest dimension. The lymph nodes are entirely submitted in 6A-6B. 7. Labeled #7, "level 7 lymph nodes". Gross Description: Received fresh labeled "level 7 lymph nodes". It consists of multiple soft black-brown anthracotic lymph nodes measuring from 0.5 up to 1.5 cm in greatest dimension. The lymph nodes are entirely submitted in 7A-7C. Designation of Sections: 7A- two large bisected lymph nodes, 7B-7C- multiple anthracotic lymph nodes. LUNG TEMPLATE: Specimen Type: Wedge resection. Laterality: Left. Tumor Site: Lingula. Tumor Size: Greatest dimension: 15 cm (T1 if <=3.0 cm; otherwise T2). Histologic Type: Squamous cell carcinoma. Histologic Grade: Poorly differentiated. Extension of Tumor: Carcinoma does not involve visceral pleura (T1 unless > 3.0 cmT2)/. Venous (Large Vessel) Invasion: Present. Arterial (Large Vessel) Invasion: Absent. Margins: Margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Distance from the closest margin 0.5 cm. Regional Lymph Nodes: 39 regional lymph nodes examined. Regional lymph node metastasis: 13 ipsilateral mediastinal and/or subcarinal lymph node(s) with metastatic carcinoma (N2). pTNM: T2 N2 Mx.

The pathology report describes a left upper lobe lung wedge excision and lobectomy, along with the inferior mediastinal, aortic, and N1 lymph nodes. The diagnosis reveals a Grade 3 (of 4) squamous cell carcinoma, which forms a 2.3 x 2 x 1.8 cm mass adjacent to the pleura but without direct invasion. There is benign lung parenchyma and multiple intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes present, but no residual tumor is seen. The bronchial margin is negative, and all lymph nodes are also negative for tumor. Tissue from the aortopulmonary lymph node shows only fibrovascular tissue, and there is no lymphoid tissue identified.

DIAGNOSIS: Grade 3 squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobe of the lung has formed a mass measuring 3.8 x 3.7 x 3.5 cm, invading the visceral pleura. Eight intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The bronchial margin is negative for tumor as well. Multiple excised mediastinal lymph nodes, including 3 right paratracheal and 4 subcarinal, are negative for tumor.

The pathology report describes the results of a surgical procedure in a patient with a pelvic mass. The report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary serous carcinoma in various organs, including the omentum, ovaries, fallopian tubes, cervix, colon, peritoneal implant, appendix, umbilical nodule, and anterior abdominal wall. The report also notes the size, location, and extent of the tumors, as well as involvement of lymph nodes. The report provides details of the gross and microscopic findings and confirms the diagnosis of Stage IIIC T3c N1 Mx.

The pathology report describes a case of ovarian cancer with involvement of both ovaries, including capsular invasion and necrosis. The tumor is identified as serous carcinoma with nuclear grade 3/3 and clear cell features. No lymphatic invasion is identified, but there are clusters of malignant cells in the omentum. The report also notes the presence of Nabothian cysts on the cervix, a uterine leiomyoma, and benign lymph nodes in two omentum samples. The appendix is without histopathologic abnormalities. A liver biopsy shows portal tract lymphocytic infiltrates, and an ileum adhesion biopsy has acute and chronic inflammation with numerous macrophages but is negative for malignancy. Frozen sections of the left ovary show a high-grade adenoma, without mucinous components.

A brain mass consisting of tan to beige soft tissue was received for frozen section and diagnosed with malignant glioma. Another brain mass consisting of irregular ovoid cortical gray matter and underlying subcortical white matter has been submitted for Tumor Bank. Both masses have been diagnosed with glioblastoma multiforme (WHO Grade IV astrocytoma).

The pathology report describes two specimens from a left brain mass, which was detected by CT scan. The first specimen was submitted for frozen section and was diagnosed as "Malignant Glioma", while the second specimen was submitted fresh and consisted of multiple pieces of tan soft tissue. The diagnosis for both specimens was "Glioblastoma Multiforme (WHO Grade IV)." The report confirms that the laboratory is certified to perform high complexity clinical laboratory testing.
The pathology report indicates the tumor site as the left frontal region, and the histological diagnosis is glioblastoma multiforme. No additional information is provided.
Filtered pathology report: Left occipito-temporal glioblastoma multiforme.

The pathology report pertains to a patient diagnosed with adenocarcinoma in the prostate and seminal vesicles. The primary Gleason grade is 4, the secondary Gleason grade is 3, and the total Gleason score is 7. The tumor is located in the right and left posterior, with the dominant tumor mass located in the left posterior from mid to base. The report indicates no vascular invasion but perineural invasion is present. The diagnosis indicates multicentric foci of invasive carcinoma with extracapsular extension located in the left posterior base. The surgical margins have a focal presence of the tumor in the mid-gland. The non-neoplastic prostate exhibits nodular hyperplasia. No malignant cells are present in the lymph nodes, which were benign, and there is no involvement of the bladder neck or seminal vesicles.

The pathology report pertains to a patient who underwent surgery for pancreatic cancer. The biopsy of the pancreatic neck margin was negative for tumor, but the distal pancreatectomy, splenectomy, and partial omentectomy revealed a 2.2 cm invasive grade 3 adenocarcinoma with perineural invasion in the body of the pancreas. The tumor also spread to peripancreatic soft tissue, while the pancreatic ducts had pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia. Chronic pancreatitis was observed in the distal pancreas, but the surgical margins were negative for tumor. Multiple lymph nodes were negative for tumor, and the spleen parenchyma was unremarkable. The final pathology report was based on macroscopic examination and frozen section histologic evaluation of the specimen, and the available surgical material was classified as AJCC pT3NO 7th edition, 2010.

Clinical History: Hepatocellular carcinoma, history of skin carcinoma. Preoperative: NA. Specimen Type(s): A1 Gallbladder and Contents, B: Right lobe of liver. Final Diagnosis: A. Gallbladder and Contents, Cholecystectomy: Chronic cholecystitis, mild. B. Liver, right lobe, Resection: Hepatocellular carcinoma, moderately differentiated. Key Pathological Findings: Tumor configuration nodular, tumor size 15.2 cm x 6 cm x 5.2 cm, histologic grade moderately differentiated, parenchymal margin free of tumor, venous invasion absent, angiolymphatic invasion present, pathologic stage T2 NX MX. Gross Description: A. Gallbladder and Contents, tubular gallbladder with green-yellow mucosa, no stones. B. Right lobe of liver, 15.5 x 15 x 7 cm, 1.2 cm from closest resection margin, centrally necrotic tumor mass, encapsulated, non-cirrhotic liver parenchyma, no satellite nodules identified. Representative sections submitted.

The final diagnosis of the left renal mass partial nephrectomy reveals renal cell carcinoma, papillary type 1, Fuhrman nuclear grade 2 out of 4. The tumor size is 2.0cm and there is no invasion through renal capsule or Gerota's Fascia or renal vein invasion. The surgical margins are free, and there are mild chronic inflammation and focal glomerulosclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney. The pathologic stage is pT1aNXMX. The specimen is received fresh, consisting of a 2.0 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm mass surrounded by a rim of renal parenchyma. The specimen is serially sectioned to reveal a tan-yellow, well-encapsulated mass that does not involve the renal capsule or perinephric fat. A representative section was submitted to the Tissue Procurement Laboratory.

The pathology report describes specimens labeled A to F, which include a left renal mass, left adrenal gland, and peritumoral fat. The final diagnosis for the left renal tumor is papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 1, with low-grade nuclear grade and predominantly tubular growth pattern. The tumor has three nodules measuring 4.0 cm, 0.7 cm, and 0.3 cm. The surgical resection margins are negative for malignancy. The left adrenal gland has nodular cortical hyperplasia, negative for malignancy. The peritumoral fat is negative for malignancy. There is chronic interstitial inflammation and focal fibrosis in the non-cancerous kidney tissue. The lymph nodes are not examined, and the pathological stage is Tia NX XX. The attending pathologist has personally reviewed the entire case and rendered the diagnosis. The frozen sections of the specimens are submitted to the tissue procurement laboratory.

Final diagnosis: Renal cell carcinoma, papillary type 1, Fuhrman nuclear grade 2, with two separate foci, confined to the left kidney measuring 0.7 cm and 2.5 x 2 x 1.7 cm. Resection margins (ureteral, vascular, and peripheral soft tissue) were free of tumor. Multiple papillary adenomas (17) and acquired cystic disease of the kidney were also present. Pathologic stage (for both foci): pT1a NX MX. Immunohistochemical stains support the diagnosis. Surgical margins were clear, and lymphovascular invasion was not identified. The patient had a clinical history of end-stage renal disease and had undergone a living-related donor right renal transplant.

Final Diagnosis: A. Benign renal parenchyma in the deep margin of the right kidney. B. Renal cell carcinoma, papillary type II present in the right kidney. Surgical margins are free of malignancy. Pathologic stage: pT1a NX MX. C. Benign adipose tissue in the additional right cystic wall. Key Pathological Findings: - Procedure: Partial nephrectomy. - Specimen laterality: Right - Tumor size: 2.9 cm. - Tumor focality: Unifocal. - Macroscopic extent of tumor: Tumor limited to kidney. - Histologic type: Papillary renal cell carcinoma. - Sarcomatoid features: Not identified. - Tumor necrosis: Present at 10%. - Histologic grade (Fuhrman Nuclear Grade): G3. - Microscopic tumor extension: Tumor limited to kidney. - Margins: Margins uninvolved by carcinoma. - Perineural invasion: Absent. - Angiolymphatic invasion: Absent. - Lymph-vascular invasion: Absent. - Primary tumor (pT): pT1a: Tumor 4 cm or less in greatest dimension, limited to the kidney. - Regional lymph nodes (pN): pNX: Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed. - Distant metastasis (pM): pMX. Clinical History: History of prostate cancer. Preoperative Diagnosis: Renal mass. Intraoperative Consultation: FSA1. DEEP MARGIN RIGHT KIDNEY: No tumor identified. Gross Description: A. Benign renal parenchyma in the deep margin of the right kidney. B. Encapsulated rubbery nodule consisting of renal cell carcinoma, papillary type II, with a size of 2.9 cm and limited to the kidney. Necrosis up to 10% noted with focal hemorrhage. C. Benign adipose tissue in additional right cystic wall. Note: The report has been filtered to exclude irrelevant information that cannot be inferred from a whole slide image.

The pathology report describes a 6.0 cm moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lower lobectomy, associated with angiolymphatic and visceral pleural invasion. No involvement of N1 or N2 lymph nodes was observed. All margins were free, and the pathologic stage was T2 NO MX. Biopsies of lymph nodes at various levels show reactive changes, with no evidence of malignancy except for a single fibrocalcific granuloma in one lymph node that tested positive for histoplasma. The lung lobectomy also displayed mild host lymphocytic response, emphysematous change associated with osseous metaplasia, and focal post-obstructive pneumonia. Biopsies of the bronchi and carina show no evidence of malignancy, but squamous metaplasia with basal cell hyperplasia and submucosal acute and chronic inflammation were present. The squamous cell carcinoma displays an interesting pattern of subpleural growth in a lepidic fashion, with lymphatic infiltration and coincides with an airspace-filling pattern of growth in the main tumor mass.

Diagnosis: primary lung cancer, squamous cell carcinoma, in a Caucasian male. Clinical information: ethnicity - Caucasian, clinical specimen - lung tissue, tumor anatomical site - not specified, sample type - OCT block, histological grade - 3, TNM stage - T4N2M0. There is also a blood sample mentioned with no tumor present, frozen in a tube, and no further information on diagnosis or treatment. The report includes a reference to a medical criterion from 12/19/12.

Diagnosis: A: Lung, right upper lobe, lobectomy - Adenocarcinoma, poorly differentiated, with focal papillary architecture, 4.5 cm diameter, morphologically similar to previous uterine papillary serous carcinoma. Bronchial margin not involved, pleural margin focally involved (see light microscopy). B: Lymph node, Station 7, biopsy - No metastatic carcinoma identified (0/1). C: Lymph node, R9, biopsy - No metastatic carcinoma identified (0/4). D: Lymph node, R10, biopsy - No metastatic carcinoma identified (0/2). Comment: None. Intraoperative Consultation: A frozen section is requested by Dr. FSA1: Right upper lobe, lobectomy, bronchial margin - No in situ or invasive carcinoma identified. Clinical History: The patient is diagnosed with non-small cell lung carcinoma of the right upper lobe. Gross Description: Four appropriately labeled containers are received. Container A is additionally labeled "right upper lobe." Within is a plastic yellow biopsy cassette labeled FSA1. Also within is the lobectomy specimen. Specimen fixation: formalin. Type of specimen/parts of lung received: right upper lobe partial lobectomy. Size of specimen: 13 x 12 x 4.5 cm. Weight of specimen: 220 grams. Other attached structures: none. Tumor size: 4.5 x 4.1 x 3.5 cm. Tumor description: ovoid, circumscribed, tan, and solid with central softening. Relationship of tumor to bronchus: directly involving a medium-sized bronchus. Distance of tumor to bronchial margin: 9 mm. Relationship/distance of tumor to pleura: the tumor grossly comes to within 1 mm of the visceral pleural surface but not directly involving it (the overlying pleura is pink/purple and smooth). Distance of tumor to other surgical margins: a 9 cm linear stapled margin of resection runs parallel to the longitudinal axis of the ovoid tumor; the tumor's closest approximation to this stapled margin is approximately 1 cm. Presence/absence of satellite tumor nodules: absent. Description of non-tumorous lung: unremarkable pulmonary parenchyma. Block Summary: A1, A2 - tumors relationship to bronchus. A3, A4 - tumors relationship to pleura. 5 - tumor. - tumor at area of central softening. ni - tumor/normal parenchymal interface. A8 - representative sections of normal parenchyma. A9 - en face section of previously inked hilum. Container B is additionally labeled "station 7." Within are two brown/black soft tissue fragments measuring 1.1 x 0.5 x 0.4 cm in aggregate. Container C is additionally labeled "R9." It holds a 1.5 x 0.6 x 0.5 cm tan/gray soft tissue specimen that is bisected and entirely submitted in block C1. Container D is additionally labeled "R10 lymph node." Within is a 0.9 x 0.5 x 0.4 cm tan/gray soft tissue specimen which is bisected and entirely submitted in block D1. Light Microscopy: A light microscopic examination is performed by Dr. The frozen section diagnosis is confirmed (Specimen A). Tumor histologic type (WHO classification): adenocarcinoma, with focal papillary features. Tumor histologic grade (WHO classification): poorly differentiated. Tumor size (greatest dimension): 4.5 cm diameter. Histologic assessment of surgical margins: bronchial margin not involved. Pleural involvement: focally positive (block A3). In situ carcinoma: no definite in situ carcinoma identified. Invasion: angiolymphatic - present (small vein), perineural - not identified. Lymph nodes (by node group): no metastatic carcinoma identified (0/7 total).

CLINICAL INFORMATION: The patient has a reported history of non-small cell carcinoma involving the left lung. No other clinical information is provided. GROSS DESCRIPTIONS: Six formalin-filled containers labeled with the patient's name and medical record number are received. The first container is additionally labeled "station 9." It holds three nodules of tan/black, soft tissue, which, in aggregate, measure 2.1 x 0.7 x 0.6 cm. These are submitted in their entirety in block 1. The second container is additionally labeled "station 10." It holds a single somewhat irregularly shaped nodule of tan/black, soft tissue, which measures 2.2 x 1.1 x 0.7 cm. The specimen is bisected and submitted in total in block 2. The third container is appropriately labeled "station 7." It holds two nodules of tan, soft tissue using focal areas of black discoloration. The larger fragment measures 2.9 x 1.3 x 0.9 cm, and the smaller fragment. measures 1.8 x 0.6 x 0.5 cm. The specimens are bisected, and half of the smaller fragment and half of the larger fragment are submitted in block 3, and the remaining half of each specimen is submitted in block 4. The next container is appropriately labeled "station 5." It holds three irregularly shaped fragments of tan, soft tissue with focal areas of black discoloration. In aggregate, these measure 3.2 x 2.2 x 1.2 cm maximally. The specimen is submitted in its entirety in blocks 5 and 6. The fifth container is additionally labeled "lymph node 4L." It holds two nodules of tan/brown, soft tissue. The smaller nodule measures 0.7 x 0.4 x 0.5 cm, and the larger measures 2.2 x 0.9 x 0.9 cm. Both are submitted in block 7. The sixth container holds a left lung consisting of a left upper lobe as well as a left lower lobe and lingula. The apex of the left upper lobe has the pleural surface marked in black ink and has previously been opened for tissue procurement, revealing a tan/white lesion with central necrosis. The borders of this lesion are somewhat irregular. This mass measures 4.6 cm x 4.2 cm x 4.3 cm. This lesion appears to come within half of a millimeter of the pleural surface. This lesion does not appear intimately associated with any airways grossly. The remaining lung parenchyma appears tan/brown in color with focal enlargement of air spaces. Representative sections of the lesion and lung are submitted as per block summary. Several lymph nodes are present adjacent to the left upper lobe bronchus. They measure 1.5 cm, 1.2 cm, and 1.1 cm in diameter, respectively. These are bisected and submitted in total in blocks 9 and 10. Specimen fixation: formalin. Type of specimen/parts of lung received: left lung, including both upper and lower lobes. Size of specimen: 23.3 cm x 14.1 cm x 6.2 cm. Weight of specimen: 750 g. Other attached structures: none. Tumor location: apex of left upper lobe, near periphery. Tumor size: 4.6 cm x 4.2 cm x 4.3 cm. Relationship of tumor to bronchus: not obviously associated. Distance of tumor to bronchial margin: 5.8 cm. Relationship/distance of tumor to pleura: grossly extends extremely close, 0.05 cm. Presence/absence of satellite tumor nodules: none. Involvement of attached structures by tumor: not identified. Description of nontumorous lung: focal dilatation of air spaces. BLOCK SUMMARY: 1 - station 9 lymph nodes. 2 - station 10 lymph nodes. 3,4 - station 7 lymph nodes. 5,6 - station 5 lymph nodes. 7 - station 4L lymph nodes. 8 - left upper lobe bronchial margin. 9,10 - peribronchial lymph nodes (3). 11-15 - representative sections of tumor. 16,17 - left upper lobe, lung parenchyma. 18,19 - left lower lobe, lung parenchyma. MICROSCOPY: Light microscopic examination is performed by Dr. Tumor histologic type (WHO classification): Adenocarcinoma. Tumor histologic grade (WHO classification): Poorly differentiated. Tumor size (greatest dimension): 4.6 cm by gross measurement. Histologic assessment of surgical margins: Negative. Pleural involvement: Tumor focally extends to pleura but does not appear to penetrate it. In the area of closest approach of the tumor to pleura, there is adherent adipose and skeletal muscle, consistent with focal adhesion to the chest wall. Carcinoma in situ: Not identified. Invasion: Angiolymphatic - present, vascular involvement within the tumor mass. Perineural - not identified. Lymph nodes (by node group): See below. Findings in nontumorous lung: Emphysema, scattered lymphoid aggregates. SPECIAL STAINS: PAS stains show occasional intracytoplasmic globules which are diastase-resistant. DIAGNOSIS: LEFT LUNG, REMOVAL - POORLY DIFFERENTIATED ADENOCARCINOMA, 4.6 CM GREATEST DIMENSION. - VASCULAR SPACE INVASION IDENTIFIED WITHIN MAIN TUMOR MASS. - TUMOR EXTENDS TO, BUT NOT THROUGH, PLEURA. - SURGICAL MARGINS NEGATIVE FOR TUMOR. - 3 STATION 12 L LYMPH NODES WITH NO TUMOR SEEN (0/3). LYMPH NODES, STATION 9, REMOVAL - NO TUMOR SEEN IN 4 LYMPH NODES (0/4). LYMPH NODES, STATION 10, REMOVAL - NO TUMOR SEEN IN 2 LYMPH NODES (0/2). LYMPH NODES, STATION 7, REMOVAL - NO TUMOR SEEN IN 2 LYMPH NODES (0/2). LYMPH NODES, STATION 5, REMOVAL - NO TUMOR SEEN IN 3 LYMPH NODES (0/3). LYMPH NODES, STATION 4L, REMOVAL - NO TUMOR SEEN IN 2 LYMPH NODES (0/2).

The pathology report describes a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with a 2.5 cm diameter, consistent with a primary lung tumor, found in the right upper lobe. The margins of the surgical sample were not involved, and pleural invasion was absent. The patient has a history of grade 3, ductal breast carcinoma but this adenocarcinoma is more likely a lung primary based on the immunophenotype, which showed TTF-1 and HER2 immunoreactivity with no reactivity for GCDFP or ER. The report also includes gross description of the specimen and references the intraoperative consultation for further testing to exclude metastasis.

Former smoker with right lung nodules discovered on chest CT. Biopsy revealed squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe lung wedge, moderately differentiated, with no vascular or perineural invasion identified, and in situ carcinoma present. The tumor extends subpleurally but not to the pleural surface, with in situ carcinoma also present. The stapled margin is free of tumor. The non-neoplastic lung shows interstitial fibrosis and focal organized pneumonia. The lymph node status is as follows: peribronchial 3/7. No direct tumor extension into lymph nodes is identified. Multiple fragments of benign anthracotic lymph nodes were found in some specimens. Intraoperative consultation confirmed benign lymph nodes in most specimens and infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma in the right upper lobe lung wedge. The case was also reviewed by WHO, who agreed with the rendered interpretation.

The pathology report indicates the presence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in various lymph nodes and the left lower lobe of the lung. Some lymph nodes showed benign lymphoid tissue, while others had metastatic carcinoma. The total number of lymph nodes examined is not specified, and the report includes sections of the specimens submitted for frozen and permanent sections. The lung tumor measures 3.8 x 1.8 x 1.6 cm, shows vascular invasion and extends subpleurally but not to the pleural surface. The bronchial margin is free of tumor, and no in situ carcinoma is identified. Other abnormalities in the non-neoplastic lung include focal atelectasis, emphysematous changes, chronic bronchitis, respiratory bronchiolitis, and scar. The lymph node status indicates that 4 out of 4 peribronchial lymph nodes and 1 out of 2 lymph nodes in other areas are metastatic. Intraoperative consultation confirmed that some the lymph nodes were benign and one was metastatic squamous cell carcinoma.

The pathology report pertains to a patient with squamous cell carcinoma in the left upper lobe of the lung. The report contains information on six specimens that were submitted for examination. The first five samples were noncancerous, while the sixth sample from the left upper lobe showed moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor measured 1.9 cm and showed lymphovascular invasion but no perineural invasion. No tumors were found in the bronchial margin or pleura. A separate focus of bronchioloalveolar carcinoma measuring 0.5 cm was identified away from the main tumor. Multiple atypical adenomatous hyperplasias were also observed. The lymph node status showed no metastatic nodes. The remaining sections of the report provide details on the specimens received for examination.

The patient had a workup for an MVA with a right upper lobe mass and a right lower lobe nodule. The diagnosis was moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 3.2 cm in the right upper lobe of the lung, involving the chest wall into skeletal muscle, with vascular invasion present. Eleven benign lymph nodes were excised, and no tumor was seen in the bone and skeletal muscle specimens. Nine additional lymph nodes were excised, with three found to be benign and submitted entirely. The lung specimen contained a well-circumscribed tan firm mass measuring 3.2 cm x 3.2 cm x 1.5 cm at the periphery in the lateral aspect at 4.3 cm from the bronchial margin, and anthracotic peribronchial lymph nodes were identified. Background lung parenchyma showed severe emphysematous changes. The frozen section diagnosis was benign, and the permanent diagnosis was the same.

Final diagnosis includes chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder, invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of pancreas, portion of stomach and duodenum. There is no malignancy found in lymph nodes sampled from the left hepatic artery. Margins are free of tumor, but pancreatic margin has focal pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN-1a). Pathologic TN stage is pT3 NO. Additional findings include pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia, chronic pancreatitis, and lobular atrophy. Gross descriptions note an indurated, ill-defined mass in the pancreas, and mucosa surfaces appear green-yellow and velvet-like in the gallbladder.

The pathology report documents the investigation of nodules on the liver, lymph nodes, and pancreatic head cancer. The liver samples show steatosis, necrosis, and no malignant evidence. Most lymph nodes show no malignancies, but one posterior lymph node showed positive results for tumor, and there is a fragmentation of the lymph node junction. The pancreatic sample demonstrates poorly-differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma invading adjacent organs and positive lymph nodes. Additionally, intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm with low and moderate-grade dysplasia was observed, and some extent of invasion of lymphatic vessels and perineural tissues were present. Chronic pancreatitis, cholecystitis, and acute serositis of the duodenum were identified as concomitant pathologies. Margins were free of tumor except for the pancreatic resection margin that involved low-grade dysplasia IPMN.

The pathology report pertains to a patient with a history of pancreatic neuroendocrine tumor who underwent surgery. The report includes findings from several organ biopsies, including lymph nodes, the gallbladder, and omentum excisions. The main finding is a well-differentiated pancreatic endocrine neoplasm measuring 3.5 cm, which is confined to the pancreas, with no lymphatic, vascular, or perineural invasion. All margins are free of neoplasia, and 16 lymph nodes are free of metastatic disease. Focal PanIN-3 is noted in an area of atrophic pancreas, with a retention cyst noted in adjacent pancreas. The report also includes details on the surgical specimens, including the pancreaticoduodenectomy, gallbladder, retroperitoneal node, omentum, and final pancreatic margin. The report mentions the absence of venous and lymphatic invasion, perineural invasion, and mitotic activity. Ancillary studies for various hormones were negative.

The pathology report pertains to a resected portion of the spleen and pancreas, with a palpable mass grossly appreciated. The final diagnosis reveals a pancreatic endocrine neoplasm, well-differentiated, with a tumor size of 3cm and about 1/mitotic count per 10 HPF. The report further states no necrosis present, and the pancreatic margin is free of the tumor. A focus of PanIN 1-2 is located at the pancreatic resection margin. Immunohistochemistry staining indicates the tumor cells to be positive for Synaptophysin and chromogranin and CD56. The Ki-67 immunostain reveals a proliferation index of approximately less than 1%. The report mentions a grossly unremarkable spleen, while the attached spleen measures 11.5 x 6.5 x 5.5 cm, with the capsule intact. The remaining pancreatic parenchyma is grossly unremarkable. Permanent representative sections are submitted following decalcification.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis of a dedifferentiated liposarcoma in a left retroperitoneal tumor that measures 25 x 15 x 8 cm. The tumor involves the distal pancreas and approaches the adrenal gland and kidney, but surgical margins are free of tumor except for the peritoneal margin, which is less than 1 mm. The report also notes the presence of a benign multiloculated supercapsular renal cyst as an incidental finding. Various tissue samples are taken, including the gonadal vascular margin, the retroperitoneal margin, and the lateral margin. The attending pathologist reviews all slides and materials, and the report includes gross descriptions of the specimens.

A left knee soft tissue mass was resected and diagnosed as a partially encapsulated moderate-to-high grade leiomyosarcoma with spindle and pleomorphic cellular morphology, 5-6 mitoses per 10 high-power field, and 15% tumor necrosis. Margin status showed that the closest medial and posterior margins were free of tumor, and were defined by a fibrous pseudocapsule. The gross description of the lesion revealed an irregular, tan-yellow fragment of soft tissue measuring 8.0 x 6.5 x 4.0 cm, with a thin fibroconnective pseudocapsule located at 0.1 cm from the medial and deep-posterior margin of resection. Areas of necrosis were present in the lesion (15%). Representative fresh tissue and sections were submitted for further analysis. No other clinical data was provided.

The pathology report describes a case of malignant mesothelioma in a female patient with metastatic tumors in two of six lymph nodes and a deposit of the same in pericardial fat. The left pleura and pericardium show a diffuse tumor with two dominant nodules, extending into mediastinal fat and aortic adventitia. The tumor is histologically classified as epithelioid mesothelioma, with tubulopapillary and deciduoid types. The regional lymph nodes show N2 metastasis. The report includes details about the specimens received for diagnosis and surgery.

The pathology report summarizes the findings from the biopsy and gross examination of a left occipital brain tumor. The frozen section diagnosis and microscopic observation indicate the presence of a glioblastoma multiforme tumor, which appears as a hypercellular glioma with mitotic figures, new vessel formation, and areas of necrosis. The report does not include any patient information, treatment plan, or hospital references.

The pathology report describes two specimens received labeled "omentum" and "terminal ileum, cecum, appendix and omentum", both with a diagnosis of metastatic poorly differentiated serous carcinoma, FIGO grade 3, with lymphatic space invasion. The omentum specimen consists of a 17 x 9 X 1.5 cm firm rubbery piece of tan to pink tissue consistent with omental cake. No normal omental fat is present. The terminal ileum, cecum, appendix, and omentum specimen is a right colon and portion of omentum with a yellow lobular cut surface showing possible tumor present, and tumor makes up approximately 40% of the specimen grossly. Additionally, the specimen shows a portion of small bowel which is 30 cm, and the mucosa of the specimen shows pink-tan smooth glistening mucosa. The appendix is identified adherent to the fat measuring 5 X 0.3 cm and is studded with tumor nodules. The diagnosis recommends clinical correlation in regard to any further distant metastases that have not been sampled at the time of the procedure.

The pathology report describes a left upper lobe lung specimen marked by a 1.8 cm tumor with a moderately-differentiated non-small-cell carcinoma, without involvement of the main bronchus. The resection margin is negative, and no angiolymphatic or direct extension of tumor is identified. The report also includes biopsy results for several lymph nodes at different levels, all of which appear negative with no involvement. The diagnosis includes a moderately-differentiated non-small-cell carcinoma with squamous features and negative margins of excision.

The pathology report describes several specimens received from a patient. The report includes the gross description and microscopic description of each specimen, along with the diagnosis. The specimens include lymph nodes from levels 10, 11, 12, 2R, 4R, 8, 7, and 9. The report also describes a right upper lobe lung specimen which shows a 5 cm poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with uninvolved surgical margins and no identified arterial, venous, or lymphatic invasion. Four lymph nodes are negative for metastatic disease. Additionally, there is no evidence of metastasis in any of the lymph nodes examined (0/1) (0/4) (0/3) (0/1) (0/4) (0/2) (0/1) for the corresponding levels mentioned above.

Specimen: A right upper lobe lobectomy containing a tumor, 2.6 x 2.6 x 2.4 cm, which is diagnosed as poorly-differentiated Squamous cell carcinoma. Two of six peribronchial/hilar lymph nodes show carcinoma, while the margins of resection, direct extension of tumor, and venous/arterial invasion show negative results. Microscopic Description: The primary tumor is 2.6cm in greatest dimension and has poorly-differentiated Squamous cell carcinoma. The resection margins, direct tumor extension, and venous/arterial invasion are negative, while two of six peribronchial/hilar lymph nodes show carcinoma. Level 11 shows two negative lymph nodes (0/2), level 10 shows two negative lymph nodes (0/2), level 2 shows two negative lymph nodes (0/2). 4R indicates two negative lymph nodes (0/2), level 7 shows two negative lymph nodes (0/2), and level 9 shows one negative lymph node (0/1).

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of lymph nodes, level 11 and level 7, excisions - negative for tumor. Regarding the lung, a poorly differentiated non-small cell carcinoma was found in the right lower lobe, compatible with poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The margins are negative for malignancy, and no direct extension of tumor or pleural invasion was identified. The regional lymph nodes included in the excision are negative for tumor. The lung away from the tumor has scattered chronic inflammation and interstitial thickening. The report includes gross descriptions of four specimens labeled A, B, C, and D, which are all fragments and tissue pieces from the excision. There is a block summary of the specimens indicating bronchial and vascular margins, lung tissue away from the tumor, tumor, and lymph nodes. No distant metastasis was identified. Overall, the report indicates the presence of non-small cell carcinoma in the lung and the absence of malignancy in the excised lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes the results of a surgical procedure performed on the right lung of a patient with a right lung mass. The report indicates that the patient has moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with a dimension of 2.1 cm. The margins of the resection are uninvolved, and no evidence of metastasis is found in the lymph nodes. Microscopic examination identifies seven lymph nodes with no metastasis in the R4 lymph nodes and four lymph nodes with no metastasis in the subcarinal lymph nodes. The specimen descriptions suggest that the wedge resection of the right upper lobe, Level 10 lymph node resection, lobectomy of the right upper lobe, R4 lymph node resection, and subcarinal lymph node resection were performed during the procedure. There is no identified direct extension of tumor, venous, arterial, or lymphatic invasion, and no other findings. In conclusion, the patient has squamous cell carcinoma with no evidence of metastasis in the lymph nodes.

Specimen A is a lobectomy of the right upper lobe. The gross description shows a 2 x 1.8 x 1.8 cm rubbery pale-tan lesion within the inferior portion of the specimen and two slightly rubbery gray-black tissues up to 1.3 cm in greatest dimension from the hilar region, which are lymph nodes. The tumor of 2 cm in greatest dimension is diagnosed as adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, with venous and lymphatic space invasion present. Resection margins are negative for tumor. Two lymph nodes from specimen A are negative for metastatic tumor, as well as one lymph node from specimen B and four lymph nodes from specimen C.

Final Surgical Pathology Report: Lung, right upper lobe, resection revealed adenocarcinoma, poorly differentiated, 3.5 cm in greatest dimension. Surgical margins were uninvolved. No evidence of metastasis found in 5 lymph nodes. No evidence of metastasis found in 3 lymph nodes in R4 region and 1 lymph node in level VII region. Histologic type: Adenocarcinoma, poorly differentiated. Primary tumor size: 3.5 cm. Margins of resection were uninvolved and no direct extension of the tumor was identified. No venous, arterial, or lymphatic vessel invasion was identified. Distant metastasis was not evaluated by this specimen. The tissue procurement was submitted for normal parenchyma and lymph nodes. No additional mass lesion or abnormality was observed in the remaining parenchyma.

The pathology report describes specimens received from various locations in a patient's body, including lymph nodes, a rib, and a right lower lobe of the lung. The report identifies a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right lower lobe, measuring 15 cm in greatest dimension, with no invasion of surrounding tissue and surgical margins uninvolved. There is no evidence of metastasis in any of the lymph nodes examined. The rib and remaining lymph nodes show no abnormalities.

The pathology report shows the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the right upper lung lobe of a patient with lung cancer. Lymph nodes in multiple levels (R4, level x, and level VII) showed no evidence of malignancy. The tumor size is 3.7 cm with a mitotic index of 4 Mitoses/10 HPFs. The resection margin, pleura, and attached lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. Emphysema was present in the non-tumorous lung tissue. The immunohistochemical staining pattern is compatible with adenocarcinoma, with TTF-1 staining positive, CK5/6 negative, and p63 weakly positive. The report notes that a portion of the tumor has a more solid appearance. The specimen sizes and descriptions are also provided.

The report describes a pathology sample consisting of lymph nodes and a wedge resection from the left lung. The lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. The resected tissue shows a moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma, confined within the lung, with a maximum diameter of 1.5cm. There is no extension to other structures. The margins are uninvolved, with the tumor sitting 2.2 cm from the closest parenchymal margin. There is no vascular or venous invasion, and no involved lymph nodes. The pTNM stage is pT1a NO MX.

The report describes the diagnosis of a papillary renal cell carcinoma in the left kidney of a female patient who underwent radical nephrectomy with an unremarkable adrenal gland. The tumor was unifocal and limited to the kidney, without invading into the perinephric fat or renal pelvis/calyces. Margins were negative for invasive carcinoma, and only one hilar lymph node showed no tumor involvement out of one submitted. Additional sections of the tumor were evaluated microscopically, and the perinephric soft tissue margin was inked black. The report also includes details on the gross appearance and size of the tumor, as well as the submitted cassettes for microscopic evaluation.

A radical prostatectomy was performed for a patient diagnosed with carcinoma of the prostate. The postoperative diagnosis revealed acinar adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 8 (4+4), involving both lobes and seminal vesicles, with perineural and vascular invasion but no extracapsular invasion identified. Resection margins were positive for tumor. The two left and right pelvic lymph nodes tested negative for metastatic carcinoma. The received fresh prostate measured 5.0 x 4.0 x 4.0 cm with a firm, lobulated gray cut surface, and the received fresh lymph nodes samples were portions of adipose tissue containing two lymph nodes each, measuring 1.0 cm in greatest dimension.

Histological examination of a pericardium biopsy revealed invasion by a thymoma B tumor. Conventional histological examination confirmed the diagnosis of thymoma (1A) and revealed a thymectomy specimen measuring 15 cm x 7 cm x 5 cm with a tumor measuring 9 cm x 6 cm that invaded the pericardium and lung parenchyma, and had areas of necrosis and calcifications. Two sub xiphoid fragments, a Barety ganglion, and a high latrotrachal ganglion were also examined. The samples taken at the level of the thymic tumor and pulmonary parenchyma showed invasion of the lung by the thymic tumor. Immunohistochemical examination revealed expression of CK19, 7, 5/6, and absence of expression of CK20, CD5 and CD20. Thymoma subtype B3 with a size of 9 cm by 6 cm was diagnosed along with lymph node metastasis. The Modified Masaoka classification was IVb and the WHO classification was T4 N2 M0.

Thymectomy sample weighing 189 g, with a nodule of 8 cm x 7 cm x 5 cm located on the lower horn section on the right. Tumor parenchyma is marked by necrotic and hemorrhagic rearrangements. The tumor architecture is lobulated, consisting of numerous lymphocytes to small type lymphocytes, and numerous differentiation medullary zones. Epithelial cells are small without atypia, characterized by a pale nucleus with a small nucleolus, and are scattered within the lymphocyte quota with rare perivascular spaces. Immunohistochemical study reveals positive and diffuse CK19, CK18, and CK7 labeling with low absence of labeling with the CK20 CD 5 and CD20, and T CD1A immature CD5 and CD99 labeling in lymphocytes. Diagnosis: Thymoma subtype B1, measuring 8 cm x 7 cm, with minimal infiltration and complete resection, classified as Modified Masaoka stage II and WHO classification T2N0M0.

Bladder and prostate tissues were analyzed and revealed the presence of Papillary urothelial high grade carcinoma. Tumor was limited to the bladder with infiltration to the outer third of the muscular propria. Neoplastic involvement was absent in the surgical margins, deferens and seminal vesicles. Angiovascular, lymphatic vessels, and blood vascular invasions were not detected. The prostate displayed nonspecific chronic prostatitis and nodular hyperplasia.

The pathology report presents the results of various biopsies taken from different regions of the lung of a patient. A moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma, 6.2 cm in size, was found in the right upper lobe, which had penetrated the visceral pleura but had not spread to any of the four lymph nodes identified during the examination. A nodule detected in the visceral pleura was free of carcinoma. The remaining biopsies, including multiple lymph nodes, did not show any malignancy. The diagnosis is pT2, NO, MX. The tumor had a cystic area, but margins were free of invasion. The pleural surface had adhesions between tumor and attached tissue/parietal pleura, but the tumor did not penetrate into the soft tissue margin.

The pathology report describes findings from a lung cancer patient's tissue samples. The report indicates the presence of lung neoplasms, lymph nodes, fibrosis, and metastatic carcinomas. Tissue samples from various parts of the lung and lymph nodes were analyzed, and the report provides a detailed description of each specimen's gross characteristics. The final diagnosis indicates adenocarcinoma of the lung without invasion into nearby structures, involvement of one regional lymph node, and margins free of invasive carcinoma. The report also includes staging information that shows a tumor size of 1.2 cm and involvement of one regional lymph node. At the bronchial margin and in the peribronchial lymph node, no tumor was identified.

Filtered report: Diagnosis: Lung adenocarcinoma, left upper lobe, measuring 2.0 cm in greatest diameter, moderately differentiated, extending up to but not through pleura. Frozen section diagnosis: Large cell carcinoma, margins free. The tumor is identified within endothelial lined lymphovascular space, showing areas of fibrosis. No lymph nodes were resected. The tumor does not extend into the pleural surface or through the surgical margins.

The pathology report describes the findings of a specimen received from a right lower lobe, a Level 3 subcarinal lymph node, and a Level 4 lymph node peritoneal. The histologic type of the tumor in the right lower lobe is adenocarcinoma, and its size is 3.7 cm with a poorly differentiated grade. The tumor is confined to the lung, and there is no involvement of regional lymph nodes. The report states that metastasis cannot be assessed, and margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Some lymphovascular invasions such as venous or arterial are absent. A subpleural, benign bronchial resection margin, and 13 benign regional symptronodes were observed. Among nine lymph nodes biopsied from Level 7 subcarinal, one has metastatic poorly-differentiated carcinoma. Three benign lymph nodes were found in Level 4. The Pathologic stage report shows pT2 pN2 pMX. The patient presented with a right posterior lung mass, and the bronchial margin was negative during intraoperative consultation. The report describes the specimen's gross appearance and size, including multiple lymph nodes in each level, their relationships to retracted pleura and adjacent parenchyma, vascular margins, and the presence of masses and lesions. The microscopic examination has been performed on all slides, and the pathologic diagnosis encompasses the essential microscopic findings.

Pathology report of lung biopsy shows invasive adenocarcinoma consisting of cells with scattered glandular structures, positive for CK7 and TTF-1, and negative for CK20, SK, and p63. Weak staining for synaptophysin suggests non-neuroendocrine adenocarcinoma. EGFR and KRAS mutation status should be determined for TKI therapy selection. ALK gene rearrangements are associated with resistance to TKIs and favorable response rates to Crizotinib. Bronchus washing is negative for malignant cells. The patient has a right upper lobe lung mass.

The pathology report describes a surgical excision of lymph nodes and a left lung pneumonectomy due to a malignant neoplasm of the bronchus/lung. The lymph nodes excised from levels 9L, 5, and 7 did not show any metastatic carcinoma through frozen section diagnoses. The pneumonectomy revealed a 4.5 cm poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma tumor in the left upper lobe that invaded the visceral pleura and lymphovascular space. One out of the six lymph nodes received contained metastatic carcinoma with extracapsular extension, involving the adjacent artery wall. The tumor approached the pleural surface but was free from the bronchial and vascular resection margins. The pTNM staging is pT2aN1MX. The report recommends mutation analysis for EGFR, KRAS, and ALK to help select patients for tyrosine-kinase inhibitor therapy, which is available on request as a lung cancer mutation panel.

The pathology report describes surgical specimens received for analysis, including a lung wedge, lymph nodes, and a lung lobectomy. The lung wedge shows an old calcified granuloma, while lymph node level 2 shows one benign lymph node, and level 6 and 9 lymph nodes show two and one benign lymph nodes, respectively. The lung left upper lobe shows poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma measuring 4.1 cm in the greatest dimension. One of six lymph nodes is positive for metastatic carcinoma, which is adjacent to the bronchus in the lobectomy specimen. Margins are uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, while lymphovascular invasion is present, and venous and arterial invasions are absent. The report concludes with pathology stage and clinical history information.

The pre-operative diagnosis was a right lower lobe lung nodule, and the intraoperative consultation diagnosed "Non-small cell carcinoma; lesion inked black." The post-operative diagnosis confirmed the right lower lobe lung nodule was adenocarcinoma, bronchoalveolar type, well-differentiated, without vascular invasion and without involvement of regional lymph nodes. There were no metastases found in any of the lymph nodes submitted, and sinus histiocytosis with focal anthracosis was observed in lymph nodes A, C, and D. The lesion does not disrupt the overlying pleura, and the surrounding pulmonary parenchyma shows changes of mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease.

The report describes a biopsy of a left lung mass suspected to be cancerous. The specimens received include lymph nodes, the left upper lobe of the lung, and a portion of the bifurcated bronchus. Gross descriptions reveal several lymph nodes that are metastatic adenocarcinoma. The lung mass is a moderately-poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma histologically consistent with pulmonary origin. The tumor invades within 1 mm of the inked hilar pleural surface in block F4. The results indicate positive regional lymph node involvement, extensive lymphvascular invasion, and negative margins. No direct extension of tumor or large vessel invasion is present. The final diagnosis is infiltrating carcinoma of the left upper lobe of lung with regional lymph node dissection and biopsies, pT1, pN2 (ten of twelve lymph nodes involved by metastatic carcinoma), and pMX (no distant metastasis). Additional pathologic findings are none significant.

A female patient underwent a right lower lobe lobectomy due to a 6.5cm x 5.7cm x 4.5cm subpleural adenocarcinoma histologically graded as poorly differentiated. No visceral pleural invasion or lymphovascular space invasion was identfied. All 8 lymph nodes received were negative for malignancy. The tumor approached within 2.5cm of the bronchial margin, however, discrete invasion into adjacent bronchi and vasculatures were not identified. A level 8 lymph node excision was negative for malignancy. Preoperative and postoperative diagnoses were identified as lung cancer. The specimen consisted of a purple-gray, anthracotic lung lobe with multiple gray-black anthracotic nodules consistent with lymph nodes present. The specimen is primarily composed of uninvolved pink-tan, spongy parenchyma with no additional lesions identified. A 6.0cm x 4.5cm x 1.4cm area of umbilication in the pleura was present, which is inked.

The report describes a lobectomy of the right upper lobe due to moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, with negative margins and no lymphatic or vascular invasion. A single peribronchial lymph node showed no malignancy. The lymph nodes in the levels 7, 9, 11R, 12R, and subcarinal were benign. The pathologic stage was pT2aNOMO, stage IB, and the histologic grade was G2. No fresh tissue was available for further testing.

The pathology report relates to a lung lobectomy specimen of a patient diagnosed with adenocarcinoma. The report indicates that EGFR mutation was not detected, but a KRAS mutation was detected. FISH for ALK rearrangement was negative with the observation of additional ALK gene copies noted in 80% of cells. The lymph nodes contained benign hyperplasia with non-caseating granulomatous inflammation. The report suggests the possibility of sarcoidosis in the pattern of granulomas. No metastatic carcinoma was found in the lymph nodes, and the tumor was unifocal and moderately differentiated with no identified invasion. The report has also indicated a non-pathogenic polymorphism, which does not affect clinical significance.

The pathology report describes the case of a patient with right lung cancer, where a lobectomy was performed. The report details the gross and microscopic features of the submitted tissue samples, including lymph nodes and lung tissue. The final diagnosis of the lymph nodes reveals anthrasilicosis and mild reactive sinus histiocytosis, with no metastatic carcinoma identified. The lung tissue shows a poorly differentiated large cell carcinoma with squamous differentiation, extending to within less than 1 mm of the pleural surface with lymphovascular space invasion identified, but no invasion of the pleura. Occasional granulomas were present in one of the lymph nodes, at level 8. Overall, the report suggests that clinical correlation and follow-up are recommended, and the report has been finalized by the pathology department at a particular campus.

Diagnosis: Invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma involving the left upper lobe and mainstem bronchus, without visceral pleura invasion. Carcinoma was found in 3 out of 30 total lymph nodes. Pathologic stage IIIA. Margin status: negative. Tumor size was 7.5 cm in maximum dimension. Lymphovascular invasion was present. Pulmonary edema and post-obstructive pneumonitis were observed. The specimen was received intact without fixative and weighed 628 grams. The bronchial margin was removed but uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. The tumor blocked and obstructed the upper lobar bronchus and tracks outward along the bronchi into the lung parenchyma over an area measuring 7.5 X 6 X 6 cm. Additionally, there were multiple fibrous adhesions at the interlobar fissure and anthracotic nodes along the lobar and segmental bronchi.

Diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated, in the right lower lobe with a tumor size of 3.3 cm. No tumor found in any of the 25 lymph nodes (pN0) or identified in the margins, allowing for a pathologic stage of IB. No lymphovascular or perineural invasion was identified. Uninvolved lung with organizing pneumonia was noted. No treatment effect mentioned. The various specimens of lymph node candidates are listed, along with their respective dimensions and submitted for microscopic evaluation. Histologic grade, tumor extension into extrapulmonary structures, and lymphovascular invasion were not identified. The bronchial margin was negative, and the vascular and parenchymal margins were greater than 1 cm. The tumor mass was centrally necrotic and placed within 0.2 cm of the anterior-medial pleura. Few other details are included, such as no evidence of distant metastasis, and no additional nodularities that appeared suspicious for neoplasia. The granuloma was grossly uninvolved and fibrotic.

Summary: The pathology report describes the examination of six tissue specimens, including a pleural peel, lymph nodes, and a lung mass from a patient with a history of lung cancer. The pleura was found to be benign with chronic inflammation, and all lymph nodes biopsies were negative for cancer. The lung mass was moderately to poorly differentiated, invasive squamous cell carcinoma with negative margins for bronchial resection and pleural surface. There was direct extension of the tumor and benign apical pleural plaque. The lymphovascular space status was negative. The pathologic stage was determined to be pT2a pNO.

The pathology report describes the presence of moderate to poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a 6.4 cm mass in the right upper lobe of the lung, with a focus suspected to indicate lymphovascular invasion. No visceral pleural involvement is identified, and negative bronchial and vascular resection margins are reported. One large lymph node shows evidence of micrometastasis, while the remaining 13 lymph nodes sampled show no evidence of metastatic neoplasm. The patient has been diagnosed with T2b,N1 stage cancer. Additional testing is pending to verify suspected metastasis and identify potential microorganisms in certain lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes the results of a surgical panel including lymph node resections and a lung lobectomy for a patient with a history of lung cancer and B-cell chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The report notes that lymph nodes in multiple locations were involved by small lymphocytic lymphoma, but there was no evidence of involvement by metastatic carcinoma. In addition, the lung lobectomy revealed the presence of a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma measuring 4.5 x 4.5 x 3 cm, but the surgical margins were free of involvement and pleural and lymphatic vascular invasion were absent. The report also includes details on the TNM staging, regional lymph node involvement, and distant metastasis, as well as information on the tissue blocks available for ancillary testing. The report concludes that the final TNM stage is pT2aN0M0, indicating stage IB lung cancer.

A male patient underwent a left upper lobe lobectomy due to a lung mass. A lymph node labeled left upper lobe level 12 was biopsied and found negative for malignancy. The tumor was histologically graded as a focally keratinizing squamous carcinoma, moderately differentiated with a size of 4.8 x 2.0 x 2.0 cm. The tumor was unifocal and confined to the lung with no lymphovascular space invasion. Surgical margin status was reported with a distance of 3.5 cm from the bronchial margin, and the tumor abutting the pleural surface. Lymph nodes labeled level V/level VI and level VII were biopsied and found negative for malignancy. The tumor approaches, but does not penetrate the pleural surface. Pleural invasion was not seen during the examination.

Diagnosis: Papillary sebosradenocareinoma grade tumor, which completely replaces the specimen's surface, identified in the left ovary and fallopian tube. Lymphovascular space invasion was not identified. Metastatic serous adenocarcinoma involving one of the two examined pelvic lymph nodes was also identified. Inflammation and mesothelial reaction were detected in the omentum specimen, but no neoplasm was found. No pathologic changes were detected in the right ovary, fallopian tube, cervix, endometrium, and myometrium. Staging sheet #3 indicates pTNM staging of T3c, N1, MX (FIGO: IIIC). Preoperative diagnosis was a pelvic mass, and symptoms/radiologic findings were not specified. The specimens received were left tube and ovary, left pelvic, omentum, uterus, cervix, and right tube and ovary. Gross description details for each specimen were provided, including their dimensions, color, texture, and presence of lesions. Genomic research study cassettes were also received for three of the specimens.

The pathology report describes a specimen received from a female patient with a white breast containing a spiculated nodule measuring 3.5 x 2.5 x 0.8 cm, identified as invasive lobular carcinoma grade 1. The report indicates that all surgical margins are clear and there are no lymph node metastases. Axillary lymph nodes contain nodular fibrofatty tissue, and no gross lesion is observed. Further details regarding participants, issuers, reviewers, and treatment plans are not provided in the report.
Papillary Renal Cell Carcinoma, Type I, poorly differentiated with solid growth component. ICD-0-Code: 8260/3.

The pathology report describes an ovarian tumor in a female patient. Both ovaries show significant involvement by tumor resulting in large bilateral tumor masses. The tumor is papillary serous adenocarcinoma with high grade cytologic atypia. The right ovary tumor measures 19.0 cm and the left ovary tumor measures 9.5 cm in greatest dimension. The tumor has not spread to the fallopian tube or omentum. The capsule of both ovaries appears intact, but the report cannot conclude if it is a synchronous or metastatic tumor. The patient has a history of pelvic pain and mass. No lymph node sampling was performed.

The pathology report describes the examination of multiple specimens, including lymph nodes and lung tissues obtained from a patient undergoing surgery for a left lower lobe lung carcinoma. The lung tumor is described as a non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma that measures 6.5x6.5x5.5 cm and invades the left lower lobe bronchus. The tumor is moderately to poorly differentiated, with no angiolymphatic or perineural invasion. The report indicates lymph node involvement in one out of eleven peribronchial lymph nodes and no involvement in other lymph nodes. The bronchial margin and visceral pleural margin are negative for tumor. Emphysematous changes are noted in the non-neoplastic lung.

Summary: A tumor measuring 4.0 x 3.5 x 2.0 cm was found in the left lower lobe of the lung measuring 15.0 x 10.0 x 7.0 cm. The tumor was diagnosed as adenocarcinoma with a mixed subtype, predominantly papillary, partially solid, acinar, and BAC. There was infiltration of the pleura visceralis. The tumor was classified as pT2, pNO (0/20), pMx, G2.

Histology report shows the presence of Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in the left interlobar lymph node station 11. The biopsy also indicates the presence of squamous cell carcinoma with squamous cell carcinoma in-situ in the left lower lobe wedge upper lobe. The carcinoma is found to be extending very close to the resection margin. The patient is diagnosed with T1, N1, M0, stage III cancer with a size of 2.1 cm. Age and gender information are not provided. No information about the hospital, doctor's name, or patient's name is available.

The pathology report describes a tumor sample diagnosed as Squamous Cell Carcinoma, Not Otherwise Specified (NOS) with a histology of Squamous carcinoma. The sample was collected from the right upper lobe and measured 4.5 cm in size. The grade or differentiation was II and the pathological stage was T2, NOS. No information was provided regarding metastasis or lymph node involvement. The report also includes a sample type BUFFY, but no additional information about it was provided.

The report describes findings from a sample of the right middle lobe, including nodes and bronchial tissue. The tumor in the middle lobe of the lung is diagnosed as a moderately differentiated, large-cell, slightly keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma. There is evidence of lymph node metastases, primarily in parabronchial lymph nodes and some reactive lesions and pigment deposits in other lymph nodes. The tumor has spread to the mucosal surface and obstructed the middle lobe bronchus. The resection margin to the main and upper lobe bronchus is free of dysplastic epithelial changes, and there is no evidence of infiltration of the visceral pleura. The diagnosis is TNM classification pT2 pN1, V1 R0, stage IIB, with a secondary diagnosis of slight chronic retention pneumonia peripheral to the tumor.

The pathology report describes macroscopic and microscopic findings from a resected left inferior lobe sample. The report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated, keratinizing, maturing squamous cell carcinoma measuring a maximum of 40 mm. The tumor extends to the still tumor-free, reactive, thickened pleura and displays hemoangioinvasion, with adjacent and hilar tumor-free lymph nodes with anthracotic pigment. There is also evidence of pneumonia and hyaline plaque build-up in the parietal pleura. The tumor is classified as M-8071/3, G3, pT2, pV 1, pN 0, pMX, stage IB, with R0.

The examination report describes a resected right superior pulmonary lobe with poorly differentiated and non-keratinizing, maturing squamous cell carcinoma measuring a maximum of 65 mm with infiltration of the visceral pleura and tumor-free bronchial resection margin as well as peribronchial lymph nodes with anthracosis. Multifocal angioinvasion is present in the center of the tumor with vascular tumor thrombi, while all other lymph nodes are tumor-free but with varying degrees of distinct anthracosis.

The pathology report describes the examination of a left upper lobe sample, diagnosed with locally advanced squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor has spread to adjacent sections of S1 and S3 and the pleura in the region of the adhesion zone. Tumor spread is found up to the caudal margin of the pleura. There is evidence of inflammation, necrosis, and active chronic peripheral bronchitis and bronchiolitis. The tumor extends to the adherent part of the parietal pleura and parts of the chest wall. The resection margins of bronchus and vessels, chest wall tissue, and all excised lymph nodes are tumor-free. Asbestos exposure cannot be confirmed through prepared section planes. The report concludes with a secondary diagnosis of lymph nodes with uncharacteristic reactive lesions, anthracotic pigment deposits, and sclerosis zones.

The pathology report describes a specimen of mediastinal squamous epithelium from a patient with a clinical diagnosis of bronchial carcinoma in the left upper lobe. The report details the macroscopic and microscopic findings of the tumor and its involvement with surrounding tissue. The primary diagnosis is a poorly differentiated, nonkeratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, with secondary diagnoses of tumor necrosis, pleuritis, and anthracosis. The tumor shows partial endobronchial growth and has metastasized to local bronchopulmonary lymph nodes. Large pulmonary vessels are not invaded by the tumor, and the resection margins of the main bronchus, large pulmonary vessels, lower lobe of the lung, and other lymph nodes are tumor-free. The report concludes that the tumor is locally advanced and classified as stage III, with a potential classification of R1 or R0 depending on further examination.

The pathology report describes several specimens of lung tissue received for evaluation.
