The report mentions adenocarcinoma with various components and invasion of the visceral pleura in the right upper lobe. In the right lower lobe, there is also adenocarcinoma with multiple components and invasion of the bronchial margin. Lymphatic invasion is present in both tumors, and there is evidence of emphysema and atypical adenomatous hyperplasia in other areas of the lung. The final diagnosis is of adenocarcinomas with slight histologic differences, interpreted as at p stage IIIA. The report includes descriptions of specimens submitted and their respective sizes and margins. Additional comment notes that EGFR mutation analysis will be performed and reported separately.

The pathology report describes a case of lung cancer involving the right middle lobe. Adenocarcinoma with solid, acinar, and cribriform patterns, along with clear cell change and focal signet ring cell patterns, was identified in the affected tissue. Certain margins of excision revealed detached atypical cells consistent with adenocarcinoma, and an immunohistochemical panel confirmed the presence of tumor cells positive for CAM 5.2 and TTF-1, as well as negligible positivity with synaptophysin. The tumor was negative for chromogranin, p63, and CD56 expression, and EGFR mutational analysis was performed. The other lymph nodes and margins were negative for neoplasm. The pathological staging was pT2a NO, Stage IB.

The pathology report describes lymph node excisions, a partial excision of chest wall, and a right upper lobe lobectomy. One lymph node was found to be negative for malignancy in each excision. The lobectomy revealed invasive adenocarcinoma, acinar type, with surgical margins and two lymph nodes negative for carcinoma. The tumor is located in the right upper lobe with a size of 3.2 X 3.1 x 2.1 cm, without vascular or lymphatic invasion. The bronchial, vascular, parenchymal, and pleura/soft tissue margins were negative. Pathologic stage was pT2a pNO pMX Stage 1b. Anthracotic nodules, which were negative for neoplasm, were also identified in the report.

Site of tissue: Lung. Sample type: FF (fresh frozen) tissue. Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma. Grade: Not specified. Size: 2.00 cm. Histology: Not specified. Differentiation: Not specified. Pathological T: T2, N0, M0. VALCSO Stage: I. Comments: Resected RUL (right upper lobe).

A description for each data field can be found in the "Data description" worksheet (yellow tab). The pathology report describes a case of poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right lung, measuring 35mm in size. Blood vessel permeation is present, but no lymphatic or perineural invasion is observed. No pleural invasion is identified, and the carcinoma is clear of the bronchial margin. Peribronchial lymph node metastases are seen, and the tumor cells do not stain with neuroendocrine markers, indicating that it is a squamous cell carcinoma without evidence of neuroendocrine differentiation. Additionally, the report notes the presence of distal acute and organizing pneumonia and focal round atelectasis. The patient's condition is classified as T2N1MX. No evidence of malignancy is found in the received lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes the findings of a left lower lobe lung biopsy and a lymph node biopsy. The lung biopsy shows a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma located beneath the pleural puckering area, measuring 27mm. Pleural invasion is present, but there is no evidence of lymphatic, blood vessel, or perineural invasion. The bronchial margin is clear. Metastatic carcinoma is found in all the identified hilar lymph nodes. The adjacent lung shows evidence of emphysema, fibrosis with UIP-like pattern, and honeycomb changes. The lymph node biopsy does not show evidence of metastases but contains carbon pigment consistent with silica. The diagnosis is T2a N1 [AJCC 7th ed].

The pathology report describes a right lower lobectomy specimen consisting of lung tissue with a 40mm mucoid grey tumour abutting the pleura. Microscopy indicates a well differentiated mucinous adenocarcinoma growing in a lepidic pattern with focal central necrosis. Ten lymph nodes from the 11R group are free of malignancy. The excision lines are clear of malignancy. The report concludes that the specimen is consistent with a lung primary, but a metastatic tumour could produce a similar appearance.

The pathology report concerns a female patient who presented with a right upper lobe mass. The lobectomy measures 150 x 130 X 45 mm when inflated. A cream nodule measuring 27 mm in maximum dimension was found, well clear of the lateral pleural aspect and bronchial resection margin. The lung parenchyma shows emphysema predominantly towards the apical portion. Microscopy revealed a moderately to poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a central fibroelastotic scar, invading the visceral pleura on the medial aspect, but well clear of the lateral pleural surface. No lymphatic, vascular or perineural invasion was identified. No lymph node metastases were found. The adjacent lung tissue shows features of emphysema. Pathological stage was T2NOMX.

The pathology report describes specimens obtained from a patient with a lesion on the vocal cords and left parietal brain tumor. The specimen was received in four parts labeled A to D. Part A consisted of the right false vocal fold and showed Candidiasis (noninvasive). Part B was a frozen section of the left parietal mass which showed Glioblastoma multiforme. Part C showed normal dense membranous connective tissue consistent with dura, and Part D was additional tissue from the left parietal mass which was also a Glioblastoma multiforme. No evidence of dysplasia or inflammation was found, and the final diagnosis included Candidiasis (noninvasive) for the right false vocal cord and Glioblastoma multiforme for the left parietal mass and additional tissue.

Specimen type: Lobectomy. Tumor site: Lung. Tumor size: 4x3x3cm. Histologic type: Squamous cell carcinoma. Histologic grade: Moderately differentiated. Lymph nodes: 2/16 positive for metastasis (Hilar 2/16).

Type of Specimen: Lobectomy of the left-upper lung tissue. Tumor Description: 3 x 2 x 2 cm poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. Tumor Extent: Not specified, no information about other tumor nodules, lymph nodes, lymphatic invasion, venous invasion and margins. Neo-adjuvant Treatment: Not specified. Additional Pathologic Findings: Not specified. Comments: None.

The pathology report describes a lung tissue biopsy containing a subpleural mass causing pleura puckering. Microscopic examination confirms the diagnosis of moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor is 2.4 x 1.5 cm in size, with no angiolymphatic invasion, venous invasion, or lymphatic invasion. Lymph node metastasis is present and the TNM staging is T1b NO MX. No additional pathologic findings or comments are mentioned in the report.

The report describes a case of squamous cell carcinoma in the left lower lobe of the lung. The tumor measured 2 x 3 x 2.5 cm and was poorly differentiated. There is no information on tumor extent, other tumor nodules, lymph nodes, lymphatic or venous invasion, margins, or neo-adjuvant treatment. No additional pathologic findings were noted, and there were no comments.

Specimen type: Lobectomy. Tumor site: Lung. Tumor size: 5 X 5 X 5 cm. Histologic type: Squamous cell carcinoma. Histologic grade: Moderately differentiated. Lymph nodes: 0/4 positive for metastasis. (Regional 0/4). Comments: Right-lower lobe.

Final Surgical Pathology Report: The report indicates the presence of two separate primary adenocarcinomas of the lung, one in the upper and the other in the lower lobe. The tumors display different histologic patterns of growth and CK20 immunoprofile. The tumors are not classified as metastatic mesothelioma or secondary lung tumors. The report mentions the tumor size, angiolymphatic invasion, and foci of tumor extending to the inked edge. No visceral pleural or perineural invasion is detected. The tumor cells indicate the presence of emphysema and carcinoid tumorlets. Immunohistochemical stain results show CK7, TTF1, and Napsin positivity. The report recommends clinical correlation for the inked edge and synoptic report regarding TNM staging. Additionally, the report suggests the presence of tobacco-related disease in the patient's clinical history.

The pathology report is for a patient who had a right upper lobectomy for adenocarcinoma, mixed subtype, with solid and micropapillary patterns measuring 6.3 x 6.3 x 5.0 cm. The tumor has perineural invasion and visceral pleural invasion. The resection margins are negative for carcinoma, except for one peribronchial lymph node involved with metastatic carcinoma. The other lymph nodes (#7, 4R, 11R, posterior 11R, and 12R) are negative for metastatic carcinoma. There is also a seborrheic keratosis in the excision of the skin on the right posterior chest. Microscopic examination has been performed.

There are five specimens received for pathology evaluation: a left lower lobe nodule, lymph nodes from levels 9, 6, and 5, and a left lower lobe lung lobectomy. The diagnosis is adenocarcinoma of the lung, mixed type, moderately to poorly differentiated, located in the left lower lobe, measuring 2.5 cm, with no residual carcinoma in the lung lobectomy specimen. 28 lymph nodes were examined, and all were negative for carcinoma. The tumor was confined to the lung parenchyma, with absent lymphovascular invasion. The pathologic staging is Stage IA (pT1 NO Mx). The report includes a macroscopic description of each specimen and the results of intra-operative consultations. Immunohistochemical stain results are also included.

The pathology report describes a case in which a male patient's lung was excised due to squamous cell carcinoma, which was moderately to poorly differentiated, and measured 0.65 cm in size. Fragments of lymph nodes (#4, #2, #7, #8, #9, #10, and #11) were negative for malignancy. The tumor was found to be close to the surgical staple line, and the pathologic stage was stage pT1AN0MX. No lymph node metastasis was identified. The report also includes details on the containers used to submit the specimen for examination, as well as microscopic examination findings.

Summary: The report describes the results of surgical excision of lymph nodes and lung tissue from a male patient with a right lung mass. The lymph nodes excised from various levels are negative for malignancy, except for level X-R, where 5 out of 5 nodes are negative. The lung tissue from the right upper lobe shows moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma invading the visceral pleura, with a tumor size of 5.2 cm. The peribronchial lymph node is negative for malignancy, and surgical margins are negative. The report concludes with a synoptic report summarizing the size, foci, histologic type, and lymph node involvement of the tumor, which is classified as pT2bN0M0.

The pathology report concerns a female patient with a history of lung cancer who underwent lobectomy for a tumor in the right upper lung. The report notes the presence of two tumor nodules measuring 5.5 cm and 1.0 cm, with peribronchial invasion and involvement of one lymph node in level IV. However, no malignancy is found in the other lymph nodes excised (levels VII, VIII, IX, X, and XI, as well as level II). The tumor is identified as adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated with bronchoalveolar features. The gross description includes the designation of each specimen received and the dimensions of each fragment or tissue. The microscopic examination performed reveals that the specimen is intact and that no visceral pleural invasion or lymph-vascular invasion is identified. The summary of the synoptic report indicates the location, size, histologic type, and grade of the tumor (adenocarcinoma, G2, pT3), as well as the absence of bronchial margin involvement and the identification of metastasis in one regional lymph node (pN2).

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: The left axilla sentinel lymph node biopsy showed no tumor, and the left axilla excision and left axilla lymph node biopsy also showed no tumor. The left breast needle localized partial mastectomy showed an invasive ductal carcinoma, 4cm, grade 2, present at the anterior margin, and a ductal carcinoma in situ with low and intermediate nuclear grade and necrosis, negative margins, calcifications associated with DCIS, benign epithelium, proliferative fibrocystic changes, and prior biopsy site changes. The tumor had lymphatic-vascular invasion and perineural invasion was not identified. The resection margins for invasive tumor were negative except for the anterior/superior margin, which was positive. The resection margins for ductal carcinoma in situ were negative except for the anterior/superior margin, which was negative. The lymph node status was negative, and the number of positive lymph nodes was 0. The AJCC/UICC stage was pT2NOMX. An immunohistochemical test for estrogen and progesterone receptors showed positive nuclear staining in >90% of tumor cells. The test for HER2/neu was negative for over-expression, and genotyping by FISH was not performed. Other specimens received were lip (mucous retention cyst), left breast excisional biopsy (no residual tumor), vaginal/cervical/endocervical direct (benign cellular changes with shift in flora suggestive of bacterial vaginosis, no intraepithelial lesion or malignancy), endometrium biopsy (inactive endometrium, weakly proliferative pattern with gland and stromal breakdown, simple hyperplasia without atypia, disordered proliferative endometrium with cystic and oncocytic changes and stromal breakdown), and left breast fine needle aspiration (benign cyst, fibrocystic change). The specimen class, specimen(s) received, and final diagnosis are provided for each case.

The pathology report describes a biopsy of a white female's right breast, including two sentinel lymph nodes and a lumpectomy. The sentinel lymph nodes were all negative for malignancy, but the lumpectomy revealed a well-differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma grade 4, measuring 2.0 cm in size. Ancillary studies are still pending, but the margins are clear of both ductal carcinoma in situ and infiltrating ductal carcinoma. Estrogen and progesterone receptors are detectable in 40% and 80% of the tumor nuclei respectively through an immunohistochemical protocol. The report includes a gross description of the specimens, including their size and designated cassettes for each protocol to be submitted.

Final diagnosis: Infiltrating lobular carcinoma in a poorly defined, indurated mass in the upper inner quadrant of the left breast, size 9 cm, with angiolymphatic invasion identified and focal dermal lymphatic involvement. Tumor is within 1 mm of deep margin and focal lobular carcinoma in situ is present. Florid intraductal hyperplasia and fibrocystic changes are also observed. All 16 identified lymph nodes are negative for malignancy. AJCC stage IIB (T3 NO MX). Clinical diagnosis and history: a female with left breast carcinoma. Gross description: 1,044.0 gram modified radical mastectomy specimen measuring 20.5 cm medial to lateral, 20.0 cm superior to inferior, and 4.5 cm anterior to posterior with an attached axillary tail and an overlying ellipse of nipple bearing skin. Ink code: Blue=superficial, green=inferior, black=deep. Multiple sections are harvested for the protocol.

The pathology report describes the specimens collected during a prophylactic bilateral mastectomy for a year-old woman with left breast cancer and a family history of the disease. The report details the findings of the removed breast tissue and left axilla sentinel node. There is focal usual ductal hyperplasia, focal lactational/secretory change, stromal sclerosis and focal apocrine metaplasia in the right breast, but no evidence of malignancy. The left breast shows well-differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma Nottingham score 5 out of 9, estrogen and progesterone receptor positive, HER2 negative, with ductal carcinoma in situ, intermediate nuclear grade, solid and cribiform types with focal intraluminal necrosis and calcifications. No skin or nipple involvement is noticed. The pathologic stage is pT1cNO (i-)Mx. The left breast tissue lower inner quadrant is benign, negative for tumor.

The pathology report describes a female patient with infiltrating ductal carcinoma of the left breast. Two sentinel lymph nodes were excised, one of which was found to contain two lymph nodes and the other lymph node was negative for malignancy. The left breast biopsy revealed multifocal infiltrating ductal carcinoma, comprising two foci of 1.5 cm and 0.6 cm in greatest dimension, with intermediate grade. There was no evidence of lymphovascular invasion and an in-situ component was present, comprising of ductal carcinoma in-situ. Surgical margins were identified as larger tumor 2.0 mm from superior margin and smaller tumor 1.5 mm from superior margin. The gross description of the left breast tissue showed a 1.5 cm tumor with well-defined margins and a second well-defined nodule approximately 1.0 cm lateral to the tumor. The remaining tissue was mostly fat with patches of white, fibrous tissue. The specimen was sectioned and submitted for the CBCP protocol, and labeled in additional cassettes from lateral to medial.

Summary: The pathology report is for a female patient who underwent modified radical right mastectomy for right breast cancer. The report describes the tissues examined, including several lymph nodes and the breast and axillary contents. The lymph nodes were examined via frozen section and diagnosed for metastatic malignancy. The specimen size was 27 cm with a tumor size of 7.5 cm, showing invasive ductal carcinoma and poor differentiation. A total of 19 lymph nodes were examined, and 5 had metastatic deposits. Immunohistochemistry was performed, and the tumor was seen to be ER positive and PR negative. Microcalcifications were present in non-neoplastic tissue. The final TNM stage was T3 N2a M not applicable, Stage IIIA, G3, invasive ductal carcinoma.

Specimen #: Left breast mastectomy and axillary contents. Final diagnosis: Residual invasive ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, present in the area of biopsy cavity and lower outer quadrant. Separate tumor mass in the upper outer quadrant, infiltrating ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated. Metastasis to 6/10 axillary lymph nodes with extracapsular extension. Skin and nipple negative for carcinoma. Fibrocystic changes. Biopsy site changes. AJCC stage: T2N2MX. Clinical diagnosis: Left breast carcinoma. GROSS DESCRIPTION: Modified radical mastectomy specimen with a multiloculated biopsy cavity with associated hemorrhage and fat necrosis in the lower outer quadrant. Multiple firm lymph nodes in the axilla. A separate 2.0 cm tumor mass is present in the upper outer quadrant. Samples taken from the tumor mass, lymph nodes, biopsy cavity site, fibrous tissue, nipple, and scar.

The pathology report describes a left breast lumpectomy with infiltrating and intraductal carcinoma of the comedo-type, Bloom-Richardson grade 9. Tumor involvement is present at the inferior, superior, and anterior margins. A high-grade intraductal carcinoma is also noted at the new medial margin with tumor involvement present at the margin. The sentinel lymph node biopsy is positive for metastatic carcinoma while the axillary contents biopsy reveals no evidence of malignancy. The AJCC pathologic staging is pT2 pN1c pMX. The report also notes that the HER2 analysis by immunohistochemistry reveals weakly positive results, with FISH analysis previously performed and showing no amplification. The gross description details the size and orientation of the lumpectomy specimen, which contains a poorly differentiated mass with multiple calcifications. The report concludes with a description of the remaining specimens received.

The pathology report describes a right breast mastectomy specimen and lymph node biopsies. The breast tumor is described as an infiltrating ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, with extensive venous and lymphatic invasion, and presence of microcalcifications. Margins are negative and the tumor measures 3.0 cm in the greatest dimension. The tumor shows ductal carcinoma in situ with apocrine features and has estrogen and progesterone receptors positive with HER2 negative by IHC. One sentinel lymph node and two non-sentinel lymph nodes from the right axilla are involved with metastatic carcinoma. The largest metastatic focus is 1.5 cm, and extranodal extension is identified. Pathologic stage is pT2 N1a Mx. The report also describes a variety of additional pathologic changes. No lymph nodes are identified in the specimen.

The pathology report relates to a left breast mastectomy with axillary dissection. The tumor is unifocal invasive ductal carcinoma (no special type), with nuclear grade 3 and a size of 2.5 cm. The tumor necrosis is present in both invasive and in situ carcinoma, and there are microcalcifications in ductal carcinoma in situ and benign breast tissue. There is no definite identification of venous or lymphatic invasion. There is ductal carcinoma in situ with central expansive "comedo" necrosis. Three out of 17 lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma. The largest metastatic focus is 1.2 cm. Estrogen and progesterone receptors are negative, while HER2 by FISH is negative. The specimen also contains fibroadenoma, usual ductal hyperplasia, moderate, small peripheral papilloma, and fibrocystic changes. The final pathologic stage is pT2 N1a.

The pathology report describes a modified radical/total mastectomy procedure performed on a patient with preoperative diagnosis of left breast cancer with positive node. The report includes a gross description of the tissue removed from the right and left breasts, and axillary contents, revealing fibrocystic change, duct hyperplasia, apocrine metaplasia, and cyst formation in the right breast mastectomy specimen, and multiple invasive tumors, lymphatic invasion, and metastatic carcinoma in 2 of 7 axillary lymph nodes in the left breast and axillary contents modified radical mastectomy specimen. The report notes that the posterior and anterior margins and nipple are free of neoplasm and that a discrepancy was noted in the highest axillary left lymph nodes.

Diagnosis: Clear cell adenocarcinoma located in the lower pole of the right kidney. The tumor measures 3.7 x 3.0 cm and extends to the capsule of the kidney but not through it. There is no invasion of lymphovascular space, transcapsular invasion, or renal vein invasion. The Fuhrman grade is 2/4. Surgical margins are negative. The specimen consists of a kidney with attached perinephric fat, weighing 365 gm, and measuring 14.0 x 8.0 x 7.0 cm. The ureter stump and renal artery and vein stumps are grossly unremarkable. Representative sections were taken for genomic studies and placed in orange cassettes labeled A through D. Sections from the mass, ureter, renal artery and vein, and uninvolved renal cortex are submitted in cassettes: blocks 1 through 4, block 5, block 6, and block 7, respectively.

The pathology report pertains to a right kidney radical nephrectomy of a patient with a renal mass. The diagnosis is renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with the tumor measuring 6.5 x 4 x 3.5 cm. The tumor extends into periadrenal adipose tissue, and there is lymphovascular space invasion. One lymph node was examined and found to contain metastatic carcinoma. The pTNM stage is pT3a N1 MX. A single lymph node labeled 'precaval' is received, which demonstrates metastatic renal cell carcinoma. The adrenal gland is not involved by the tumor. Samples have been taken for genomic studies.

Diagnosis: Left kidney resection indicates conventional clear cell renal cell carcinoma, grade 2 with a tumor size of 5.3 cm without invasion into perirenal fat, lymphovascular invasion, or renal vein invasion. The adrenal gland is benign. AJCC pathologic staging data: pT1b, NX. Gross Description: The specimen is a 219-gram kidney with a small amount of attached perinephric fat and has a soft yellow-tan focally hemorrhagic mass that is confined to the kidney and abuts the cortical surface. No additional masses or areas of interest are grossly identified. The adrenal gland is adherent to the kidney, and there is no enlargement of the lymphoid tissue at the renal hilum. Margins are negative.

The pathology report describes a left partial nephrectomy with a unifocal, conventional-clear cell carcinoma in the left kidney measuring 2.5 x 2 x1.5 cm. Surgical margins are uninvolved, but the tumor abuts the kidney capsule and is approximately 0.1 cm from the posterior margin. There is no lymphovascular space invasion or sarcomatoid features identified, and no lymph nodes were received for examination. The tumor is classified as pT1a NX. The specimen is submitted for genomics research. No other significant findings are reported.

Summary: The pathology report describes a 1.5 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma with Fuhrman nuclear grade I/IV identified in the left kidney, along with a benign renal cyst. The tumor is limited to the wedge resection and there is no involvement of margins. Angiolymphatic invasion is not identified. The AJCC pathologic stage is T1, Nx. The adjacent renal parenchyma is tan-gray and up to 0.4 cm thick. The cyst has a collapsed thin-walled cyst wall measuring 2.3 x 1.2 cm with less than 0.2 cm thickness.

Final Diagnosis: Papillary renal cell carcinoma (Fuhrman grade 3) in the right kidney, partial nephrectomy. Tumor size is 4.5 cm and there is no angiolymphatic or capsular invasion. The margin is free of tumor. AJCC pathologic staging data: pT1b, NX. Frozen section diagnosis shows a 4.5 x 4.5 x 4.0 cm yellow-red mass, which is sampled as FSA. Margin is free. Gross description shows a 53 gram, 6.0 x 5.0 x 4.5 cm segment of kidney with a yellow-red friable mass that comes to within 0.2 cm of the inked margin at frozen section. Three kidney tissue fragments, less than 1 gram and ranging from 0.9 to 1.5 cm in greatest dimension, were also received and all fragments will be inked black and submitted in toto.

The pathology report pertains to a left renal cancer specimen received for histopathological examination. The tumor is described as friable, tan-brown, and necrotic, with a size of 5 x 5 x 4.9 cm and located at the superior pole without involvement of renal sinus, pelvis/calyces, or renal vein. The tumor bulges the capsule but does not invade fat, and it is confined to the kidney with negative margins. The histologic type is papillary renal cell carcinoma (type 2) with a Fuhrman grade of 2. The non-neoplastic kidney has nephrosclerosis and chronic inflammation. The report concludes with pathologic staging (pTNM) indicating primary tumor limited to the kidney with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis. No sarcomatoid features were identified.

The pathology report describes the case of a male patient who underwent surgery for left renal cyst and left renal mass. The specimens obtained include the left cyst wall, deep margin, left lateral tumor, upper pole tumor, and lower pole tumor. The report mentions the presence of papillary renal cell carcinoma in the left lateral, upper pole, and lower pole tumors, with multiple smaller foci within the adjacent renal parenchyma. No tumor transection is noted, but numerous small satellite lesions are observed, increasing the patient's risk for recurrence. The report also details the surgical margin status, lymph node status, and pTNM stage. Additionally, it mentions an addendum issued to clarify the surgical margins status, as well as the conversation and additional information from Dr. lakes. The upper pole tumor showed an area of capsular retraction with ink focally extending to the tumor, which is interpreted as a retraction artifact and not a true positive capsular/soft tissue margin. The cyst wall is negative for malignancy.

The pathology report describes a case of papillary renal cell carcinoma (5.5 cm) in the left kidney with a Fuhrman grade of 3 of 4. The tumor has focally invaded the renal sinus and a separate tumor focus is located in the proximal ureter. Metastatic papillary renal cell carcinoma is found in lymph nodes, para-aortic, and interaortocaval regions. The left adrenal gland is benign, with no identified malignancy. Immunohistochemistry testing is positive for RCC, PAX-8, and CD10, but negative for CK5 and p63. The morphologic features and immunohistochemical profile support the diagnosis of papillary renal cell carcinoma. There is no involvement of the ureter, although it shares the same tumor as the main kidney mass. Clinic history shows a case of left kidney cancer. The gross description identifies a tan-white to pink friable mass present within the center of the kidney. The uninvolved tissues include mild, patchy, interstitial, chronic inflammation.

The pathology report describes a case of endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, grade 3, invasive, with extensive lymphatic invasion present in the uterus and cervix. Leiomyomas are also present. Metastatic endometrioid carcinoma is found in various lymph nodes including the right paraaortic lymph node, right pelvic lymph node, left pelvic lymph node, cephalad IMA node, left PA lymph node, and left renal lymph node. A mucinous neoplasm of borderline malignancy is present in the appendix with a small focus of metastatic endometrioid adenocarcinoma present on its serosa. A tubular adenoma is found in the right colon, distal ileum. There are clear cell changes, and squamous metaplasia is present in the primary tumor and its metastases, making it difficult to accurately grade the tumor.

Diagnosis: Endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, FIGO grade 2, nuclear grade 2-3, with a rare microscopic focus of possible early myometrial invasion. Leiomyoma and focal squamous metaplasia are also present. No metastatic carcinoma is identified in pelvic and periaortic lymph nodes. The appendix shows no significant histopathologic changes. Gross Findings: Total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy with uterus, bilateral adnexa weighing 130 grams. A friable tumor measuring 3.4 x 2.9 x 1.0 cm in size extends 0.7 cm into the posterior myometrium. Hemorrhagic cysts are present in the ovaries and nabothian cysts are identified. Multiple lymph nodes are present, no gross abnormalities are detected. Histopathological examination of a portion of adipose tissue from the right and left pelvic, and periaortic lymph nodes, and vermiform appendix is also conducted.

Diagnosis: Endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, with clear cell changes, grade 2, involving endometrial polyp with minimal superficial invasion. Other findings include chronic inflammation in the cervix, adenomyosis, and leiomyomas. No pathologic diagnosis of the left ovary and fallopian tube. Presence of endosalpingiosis in the left obturator lymph node and adipose tissue with focal fibrosis in left pelvic, right obturator, and right pelvic lymph nodes. No lymphatic invasion detected in the endometrial tumor. Stage of neoplasm is 1B, NO, Mx.

Report Summary: A pathology report for a patient who underwent laparoscopic-assisted vaginal hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy revealed the presence of endometrial adenocarcinoma, papillary endometrioid type, FIGO grade II with tumor size measuring 4.0 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm and myometrial invasion. No involvement of the cervix was observed. Multiple subserosal and intramural leiomyomas were present, along with an ovary and fallopian tube with endometriosis and xanthomatous salpingitis. One lymph node, identified in the omental biopsy, was negative for tumor. The report also mentions the status of multiple lymph nodes in the pelvic region and para-aortic region that did not show any evidence of metastases. The report concludes that the patient has primary Tumor (pT): pT1b [IB]: Tumor invades greater than or equal to one-half of the myometrium with no regional lymph node metastases according to Pathologic Staging (p TNM [FIGO]) AJCC 7th Edition 2010.

The pathology report describes two specimens received for analysis, including a transverse colon and an appendix. The transverse colon specimen shows an exophytic adenocarcinoma tumor extending through the wall and into adjacent pericolonic tissue. The tumor is moderately differentiated with focal poorly differentiated carcinoma identified, with two positive regional lymph nodes out of 26. The appendix specimen shows no discrete gross lesions and no tumors. An addendum will be issued regarding microsatellite instability testing on the transverse colon tumor.

Specimen obtained from a 17 cm segment of proximal right colon with attached distal ileum. Grossly, there is a 7.8 x 4.6 cm lobulated soft tan-pink tumor, which has invaded through the muscularis propria. The appendix has endometriosis. Microscopic examination shows invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, which has metastasized to two out of twenty-eight lymph nodes. Resection margins are negative for carcinoma. MSI testing has been requested.

The report describes the pathological findings of breast tissue surgical specimens. The left axillary sentinel node, left breast, and left axillary content were excised for biopsy, and the right breast tissue underwent excision for biopsy site changes. The clinical diagnosis was left breast carcinoma, and the post-surgery diagnosis revealed a large (5.5cm) infiltrating lobular carcinoma with a minor associated component of invasive ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ. Margin assessments were negative for tumor. The biomarker studies for the invasive ductal carcinoma are unavailable due to the extended cold ischemia time. Metastasis was confirmed in one lymph node among the 16 excised, with extracapsular extension. The report also indicated lobular carcinoma in situ, ductal carcinoma in situ, and an invasive ductal carcinoma <1mm from the inferior margin in the right breast tissue. The thirteen lymph nodes in dissection were all negative for metastasis.

The pathology report describes a case of left breast cancer. The biopsy of the sentinel lymph node reveals one lymph node with metastatic carcinoma. Left breast mastectomy shows an invasive pleomorphic lobular carcinoma of size 2.2 cm with negative margins of excision. The lymph nodes from left axilla lymph node dissection show nine negative lymph nodes. The invasive carcinoma is histologically a lobular type with a grade of 2 and an overall grade of 7/9. The nuclear score ranges from 1-3, and there is a mixture of conventional and pleomorphic lobular carcinoma. No vessel invasion or ductal carcinoma in situ is identified. One out of ten lymph nodes shows metastatic carcinoma of size 7mm but no extracapsular extension is observed. Prior biopsy site is identified within the tumor. The size of the lesion is pT2; margins are negative for invasive carcinoma except for lobular carcinoma in situ, which is focally present 0.5 mm from the anterior margin. The prognostic markers are seen in the previous core biopsy. The report includes the gross description of the received sample of unfixed left axillary sentinel node, left breast mastectomy, nipple core, and left axillary contents. The specimen margins and other details are also explained.

A patient underwent lumpectomy and axillary sentinel lymph node excisional biopsy for breast cancer. The lumpectomy revealed invasive ductal carcinoma, grade 2, as well as ductal carcinoma in situ, cribriform type, nuclear grade 2. Resection margins were negative for invasive and in situ carcinoma. The sentinel lymph node biopsy showed metastatic ductal carcinoma, 7 mm size with extranodal extension. The microscopic examination of the lumpectomy specimen revealed architectural, nuclear, and mitotic scores. The greatest dimension was 1.7 cm, and the specimen margins were negative for carcinoma. The lumpectomy specimen contained fibrosis, apocrine metaplasia, microcysts, and ordinary ductal hyperplasia and adenosis. The axillary sentinel lymph node had metastatic ductal carcinoma measuring 7mm in greatest dimension and extranodal tumor identified in block 1. The gross examination of the lumpectomy specimen showed a yellow-white fibrofatty cut surface with a stellate, ill-circumscribed, white-tan firm lesion that was 1.7 x 1.5 x 1.5 cm in size and grossly consistent with the previous biopsy site. The axillary sentinel node was a blue-stained pink-yellow irregular rubbery tissue fragment.

Diagnosis: Poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with multiple skin ulcerations. Tumor size is 17 cm with a minimum distance from preparation margins of less than 0.1 cm. Classification: NOS, G III, pT4bpNOLOVORO.

A breast sample was examined and revealed a poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with multiple tumor foci ranging in diameter from 1.7 cm to 7 cm, one of which had focal ulceration of the skin and spread intraductally. Focal angioinvasion was also observed. The dorsal resection margin was tumor-free. Overall, the tumor is classified as NOS, G III, pT4b(mult)N3aL1V0R0.
Diagnosis: Bifocal poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with tumor diameters of 2.8 and 0.8 cm. Tumor classification: NOS, G III, pT2(mult)NOLOVORO.
Diagnosis: Moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma, with tumor diameter of 3.5 cm and margin distance dorsally 3 cm. Tumor classification is NOS, G II, pT2N3aLOV0R0.

Left breast has invasive breast carcinoma with mixed differentiation and a tumor. It is classified as pT2 (28 mm) pM0 (0/28) grade 1. There is also associated extensive lobular neoplasia and DCIS grade 1 corresponding to pTis RI ventral.

A poorly differentiated invasive ductal breast carcinoma measuring 2.2cm was found in the right breast resection material with minimum margins of almost 1cm. The tumor was surrounded by fibrolipomatous atrophic glandular tissue and there was no evidence of an intraductal tumor component. The overlying skin, including the nipple, was tumor-free. The tumor is classified as M-8500/3, G3, pT2, pN2a, pMX, stage IIIA, and R0.

Filtered report: The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with intraductal patterns of spread. The tumor is classified as NOS, G III, pT2N1aLOV0RX based on its size and lymph node involvement.

The pathology report indicates moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with focal intraductal components, resulting in a tumor classification of NOS, G II, pT1cN1aL1V0R0. The tumor diameter is reportedly 1.9 cm.
Diagnosis: Ablated (right) breast sample with invasive and ductal carcinoma. Paget's disease of the nipple. Dorsal margin tumor-free. Tumor classification: NOS, G II, pT4bN1aL1 1VORO.

Moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with two foci (tumor diameters: 3 cm and 2 cm), focal intraductal components, and circumscribed angioinvasion. No infiltration or ulceration of the skin. Tumor classification: NOS, G II, pT2(mult)N1aL1VOM1RO.

Summary: The pathology report indicates the presence of invasive ductal breast carcinoma with a diameter of 2.2 cm that has extended cranially to within 5 mm of the resection margin at 3 and 12 o'clock. The follow-up resection material and sentinel lymph nodes were tumor-free. The tumor classification is M-8500/3, G2, pT2, pN0 (sn), MX, and R0.

Left breast segment has a 3 cm moderately differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with low-grade DCIS grade II. Resection margins are healthy on all sides. Two of 16 lymph nodes show metastases. Tumor classification: pT2 (3 cm), pN1a (2/16), MX, R0; G2, L0, V0.

Filtered report: Diagnosis: Moderately differentiated invasive lobular carcinoma (tumor diameter: 8 cm) found in ablated breast sample. Tumor-free dorsal resection margin. Tumor classification for right breast: lobular carcinoma, G II, pT3N0L0V0R1.

Summary: The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of invasive lobular breast carcinoma with extensive skin infiltration but no ulceration. The tumor is classified as G II with a diameter of 3 cm and a minimum distance of 2.5 cm from the resection margin. The tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors but negative for C-erb B-2 oncoprotein. There is no evidence of metastatic infiltration or invasion into the axillary lymph nodes, confirming a pNO status.

Filtered report: A poorly differentiated, largely ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type, with infiltration of the pericolic fatty tissue (pT3; G3), was found during a 24-cm-long resection of the colon. The tumor was of a maximum of 3.5 cm in diameter. Tumor-free resection margins of the colon were observed. Additionally, three tubular adenomas in the colonic mucosa with low- to moderate-grade dysplasia were detected. A total of 28 histologically tumor-free lymph nodes of a maximum of 0.8 cm in diameter were determined after acetone fixation. Final tumor stage: pT3 pNO (0/28) pMX; G3.

The right hemicolectomy specimen showed a small and larger adenoma with moderate dysplasia, a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with infiltration of perimuscular fat tissue (G3, pT3), and a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with infiltration of the submucosa (G2, pT1) in the proximal large bowel, with a detectable ulcer in the aboral section, and tumor-free resection margins. The appendix and omental tissue were also tumor-free. Twenty-one lymph nodes were dissected and found to be tumor-free, thus placing the double carcinoma of the right colon in category pNO (0/12). A follow-up report will be made on lymph node status.

A right hemicolectomy specimen was examined that contained an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma located at the right flexure, with infiltration and penetration of the lamina muscularis propria. The size of all 18 dissected lymph nodes in the vicinity of the tumor were up to 0.9 cm and were determined to be tumor-free. Additionally, a rectal resectate contained a broad-based tubulovillous adenoma with mild dysplasia and free resection margins. The fatty tissue on the rectal resectate showed no histological abnormalities. Overall, the adenocarcinoma was determined to be at stage pT2 pNO (0/18).

The pathology report indicates the presence of a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma in the ascending colon, which has extensively infiltrated the pericolic fatty tissue, with two regional lymph node metastases. The report also notes a small tubular adenoma of the colonic mucosa with slight dysplasia, as well as tumor-free large and small bowel resection margins and tumor-free mesenteric and omental fat tissue. The tumor stage is reported as pT3 pN1 (2/28) pMX; G2, L0, V0 R0.

Resection of sigmoid colon with diverticulosis and moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma infiltration of perimuscular fatty tissue. Tumor-free oral and aboral resection margins with thirty-seven regional lymph nodes also tumor-free with uncharacteristic reactive changes. G2, pT3 pN0 (0/37) LO. V0 RO.

Diagnosis: Colon carcinoma of moderately differentiated, partially mucus-producing colorectal adenocarcinoma present in a resected section of colon (sigma) measuring a maximum of 2cm in diameter and spreading invasively to the internal sections of the muscularis propria. The rest of the intestinal wall has some pseudodiverticula and peridiverticulitis with chronic scarring. Oral and aboral margin of the resected material is tumor-free. 22 mesocolic lymph nodes are tumor-free with uncharacteristically reactive changes. Tumor stage is pT2, pNO (0/22) L0, V0; G2 R0.

Summary: Colon and rectosigmoid resection material shows a moderately differentiated colorectal adenocarcinoma extending 6 cm encircling the colon wall and invading all intestinal wall layers to the nearby mesocolic fatty tissue. The tumor is within 3.5 cm of the resection margin, but both oral and aboral resection margins are tumor-free. Thirty-three mesocolic lymph nodes are tumor-free with uncharacteristic reactive lesions. Tumor stage: pT3 pNO (0/33) LO V0; G2.

Resected colon sample (10 cm in length) with moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (colorectal type) measuring a max of 3cm, with widespread infiltration of pericolic fatty tissue, serosa penetration, and 4 regional lymph node metastases. Additionally, 2 tubular adenomas with moderate dysplasia were observed. Tumor stage: pT4 pN2 (4/15) pM1 (clinically liver metastases); G2, L0, V0, locally R0. Tumor-free colon resection margins.

The report describes a case of right hemicolectomy preparation with tumor-free oral and aboral resection margins and a hyperplastic polyp in the ascending colon. It also identifies an ulcerated adenocarcinoma in the cecum with extensive infiltration of the perimuscular fatty tissue (G3, pT3). After acetone clarification, 40 lymph nodes were analyzed and were found to be microscopically tumor-free throughout. The report concludes with a diagnosis of stage pT3 pNO (0/40) LO V0 R0.

Filtered Report: Diagnosis: Right-sided hemicolectomy preparation with tumor-free oral and aboral resection, which includes an ulcerated, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the cecum with penetration of the peritoneum, multiple regional lymph node metastases, and peritoneal seeding. (G2, pT4 pN2 L1, V0, pN2 12/35 pM1).

Summary: The report describes a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon with ulceration and erosions, accompanied by chronic and acute inflammation. The tumor has spread to the parietal layers of the colon and the fatty connective tissue beyond the muscle layer, but the lymph nodes are tumor-free. There is also moderate chronic lymphadenitis and a diverticulum within the tumor. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA-M 8140/3 and corresponds to a tumor stage of pT3, pNO, MX, L1, R0. Tumor-free overview slices are identified from all other resection margins and perivascular fatty tissue, and omental fatty tissue.

Moderately differentiated colic adenocarcinoma, G2, with infiltration of all wall layers (pT3), vascular infiltration L1,V1, and free lymph nodes (pN0) (0/14). Free resection margins indicate R0. Tumor classification: ICDO-DA M-8140/3, G2, pT3, L1, V1, pN0, consistent with R0. Lymph nodes were large enough to be notable in imaging procedures.

Diagnosis: Invasive adenocarcinoma of the colon (cecal carcinoma G3) with a tendency towards infiltration into the adjoining fatty connective tissue and vascular infiltration is observed in Block A. In Block B, in addition to a polyp of tubular adenoma type with focal severe dysplasia, a circumscribed adenocarcinoma with infiltration of the submucosa is present (G2, pT1). Resection margins are free, lymph nodes (0 to 17) are free. Tumor classification: ICDO-DA M 8140/3. G3 - pT3 L1, V1, (1st tumor). G2 - pT1 L0, V0, (polypoid lesion). Locally R0.

Diagnosis: right-sided hemicolectomy with moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (in the ascending colon) of histopathological differentiation grade G2, with tumor infiltration of the colon wall layers along with pericolic fatty connective tissue. There is also chronic appendicitis. Tumor stage: pT3, pNO (0/16), MX, L1, R0. Tumor classification: ICDO-DA-M. 8140/3, G2. 11+.

Summarized report: The resected section of the colon (descending and sigmoid colon) shows a moderately differentiated ulcerated adenocarcinoma that has metastasized to several regional lymph nodes. There is also perifocal inflammation that is encroaching on the peritoneum of the abdominal wall. The resection margins are tumor-free.

Filtered pathology report: Invasive, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon (G2) without vascular infiltration (LO, V0) but with infiltration of the muscularis (pT2). Tumor classification: ICDO-DA-M 8140/3. G2. pT2, L0, V0. pNO (0 of 14).

The diagnosis is a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon ascendens, with infiltration of pericolic fatty tissue. There are eight lymph node metastases out of 30 that were examined. The tumor classification is adenocarcinoma G2 pT3 N2 (8/30).

The pathology report indicates the presence of an invasive, poorly differentiated carcinoma with lymph and blood vessel invasion and free lymph nodes and resection margins. The tumor is confirmed to be of epithelial nature and likely a neuro-endocrine carcinoma. Provisional tumor classification is at least p T 3, p N 0, M X, R 0. Marked S100 protein positivity and positive reaction for chromogranin and synaptophysin were also observed.

The pathology report describes a case of right breast cancer with invasive lobular carcinoma detected in a biopsy of the breast mass and in a sentinel lymph node from the right axilla. The tumor is mostly infiltrating and poorly differentiated, with periductal targetoid-like areas and occasional prominent nucleoli. The Nottingham score is 7, indicating a grade II malignancy. Other findings include no evidence of microcalcifications, lymphovascular invasion, or ductal carcinoma in situ, and a distance of approximately 0.1 mm to the posterior inked margin of the excised mass. In addition, breast cancer prognostic panel studies were performed, showing normal limits for HER-2/neu staining, favorable results for ER and PR staining, and borderline results for Ki-67 staining. Immunostain for E-cadherin on block A was entirely negative, supporting the diagnosis of lobular carcinoma. Metastatic lobular carcinoma was identified in two of six axillary lymph nodes, for a total of three positive lymph nodes out of seven, including the sentinel lymph node. Ancillary studies and marker studies for breast cancer are pending.

The pathology report describes a partial lumpectomy of the right breast for invasive lobular carcinoma. Five specimens were received, including the breast lump, two sentinel lymph nodes, and two samples of breast tissue. The breast lump specimen measured 5.7 x 7 x 1.8 cm, with a 2.8 cm sclerotic tumor mass close to the anterior margin. Microscopic examination confirmed the presence of lobular carcinoma and a tiny focus of lobular cancerization. One sentinel lymph node showed metastatic adenocarcinoma, while the other was benign. The final margins appear free of tumor, and hormone receptors are predominantly positive. Cytokeratin E1/E3 immunohistochemical stain supported the metastatic diagnosis in one sentinel lymph node.

The pathology report is for a patient who had a right breast and axillary sentinel lymph node mastectomy and biopsy. The report shows the presence of multicentric invasive lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade 1-2, which is spread across an 8cm area of the breast. Two axillary lymph nodes are tumor-free, and resection margins are also free of cancerous tissues. Lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS) is widespread throughout the right breast, and the patient has no distant metastasis. The invasive tumor size in the central area of the breast is 8cm, has a slightly stellate appearance, and is soft and rubbery. The grossly identifiable surgical margins of the specimens are negative, and no lymph nodes are identified within the lateral portion of the excision. The pathology report also shows the presence of subareolar duct ectasia, focal fibrosis, cysts, mild usual type ductal hyperplasia, and a discrete focus of scar tissue in the central inferior breast. As for receptor status and HER2/neu, Estrogen and Progesterone receptors are positive, while Her2/neu is 1+. The pathological stage is IIB.

Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma in the right colon, moderately differentiated, extending through muscularis propria and into subserosal adipose tissue. No lymphovascular space invasion, perforation of visceral peritoneum, or mesenteric deposits identified. No metastatic carcinoma found in any of the 12 examined lymph nodes. Fibrous obliteration of the luminal tip in appendix, with no carcinoma identified. No carcinoma found in proximal, distal, or radial surgical margins. Macrophages containing brownish black pigment, consistent with prior tattoo. Stage: pT3NO.

Distal ileum and right colon (right hemicolectomy): Histologic type: Adenocarcinoma tumor located within the cecal pouch, measured 4.6 X 3.0 cm in size with moderately differentiated grade, and invaded the muscularis propria into subserosal adipose tissue with focal perforation of visceral peritoneum. No mesenteric deposits were found but 11 out of 17 lymph nodes examined had metastatic carcinoma. Fibrous obliteration of the luminal tip was seen in the appendix. Final stage: pT4aN2bVL.

The pathology report describes two specimens: A) a portion of adipose tissue from a colon for rule out metastatic colon cancer showing a poorly demarcated firm dull tan nodule that is confirmed to be metastatic adenocarcinoma on frozen section, and B) a rectosigmoid colon segmental resection with a deeply invasive, moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma present extending into the pericolonic fat and penetrating the visceral peritoneum. The report states that the tumor is moderately differentiated and that there is no lymphatic invasion found. The report also notes the presence of pericolonic soft tissue metastases and 37 regional lymph nodes, 18 of which contain metastatic adenocarcinoma. The report concludes by stating that the tumor is compatible with colonic origin and no distant metastasis is detected.

Filtered pathology report: Moderately differentiated rectal carcinoma in rectal position with infiltration of the muscularis (pT2) and no vascular infiltration (L0 V0), as well as free lymph nodes. Tumor classification: ICDO-DA M-8140/3. G2. pT2, L0, V0, pNO.

Summarized report: Moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colon, specifically rectal carcinoma, infiltrating muscularis and fatty connective tissue (pT3). Vascular infiltrates present (L1, V1). Tumor classification: ICDO-DA M8140/3, G2. No lymph node involvement (pNO 0/15), locally removed with no residual cancer (R0).

Summary: The rectosigmoid resected material showed a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the colorectal type. The tumor was located 3 cm from the aboral resection margin, 4 cm in diameter, had infiltrated the perirectal fatty tissue, and had caused carcinomatous lymphangitis. Three local lymph node metastases were found. The tumor-free colon and mesenteric resection margins were noted, as well as tumor-free circumferential resection margins. Diverticulosa coli was also present. The tumor stage was pT3, pN1 (3/35), pMX; G2, L1, V0, local R0.

Filtered pathology report summary: Rectal adenocarcinoma with infiltration of pericolic fatty tissue was found during resection. Tumor resection margins and lymph nodes tested (14) were tumor-free. The tumor was classified as poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma G3, pT3 NO (0/14) L0 V0 R0. Superficial splenic tissue had hemorrhaging and capsule defects, but no indications of malignancy were found.

Summary: The pathology report describes a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the rectum with histopathological grade, ulceration, tumor infiltration, and lymphatic and vascular involvement. There is also chronic inflammation, adenocarcinoma in the attached tissue, chronic lymphadenitis, hyperplastic polyps, and tubular adenomas. The tumor classification is pT3, pN0, Mx, L1, V1.
Invasive rectal carcinoma of mucinous type with infiltration of all layers of the wall, lymph node metastasis, and free resection margins in the region of the mucosa.

The pathology report describes the histopathological examination of a colon cancer patient. The specimens received were a lymph node and colon segments. Gross examination of the colon segment revealed a polypoid centrally ulcerated mass invading the wall. Metastatic adenocarcinoma was identified in 3 out of 17 lymph nodes. The lymph node biopsy showed one benign lymph node negative for metastatic carcinoma. The anastomotic rings showed no significant pathological alteration or malignancy identified. The cancer case summary checklist indicated invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with invasion through the muscularis propria into the subserosal tissue. The tumor was found to have arisen in a villous adenoma with pT3 and pN1b staging. No prior treatment was identified, and lymphovascular or perineural invasion and tumor deposits were not identified. Consultation was obtained.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis and characteristics of a tumor found in a female patient's uterus, cervix, and lymph nodes. The tumor is identified as endometrioid adenocarcinoma with a histologic grade of 3 and extends 0.7 cm into the myometrium. No involvement of other organs or lymph nodes is detected. Surgical margins are uninvolved, and the lymph node status is negative. Additionally, leiomyomata is found in the myometrium, and stromal hyperthecosis is identified in an attached ovary. Immunochemical stains reveal focally positive lesional cells for P53 and positive cellular proliferation for inhibin. The specimen consists of omentum biopsy, paraaortic and pelvic lymph nodes excision, and hysterectomy with bilateral salpingoophorectomy. Representative sections from different organs are submitted in cassettes for further analysis.

A pathology report summarizes the findings of a biopsy performed on a patient with a pre-op diagnosis of endometrial cancer. The report describes multiple tissue samples, including an omental biopsy, peritoneal implant, and samples from the uterus, cervix, bilateral tubes, ovaries, and lymph nodes. The final diagnosis reveals a poorly differentiated (grade 3) endometrial adenocarcinoma, which extensively involves the endometrial cavity and has invaded the myometrium. The report notes lymphovascular space invasion but reports negative lymph nodes in all regional resections. The diagnosis recommends clinical correlation, and the slides were reviewed by another pathologist who concurred with the findings.

The pathology report pertains to a patient with a pre-operative diagnosis of endometrial cancer who underwent a hysterectomy and pelvic lymph node dissection. The report includes gross and microscopic descriptions of the extracted tissues. The left and right pelvic lymph nodes contained eight and six benign regional lymph nodes, respectively. The endometrial cavity contained a moderately differentiated (G2) endometrial carcinoma, which invaded more than half of the myometrium up to a depth of 11 mm. The tumor did not extend beyond the endometrial cavity, and no lymphovascular space invasion was identified. The cervical, left parametrial, and right parametrial margins were all negative. No metastatic carcinoma was detected in the 14 examined lymph nodes. Additionally, complex hyperplasia with atypia was observed in the endometrium, and leiomyoma and focal endometriosis were found in other sections of the uterus. The final diagnosis was pT1bNO endometrial carcinoma.

Sex: Female. Diagnosis: Breast Cancer. Histological description: Infiltrative ductal-lobular carcinoma. Anatomic Site: Left Breast. Tumor location: Primary. Grade: 2. T Stage: 3. N Stage: 0. M Stage: 0. Treatment: none. Normal Sample. Anatomic Site: Blood. Sample Type: Normal.

Patient is Female, diagnosed with Infiltrative ductal carcinoma in the Right Breast. The tumor is primary and located in the Grade 3 radical mastectomy. The tumor specimen is frozen in cryomold. There is no treatment given or specified. A normal blood sample is also taken.

Patient has been diagnosed with left breast invasive ductal carcinoma (IDC) and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with intermediate nuclear grade located in the upper inner quadrant measuring 1.5cm in its largest dimension. The malignant tissue is negative for vascularity and it is not affecting the surgical margins. The results of special stains and re-cuts from deeper levels have been ordered, and the results will be noted in an addendum that includes the HER2 test, estrogen receptor (ER) and progesterone receptor (PR) status. Additionally, benign breast tissue with fibrocystic changes, including ductal hyperplasia without atypia and apocrine metaplasia, is identified in right breast mastectomy. No metastatic tumor is found in the examined sentinel lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes the results of a lymph node excision and a left breast mass excision. The lymph node excision consists of four sentinel lymph nodes, with each node being excised and examined for metastatic tumor cells using H/E staining and immunohistochemical stains for cytokines. All four nodes are reported as benign with no evidence of metastatic tumors. The breast mass excision reveals a 4.5 cm, poorly differentiated, invasive ductal carcinoma, without any in situ component or vascular invasion. Focal calcifications are present in benign breast parenchyma. Immunohistochemical stains are performed on the formalin-fixed tissue with the following results for invasive carcinoma: estrogen receptor (positive nuclear staining), progesterone receptor (negative nuclear staining), HER2 (negative). The margins of resection are negative for carcinoma, and no involvement of the skin is observed. Furthermore, intraoperative consultation shows all four sentinel nodes as benign.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive lobular carcinoma in the right breast of a female patient. The tumor is classical in type, measuring 0.4 cm in the largest dimension. Focal ductal carcinoma in situ and lobular carcinoma in situ (type A) are also identified. The nipple base is involved by invasive carcinoma, and calcifications are present in benign breast parenchyma. Vascular invasion is not noted, and the surgical margins do not show involvement by invasive carcinoma. The skin shows an ulcer. No involvement of the attached skeletal muscle by carcinoma is identified. The non-neoplastic breast tissue shows biopsy site changes. Four benign intramammary lymph nodes are identified. Gross examination reveals a breast without attached axillary tail, measuring 30.5 x 17.5 x 7.5 cm with overlying skin. A biopsy cavity is identified under the scar, and no gross nodule is identified. The report includes a summary of the sections submitted for examination.

The pathology report describes a case of a poorly differentiated invasive ductal carcinoma with ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) in the right lower inner quadrant of the breast, accompanied by microcalcifications. The right axillary lymph nodes are dissected and biopsied. Of the six lymph nodes examined, one sentinel node has metastatic carcinoma, while the other six lymph nodes, including two other sentinel nodes, are benign. The invasive carcinoma ranges in size from 0.1 cm to 3 cm, with high nuclear grade and moderate necrosis. The ER and PR status of the specimen shows 90% nuclear staining of ER and only 1% nuclear staining of PR. The HER2/neu status is positive. The specimen is negative for skin involvement and positive for vascular invasion. Intraoperative consultation confirms metastatic carcinoma in the sentinel lymph node and negative lymph nodes in the other two sentinel nodes.

The pathology report relates to a year-old patient who was diagnosed with right breast cancer and scheduled for a right total mastectomy. Six specimens were submitted for testing, including four lymph nodes and the right breast tissue. The diagnosis has shown that the non-sentinel lymph node from the right axilla was negative for the tumor. The invasive ductal carcinoma was detected in the upper-inner quadrant of the right breast and measured 2.5 cm in largest dimension grossly. No involvement of the nipple or benign breast parenchyma calcifications was identified. The non-neoplastic breast tissue showed biopsy site changes, fibrocystic changes, and fibroadenomatoid change. The report also confirms that deeper level recuts and special stains have been ordered. Finally, the immunohistochemical stains for cytokeratins showed no evidence of metastatic tumor, while the ER/PR is positive, HER2/neu is negative.

The pathology report describes a left breast core biopsy showing invasive ductal carcinoma, histologic grade II-III/III, with a minor component of ductal carcinoma in situ. There is lymphovascular invasion present and focal extranodal extension of carcinoma in the lymph nodes. The report also mentions the diagnosis of benign breast tissue with sclerosing adenosis and ductal hyperplasia without atypia in the prophylactic right mastectomy. The lymph node status is provided as 0/8 for level I and 1/7 for level II. The nipple, skin, and surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Additional special stains and immunostains will be reported in an addendum. The gross description includes the dimensions and characteristics of the specimens submitted. In the addendum report, the left breast is identified as HER-2/neu positive.

The patient is a female with multicentric invasive carcinoma of the left breast consisting of two foci located at 3:00 and 5:00. The left total mastectomy with possible ALND was performed, and four specimens were submitted for analysis. The lymph node sentinel #1, level 1, lt. axilla contained one lymph node positive for metastatic carcinoma (1/1), measuring 0.3 cm with extranodal extension identified. The lymph node sentinel #2, level 1, lt. axilla, and non-sentinel tissue, lt. axilla both contained one benign lymph node (0/1). The left total mastectomy revealed multiple foci of invasive ductal carcinoma, NOS type, histological grade II/III, and nuclear grade II/III, ranging in size from 0.3 cm to 1.8 cm. Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) was also identified, constituting less than or equal to 25% of the total tumor mass, admixed with the invasive component. Calcifications were present in both the in situ and invasive carcinoma, and vascular invasion was detected, with no involvement of the surgical margins by either invasive or in situ carcinoma. There was no skin involvement by carcinoma, and attached skeletal muscle was negative for the tumor. ER/PR were positive, and HER2/NEU was negative. The specimen had multiple representative sections submitted for analysis. The intraoperative consultation reports were benign, and the permanent diagnosis matched the final diagnosis.

A male patient with left breast cancer underwent a mastectomy. Histopathology of the breast tissue revealed invasive ductal carcinoma, histologic grade III/III, nuclear grade III/III, measuring 2.2 cm in largest dimension, as well as ductal carcinoma in situ. The invasive carcinoma was located in the lower inner quadrant and central area, involving the nipple, with perineural and focal lymphatic invasion. There was no involvement of surgical margins by either invasive or in situ carcinoma. One sentinel lymph node was found to have metastatic carcinoma, measuring 1.8 cm, with no extranodal extension. ER, PR, and HER2/neu tests were negative. A frozen section diagnosis of metastatic carcinoma was confirmed by permanent diagnosis.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive lobular (questionable duct) carcinoma in the left breast, which was treated by wide excision with needle localization and sentinel lymph node biopsy. The report details the status of sentinel nodes #1-3, non-sentinel tissue, and margins, and provides a diagnosis of invasive carcinoma (solid growth pattern, minimal or no tubule formation, pronounced nuclear grade), with focal associated lobular carcinoma in situ. The report contains information on immunohistochemistry results, including positive estrogen and progesterone receptor staining, and equivocal HER2 staining (with FISH to be performed). Oncotype testing was subsequently carried out, with results indicating that the HER2/neu gene was not amplified. The surgical margins were reported as benign, and no lymphovascular invasion was identified. The report notes that the tests performed were all clinically approved, and that the laboratory is certified for high complexity clinical testing.

Specimens submitted include uterine and cervical tissues, fallopian tubes, and lymph nodes from various locations. The diagnosis reveals adenocarcinoma of endometrium, papillary serous type, invading more than half of the myometrium with a maximal thickness of myometrial invasion at 11mm. No endocervical or vascular invasion is identified. The endometrium shows atrophy, while the myometrium and all adnexae are unremarkable. The lymph nodes from external iliac, hypogastric, obturator, and para-aortic regions are benign except for one in the left external iliac and one in the left para-aortic lymph node positive for metastatic carcinoma. Left abdominal wall excision shows a benign lipoma and skin.

The pathology report describes a case of endometrial adenocarcinoma of serous type that showed invasion of the myometrium (>50%) in the uterus, cervix, fallopian tubes, and ovaries. No lymphovascular invasion was identified. Lymph nodes in the para-aortic, common iliac, external iliac, and obturator regions did not show involvement. The omentum and biopsies of the pelvic wall, cul-de-sac (anterior and posterior), paracolic gutter, and diaphragm revealed benign fibroadipose or fibromuscular tissue. One leiomyoma was identified in the myometrium.

The report describes multiple specimens submitted, including uterus, cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes, ovaries, and lymph nodes excision. The diagnosis indicates the presence of adenocarcinoma of endometrium, endometrioid type, with multiple microscopic foci of microinvasion and nuclear grade 3. The thickness of the myometrium in the area of maximal tumor invasion is 19.0 mm. The report also mentions complex hyperplasia with atypia in the background of proliferative endometrium. The lymph nodes examined indicate benign lymph nodes with various numbers excised from different regions. The report is based on a personal examination of the slides and other materials.

The report describes the examination of ten specimens, including biopsies and lymph nodes. The anterior cul-de-sac biopsy shows fibrous tissue with calcifications and focal endosalpingiosis. The hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy specimens (2-4,6-9) show two separate foci of adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, endometrioid type. The larger focus of tumor invades </= half of the myometrium, with a maximal thickness of myometrial invasion at 3mm and an 8mm thickness of the myometrium in the area of maximal tumor invasion. The smaller focus of tumor is limited to the endometrium, with no identified vascular invasion. Endocervical invasion is present in both the mucosa and stroma. The lymph node status shows no metastatic nodes identified in the right obturator, right external iliac, right hypogastric, left obturator, left external iliac, and left common iliac lymph nodes. The left hypogastric lymph node excision and left lateral external iliac lymph node excision specimens show benign fibroadipose tissue, with no identified lymph nodes.

Specimens Submitted: 1. SP: Uterus, cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes, and ovaries. 2. SP: Abdominal pannus. 3. SP: Left external iliac lymph node. 4. SP: Left obturator lymph node. 5. SP: Right external iliac lymph node. 6. SP: Right obturator lymph nodes. 7. SP: Right common iliac lymph nodes. 8. SP: Portion of omentum. Diagnosis: 1) UTERUS, CERVIX, BILATERAL FALLOPIAN TUBES, AND OVARIES - TOTAL HYSTERECTOMY AND BILATERAL SALPINGO-OOPHORECTOMY: - ADENOCARCINOMA OF ENDOMETRIUM, ENDOMETRIOID TYPE, FIGO GRADE III (>50% SOLID GROWTH), NUCLEAR GRADE 2. - THE TUMOR INVADERS TO <HALF OF THE MYOMETRIUM. - THE MAXIMAL THICKNESS OF MYOMETRIAL INVASION IS 9 MM. - THE THICKNESS OF THE MYOMETRIUM IN THE AREA OF MAXIMAL TUMOR INVASION IS 22 MM. - NO INDOCERVICAL INVASION IS IDENTIFIED. - NO VASCULAR INVASION IS IDENTIFIED. - THE ENDOMETRIUM IS INACTIVE. - THE MYOMETRIUM SHOWS ADENOMYOSIS AND SUBSEROSAL LEIOMYOMA. - THERE IS ALSO AN ENDOCERVICAL POLYP. - ALL ADNEXAL STRUCTURES ARE UNREMARKABLE. 2) ABDOMEN, PANNUS; PANNICULECTOMY: - UNREMARKABLE SKIN AND SUBCUTANEOUS ADIPOSE TISSUE. LYMPH NODES: 3) LEFT EXTERNAL ILIAC; EXCISION: SEVEN BENIGN LYMPH NODES (0/7). 4) LEFT OBTURATOR; EXCISION: NINE BENIGN LYMPH NODES (0/9). 5) RIGHT EXTERNAL ILIAC; EXCISION: FOUR BENIGN LYMPH NODES (0/4). 6) RIGHT OBTURATOR; EXCISION: FOUR BENIGN LYMPH NODES (0/4). 7) RIGHT COMMON ILIAC; EXCISION: ONE BENIGN LYMPH NODE (0/1). 8) OMENTUM; PARTIAL OMENTECTOMY: - BENIGN ADIPOSE TISSUE. I ATTEST THAT THE ABOVE DIAGNOSIS IS BASED UPON MY PERSONAL EXAMINATION OF THE SLIDES (AND/OR OTHER MATERIAL) AND THAT I HAVE REVIEWED AND APPROVED THIS REPORT.

The report describes the medical findings of multiple specimens submitted for analysis. The uterus, cervix, bilateral tubes, and ovaries were removed and diagnosed with adenocarcinoma of the endometrium, endometrioid type, with no endocervical or vascular invasion identified. The maximum thickness of myometrial invasion was 1.3 cm. The omentum specimen was identified as benign fibroadipose tissue. Multiple lymph nodes were excised, and the majority were identified as benign with the exception of a single lymph node with focal endosalpingiosis and four benign lymph nodes identified in the left obturator. The report was reviewed and approved by the examiner.

The pathology report pertains to a patient who underwent surgery involving removal of the uterus, cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes, ovaries, and lymph nodes. The report indicates that the patient has a type of tumor with spindle cell component, identified as adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type with nuclear and FIGO grade 3. The tumor exhibits at least two distinct morphologies, including solid, spindled, and transitional-cell like endometrioid adenocarcinoma. The report also includes the presence of metastatic carcinoma to both ovaries, with additional immunostains pending for microsatellite instability testing. A pannus excision showed benign skin and fibroadipose tissue. The report concludes with immunohistochemical staining results indicating that the tested DNA mismatch repair proteins are present in the tumor.

The pathology report is for a left partial mastectomy performed on a patient with left breast cancer. The tumor is invasive ductal carcinoma with a Nottingham combined histologic grade of 3 and a unifocal focality. The tumor size is 4.9 cm with no lymphovascular invasion or in situ component identified. The margin status for the invasive component is negative with the anterior margin being 0.3cm from the tumor. There is no atypia or carcinoma identified in the sentinel left breast lymph node, left lateral margin, or left medial margin. The pathologic TNM stage is pT2 pNO. The specimen weighs 229 grams and measures 13.5 cm superior to inferior, 11 cm medial to lateral, and 6cm anterior to posterior. The biopsy site contains one discrete mass measuring 4.9 X 3.6 X 3.8 cm and located in the central portion of the resected specimen. There is no gross involvement of skin or fascia/muscle by tumor. The remainder of the breast is composed primarily of yellow lobulated fat. No microcalcifications are identified, but duct ectasia is present.

Left breast mastectomy revealed infiltrating lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade I, forming a mass. Lobular carcinoma in situ is present. Non-neoplastic breast parenchyma shows nonproliferative fibrocystic changes with duct ectasia. Calcifications are present in benign ducts and acini. Surgical margins, including the deep margin, are negative for tumor. Sentinel lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, while multiple axillary lymph nodes show no metastatic carcinoma. Estrogen and progesterone receptor analysis and Her-2/NEU have been ordered.

Breast, total mastectomy, right: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III, forming two masses (central: 2.6 x 2.2 x 1.6 cm and upper inner quadrant: 0.3 x 0.2 x 0.2 cm), with ductal carcinoma in-situ composing less than 5% of tumor volume. Angiolymphatic invasion is absent, and surgical margins are negative for tumor. Right axillary non-sentinel lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma, with one showing focal extracapsular extension. Right axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative. Residual right breast tissue has non-proliferative fibrocystic changes. Breast, left, simple mastectomy: benign breast parenchyma with proliferative fibrocystic changes, including a complex sclerosing lesion, and negative for malignancy. Additional left breast tissue has benign breast parenchyma with non-proliferative fibrocystic changes and negative for malignancy.

Breast, left, modified radical mastectomy: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II (of. III) forming a mass (2.8 x 2.3 x 2.1. cm) located in the retroareolar region of the breast. Ductal carcinoma in situ is absent. Angiolymphatic invasion and calcifications are not seen. Tumor involves the overlying skin [AJCC pT4]. A single left axillary mid/low lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma with extranodal extension. Lymph nodes, left high axillary, excision: Multiple (2) left high axillary lymph nodes are negative for tumor. All surgical resection margins, including the skin and deep margins, are negative for tumor (minimum tumor free margin, 1.1 cm, anterior superior margin).

Diagnosis: Left breast infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III (of III), with a 2.0 x 1.8 x 1.5 cm circumscribed mass and focal (5%) high grade ductal carcinoma. In situ with necrosis and no angiolymphatic invasion. Non-neoplastic breast parenchyma shows nonproliferative fibrocystic changes with calcifications. All surgical resection margins are negative for tumor after a single separately submitted re-excision of the anterior/inferior margin, with minimum tumor free margin of 0.7 cm at the superior margin. One of three left axillary sentinel lymph nodes is positive for an isolated tumor cell cluster measuring 0.11 mm, while all other lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma.

Final diagnosis indicates Invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade III forming a 2.7 x 2.7 x 1.5 cm mass on the left side. The margins, including the separately submitted superior margin, are negative for the tumor. Multiple (2) left axillary sentinel lymph nodes are negative for the tumor. The immunohistochemical cytokeratin stain confirms the H&E impression on the paraffin-embedded sentinel lymph node tissue.

Final Diagnosis: Infiltrating ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade II, with a minor component of ductal carcinoma in situ, intermediate nuclear grade, present in the left breast, forming a 1.9 x 1.2 x 1.0 cm mass, and negative margins for tumor. Multiple (3) left axillary sentinel lymph nodes and a single left axillary lymph node are negative for tumor (AJCC pN0). A Her-2/NEU analysis has been ordered on paraffin embedded tissue.

Final Diagnosis: Breast, right, mastectomy: Infiltrating lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade II (of III), forming a 2.8 x 2.0 x 1.2 cm mass, located in the upper outer quadrant of the breast. Angiolymphatic invasion is present. All surgical resection margins are negative for tumor. Lymph node, right axillary, sentinel biopsy: One axillary sentinel lymph node is positive for metastatic carcinoma, the largest measuring 2.0 cm. Extranodal extension is present. Breast, left, mastectomy: Infiltrating lobular carcinoma, Nottingham grade II (of III), and lobular carcinoma in situ, forming a 4.1 x 3.8 x 2.4 cm mass located in the upper subareolar aspect of the breast. Angiolymphatic invasion is absent. All surgical resection margins are negative for tumor.
