Lymph node, left axillary, sentinel biopsy: One axillary sentinel lymph node is negative for metastatic carcinoma. Lymph node, left axillary #2, sentinel biopsy: One axillary sentinel lymph node is negative for metastatic carcinoma. Lymph nodes, right axillary, dissection: Multiple (14) axillary lymph nodes are negative for metastatic carcinoma.

The pathology report includes four parts. Part 1 reports a benign portion of bone in the excised 9th rib on the left side. Part 2 describes a high-grade pleomorphic malignant tumor with extensive sarcomatoid differentiation, favoring sarcomatoid renal cell carcinoma, that arises from a focus of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma. There is extensive necrosis, invasion of perinephric adipose tissue, omentum, and colon, as well as angiolymphatic invasion. One colon resection margin is positive for neoplasm, while the rest are free of neoplasm. Sarcomatoid tumor is present in the soft tissue surrounding the vascular margin. Chronic interstitial inflammation is seen in the non-neoplastic kidney. The TNM stage is PT4 NX M1. Part 3 reports metastatic renal cell carcinoma with extensive sarcomatoid differentiation in the spleen that invades the splenic capsule and focally invades the underlying parenchyma. There is no perineural or angiolymphatic invasion, and the resection margins are free of neoplasm. Part 4 describes adpose tissue with metastatic renal cell carcinoma with extensive sarcomatoid differentiation and angiolymphatic invasion. There is no pancreatic tissue identified, and the neoplasm extends to the resection margins with no evidence of neoplasia in 4 lymph nodes.

Final diagnosis: Right laparoscopic nephrectomy - clear cell renal cell carcinoma, Fuhrman grade 4 of 4 with areas of spindle cell differentiation, 13.2 cm in largest diameter. Carcinoma invades into, but not through the renal capsule. All surgical resection margins are free of carcinoma. Adrenal gland present with no neoplasia seen. pTNM stage (5th edition) = pT2, NX, MX. Non-gyn cytology diagnosis: No malignant cells seen.

Left kidney and adrenal gland removed with a clear cell variant of renal cell carcinoma found in the lower pole of the kidney with focal microscopic invasion of the peripelvic fat. Vascular and lymphatic invasion present, but renal vein margins and adrenal gland were free of tumor. Stage T3NIMX. No tumor found in the inferior aortic node, but a lymph node excision showed metastatic renal cell carcinoma.

Specimen: Right kidney. Clinical notes: Right renal mass. Gross description: A 12.0 X 6.5 X 5.5 cm. kidney with a centrally located 5.8 X 3.5 X 3.5 cm. tan gold-red tumor mass. Microscopic description: Clear cell renal cortical carcinoma, pT1b, grade 2. Margins of resection negative for tumor. No lymph node involvement or adrenal gland presence. Vascular invasion negative. Non-neoplastic kidney with rare intratubular calcification.

The pathology report concerns a kidney sample labeled as a primary tumor, specifically renal cell carcinoma. The specimen was frozen and contained tissue in a cryomold weighing 260 mg, as well as 4 ml of frozen normal blood in a tube. The report provides no data on prior treatment, histological type, TNM stage, grade, or hormonal therapy. The only available information is that the tumor was cellular and composed of 80% tumor cells.

Diagnosis: Renal Cancer. Anatomical site: Kidney - Primary Tumor. Specimen: Frozen tissue in cryomold, 280 mg, right side of kidney. Blood specimen: Frozen tube, 4 ml. Histological type: Renal cell carcinoma. TNM staging, grading, and hormone therapy information not available. Cellular tumor percentage: 90.

A 173g uterus with a 7x6x1.9cm friable white mass involving both anterior and posterior walls and filling the endometrial cavity is identified. The tumor approaches but does not invade the lower uterine segment and cervix, and the serosal surface is unremarkable. The tumor is identified as an endometrioid adenocarcinoma with a FIGO grade of 1 and 1cm maximum depth of myometrial invasion in a 2.2cm thick wall. No lymphatic/vascular invasion is identified. No tumor is seen in the right and left ovaries and fallopian tubes. Thirteen left pelvic lymph nodes and nine right pelvic lymph nodes are free of tumor.

The pathology report describes a hysterectomy, oophorectomy, and lymph node procedure performed on a patient with a malignant neoplasm of the corpus uteri. The report details the gross examination of the specimens, which include a uterus weighing 109 grams with a tumor in the posterior corpus measuring 4.5 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm and invading the myometrium to a depth of 1.0 cm. No lymphatic or vascular invasion is observed. Leiomyomas are present in the remaining myometrium, and no tumor involvement is found in the cervix, serosa, or specimen margins. The report also mentions lymph node specimens, which are free of tumor (0/2 in the right external iliac lymph nodes, 0/3 in the right obturator lymph nodes, 0/2 in the periaortic lymph nodes, 0/2 in the left external iliac lymph nodes, and 0/4 in the left obturator lymph nodes). The histologic type of the tumor is endometrioid adenocarcinoma, with a FIGO grade of 3. No pathologic diagnosis is given for the ovaries, fallopian tubes, or mesothelium and soft tissue adjacent to the left ovary, except for mesothelial hyperplasia. The report emphasizes that pathology stage should not be substituted for clinical stage and notes that the exact operative procedure is available in the surgeon's operative report.

Clinical history: A woman with a right subareolar breast mass for three months. Right breast carcinoma. Gross examination: A "Right breast mass-wide local excision" in formalin. A portion of the breast tissue with a skin ellipse and nipple was obtained. Directly beneath the skin ellipse is a sharply circumscribed 2.5 x 2 x 1.5 cm mass composed of tan firm and friable tissue with focal areas of hemorrhage. Microscopic examination: Large portions of the tumor consist of well-formed papillary tumor with fibrovascular cores lined by malignant and complicated stratified epithelium. Cribriform and tubular foci infiltrate desmoplastic fibrous tissue. Diagnosis: Invasive papillary adenocarcinoma of breast (2.5 cm in greatest diameter). The margins of resection are free of tumor.

Summary: The specimen received is a single breast with a hard mass in the upper inner quadrant measuring approximately 6.5 x 7 x 2.5 cm, and a smaller firm area measuring approximately 2 x 3 x 2 cm in the lower outer quadrant. Upon cross-sectioning, the larger mass is firm, tan-white with multiple areas of hemorrhage. Both the upper outer and lower outer quadrants contain abundant breast parenchyma. The axillary tail received weighs 79 grams and contains five mobile, hard nodules. The diagnosis is invasive ductal carcinoma, type probably ductal, with a histologic grade of 2 and nuclear grade of 3, measuring 7.0 cm in greatest dimension. 19 regional lymph nodes were examined and found negative for cancer, and all final surgical margins were negative for cancer.

The pathology report describes a biopsy of a 3.5 cm breast self-detected lesion that was diagnosed as infiltrating ductal carcinoma, NSABP histologic grade 2 of 3, moderately differentiated with vascular invasion identified. The mastectomy specimen with axillary tail showed no residual carcinoma, rather it had benign proliferative changes including epithelial hyperplasia of usual type and blunt duct adenosine with recent biopsy cavity and no evidence of malignancy. Skin and nipple showed no histologic abnormality. Axillary lymph nodes had metastatic carcinoma in 4 of 7 nodes with extracapsular spread present with the largest lymph node being 2.1 cm. Representative sections of the tumor, biopsy cavity, breast and lymph node candidates were submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report describes a modified radical mastectomy specimen from a patient with infiltrating ductal carcinoma in the right breast. The tumor is tubulolobular subtype, with a histologic grade of 1-2 of 3 and a nuclear grade of 1-2 of 3. The tumor size is 3 cm, located in the upper outer quadrant and has lymphatic/vascular invasion. The surgical margin status is negative, with no Paget's disease in the nipple or malignancy in the skin. Eleven of the 21 lymph nodes examined are positive for carcinoma, with extracapsular extension present in 4 of them. The largest involved lymph node measures 1.6 cm. The status of non-neoplastic breast tissue shows intraductal hyperplasia, microcyst formation, apocrine metaplasia, and sclerosing adenosis. Estrogen/progesterone and cell cycle analysis are still pending.

A 10.5 x 7.7 x 4.0 cm excisional breast biopsy was taken from the right breast mass situated at the 9:00 position, and a fibroadipose tissue was sectioned and submitted entirely in blocks C1-C25. The sentinel node #1 exhibited metastatic carcinoma of 0.8 cm in size, negative for extracapsular extension, while sentinel node #2 was negative for malignancy. The right breast mass was diagnosed as invasive ductal adenocarcinoma of grade 3 of 3, measuring 2.0 x 1.8 x 1.0 cm with lymphatic/vascular invasion. In-situ carcinoma was present, nuclear grade 3 of 3, with necrosis, while the non-neoplastic breast tissue had minute fibroadenoma with apocrine metaplasia. Microcalcifications were present in association with the in-situ carcinoma, and the anterior margin was close to the tumor within 0.2 cm, grossly. The excised anterior inferior margin was negative for malignancy. Further supplementary tests were conducted but not included in the report.

The pathology report describes an excisional biopsy of a right breast lump, revealing infiltrating ductal carcinoma with a nuclear and histologic grade of 3 of 3. The gross tumor size is 2.4 x 2.4 x 1.5 cm, with the invasive component measuring 2 x 1.5 cm. There is no evidence of lymphatic or vascular invasion, and there is no multifocal tumor. In-situ carcinoma is present, occupying less than 5% of the tumor and consisting of comedo and cribriform types. The biopsy is 6.8 x 5.2 x 3.4 cm in size, and the surgical margin status is negative; however, there is a large area of ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) adjacent to the tumor. The report also includes re-excision results showing no evidence of malignancy in breast tissue from new margins, and metastatic adenocarcinoma in two of fourteen axillary lymph nodes with no extracapsular extension. The estrogen and progesterone receptors were found to be negative. An immunostain for HER2/neu showed moderate membrane staining in 50-75% of the tumor cells, interpreted as positive for HER2/neu overexpression.

Diagnosis: Renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type with a focal tumor size of 5.4 cm, Fuhrman nuclear grade 2, and pT1b staging. The tumor is confined to the kidney without invasion into perirenal adipose tissue, Gerota's fascia, renal sinus, major veins or ureter. The surgical margins, including Gerota's fascia, renal vein and ureter, are negative. The adrenal gland and lymph nodes are not present. The rest of the right renal parenchyma appears normal with no additional masses, atrophy or scarring. Multiple sections of the tumor and normal tissue are submitted for special investigations.

Diagnosis: Left kidney partial nephrectomy due to clear cell renal cell carcinoma. Tumor size is 5.5 cm in diameter with unifocal tumor focality and no extra-capsular or vascular invasion. Tumor is graded 2 out of 4, according to the Fuhrman classification. No carcinoma is identified in the overlying fat biopsy. No other significant findings or lymph node involvement are identified. AJCC Stage: T1b pNx pMx. Gross Description: 6.5 x 5.4 x 3.6 cm partial nephrectomy specimen is observed with a 5.5 x 3.8 x 3.2 cm circumscribed cortical nodule with a solid, variegated dark red to orange/brown cut surface, expanding the capsule. The overlying perinephric fat appears intact and unremarkable. The tumor and black inked parenchymal and perinephric adipose tissue margins are negative. Light Microscopy: No further details provided.

The report describes a laparoscopic radical nephrectomy procedure on the patient's left kidney due to the presence of renal carcinoma. Two tumors were detected and examined. The first tumor, a conventional clear cell carcinoma with no sarcomatoid features, measured 7.5cm. The second tumor, a papillary renal cell carcinoma type 1 with no sarcomatoid features, measured 0.8cm. Histological assessment of surgical margins was negative, and no tumor was detected in one lymph node. There was evidence of arteriolonephrosclerosis in the non-neoplastic kidney tissue. The AJCC Staging was pT2a pNO for tumor 1 and pTla pNO for tumor 2. The report includes a gross description of the tumor size and location, extent of invasion, and surgical margins, as well as details of the tissue submitted for special investigations. The report concludes with a description of kidney tissue away from the mass and the absence of any significant findings.

Diagnosis: Left kidney and ureter removed due to renal cell carcinoma, papillary type 1, of size 7.9cm. No invasion of renal vein, ureteral wall, perirenal adipose tissue, or Gerota's fascia observed. Fuhrman nuclear grade 2. Non-neoplastic kidney had severe atrophy and cystic change. The ureter showed free-floating fragments of renal cell carcinoma without invasion of ureteral wall. AJCC staging: pT2a pNx. The tumor encompassed the entire kidney, causing it to appear necrotic, fleshy, and friable on cut surface. Multiple cysts with smooth linings were found at inferior pole of the kidney. No lymph nodes were identified. A representative tumor and representative normal renal parenchyma submitted for tissue procurement. All ureteral margin was included in the specimen.

Diagnosis: Kidney, left, partial nephrectomy. Histologic tumor type/subtype: Renal cell carcinoma, papillary type. Histologic grade: Fuhrman grade 2. Tumor size: 2.4 cm. Extent of tumor invasion: Capsular invasion and minimal perirenal adipose tissue present, negative for carcinoma. Histologic assessment of surgical margins: Tumor is 2 mm from black inked renal parenchymal margin. Lymph nodes: Not present. Other significant findings: Chronic inflammation and mild glomerulosclerosis. AJCC Staging: pT1a. Gross Description: Partial nephrectomy consisting of a 14.9 g, 4.5 x 3.5 x 2.5 cm partial nephrectomy with a well-demarcated pale tan soft mass measuring 2.4 x 2.3 x 2.0 cm, which is entirely submitted in blocks A1-A7.

The pathology report is for a patient with stage IV squamous cell carcinoma of the mouth. Biopsies from all margins, except for the anterior margin, were negative for carcinoma. The anterior margin biopsy showed mild dysplasia of squamous epithelium. The tumor was moderately differentiated and keratinizing. It extended to the ventral surface of the tongue and left floor of the mouth, invading a sublingual salivary gland and large muscle fibers of the oral tongue. No in situ component or angiolymphatic or perineural invasion was identified. All margins, except for the superior margin, were negative, and there was metastatic carcinoma in lymph nodes in the neck but without extranodal extension.

The pathology report describes biopsies and lymph node dissections from various locations in the mouth and neck of a patient with a squamous cell carcinoma. No dysplasia or invasive carcinoma was identified in most biopsy sites. However, invasive squamous carcinoma was identified in the floor of the mouth specimen, which was poorly differentiated with a size of 2.4 cm diameter and 0.7 cm depth. The report also indicates that the lymph nodes examined showed no metastatic carcinoma. The surgical margins were negative but close. No bone involvement was identified, and the tissue submitted for special investigations was none. The report concludes by stating that the frozen section diagnoses were confirmed by light microscopy.

Summarized report: The pathology report describes biopsies and removals of various tissues in a patient with right hard palate cancer. The diagnosis reveals invasive, well-differentiated, keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma involving the maxilla and effacing the hard palate. The tumor size is 3.2 cm, and there is no evidence of lymphovascular space invasion or perineural invasion. Margins of resection are negative for tumor, but some are close to the tumor. The lymph nodes show no metastatic carcinoma with benign lymphoid follicular hyperplasia. The sinuses contain mostly benign mucosa with mild to moderate chronic inflammation and edema. The report contains a detailed gross description of the specimens with block summaries. The frozen sections show no tumor in all biopsy specimens.

Diagnosis: A- Nerve, pharyngeal plexus, biopsy shows no malignancy identified. B, C, E, F and G - Lymph nodes show presence and size of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma, with some showing extracapsular extension. H- Total laryngectomy shows moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma involving bilateral supraglottis, bilateral false cords, bilateral aryepiglottic folds, and hyoid bone without vocal cord fixation or angiolymphatic invasion. Perineural invasion is present, and surgical margins are negative but very close (<1 mm) from blue-inked right margin. The tumor abuts but does not involve the bilateral strap muscles. P16 IHC status and HR HPV ISH status are pending. AJCC PATHOLOGIC TNM STAGE: pT4a pN2c pMx. In specimen G, bland appearing thyroid epithelium is present in the subcapsular sinus of two lymph nodes. No parenchymal involvement is identified, and no nuclear features of papillary thyroid carcinoma are identified. This may represent benign thyroid inclusions in lymph node - however, a metastatic carcinoma of thyroid origin cannot be excluded. Clinical evaluation and imaging of the thyroid gland is recommended.

Diagnosis: Invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in a right palate lesion biopsy. Clinical history: Patient presents with a palate mass. Gross Description: The received tissue measures 1.4 X 1.0 X 0.6 cm in aggregate composed of multiple pale tan soft tissue fragments. Addendum: P16 protein expression and high-risk HPV screening tests were performed and were negative.

The pathology report describes a sample of oral mucosa and a tooth extraction. The mucosal margins (superior, lateral, inferior, and medial) are negative for tumors. However, the left neck (modified dissection) shows metastatic carcinoma involvement in lymph nodes across levels I, II, III, and IV, with a total of four out of fifty-two lymph nodes affected. The left tonsil and soft palate excision show poorly differentiated, infiltrating squamous cell carcinoma (3 cm) extending to a depth of 3 cm with invasion of deep skeletal muscle. The surgical margins, except for the deep margin, are negative for tumors. Extensive angiolymphatic invasion is identified.

RG PATH REPORT COLLECTION DATE/TIME: FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. LEFT TONGUE, DEEP MARGIN (Bx): Skeletal muscle. Negative for tumor. 2-5. ANTERIOR MARGIN, POSTERIOR MARGIN, INFERIOR MARGIN, SUPERIOR MARGIN (Bxs): Negative for tumor. 5. LEFT TONGUE (HEMIGLOSSECTOMY): Infiltrating moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma (4.0 cm), extending to within 1 mm of the deep aspect of the medial margin. The remaining margins are negative for tumor. SPECIMEN TYPE: Resection - Partial glossectomy. TUMOR SITE: Oral tongue. TUMOR SIZE: Greatest dimension 4 cm. HISTOLOGIC TYPE: Squamous cell carcinoma, conventional. HISTOLOGIC GRADE: Moderately differentiated. EXTENT OF INVASION: PRIMARY TUMOR (pT): Tumor more than 2 cm but not more than 4 cm in greatest dimension. REGIONAL LYMPH NODES (pN): pN2b: Metastasis in multiple ipsilateral lymph nodes, none more than 6 cm in greatest dimension (see part 7). Specify: Number examined: 51 (see part 7). Number involved: 3. EXTRACAPSULAR EXTENSION OF NODAL TUMOR: Present (focal extranodal extension). DISTANT METASTASIS (pM): pMX: cannot be assessed. MARGINS: Margins uninvolved by tumor. Distance of tumor from closest margin 1 mm (deep aspect of medial margin). VENOUS/LYMPHATIC (LARGE/SMALL VESSEL) INVASION: Present. PERINEURAL INVASION: Absent. 7. SOFT TISSUE, LEFT NECK (NECK DISSECTION LEVEL 1-4) METASTATIC SQUAMOUS CELL CARCINOMA INVOLVING THREE (3) LYMPH NODES: LEVEL I: Submandibular gland with non-specific pathological changes. LEVEL II: Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in two (2) of twenty-two (22) lymph nodes. Unofficial lab results - do not file in patient chart. Contact medical records for official chart copy. LEVEL III: Metastatic squamous cell carcinoma involving one (1) of seventeen (17) lymph nodes. LEVEL IV: Twelve (12) lymph nodes, negative for tumor. NOTE: Focal extranodal extension into perinodal tumor is present. Unofficial lab results - do not file in patient chart. Contact medical records for official chart copy.

The pathology report indicates that multiple excisions and resection were negative for tumor in various areas including the anterior tongue mucosa, deep anterior, deep lateral pharyngeal, base of tongue mucosa, deep tonsil, and deep biopsy vallecula. However, the right base of the tongue resection revealed infiltrating HPV-related squamous cell carcinoma that has invaded up to a maximum depth of 1.3 cm and extends to the deep and lateral margins. The medial margin is also closely approached by the carcinoma.

The report describes a partial laryngectomy specimen with a 3.6 cm supraglottic squamous cell carcinoma tumor involving the left false cord, left supraglottis, left aryepiglottic fold, and laryngeal epiglottis with extension into the glottis. The tumor invades the mucosa of the region outside the supraglottis, involves bilateral lymph nodes, and is present in the soft tissue with adjacent vascular invasion. The anterior soft tissue margin, mucosal margins on the right side, left cricoid margin, interarytenoid margin, anterior tracheal margin, left arytenoid margin, and left pharyngeal margin are all negative for tumor. However, the report notes metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one lymph node in the right tracheal dissection at level 2 and one lymph node at level 3, with a focus of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in the soft tissue adjacent to an involved lymph node. The left neck dissection at levels 2 to 4 also shows metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one lymph node at level 2 and one lymph node at level 3 with a white mass consistent with metastatic disease.

Right tonsil mass (excision): HPV-related squamous cell carcinoma with strong p16 immunoreactivity and positive high-risk HPV by in situ hybridization. Gross description shows the specimen consists of two unoriented soft red-tan tissue pieces, with a cauterized resection margin inked black, measuring 3.1 x 1.1 x 0.6 cm in aggregate. No further details provided.

The pathology report describes the examination of various biopsies of the hypoglossal nerve, right soft tissue on vagus, right tonsil, right deep base of tongue, right and left base of tongue mucosa, deep base of tongue midline, left base of tongue, right neck level 1B, right and left neck dissections, left modified radical neck dissection levels 2-5, total laryngectomy and base of tongue, and right skull base retropharyngeal node. The report reveals metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in several lymph nodes, and invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left base of tongue and base of tongue. The tumor is present in the larynx and has invaded the vocal cords and false vocal cords, and there is extranodal extension. The thyroid cartilage is not invaded. The report includes details of the size and location of the tumor, lymph nodes involvement, and margin status.

The report describes a left liver lobe resection in a patient with a history of hepatocellular carcinoma. The gross descriptions mention a well-circumscribed tumor mass with necrotic and hemorrhagic regions, measuring 8.0 cm in greatest dimension, protruding from the surface and with no other masses identified. Light microscopy shows a well-differentiated, predominantly trabecular pattern with focal pseudo-acinar structures and areas of tumor necrosis and hemorrhage. There is lymphovascular space invasion in the capsule, and the adjacent liver tissue has no significant fibrosis or steatosis. The diagnosis is hepatocellular carcinoma, well-differentiated, with surgical margins clear.

The report describes a liver resection from a female patient with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in the right lobe, which involved a large 7.5 cm diameter mass with multifocal clustering, moderate differentiation, and coagulative necrosis. Capsular disruption is observed in three foci (two superior and one inferior). The tumor is confined by the capsular surface, and there is no vascular invasion. Surgical margins are focally positive in superior gross capsular disruption but otherwise negative. The non-neoplastic parenchyma of the liver has mild portal chronic inflammation without significant fibrosis. The liver segment 2 and segment 3 margins, as well as the diaphragm, show no sign of carcinoma, and the gallbladder is not histologically abnormal. The report confirms the diagnosis of HCC with trabecular architecture, plate expansion, and nuclear pleomorphism. Furthermore, rare mitotic figures and apoptotic nuclei are present, and the liver does not appear cirrhotic. Overall, the report suggests the presence of a moderately differentiated HCC with multifocal clustering in a female patient with an extensive liver resection.

Filtered pathology report: Melanoma in skin tissue from left lower thigh region, surgically resected. Microscopically, mixed epitheloid and spindle cell melanoma with grade 3, Clark II-III, and Breslow 0.79mm. Tumor content 80%, with 5% stroma present. Final diagnosis: Mixed epitheloid and spindle cell melanoma.

Male. Clinical diagnosis: Melanoma. Gross description: Skin from right hand, pigmented, surgical resection. Microscopic description: Mushroom shaped epiteliod melanoma with ulceration, Clark-IV, Breslow - 11 mm, Stage IIC, T4, NO, M0. Final diagnosis: Epiteliod Melanoma.

The pathology report is for a patient who underwent a total abdominal hysterectomy, bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy, and omental biopsy due to endometrial cancer. The report indicates that the endometrial tumor is limited to the endometrium and likely arose within an endometrial polyp. The tumor is a mixed carcinoma with endometrioid comprising approximately 90% and clear cell roughly 10%. The histologic grade is poorly differentiated (FIGO 3), with a maximum dimension of 25 mm and 25% surface involvement of the endometrial cavity. No lymphovascular space invasion is identified, and all adnexa are unremarkable. The report mentions benign fibroadipose tissue in the omentum and infarcted appendices epiploica with calcification in the abdominal wall nodule. The report suggests that the patient's FIGO stage is at least IA, though no lymph node dissection was performed. No outside tissue diagnosis, prior malignancy, or chemoradiation therapy information is provided.

Diagnosis: Invasive ductal carcinoma, Nottingham grade 3 (tubule formation 3, nuclear pleomorphism 3, mitotic activity 3, total score 9/9) measuring 2.2 cm with extensive involvement of the nipple papillary dermis under the basal layer. Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), nuclear grade 2, solid type, constitutes 2% of total tumor mass. All resection margins are negative for carcinoma, invasive carcinoma is 1.1cm to the closest margin. Six out of ten axillary lymph nodes are positive for metastatic carcinoma with multiple areas of extracapsular extension. No definitive lymphovascular invasion noted. Fibrocystic changes are present. T-stage, pathologic: pT2. N-stage, pathologic: pN2a. Estrogen receptors and progesterone receptors are positive. HER2/NEU: 2+.

Final diagnosis: A moderately differentiated, invasive ductal carcinoma measuring 2.5 cm is present in the left breast, with no lymphovascular invasion identified. In situ ductal carcinoma (solid and cribiform subtypes, nuclear grade 2) is also present and occupies 25% of the total tumor volume. Carcinoma is not identified in the excised lateral margin; however, one out of two biopsied sentinel lymph nodes shows a one cm metastatic focus with extracapsular extension. The tumor is estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor positive, with HER-2/NEU negative. Surgical margins are free of any in situ or invasive carcinoma, with the closest margin 1 mm away from the tumor. No calcifications or Pagets disease of the nipple is present. Non-neoplastic breast tissue shows fibrocystic changes, ductal epithelial hyperplasia, sclerosing adenosis, and columnar cell change. The pathologic stage is pT2 and pN1a.

The pathology report describes a segmental mastectomy of a breast with invasive ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in-situ present. No lymphovascular invasion or metastasis is identified and surgical margins are negative for invasive carcinoma. The tumor is positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors and negative for HER-2. Two lymph nodes are examined with no tumor identified, and the tumor measures 2.5 cm in the largest dimension. Nottingham score is 2, indicating the tumor has moderate differentiation. Intraductal papilloma with ductal epithelial hyperplasia is also present. The T stage is pT2 and N stage is pNo. M stage is unreported.

Final Diagnosis: Left breast, segmental mastectomy - Invasive ductal carcinoma (tubules 3, nuclei 3, mitosis 2) measuring 2.6 cm, ductal carcinoma in situ with micropapillary and solid types with comedo necrosis, nuclear grade 3, representing 5% of the tumor volume. Lymphovascular space involvement seen. One lymph node positive for metastatic carcinoma (0.9 cm), two lymph nodes were examined in total with one having rare clusters of metastatic tumor cells, and one with extensive thermal effect. Margins were free of the lesion. Proliferative fibrocystic changes with atypical ductal epithelial hyperplasia and columnar cell changes, microscopic peripheral papilloma and sclerosing adenosis were observed. The tumor was ER and PR positive, with a pT2 pathologic stage, and a pN1a pathologic stage.

The pathology report is of left breast segmental mastectomy sample. It indicates the presence of invasive ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with cribriform type and comedo necrosis. The tumor is Nottingham grade 2 with a total score of 6/9. Additionally, lymphovascular space invasion is observed. The surgical margins are negative for carcinoma. One out of four lymph nodes examined is positive for metastatic carcinoma with the largest tumor deposit being 2.1mm, and no extracapsular extension is visible. The tumor cells are positive for estrogen and progesterone receptors, but negative for HER-2/neu by FISH. The not involved breast tissue features include fibrocystic changes, columnar cell change, and ductal epithelial hyperplasia. The pathological stage is pT1c, pN1a, pMX.

A segmental mastectomy and sentinel node biopsy were performed on the patient's right breast due to a chief complaint and diagnosis of right breast cancer. The biopsy found invasive ductal carcinoma at 8 o'clock measuring 2.7 cm with a Nottingham grade of 3, but no lymphovascular space invasion was identified, and all margins were negative for neoplasm except for the tumor's closest margin that approached 9 mm. The lymph node examined was negative for neoplasm. The left breast tissue was also examined and found sclerosing adenosis, columnar cell change, and fibrocystic changes. The pathology report revealed a primary invasive carcinoma of the breast in the right breast with a maximum dimension of 27 mm and positive estrogen and progesterone receptors but negative HER2/neu.

Summary: The patient underwent a left total mastectomy and axillary dissection due to a diagnosis of infiltrating poorly differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma of the left breast, measuring 3.0 by 2.5 by 0.7cm, located in the lower outer and lower inner quadrant. Two out of twenty-five lymph nodes from the left axillary contents showed metastatic poorly differentiated ductal carcinoma. The tumor is weakly positive for HER-2/neu (score 2+). ER/PR will be performed separately, and a report will follow. The margins, nipple, and skin are free of tumor. The breast tissue also shows proliferative fibrocystic changes with duct ectasia, radial scar, and sclerosing adenosis. The immunoperoxidase test for hormone receptor proteins and the Her-2/neu FISH test were performed using FDA approved methods.

Final diagnosis: Right segmental mastectomy reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma with intermediate histologic and nuclear grade, Nottingham score of 5, retrograde extension into lobules, lymphocytic infiltration, microcalcifications, proliferative fibrocystic changes, intraductal papilloma, and sclerosing adenosis. Margins are free. ER/PR immunoperoxidase identification shows distinct intranuclear staining for estrogen receptor (95%) and progesterone receptor (95%), both interpreted as positive. HER-2/NEU immunostaining shows no distinct complete membrane staining and is interpreted as negative (score 0).

The patient underwent left total mastectomy and left axillary sampling due to a left breast cancer diagnosis. Two foci of invasive ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated, multifocal in the upper outer quadrant were found, with sizes of 2.0x2.0x2.0cm and 1.5x1.5x1.0cm. Nottingham score was 8. Surgical margins were free of tumor. One lymph node was positive for metastatic carcinoma. ER/PR and Her-2/NEU testing will be performed. ER/PR results were borderline for progesterone receptor and negative for estrogen receptor. Her-2/NEU results were negative.

Final Diagnosis: The patient underwent a right (mod) radical mastectomy due to infiltrating duct carcinoma, extensive ductal carcinoma in situ (comprising >25% of the tumor), angiolymphatic invasion, tumor-associated microcalcifications, skin or nipple and areola involvement by the tumor, and fibrocystic changes. Eight out of ten lymph nodes were positive for tumor with extracapsular extension in five nodes. ER/PR immunoperoxidase assay was performed and only estrogen receptor (ER) was identified with 50% intranuclear staining. Progesterone receptor (PR) was not identified. ER is interpreted as positive and PR as negative.

The pathology report describes a case of papillary thyroid carcinoma, tall cell variant, with metastasis in lymph nodes, extranodal spread, and venous invasion. Mutational analysis identified BRAF V600E mutation, while mutations in NRAS61, HRAS61, KRAS12/13 were not found, and the FISH test results were negative for RET/PTC rearrangement. The tumor extended to the margin, measured 2.4 cm, and showed extrathyroidal extension. No parathyroid glands were seen. The report also mentions nodular goiter, and FISH analysis for MAML2 is being performed to rule out primary mucoepidermoid carcinoma of the thyroid. The report includes synoptic data on the tumor, including size, site, foci, stage, and margins involved. The RET/PTC probe analysis showed that the targeted area is not rearranged for the RET/PTC region.

The pathology report pertains to a patient who underwent a total thyroidectomy due to papillary thyroid cancer. The report confirms the presence of two foci of papillary thyroid carcinoma (measuring 1.3 cm and 0.1 cm) in the right and left lobes respectively, along with metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in two out of three lymph nodes. No extrathyroidal extension or extranodal spread was identified. The report also notes the presence of chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. The distance of invasive carcinoma to the closest margin was 1 mm. Additional molecular analysis was not possible due to decalcification. No details are provided regarding the patient's medical history or prior malignancy.

Summary: The report describes a case where a total thyroidectomy was performed on a patient with a thyroid nodule. Pathological examination of the tissue showed papillary carcinoma in the right lobe, confined with angiolymphatic invasion, and a follicular adenoma with oncocytic change in the left lobe. The patient also had nodular thyroid hyperplasia and mild chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. The tumor was staged as pT1bNx and there was no identified extranodal or extrathyroidal extension. Margins were uninvolved by carcinoma, and lymph-vascular invasion was not identified. No information was provided regarding the patient's history, procedure, or prior malignancies, chemoradiation, organ transplant, immunosuppression, or other diseases.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in a patient who underwent a total thyroidectomy. The tumor is present in both the left lobe and the isthmus, with the largest nodule measuring 1.5 cm. An additional focus of carcinoma is confined to the left lobe. Vascular invasion and extracapsular spread are absent, but there is minimal extrathyroidal extension, and the carcinoma is about 0.1 cm from the margin. In addition, chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis is present. The pathology stage is pT3N1a. The report also notes the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in six of fourteen central compartment lymph nodes examined, without extranodal extension. A trichilemmal cyst measuring 1 cm is present in the left abdominal wall, and a biopsy of the right inferior parathyroid gland reveals normocellular parathyroid tissue. The report includes synoptic data which confirms the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, the tumor site, size, and foci, as well as lymph node involvement, extrathyroidal extension, and margins. Lymph-vascular invasion is not identified, and distant metastasis is not applicable. Further, the report mentions the prior molecular testing which showed a BRAF p.V600E mutation in the right isthmus thyroid fine needle aspirated.

Summary: The patient has been diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, nuclear grade II/IV, with an acinar pattern of growth. The tumor has a diameter of 3.7 cm and is completely enclosed by the renal capsule. All surgical margins are free of tumor except for 1.0 mm of the renal parenchymal margin. The non-neoplastic kidney shows chronic pyelonephritis, nephrosclerosis, and papillary adenoma. The left peri-nephric fat tissue excision is benign adipose tissue. The intraoperative frozen section diagnosis was renal cell carcinoma within 1.0 mm of the margin marked with a stitch.

The report describes a case of metastatic renal cell carcinoma in a patient with a left renal mass. A radical nephrectomy was performed, and the left kidney and adrenal gland were submitted for analysis. The tumor was identified as a conventional (clear cell) type with extensive necrosis and a nuclear grade of IV/IV. The largest diameter of the tumor measured 13.0 cm, with local invasion through the renal capsule but confined within Gerota's fascia and involvement of the renal hilar fat. No renal vein invasion was identified, but the tumor invaded muscular veins in the renal sinus. Non-neoplastic kidney tissue showed mild arteriosclerotic changes and benign cortical cysts, while the adrenal gland was not involved. No lymph nodes were identified. The tumor was staged as pT3b, with gross extension into the renal vein(s) or vena cava below the diaphragm. The gross description of the kidney revealed an ill-defined yellow-orange mass that distorted the kidney cortex without invading the perinephric adipose tissue, and areas of fibrosis, mucinous degeneration, necrosis, and hemorrhage were identified. No gross invasion into the sinus was identified, but gross extension into the hilar fat could not be assessed. Representative sections of the kidney, adrenal gland, and surrounding tissue were submitted for analysis, and a summary of the sections is provided.

Clinical Diagnosis: Right renal mass incidentally found. Specimens Submitted: 1. Right kidney; nephrectomy. 2. Lymph nodes, paracaval; excision. Diagnosis: 1. Right kidney; nephrectomy: - Tumor Type: Renal cell carcinoma - Conventional (clear cell) type. - Fuhrman Nuclear Grade: Nuclear grade II/IV. - Tumor Size: Greatest diameter is 1.5 cm. - Local Invasion (for renal cortical types): Not Identified. - Renal Vein invasion: Not identified. - Surgical Margins: Free of tumor. - Non-Neoplastic Kidney: Marked glomerulosclerosis and chronic pyelonephritis. 2. Lymph nodes, paracaval; excision: - Lymph Nodes: Not involved. - Number of nodes examined: 2. Staging for renal cell carcinomaloncocytoma: pT1 Tumor <= 7.0 cm In greatest dimension limited to the kidney. Comment: The tumor has clear cell-papillary features, as described in kidneys with impaired renal function. Special Studies: Special Stain. Gross Description: 1. The specimen consists of a kidney with attached ureter, renal vessels, and perinephric fat weighing 150 g in total. The kidney measures 8 x 5 x 3.5 cm. No adrenal gland is identified. The kidney is inked black and bivalved to reveal a well-circumscribed tan nodule in the upper pole, measuring 1.5 x 1.3 cm on cross-section. The tumor replaces the renal cortex, reaches but does not penetrate to the renal capsule and pelvis. 2. The specimen consists of multiple pieces of fibroadipose tissue measuring 3.8 x 3.3 x 1.8 cm in aggregate. Within this tissue, two lymph nodes are identified measuring 1.3 and 0.6 cm in greatest dimension. Summary of sections: 1. SP: Right kidney; nephrectomy - F. 1: Fat; LK. 1-5: Lower pole kidney; T. 5-1: Tumor; UK: Upper pole kidney; UVM: Ureteral and vessel margins. 2. SP: Lymph nodes, paracaval; excision - LN. 1.

Patient has a 5 cm right renal mass that was incidentally detected. The tumor is a conventional (clear cell) type renal cell carcinoma with areas of geographic necrosis and Fuhrman Nuclear Grade III/IV. The tumor has extended through the renal capsule but is confined within Gerota's fascia. No venous invasion was identified. Non-neoplastic kidney showed cortical scar and mild arteriosclerosis. No adrenal gland or lymph nodes were identified. The tumor extends into major veins or invades the adrenal gland or parinephric tissues, but not beyond Gerota's fascia, staging it as pT3 for renal cell carcinoma/oncocytoma. The gross description records a 254 g, 16 x 14 X 5 cm wedge-shaped portion of kidney and parinephric adipose tissue with a suture marking the deep margin. The tumor itself measures 4.8 cm in greatest diameter and has a soft, yellow cut surface with areas of hemorrhage and necrosis. The report provides a frozen section diagnosis of Renal cortical neoplasm within 1mm of the inked margin.

Diagnosis: Kidney, right renal tumor - conventional (clear cell) type renal cell carcinoma with Fuhrman nuclear grade III/IV and greatest diameter of 4.0 cm. No local invasion or renal vein invasion identified. Surgical margins free of tumor. Non-neoplastic kidney unremarkable. Adrenal gland and lymph nodes not identified. Stage: pT1 tumor limited to the kidney with size <= 7.0 cm. Gross Description: The specimen consists of a wedge-shaped portion of kidney (4.6 x 3.7 x 3.0 cm) with a tan yellow hemorrhagic mass (4.0 x 3.5 x 3.5 cm) that is 0.1 cm clearance from the resection margin. Frozen section and permanent diagnosis indicate renal cortical epithelial neoplasm with sutured margin free.

The patient had a left renal tumor which was partially removed via nephrectomy. The tumor was identified as a renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear cell) type, with a nuclear grade of III/IV and a greatest diameter of 2.5 cm. Local and renal vein invasion were not identified, and surgical margins were free of the tumor. The non-neoplastic kidney was unremarkable, and no adrenal gland or lymph node was identified. The staging for this carcinoma/oncocytoma was pT1Tumor <= 7.0 cm in greatest dimension limited to the kidney. The gross description shows a single, well-circumscribed mass with bulging homogeneous tan lobulated cut surfaces interrupted by fibrous bands. A representative section of the nearest margin was submitted for frozen section diagnosis, and a portion of the tumor was submitted for TPS. The intraoperative consultation revealed a cortical renal neoplasm on the representative section with an inked margin negative, which was confirmed as the permanent diagnosis.

A female patient with a history of ocular melanoma presented with a left renal mass, which was partially removed surgically. The pathology report indicates that the tumor is of the conventional (clear cell) type of renal cell carcinoma with a nuclear grade of II/IV. The tumor size is 3.5 cm in diameter, and there's no local invasion or renal vein invasion. The surgical margins are free of the tumor, and the non-neoplastic kidney is unremarkable. Adrenal gland and lymph nodes were not identified. The staging of renal cell carcinoma/oncocytoma identified the tumor as pT1. The gross description of the specimen reveals a cystic mass with a small yellow solid component measuring overall 0.5 X 3.5 X 3.0 cm. A representative section of the nearest margin was submitted for frozen section diagnosis, which indicated that the margin is close but clear. The final diagnosis confirms the frozen section diagnosis of "renal cortical epithelial tumor."

Diagnosis: Left kidney - partial nephrectomy for conventional renal cell carcinoma (clear cell), Fuhrman nuclear grade II/IV, tumor size 2.8 cm, no local or renal vein invasion, surgical margins free of tumor, non-neoplastic kidney with patchy chronic inflammation. The renal tissue was entirely submitted, and a representative section of perinephric fat was included in the analysis. Intraoperative examination confirmed a negative surgical margin, favoring renal cell carcinoma. Permanent diagnosis remained the same.

A left renal cell carcinoma, papillary type with extensive oncocytic cytologic features was identified in a left nephrectomy specimen. The tumor measures approximately 13.0 cm and appears to be confined within Gerota's fascia. No tumor was found in the spleen. The left and right fallopian tube and ovary specimens had unremarkable ovaries and fallopian tubes with paratubal cysts. Special stains were used for frozen section diagnosis, and representative sections were submitted for frozen and permanent sections. The intraoperative consultation showed a renal cortical carcinoma, a paratubal cyst, and a benign diagnosis.

The pathology report relates to a patient who underwent a partial nephrectomy due to a renal tumor in the right lower pole kidney. The tumor was identified as a high-grade renal cell carcinoma of the papillary type, with a diameter of 3.1cm and displayed no signs of local invasion or vascular invasion. The surgical margins were free of tumors, and no neoplastic activity was observed in the non-neoplastic kidney, adrenal gland, or lymph nodes. The specimens submitted include the kidney tumor and deep margin. The report includes frozen section diagnosis results and permanent diagnosis, which confirmed that the deep margin is free of tumor. No further details regarding treatment plan and the patient's clinical background are provided.

A left renal mass was diagnosed through partial nephrectomy. The left upper pole of the kidney showed renal cell carcinoma of the papillary type, with nuclear grade III/IV and papillary growth pattern, confined to the renal capsule, with a greatest diameter of 4.0 cm, and no evidence of malignancy in the non-neoplastic kidney, mid-pole, posterolateral mid-pole, anterior lower pole, or lateral aspect of lower pole. The tumor was at least 0.9 cm away from the surgical margin of resection. Sections were taken of the tumor, kidney parenchyma, perinephric fat, and surrounding tissue for frozen section control.

The pathology report is for a patient with a right upper kidney pole solid mass. Two specimens were submitted for analysis. The first (SP: Kidney, right; partial nephrectomy (fs)) revealed the presence of renal cell carcinoma, Papillary type 2, with a maximum diameter of 3.4 cm, but no local invasion or renal vein invasion. The surgical margins were free of tumor, and there were some focal compression-related changes in non-neoplastic kidney tissue. The second specimen (SP: Right kidney, deep surgical margin; excision) showed benign, unremarkable renal parenchyma. Intraoperative consultation confirmed the absence of tumor in the designated area of the right renal tumor. The staging for renal cell carcinoma is pT1, with a tumor size of less than or equal to 7.0 cm in greatest dimension and limited to the kidney.

Left renal mass confirmed as papillary type renal cell carcinoma (Type II) of high histological grade. Tumor size is 4.7 cm and extends through the renal capsule but confined within the Gerota's fascia without renal vein invasion. Surgical margins are free of tumor. Focal glomerulosclerosis and vascular changes are observed in the non-neoplastic kidney, with no involvement of lymph nodes or adrenal gland. A portion of benign congested spleen adherent to kidney is not involved by tumor. The tumor stage is pT1, and representative sections are submitted for TPS and permanent sections. No special studies are performed.

The specimen is a gastrectomy of a 6 x 6 x 1 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma with poorly differentiated histologic grade. Adjacent structures (specifically, greater omentum) are involved, and 3/7 intraabdominal lymph nodes are positive for metastasis. However, margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or other pathologic findings. Lymphatic, venous, and perineural invasions are not specified. No comments are provided.

Specimen type: Gastrectomy. Tumor site: Stomach. Tumor size: 6 X 6 X 1.5 cm. Histologic type: Adenocarcinoma. Histologic grade: Moderately differentiated. Adjacent structures (specifically, Lesser omentum) and 1 out of 4 intraabdominal lymph nodes were found to be positive for metastasis. No other invasion or margin details were specified. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings were observed.

A 6.5 cm ulcerated adenocarcinoma of the stomach with perigastric fat invasion and whole wall invasion was observed in a stomach segment while conducting a subtotal gastrectomy. There was evidence of metastasis to two lymph nodes (greater and lesser omentum). Venous invasion was not observed, but perigastric fat invasion was present. Margins were uninvolved. No neo-adjuvant treatment was observed. No other pathologic findings were noted. No comments were made.

A polypoid adenocarcinoma was found in the stomach with an exophytic component up to 16 cm in diameter and G2-3 in grade. The tumor invaded adjacent perigastric fatty tissue but did not invade margins or lymph nodes. The predominant type of growth was exophytic, with the subserosa being affected. Surgical margins were free of tumor elements and 0/15 lymph nodes had metastases. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment was found. The tumor is poorly differentiated with G3 presence and necrosis in the endophytic component. Laterality was not specified.

The report describes a gastrectomy specimen from the antrum region of the stomach. The tumor features an ulcerated, annular appearance and is diagnosed as a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with adjacent lesser omentum involvement and 14/14 intraabdominal lymph nodes positive for metastasis. There is no information provided regarding lymphatic, venous, or perineural invasion. Margins appear uninvolved and there is no evidence of previous neo-adjuvant treatment. No additional pathologic findings are mentioned.

In pre-pylorus, the mucosa is ulcerated and necrotic, and a 4x3x1cm poorly-differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma is invading into the serosa. The tumor is composed of tubules or small groups of infiltrating serosa. The glands are variable in size and shape, firm, and have moderately stratified tumor cells with an enlarged and prominent nuclei, irregularly hyperchromatic. Lymph nodes are positive for metastasis (3/5). The tumor has lymphatic invasion, is located in the antrum, and is ulcerated. The histologic type is tubular adenocarcinoma, and the histologic grade is poorly differentiated. There is an invasion of lymphocytes in the stroma. No additional pathologic findings or other comments are given.

The report describes a case of adenocarcinoma, signet ring type, with poorly differentiated histological grade. The tumor is located in the stomach antrum, measuring 5 x 3 x 1.5 cm, and is ulcerated and invading the muscle layer of the gastric wall. The tumor cells exhibit hyperchromatic nuclei with prominent nucleoli, and some contain mucin vacuoles, causing displacement of the nucleus. There is also invasion of lymphocytes in the fibrous stroma surrounding the tumor. Metastasis is noted in all 11 regional lymph nodes examined. No other pathological findings or treatments are mentioned.

The patient had bladder cancer and underwent a cystectomy. The final diagnosis shows urothelial carcinoma, invasive, high-grade with micropapillary features and extensive involvement of perivesicular adipose tissue. Focal carcinoma in-situ of both ureters is also present, but ureteric resection margins are free of malignancy. The urethral margin is free of in-situ or invasive malignancy. There is metastatic urothelial carcinoma in one of two lymph nodes examined in the right pelvic excision and six of seven lymph nodes in the left pelvic excision. The tumor infiltrated between smooth muscle bundles rather than the vaginal wall, and there is venous-lymphatic invasion with perivesical adipose tissue involvement. The pathologic stage is PTNM Mx. Incidental benign leiomyoma in perivesicle adipose tissue and minor urothelial atypia is also present.

The report describes a case of a male patient with high-grade urothelial carcinoma, who underwent radical cystoprostatectomy with the construction of orthotopic neobladder due to bladder cancer. The report states that the lymph nodes excised were benign and negative for malignancy. The right and left ureteral margins were also reported as benign and negative for neoplasia, respectively. The urinary bladder and distal ureters, bilateral ureters, prostate, bilateral seminal vesicles, and vas deferentia specimen showed an ulcerated, invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with a maximal tumor diameter of 2.1cm and rare perineural invasion. Metastatic urothelial carcinoma was identified in one perivesical lymph node within the specimen. The report also indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7, limited to the right lobe with focal perineural invasion. The report concludes that the specimen was surgically removed and no tumor invasion was found in the surgical margins, lymph nodes, and extraprostatic extension. TNM pathologic staging identified stage T3b, N1, MX for urothelial carcinoma and stage T2a, NO, MX for prostatic adenocarcinoma. The histologic grade for urothelial carcinoma was reported as G3, and for prostatic adenocarcinoma, it was G3-4.

The pathology report indicates a benign excision of nine lymph nodes in the right pelvic area and three in the left pelvic area. The ureter biopsies on both sides show benign urothelium and underlying submucosa with reactive changes. The prostate biopsy reveals focal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PIN) and benign prostatic hyperplasia. The radical cystoprostatectomy shows invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma that predominantly exhibits small cell features, with a 4.5cm size on the left lateral wall of the bladder. It extends into and through the detrusor muscle and involves the perivesical soft tissue. A flat carcinoma in situ (CIS) component is also identified. The neoplasm consists of solid sheets of neoplastic cells with a high N:C ratio, prominent nuclear molding, and extensive necrosis, indicating small cell carcinoma. The small cell component shows positive immunostains for synaptophysin, NSE, and CD56 and negative for chromogranin, pankeratin, and thrombomodulin. The pathologic staging is pT3a, pNO, with no involvement of the 12 lymph nodes examined, and margins uninvolved by the invasive carcinoma. No venous or lymphatic vessel invasion or direct extension of invasive tumor is identified. There is also urothelial carcinoma in situ.

Left distal ureter biopsy shows a segment lined by benign urothelial mucosa, and another segment lined by reactive urothelium, with no evidence of urothelial carcinoma in situ (CIS) or invasive urothelial carcinoma. Urinary pathology reveals invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma (3.2 cm) with bizarre pleomorphic giant cells invading detrusor muscle and adipose tissue. Surgical margins are free of tumor, although flat CIS is identified, with no evidence of perineural invasion. Angiolymphatic invasion is present, and pathological staging is pT3a N1 MX. Cystitis cystica and squamous metaplasia identified. One out of five left pelvic lymph nodes show metastatic carcinoma, while no carcinoma is identified in eleven right pelvic lymph nodes. The final diagnosis is urothelial carcinoma of the bladder, high-grade, with venous/lymphatic invasion and perivesical fat extension.

Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, endometrioid type, in uterus and cervix, with invasion to a depth of 3 mm and very focal lymphovascular space invasion identified. Acute and chronic inflammation present in organizing biopsy site and benign mesonephric remnants present. No carcinoma identified in vagina, cuff, parametrial soft tissue, or lymph nodes (except for very focal invasion in one lymph node). Inactive endometrium and no histopathologic abnormality in myometrium, right ovary and fallopian tube. No carcinoma identified in 6 out of 6 left pelvic lymph nodes and in 10 out 10 right pelvic lymph nodes.
A cervical biopsy from a 3A.D. uterus patient shows a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The patient is a year old woman, and only one slide was submitted for review.

Diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma, moderately differentiated, invasive, located in the uterus cervix biopsy. Microscopic examination confirms the diagnosis. One slide labeled with a corresponding pathology report was received, and the original material was returned. No patient history provided.

Diagnosis: Invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma detected in cervical tissue obtained via curettage. Microscopic examination confirms the diagnosis. Patient history includes a previous diagnosis of cervical carcinoma. A tissue fragment measuring 2.4 x 1.7 x 1.0 cm was received for analysis.

Diagnosis: Squamous cell carcinoma in cervical biopsy specimen. Specimens submitted: Cervix tissue fragments measuring 0.7 x 0.5 x 0.1 cm in aggregate. Gross: Received in a container of formalin. Comment: Moderately differentiated non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma with intense stromal chronic inflammatory infiltrate.

Diagnosis: The patient has invasive squamous cell carcinoma that is moderately differentiated and keratinizing in the uterus, endocervix, and cervix. Resection margins are extensively involved, and a focal lymphvascular space invasion is identified. No carcinoma is found in the right ovary or left adnexa, but the cervical cone biopsy, endocervical curettage, and posterior cul-de-sac biopsy specimens contain invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Microscopic examination of the cervical cone biopsy reveals that the tumor involves all eight blocks of tissue, including the lateral and deep margins. The tumor measures 1.4 cm in greatest lateral dimension and 0.9 cm in depth, but it may be larger given the positive resection margins. The surface epithelium adjacent to invasive cancer shows severe dysplasia (CIN 3). The specimen labeled "posterior cul-de-sac biopsy" contains a very small fragment of invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Histologic sections from the right ovarian biopsy indicate that it may represent a portion of cortex adhesed to adnexal soft tissue, and the left adnexal biopsy is composed of inflamed connective tissue with smooth muscle and serosal. No malignancy is identified in either ovarian biopsy specimen.

Filtered pathology report summary: Gastrectomy preparation with tumor-free resection margins and with the inclusion of subendocardial, poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma or gastric carcinoma (partially diffuse type with signet-ring carcinoma) situated in the region of the lesser curvature with subserosal infiltration and multiple regional lymph node metastases. Diagnosis: pT2b pN2 15/37.

Filtered report: Total gastrectomy preparation with moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (gastric carcinoma of the intestinal type) located on the side of the greater curvature, with a maximum diameter of 16 cm encompassing the corpus segment of the stomach in an almost circular growth. Invasive tumor spread within all the parietal layers of the stomach extending into the adjacent subserous fatty tissue and encroaching on the peritoneal side of the atrophic gastritis (type A). Two lymph nodes show metastatic infiltrates of the previously diagnosed adenocarcinoma or gastric carcinoma. Stage: pT4 pN1 (2/33).

The pathology report indicates the presence of a poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma or diffuse type gastric carcinoma, specifically signet ring cell carcinoma located in the antrum on the lesser curvature of the stomach and extending to the Duodenum. The report also mentions penetration of the peritoneum and the presence of metastases in six regional lymph nodes, omentum, and peritoneum. The report assigns a diagnosis of pT4a R1 pN2 (6/39) pM1.

Diagnosis: Gastrectomy and esophageal resection specimens with moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma or gastric carcinoma located in the prepyloric antrum, penetration of the peritoneum, and five regional lymph node metastases. Additionally, a poorly differentiated, partially mucinous Barrett's adenocarcinoma located in the area of the esophagogastric junction.

Diagnosis: The report describes a resection specimen of the distal esophagus and proximal stomach with an almost circular, 3.5 cm-long carcinoma of the esophagogastric junction. The carcinoma is of the histological type of a poorly differentiated, predominantly solid adenocarcinoma. There is invasive tumor dissemination within all esophageal and gastric wall layers into the adjacent fatty tissue. The gastric mucosa of the corpus and antrum-corpus junction shows minimal, non-florid chronic gastritis of the superficial type, without evidence of Helicobacter pylori. The oral and aboral resection margins are tumor-free, while three of 26 lymph nodes exhibit metastases from the carcinoma, which indicates a tumor stage of pT2b assuming a gastric localization (cardia carcinoma), or pT3 pN1 (3/26) assuming a primary localization of the distal esophagus.

Filtered report: Total gastrectomy specimen with a 4 cm moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma (gastric carcinoma of the intestinal type) on the lesser curvature side in the corpus portion. Tumor dissemination observed within all gastric wall layers up to the subserosal and perigastric fatty tissue level with lymphatic and perineural tumor extensions. Antral mucosa with mild to moderate, non-florid chronic gastritis and foveolar hyperplasia, and corpus mucosa with moderately florid chronic gastritis, slight foveolar hyperplasia, and focal intestinal metaplasia with evidence of Helicobacter pylori. Oral and aboral resection margin tumor-free. Three of 36 perigastric lymph nodes with metastases from the gastric carcinoma. Therefore tumor stage pT2b associated with the histological findings pN1 (3/39).

The report describes a case of gastric carcinoma of the intestinal type with a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The carcinoma has a maximum diameter of 7.5 cm and extends up to 5 cm from the oral and 4 cm from the aboral resection margin. The tumor has infiltrated all the wall layers of the transverse colon and formed a gastrocolic fistula. One mesocolic lymph node has metastasis from the carcinoma while another specimen from the liver includes a biliary harmatoma. The tumor stage is classified as pT4 pN1 (1/24) with evidence of Helicobacter pylori in the mucosa.

Report Summary: The total gastrectomy specimen showed an ulcerated carcinoma of the esophagogastric junction, poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma type, with invasive tumor dissemination within all gastric wall layers as well as lymphatic tumor spread. The resection margin and greater omentum were tumor-free. Additionally, antrum and corpus showed moderate chronic gastritis, foveolar hyperplasia, focal intestinal metaplasia, and partial mucosal atrophy. Helicobacter pylori was not found. Twenty-four regional lymph nodes were tumor-free with uncharacteristically reactive changes. The tumor stage was pT2b pNO (0/23).

The pathology report identifies a free lymph node and an invasive gastric carcinoma of the intestinal type in the stated area, with infiltration of muscularis up to the serosa (p T3). The mucosal area, ligature region, lymph nodes, and omental tissue are free of the tumor. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA-M 8140/3, with p T 3, L 1, p N 0. The mucosal resection margins were tumor-free.

Distal partial gastric resection specimen shows a gastric adenocarcinoma (intestinal type) of 5.5 cm size in the prepyloric gastric antrum with infiltration of the proximal duodenum, perigastric fatty tissue, and seven regional lymph node metastases. Mild to moderate chronic gastritis is observed in the tumor-free oral resection margin. The aboral margin is lined with typical duodenal mucosa. The remaining gastric mucosa shows polypoid foveolar hyperplasia, multifocal intestinal metaplasia, and the same type of gastritis observed in the oral resection margin. The omental fatty tissue is free of tumor. Tumor stage: pT2b, pN2 (7/32), pMX.

The pathology report describes various findings from a tissue sample. The spleen tissue appears normal and includes regular red and white pulp. Free fatty tissue and lymph nodes are observed. There is a poorly differentiated advanced gastric carcinoma, which is an invasive adenocarcinoma of the intestinal type that has infiltrated all wall layers, with lymphatic vessel penetration and metastases in the adjacent lymph nodes and fatty connective tissues. The report also mentions regular anastomotic rings of the small bowel and inflammatory reactive changes in the pancreas. Further secondary resections are required. The TNM classification includes infiltration of omental tissue and peritoneum, and infiltration of lymph nodes in the area of the omentum. The tumor classification is ICDO-DA-M 8140/3, pT3, pN1, L1. A consultation was held regarding the definitive TNM classification and a clear margin of healthy tissue was removed locally during the operation.

The pathology report describes a case of poorly differentiated bilateral multifocal adenocarcinoma of the prostate with tumor infiltration extending across the organ. The maximum tumor diameter is 1.6 cm, and extensive multifocal tumor involvement of perineural sheaths is observed. Foci of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia and myoglandular prostatic hyperplasia are also present. However, the surgical preparation margins are tumor-free and two tumor-free lymph nodes are observed in the right obdurator fossa, and three in the left. The tumor is classified as pT3a, with a maximum tumor diameter of 16 mm, Gleason 4+3=7 (Gleason 4: 70%), pNO (0/5), and R0. Immunohistochemical investigation shows no evidence of tumorous vessel invasion.

The pathology report indicates that there are three tumor-free lymph nodes and tumor-free fatty tissue. However, there is extensive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma present in the prostatectomy preparation with perineural growth, invasion of lymph and blood vessels, infiltration of labeled preparation margins close to the base, bilateral infiltration of seminal vesicles and the wall of the bladder, with a lymph node metastasis. The tumor is classified as pT4 pN1 L1 V1, G4, with a total score of 5+5=10, corresponding to stage IV. The preparation margins on both sides close to the base are extensively infiltrated with the tumor.

Summary: The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of a poorly differentiated, max 2.8 cm adenocarcinoma of the prostate in both lobes with perineural growth, invasion of connective tissue and vessels. Tumor-free seminal vesicles, ducts and lymph nodes were found. The carcinoma infiltrates are in the peripheral and transitional zone of both sides with right-sided predominance. The tumor is classified as pT3a, pN0, Gleason 4+4 = 8; G3, L1, V0. A possible neuroendocrine differentiation will be further investigated.

The pathology report indicates a diagnosis of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma of the prostate that has invaded lymph vessels and perineural areas with a maximum tumor diameter of 2 cm. The right seminal vesicle has some focal infiltration, and the periprostatic fatty connective tissue on the right side has lateral infiltration. Additionally, there is widespread contact with the margin of the color-labeled preparation measuring up to 8 mm in the apex region on both sides. The fatty tissue contains 4 lymph nodes free of tumors on one side and 3 on the other. The summary tumor classification is pT3b, L1, V0, R1; pN0 (0/7); and Gleason 4+3 = 7, with Gleason 4 representing about 70% of the tumor.

Multifocal and pluriform adenocarcinoma of the prostate with separate foci in the transitional zone and in the peripheral zone on both sides. Maximum tumor spread in the transitional zone on the right: 2 cm. Marked perineural invasion. Extraprostatic left rectolateral tumor growth with infiltration of the periprostatic fatty tissue. No identifiable invasion of the vessels. Tumor-free seminal vesicles. The tumor is classified as pT3a, pNO (0/16), L0, V0, Gleason 2+4 = 6 with tertiary Gleason 3 portion (approx. 50% Gleason 2, 30% Gleason 4). Carcinoma cells extend to the artificial (yellow highlighted) margin of the preparation in the apex and the right rectolateral side. All other preparation margins are tumor-free.

The pathology report shows that there is a 7cm tumor, identified as renal cell carcinoma, of conventional type, located in the right kidney. The tumor contains 60% clear cells and 40% eosinophilic cells with a Fuhrman nuclear grade 3. The tumor has invaded the renal sinus adipose and pelvicalyceal system, causing multifocal necrosis and hemorrhage in the renal tubules. The report confirms that there is no invasion into the perinephric adipose tissue or the renal vein and that there are no cancerous cells present in the four lymph nodes examined. The adrenal gland shows no tumor presence. The report also provides a gross description of the tumor and includes the sections that have been submitted to the laboratory for analysis. The clinical history of the patient is that of a renal mass.

The pathology report pertains to a nephrectomy specimen that includes the right kidney, attached ureter, and lymph nodes. The right kidney exhibits a well-circumscribed yellow-brown tumor with hemorrhage, measuring 5.0 x 5.0 x 5.0 cm, that invades into the renal pelvis but does not extend beyond the capsule. The tumor is identified to be a renal cell carcinoma, conventional subtype, predominantly composed of clear cells (90%) and eosinophilic cells (10%). The Fuhrman's nuclear grade is 3. The vascular and ureteral margins of the specimen are free of tumor, and three lymph nodes show no evidence of malignancy. The remaining renal parenchyma and lymph nodes are unremarkable. No clinical history is provided.

The pathology report includes three diagnoses. First, a subcutaneous invasive cyst that is consistent with a follicular cyst of the infundibular type. Second, a renal cell carcinoma of the conventional (clear) cell type with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 4, which is confined to the left kidney. The margins of resection, vascular, and ureteral margins are free of tumor, and one hilar lymph node is negative for tumor. Third, a segment of the 11th rib with a gross diagnosis is included in the report. The subcutaneous invasive cyst is represented in two specimen submissions while representative portions of the tumor and normal tissue are submitted for tumor banking. The histologic diagnosis for the three specimens includes subcutaneous invasive cyst, renal cell carcinoma, and an unspecified fragment of the rib. No clinical history is given.

Surgery Date: Diagnosis: (A) Right Radical Nephrectomy: Renal Cell Carcinoma, Conventional (Clear Cell) Type, Fuhrman Nuclear Grade 3 (5.2 cm), Confined to the Kidney. Ureteral and hilar vascular margins, free of tumor. Gross Description: (A) Right Radical Nephrectomy - A right kidney (11.0 x 7.0 x 3.7 cm) has a pale tan to brown tumor (5.2 x 4.7 x 3.0 cm) with a central scar. The tumor is well circumscribed with pushing areas near the renal capsule and renal sinus. No lymph nodes are identified. Portions of the tumor are submitted for electron microscopy. A photograph is obtained. Section Code: A1, vascular and ureteral margin; A2-A4, tumor with renal sinus; A5, central scar; A6, A7, tumor with perinephric fat; A8-A10, tumor with adjacent renal parenchyma; A11-A12, distant normal kidney. Clinical History: None given. SNOMED Codes: T-71000, M-83123. 1.

The report describes a left kidney nephrectomy specimen with a tumor measuring 14 cm in maximum dimension that has invaded the perirenal adipose tissue, renal sinus adipose tissue, and renal vein. Vascular/lymphatic invasion is present, and the tumor is of Fuhrman nuclear grade 4. The ureteral, vascular, and soft tissue margins of resection are free of tumor. A liver biopsy shows adjacent fibrosis, but no histologic evidence of metastatic carcinoma is identified. A left adrenal gland specimen of 8 cm x 5 cm x 3.5 cm is described, with a well-circumscribed 0.9 cm x 0.5 cm x 0.5 cm medullary-based hemorrhagic fleshy tan nodule. A cystic area of 1.0 cm x 1.0 cm x 0.8 cm with cyst contents composed of hemorrhage and a smooth 0.5 cm x 0.5 cm x 0.5 cm fleshy tan nodule is also noted. A spleen of 13 cm x 8 cm x 4.5 cm with mild red pulp expansion and prominent white pulp nodularity but no masses is present.

The pathology report describes a case of renal cell carcinoma in the right kidney and adrenal gland of a patient presenting with a right renal mass. The tumor measured 10.0 cm in maximum dimension and was of the conventional type, comprising 70% clear cells and 30% eosinophilic cells. The Fuhrman nuclear grade was 3, and the tumor was confined to the kidney, with no invasion into the perinephric adipose tissue or renal vein. The report notes that multiple additional deeper sections were examined, and the margins of resection were free of tumor. No tumor was present in the adrenal gland or gonadal vein on the right. The gross description of the specimen indicates that the tumor was close to the Gerota's fascia and perinephric fat in focal areas and near the pelvicalyceal system and the renal sinus. The report concludes that the tumor is submitted for the vaccine protocol. The SNOMED codes associated with this case are T-71000 and M-83123.

Clinical Diagnosis & History: Colonoscopy post GI bleed revealed adenocarcinoma of cecum. Two specimens submitted: Omentum & Right colon. Omentum specimen found to be benign adipose tissue. Right colon specimen showed ulcerative moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of cecum measuring 3.0 x 4.7 x 0.8 cm that invades into subserosa, with vascular invasion. Multiple tubular adenomas were also identified. Surgical margins of resection were free of tumor. 31 lymph nodes examined, 3 positive for metastases (pn1).

The pathology report describes a case of two separate foci of invasive adenocarcinoma in the sigmoid colon. The first tumor is moderately differentiated, invading into the muscularis propria, and measures 5.8 x 4.9 x 1.8 cm. The second tumor is smaller, measuring 2.5 x 1.0 x 1.0 cm and primarily consists of tubulovillous adenoma with intramucosal carcinoma. There is one lymph node identified with metastatic carcinoma involvement. Resection margins are negative. The report also includes information on the gross description of the specimen, including the size and location of the tumors and the submission of pericolic adipose tissue for lymph node dissection. The report was amended to include additional details on the tumors and their invasion characteristics. The proximal and distal anastomotic rings were unremarkable and negative for carcinoma.

The pathology report describes a specimen from a patient with colorectal cancer of the ascending colon. The report details the size and location of the tumor, its histological grade and precursor lesions, lack of lymphovascular invasion or lymph node metastasis, and that the surgical margins were free of tumor. The report also notes that an omentum specimen was submitted, and it was found to be benign adipose tissue. Additional immunohistochemistry testing revealed the tumor retained DNA mismatch repair proteins. No other details about the patient or treatment plan were provided.

A moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma was found in a specimen from the sigmoid colon of a patient with a history of rectal cancer, measuring 6.5 cm in length, 4.5 cm in width, and with a maximal thickness of 2.5 cm. No gross tumor perforation, lymphovascular, large venous, or perineural invasion was identified, and the surgical margins were free of tumor. One tubulovillous adenoma and benign colonic tissue were observed, while no metastasis was found in 31 examined lymph nodes or pericolorectal soft tissue. The tumor invaded the muscularis propria, and immunohistochemical staining for DNA mismatch repair proteins was positive. Excisions of the proximal and distal rings of the colon revealed benign tissue with a detached fragment of adenomatous mucosa noted in the proximal ring.

The patient's colon cancer was diagnosed as an adenocarcinoma with poor differentiation and signet ring cells. The tumor, located in the cecum, is 8.5 cm in length, 7.0 cm in width, and 1.1 cm in maximal thickness, with extensive tumor budding and lymphovascular invasion. There were 11 out of 40 examined lymph nodes with metastasis, and three tumor deposits were identified in pericolorectal soft tissue. The tumor is staged as pT3 and N2b (AJCC 7th Edition). Immunohistochemistry stains showed positive for CK20 and CDX2, and negative for synaptophysin, chromogranin, ER, and PR. The surgical margins were free of tumor, and the non-neoplastic bowel and appendix were unremarkable. There were three tubulovillous adenomas away from the carcinoma.

The pathology report describes specimens submitted from a patient with synchronous stage IV colon cancer, including left colon colectomy, gallbladder, and hepatic artery lymph node. The left colon colectomy shows a moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with focal tumor budding, invasion of the serosal surface, and a tumor deposit in pericolorectal soft tissue. Surgical margins are free of tumor, and lymphovascular invasion is not identified. 19 lymph nodes were examined and showed no metastasis. The gallbladder exhibits mild chronic cholecystitis and cholelithiasis, while the hepatic artery lymph node shows one benign lymph node.
