The report includes gross descriptions of the specimens, including size and location of the tumor, as well as a summary of sections that were examined.

The patient had a large buccal tumor with associated metastatic adenopathy. The pathology report shows invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma present in the left buccal mucosa, submandibular gland, and lymph nodes. The tumor had an infiltrative border and angiolymphatic and perineural invasion, and was present at deep, superior buccal, and inferior gingival margins. There was also a metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in the soft tissue extending into the submandibular gland and lymph nodes. The pathologic stage was pT3, N2b. Ancillary studies will be performed and reported later. The specimen is received in four parts, and gross photographs are taken. The report includes details of tissue sections taken for microscopic examination and staining.

The pathology report describes the case of a patient who underwent a tracheostomy, total laryngectomy, and bilateral neck dissection due to respiratory distress. The final diagnosis includes: right neck dissection with 16 nodes showing no squamous cell carcinoma, but 2 of 16 lymph nodes containing metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma; left neck dissection with 21 nodes showing no tumor present; left upper pharynx biopsy with mild dysplasia and no tumor present; and various biopsies from the base of tongue and upper pharynx showing no tumor present except for the larynx, which showed invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma involving various structures and 3.5 cm in size. There was no extracapsular spread, perineural invasion, or vascular invasion, and surgical margins were free. The pathological stage was pT4N0. The report also lists the number of lymph nodes examined and the results of additional testing, including immunohistochemistry and in-situ hybridization. Ancillary studies were being performed and results were pending at the time of the report. The report also includes detailed gross descriptions of each specimen and slide review information.

The pathology report describes a left composite resection and left neck dissection surgery for a patient with no known medical history or clinical question. The report includes a final diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the left neck, level 2-3, with metastasis present in one of seventeen lymph nodes. The tumor measures 2.4 cm and does not invade the bone directly. The report also notes that there is no perineural invasion, and the margins are free of tumor. The report includes detailed descriptions of the gross and microscopic findings and the tissues examined, including levels 1-3 of the left neck and the soft and hard palate margins. The pathology report also mentions that immunohistochemical staining for p16 will be performed and that the testing performed by the laboratory meets clinical standards. The final diagnosis of the tumor is squamous cell carcinoma, conventional, with a pathologic staging of pT2 N1 Mx.

The pathology report describes the case of a patient with left oral cavity cancer who underwent a DL mandibulectomy composite free flap procedure. The final diagnosis includes invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma on the left oral cavity, acute and chronic inflammation, and metastatic cancer identified in one lymph node. The margins of the resection, including bone, are free of the tumor. There is no perineural invasion seen. Other biopsy samples from different parts of the patient are benign. The tumor is frozen and banked, and digital photographs are taken. The gross description details the appearance of the tissue samples received for testing. The report concludes that this laboratory is certified to perform high-complexity clinical testing and that ASRs used in this laboratory have been certified for accuracy and precision. The report includes synoptic data, including tumor site, size, histologic type, grade, pathologic staging, margins, venous/lymphatic invasion, perineural invasion, and additional pathologic findings.

The pathology report pertains to a patient who underwent a bilateral neck dissection and total laryngectomy due to T4 N2b left pyriform. The report reveals a diagnosis of invasive basaloid squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx and metastatic basaloid squamous cell carcinoma in four of thirty-nine lymph nodes on the left. The report confirms that the thyroid cartilage was free of tumor, and resection margins were uninvolved by the tumor. The report also mentions the presence of one hypercellular left parathyroid gland. The EGFR and c-MET tests were negative, while P16 and HPV tests were negative too.

The report pertains to a patient's history of laryngeal cancer. The procedure performed included right laryngoscopy and bilateral neck dissection, revealing an invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the right supraglottic lesion measuring 4.8 cm. There was extensive invasion of the pre-epiglottic and paraglottic spaces, as well as the thyroid cartilage and anterior soft tissue. Angiolymphatic invasion was present but perineural invasion was not seen. Resection margins were free of tumor, and the right lobe of the thyroid was also free of tumor. In total, 54 lymph nodes were examined, including 29 benign lymph nodes from the right neck (levels 2, 3, and 4) and 24 benign lymph nodes from the left neck (levels 2, 3, and 4). None of the examined lymph nodes were positive for metastases. The pathologic stage was T4 NO MX.

The pathology report describes a case of laryngeal carcinoma that was treated with total laryngectomy and bilateral neck dissection. The final diagnosis indicates the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right supraglottis and pyriform sinus that has invaded into the thyroid cartilage, with perineural and angiolymphatic invasion. However, the surgical margins are free of tumor. The pathologic stage is pT4A, N2A, MX, with one of fifty-six lymph nodes showing metastatic squamous cell carcinoma with positive lymph node right level 3. The tumor measures 4.5 cm and is located on the midline of the right pyriform sinus. Other findings include a saccular cyst in the left vocal cord, a right vocal cord nodule, and chronic inflammation and fibrosis at the tracheostomy site. The thyroid parenchyma is unremarkable, and there is one normocellular parathyroid gland. The report also provides a detailed description of the gross specimens and lists the submitted sections and representative sections for histology. The synoptic data summarizes the tumor location, size, histologic type, grade, and involvement of adjacent structures, lymph nodes, and surgical margins.

The pathology report describes a biopsy of a laryngeal mass in a patient with laryngeal cancer. The biopsy reveals invasive squamous cell carcinoma that is moderately differentiated and keratinizing. The report does not provide information on the patient's medical history, specific clinical question, outside tissue diagnosis, prior malignancies, chemoradiation therapy, organ transplant, or immunosuppression. The specimen is received fresh and consists of a 1.6 cm aggregate of tan-red soft tissue. Microscopic examination supports the diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma. The report includes information on the laboratory's certification and testing procedures. One slide is reviewed with HHE and H&E stains.

The pathology report is for a patient who underwent laryngectomy due to larynx cancer. The report includes details of lymph node and neck dissections, as well as a total laryngectomy with partial pharyngectomy. There is evidence of invasive squamous cell carcinoma confined to the right thyroid lobe with no vascular invasion and margins free of carcinoma. One lymph node contains a psammoma body, and the status of immunosuppression, chemotherapy, and radiation therapy is not specified. The report identifies a tumor in the right pyriform sinus, which is firm in texture and measures 4.6 cm with perineural and venous/lymphatic invasion present, and 4 regional lymph nodes involved with no extracapsular extension. The margins cannot be assessed. No additional pathologic findings are identified. The submitted tissue samples were processed for histologic examination and slides reviewed. The immunochemical stains for TTF1 and CAM 5.2 show no additional metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma.

The pathology report pertains to multiple specimens received for a patient with left alveolar squamous cell carcinoma. The neck dissection levels 1 to 4 revealed 28 lymph nodes negative for tumour and submandibular gland with focal chronic sialadenitis. The floor of mouth margin, deep margin left cheek and left buccal margin were all negative for carcinoma. The composite resection of left mandible showed squamous cell carcinoma that is moderately differentiated with a maximum tumour diameter of 2.2 cm and no lymphovascular invasion or perineural invasion. Three teeth with no pathologic changes and surgical waste with skin with no pathologic changes were also submitted. No regional lymph node metastasis was found in 28 lymph nodes examined, and the margins were uninvolved by the tumour. Finally, all quick sections of the floor of mouth, deep margin left cheek, and left buccal margin were negative for malignancy.

Final Diagnosis: Anaplastic Astrocytoma, WHO Grade III, identified in two specimens designated "Right parietal tumor consistent with glioma." Microscopic Description: Moderately pleomorphic neoplastic astrocytes infiltrate cerebral grey and white matter. Mitotic figures are present, and GFAP immunohistochemical stain is positive in the tumor. P53 immunohistochemical stain is negative in tumor cells, and approximately 5% of tumor cell nuclei show positive Ki67 staining. Congo red stain is negative, PAS stain highlights blood vessels, and no endothelial proliferation or necrosis is identified in the tumor. Clinical History and Diagnosis: Right parietal glioma. Source of Specimen: Two specimens labeled "Right parietal tumor consistent with glioma." Gross Description: Specimens contain multiple tan-pink or tan-white soft tissue fragments measuring 1.5 x 1.0 x 0.4 cm and 2.0 x 1.0 x 0.5 cm in aggregate, respectively. Immunohistochemistry Notes: Quantification of immunohistochemistry assay for ER and PR studies is by the method of Applied Immunohistochemistry. Hercept Test (DakoCytomation), EGFR pharmDx Clone 2-18C9, and ASCR reagents were used. The use of these reagents is regulated as an analyte specific reagent.

Final diagnosis: Left parietal tumor identified as Astrocytoma, WHO grade II with a Ki67 proliferation index of 1.9%. The tumor is composed of moderately pleomorphic glial cells that infiltrate cerebral grey matter, and many tumor cells show positive immunohistochemical staining for GFAP and p53. The chromogranin immunohistochemical stain is negative for ganglion cell component of the tumor, and the NEU-N immunohistochemical stain is negative in tumor cells but positive staining of non-neoplastic cortical neurons in the area infiltrated by astrocytoma cells. Frozen section diagnosis is consistent with glioma, infiltrating glial neoplasm, oligodendrocyte tumor versus astrocytoma. The clinical history and diagnosis reveal a left parietal lesion, and the source of the specimen is the left parietal tumor of an aggregate of tan-red soft tissue measuring 1.5 X 1.5 X 0.8 cm. Touch preps are prepared, and approximately 70% of the specimen is submitted for frozen section with the remainder entirely submitted in one additional cassette. Immunohistochemistry notes indicate the use of one or more reagents in the tests, regulated as analyte specific reagents that have not been cleared by the US Food and Drug Administration.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive squamous carcinoma grade 3, measuring 3 cm in thickness in the right pyriform sinus involving the right aryepiglottic fold and right false vocal cord. Lymphatic and perineural invasion are present, and metastatic squamous carcinoma exists in two of two lymph nodes with extranodal extension. The thyroid gland shows chronic inflammation but no tumor. Additional findings include squamous carcinoma in situ with areas suggestive of microinvasion and moderate dysplasia, and squamous mucosa with no tumor present in other areas. The report also mentions the widefield laryngectomy, partial pharyngectomy, and right hemithyroidectomy that were performed and describes several sections of tissue and lymph nodes that were submitted for analysis.

This pathology report pertains to a patient who underwent a total laryngectomy, partial pharyngectomy, and bilateral neck dissection with subtotal thyroidectomy due to squamous carcinoma. The tumor involved the left vocal cord, left ventricle, and left supraglottic area and had a thickness of 2.0 cm. The report confirms that margins of resection were free of tumor. There was a nodular goiter in the right thyroid, twenty-five right cervical nodes, and thirty-nine left cervical lymph nodes  however, no tumor was detected. The specimen designated as "B1 to B13" for mucosal margins of the resection were also found to be free of tumor. A lower jugular lymph node was also examined. SNOMED codes M-80703 T-24455 were used.

Diagnosis: Total laryngectomy, bilateral node dissection II, III, and IV and left thyroidectomy. Squamous carcinoma grade 2 involving left pyriform sinus, left aryepiglottic fold, and probably thyroid cartilage. Presence of perineural and lymphovascular invasion. Metastatic squamous carcinoma in 7 of 25 left lymph nodes presence of extranodal extension (4 of 10 level II, 3 of 5 level III, 0 of 7 level IV). Left base of tongue and left pharyngeal wall free of tumor. Margins of resection free of tumor. Samples obtained for additional studies. SNOMED codes: M-80703 T-24100.

The pathology report describes a right neck dissection of levels I-V, which revealed 28 lymph nodes with no evidence of tumor. The submandibular salivary gland showed focal chronic inflammation and squamous metaplasia of ductal epithelium. In addition, there was a moderately differentiated invasive squamous carcinoma of the tongue, measuring 1.7cm in thickness, with squamous carcinoma in situ present on the anterior and dorsum of the tongue. However, no tumor was present in the glossal mandibular and pharyngeal sulcus or in the right neck lymph node. The margins of resection appeared uninvolved grossly. Teeth were also present in the sample. No perineural or lymphovascular invasion was identified. The report includes a detailed gross description of each specimen submitted for frozen section.

The pathology report describes a case of squamous carcinoma grade 3 in the floor of the mouth, with moderate to severe dysplasia in the lateral and inferior margins. A left maxillary gland with chronic inflammation and metastatic squamous carcinoma in 3 of the 12 right cervical lymph nodes and soft tissues in level 3 were also identified. There is no tumor present in the proximal and lingual margins as well as in the new right tongue margin. Additionally, the mucosal surface of the left ventral mouth shows no dysplasia or tumor present. Teeth in the specimen are grossly intact or fragmented. Several lymph nodes in the bilateral neck dissection have been submitted, and the largest measures 4.2 cm on the right side at level 2. The salivary glands are grossly unremarkable on both sides. SNOMED codes for the diagnosis are provided.

DIAGNOSIS: Moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma invading mandible, tongue, soft palate, and hard palate. Submandibular gland has focal atrophic changes, and four lymph nodes show no tumor. Microscopic tumor foci present in resection margins. Tumor also invades left pterygoid fossa. Mucosal ulceration is present, and the diagnosis for mandible and mandibular resection margins is pending decalcification. Focal vascular invasion is identified, but no lymphatic or perineural invasion is noted. SNOMED codes are T-53000 and 1-80703. This report is issued for specimens requiring decalcification and does not change any previous diagnosis.

Filtered Report: Diagnosis: Moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma invading the anterior mandible, resection margins free of tumor. Invasive, moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma involving the skin, subcutaneous tissue and floor of the mouth, resection margins free of tumor. No evidence of carcinoma in the right lingual nerve and lymph nodes in the right middle jugular. Perineural and lymphovascular invasion not seen. Specimen: Chin including anterior mandible and overlying skin and base of tongue, right lingual nerve, lymph nodes in right middle jugular. SNOMED Codes: T-11180, M-80703.

DIAGNOSIS: Minute fragment of bone and foci of squamous carcinoma from maxillary sinus, invasive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma involving bone of hard palate, fragments of invasive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma from maxillary sinus, invasive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma from mucosa of right maxillary sinus, and invasive well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma from partial maxillectomy specimen. Salivary gland tissue from lateral side of palate and respiratory mucosa from maxillary sinus show no tumor present. Multiple fragments of tan soft tissue and bone, along with teeth, are submitted for analysis. Ink code and section code provide information on orientation and margins. SNOMED codes indicate carcinoma types. Bone fragments from partial maxillectomy specimen are sent for further processing.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive squamous carcinoma in the right partial glossectomy specimen, which is well-differentiated and exhibits an infiltrative tumor border with perineural invasion. The report also includes negative findings for tumor in various other specimens, including lymph nodes and soft tissue margins. Additionally, the report notes the absence of high-risk human papilloma virus genotypes in the tumor.

The pathology report relates to a deceased individual who underwent a total laryngopharyngectomy due to invasive moderately differentiated squamous carcinoma in the left piriform sinus and pharynx. The tumor was ulcerating and measured 7 cm in the largest dimension with a depth of 2 cm invasion. It was infiltrative with thick cords > 4 cells, and mild lymphocyte infiltration was present. The report indicates that there was no vascular invasion, no bone or cartilage invasion, and no perineural invasion. Severe dysplasia at the left pharynx margin(s) was present. The report also shows that the left lateral pharyngeal wall had no tumor, and five lymph nodes in each of the left neck dissection levels (II and III, and IV) and level II "A" had no tumor present. Four perilaryngeal lymph nodes, right neck dissection level III, and level IV presented five, nine, and four respectively and had no tumor. A focal mucosal erosion was present on the epiglottis, but no tumor extended into the glottis or vocal cord. The report concludes that there was carcinoma in situ of the left pharynx/left base of tongue regions and severe dysplasia at the left pharynx margin(s). Moreover, all mucosal margins were negative, and additional sections reviewed were negative for cartilage invasion.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive squamous carcinoma, moderately differentiated, measuring 2.5cm in largest dimension and infiltrating to a depth of 1.5cm. The report confirms negative tumor status in multiple lymph nodes across various levels of the neck and parotid region. The report also notes the absence of bone or cartilage invasion in the mandible. A composite resection of mandible floor of mouth and tongue was performed and the margins of resection were grossly uninvolved. Bone margins are negative for carcinoma. No tumor was found in the left posterior tongue margin, posterior deep tongue, left mylohyoid, and digastric muscles. The patient's clinical history and SNOMED codes are also provided.

Pathology report indicates that the specimen received is a partial or total resection of the right kidney. It reveals the presence of renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type, with a size of 5.0 cm and Fuhrman grade 2. The tumor is confined to the kidney, and there is no lymphovascular invasion observed. The vascular and ureteric margins of resection are negative for tumor. The AJCC classification for the tumor is T1 NO MX. The non-neoplastic renal parenchyma shows minimal chronic changes, and a mild degree of arterial sclerosis, which are age-related. No metaphases were available from the specimen for cytogenetic analysis as per the indication for the test being RCC. Special stains are to be performed to assess the adjacent uninvolved renal parenchyma.

Pathologic diagnosis: Left kidney and adrenal gland nephrectomy; renal cell carcinoma (clear cell type, Fuhrman nuclear grade II of IV, 7.2 cm); benign renal cyst (2.5 cm). No invasion of renal capsule or vascular system. Ureteric, vascular, and soft tissue margins are negative for tumor. Adrenal gland with no significant pathologic change. AJCC Classification (6th Edition) : T2 NX MX. Cytogenetic analysis shows clonal aberrations, including deletion of chromosome 3 short arm (typical in renal cell carcinoma, clear cell type).

Diagnosis: Endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, forming a polypoid mass. The tumor invades the myometrium to a maximal depth of 0.5 cm and extends to involve the lower uterine segment. The cervix is uninvolved. The right ovary with a segment of the right fallopian tube was removed due to diagnostic abnormalities but the left ovary and fallopian tube showed no diagnostic abnormalities. Multiple lymph nodes from the right and left pelvic and para-aortic areas were negative for tumor. The report was based on gross examination and histologic evaluation of the specimens.

Uterus, bilateral ovaries, and fallopian tubes were removed due to high grade papillary serous carcinoma. Invasive tumor extends into the myometrium within the lower uterine segment. A separate non-invasive, high grade papillary serous carcinoma forming a mass is identified. Multiple benign leiomyomata and calcified nodules are identified. Omentum and lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The report is based on gross/macroscopic examination and frozen section histologic evaluation of the specimen(s).

A 3090g skin and subcutaneous tissue sample with umbilicus shows no lesions. A sample consisting of a uterus, bilateral ovaries, and fallopian tubes weighing 85g exhibits a 3.9 x 2.9 x 1.5 cm endometrial adenocarcinoma within the lower uterine segment that invades through the myometrial wall (0.9 cm thickness) but not the uterine serosa. The ectocervical margin is negative for malignancy. Multiple lymph nodes in the right and left pelvic, as well as para-aortic regions, excised and examined, are negative for malignancy. The right and left gonadal vessels show no malignancy. The omentum sample is negative for malignancy. Cervical infiltration under the transformation zone mucosa is identified through a review of permanent sections.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis of invasive endometrial adenocarcinoma in a uterus with bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes that were removed via hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The tumor is of undifferentiated and endometrioid types and is present in a background of atypical complex hyperplasia, forming a 6.0 x 3.7 x 1.8 cm mass in the anterior uterine wall. The tumor invades 1.8 cm into the myometrium, but does not involve the endocervix. The report also describes lymph node excisions and biopsies from different organs, which all tested negative for tumor. An addendum notes the presence of squamous cell carcinoma in situ in the cervix.

Diagnosis: Endometrial adenocarcinoma, endometrioid type, confined to a polypoid mass (3.0 x 2.3 x 1.0 cm) in the left wall of the endometrial cavity with 1.6 cm myometrial thickness, FIGO grade II (of III). No lymphovascular space invasion identified. The margins are negative for tumor. Uterine intramural leiomyomas (sizes ranging from 0.2 to 0.9 cm in greatest dimension) and bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are not involved.

The pathology report describes the excision of uterus, fallopian tubes, ovaries, and lymph nodes of a patient. The uterus shows a polypoid mass measuring 8.4 x 3.5 x 2.4 cm, representing a FIGO grade III endometrial adenocarcinoma, with infiltration into the myometrium. No angiolymphatic invasion is identified. The cervix is tumor-free. Multiple leiomyomata are identified in the uterus. One out of five right external iliac lymph nodes is positive for a microscopic focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The ovaries and fallopian tubes are without diagnostic abnormality. Multiple pelvic lymph nodes are negative for tumor. Multiple para-aortic lymph nodes above and below the inferior mesenteric artery are negative for tumor. The right gonadal vessel is negative for tumor. Skin and subcutaneous tissue from the abdomen are identified grossly. There were amendments made to the initial signout, which include the identification of the microscopic focus of metastatic adenocarcinoma in one of the right external iliac lymph nodes.

The pathology report describes the findings of a hysterectomy and bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to endometrial adenocarcinoma serous adenocarcinoma with FIGO grade III. The tumor is confined to a polyp attached to the fundus of the endometrial cavity, and lymphovascular space invasion is not identified. Leiomyomata are present in the myometrium, but the bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are not involved. Multiple lymph nodes are negative for tumor, and various tissues and organs are unremarkable or benign. The report is based on gross/macroscopic examination and the frozen section histologic evaluation of the specimens, with permanent sections to be reviewed for any substantive changes.

Histopathological examination of a multiple organ resection including sigmoid colon with rectum and two tumours revealed the presence of a bifocal adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare partially musinosum (G3) which infiltrates the tunicae muscularis priopriae et telae adiposae pericolicae. The first tumour, located near the proximal end of the intestine, is a cauliflower-shaped mass that surrounds 100% of the intestine circumference, while the second tumour is located 5 cm away from the first one. Both tumours penetrate the intestinal wall, and have minimum side margins of 1.1 cm and 2.5 cm, respectively. Additionally, lymphonoditis reactiva lymphonodorum (No XIV) was observed outside the first tumour. The final histopathological diagnosis is a bifocal adenocarcinoma of the colon (G3, Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNO).

Page 1 / 1. Original Examination: Histopathological examination. Cost of diagnostic procedure. Material: 1. Multiple organ resection - colon. Material collected. Expected time of examination: Clinical diagnosis: Right side of the colon along with the transverse, descending, and sigmoid colons (two tumors, one stained with blue dye on the right side of the transverse colon, the other one - tumor of the distal part of the sigmoid colon, polyps? in the splenic flexure). Macroscopic description: An 82 cm length of the large intestine with peri-intestinal tissue sized 85 x 9 x 3.5 cm, a 37 cm segment of the small intestine, a 6.5 cm appendix, and the omentum sized 30 x 13 x 3 cm. An ulceration sized 2 x 1.9 x 0.3 cm found in the mucosa. The lesion surrounds 20% of the intestine circumference and is located 18.9 cm away from the proximal excision, 6.4 cm from the distal excision line, and 15.8 cm away from the Bauhin's valve. Additionally, tumor sized 2.4 x 2.2 x 0.8 cm surrounding approx. 40% of the circumference located 69.8 cm from the proximal boundary and 8.8 cm from the distal one. The distance between the tumors is 49.3 cm. Microscopic description: Adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare bifocale (G2). Infiltratio carcinomatosa telae adiposae pericolicae. Excision lines clear of neoplastic infiltration. Outside the tumor: Adenoma tubulopapillare cum dysplasia gradus minoris. Lymphonodulitis reactiva (NO V). Histopathological diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare bifocale coli. Tubulopapillar bifocal adenocarcinoma of the colon. (G2, Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNO). Supplementary information: Additionally, five reactive lymph nodes found in the collected specimens (pNO).

Diagnostic Procedure: Histopathological examination of total organ resection - cancer of the cecum. Clinical Diagnosis: Cancer of the cecum. Macroscopic Description: The resected organ is a 20 cm length of the large intestine with an 8 cm appendix. A tumor of size 3 X 2 cm, surrounded 80% of the intestine circumference, found in the mucosa with a cauliflower-like shape. The lesion is located 3.5 cm from the proximal excision line and 1.5 cm from the distal excision line. Minimum side margin is 3 cm. Microscopic Description: Adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare partim mucinosum (G3) observed. Lymphonodulitis (No XIV). Appendix - Appendicitis chronica. Preliminary Result: Adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare partim mucinosum coli. Tubulopapillar and partially mucinous adenocarcinoma of the colon. (G3; DukesA; Astler-CollerBI; pT2; pNO). Final Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma tubulopapillare partim mucinosum coli. Lymphonodulitis No XVIII.

Histopathological diagnosis: Mucocellular adenocarcinoma of the Stomach (diffuse). Metastases in 12/16 adjacent lymph nodes. Macroscopic description: Stomach exhibiting an ulcerated tumour of 5.0 x. 4 x 2cm, located 6.0cm away from the proximal incision line, and 9cm from the distal one. Microscopic description: Gastric mucocellular adenocarcinoma (G3 acc. to Lauren, diffuse type). Tumour infiltrating the serous membrane (pT4a) Metastases to 3/3 pericardia lymph nodes, 5/5 lesser curvature lymph nodes, 1/2 greater curvature lymph nodes, 3/6 perypyloric lymph nodes - total: 12/16 lymph nodes involved. Spleen free of cancer. Two lymph of the hilum lienale nodes free of cancer.

The report describes a histopathological examination of a multiple organ resection, including the right breast and axillary tissue, in a female patient diagnosed with cancer of the right breast. The examination reveals a 3.0 cm invasive ductal carcinoma with foci of ductal carcinoma in situ and lobular carcinoma in situ. The axillary lymph nodes show metastases of carcinoma. Immunohistochemical analysis shows estrogen receptors present in over 75% of neoplastic cell nuclei and progesterone receptors present in 10-75% of neoplastic cell nuclei. HER2 protein is stained using HercepTestM by DAKO, with a score of 2+ and FISH verification recommended. HER2/neu gene amplification is not found in the FISH analysis. The immunophenotype is E-cadherin+ and CK7-.

Gender: F. Material: Lesion excision from the left breast, outer upper quad. Clinical diagnosis: Cancer of the left breast. Result of intraoperative examination: Carcinoma invasivum. Macroscopic description: Fragment of the breast sized 6 x 5 x 2 cm, with a tumor sized 1.2 x 0.8 x 0.7 cm in the middle. Histopathological diagnosis: Carcinoma ductale invasivum NHG3 (3 + 3 + 2/10 mitoses/10 HPF - visual area 0.55 mm), pT1c. Results of immunohistochemical examination: No estrogen or progesterone receptors found in neoplastic cell nuclei. HER2 protein stained negative with a score of 1+ in invasive cancerous cells.

The report describes a histopathological examination of multiple organ resection from the right breast of a female patient, with a clinical diagnosis of a tumor in the breast and right axillary lymph nodes. The macroscopic description mentions a lesion on the boundary of outer quadrants in the breast. The microscopic findings suggest invasive ductal carcinoma of the right breast, with metastases in axillary lymph nodes. The report also indicates a massive invasion of blood vessels by cancer cells and the presence of peritumoral lymphocytic reaction. The immunohistochemical examination indicates that estrogen receptor was found in less than 10% of neoplastic cell nuclei, progesterone receptors were absent in neoplastic cell nuclei, and the HER2 protein stained negative in invasive cancerous cells.

Examination: Histopathological examination conducted on a left breast organ resection, with a tumor removal site found on the boundary of inner quadrants, sized 8 x 8 x 3 cm, placed 4.0 cm from the upper edge, 0.1 cm from the base, and 0.2 cm from the skin. Histopathological diagnosis is invasive ductal carcinoma of the left breast, with NHG2, pT1c, and pNo/sn. Glandular tissue shows parenchyma atrophy. Mamilla is without faesionibus.

The pathology report describes the examination of a multiple organ resection where the right breast was removed due to cancer. The tumor, sized 1.1 x 0.6 x 1.0 cm, was found in the upper inner quadrant of the breast and identified as invasive ductal carcinoma with numerous foci of carcinoma ductal in situ. The texture of the gland showed lesions of fibrocystic mastopathy. Results of an immunohistochemical examination showed positive estrogen and progesterone receptors but a negative reaction to HER2 protein in invasive cancerous cells. The histopathological diagnosis is invasive and in situ ductal carcinoma of the right breast (NHG1, pT1c, pNx).

Final Diagnosis: The left frontal and temporal cortical regions of the brain had biopsies revealing WHO grade III fibrillary and gemistocytic astrocytomas (anaplastic astrocytomas). An intraoperative cytologic smear interpretation suggested a glioma and recommended further classification and grading.

The pathology report describes the resection of liver mass segment VI, which is a variegated mass with focal necrosis. Hepatocellular carcinoma is moderately differentiated, partially encapsulated with pushing borders and shows no large vessel invasion. The tumor is positive for polyclonal CEA and Hep-1, and negative for AFP and cytokeratin. Liver mass segment VII resection also shows hepatocellular carcinoma forming a solid nodule, with a separate hemangioma. Liver nodule excision reveals sclerosing hemangioma. However, the report also suggests mild simple steatosis and macrovesicular steatosis present in a non-zonal distribution in non-neoplastic liver parenchyma, without significant inflammatory cell infiltrate, ductular proliferation or Mallory's hyaline formation. Some neutrophils are present, consistent with "surgical hepatitis." Hold the diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma for segment VI resection to confirm with immunohistochemical stains.

Tissue from liver segments VI and V was examined, revealing a well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma mass measuring 3.6 x 2.1 x 2.1 cm. The surgical resection margins were uninvolved. A reticulin stain showed loss of the reticulin framework in the carcinoma.

Tissue from liver segments II and III and new margin were excised, totaling 170.8 cm. The well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma formed a 3.2 x 2.8 x 2.2 cm mass, which was completely removed with negative margins after a single re-excision. Mild, nonspecific portal inflammation was present in the surrounding non-neoplastic liver, with no advanced fibrosis. A minority of portal tracts contained a mixed inflammatory infiltrate, with occasional neutrophils associated with patchy ductular proliferation. Trace steatosis was present, but there was no active steatohepatitis or significant fibrosis.

The pathology report describes a liver specimen with a pedunculated type hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) located in segment 5, measuring 3.3 x 3.1 x 3.0 cm with no satellite nodule or portal vein invasion. The tumor exhibits complete capsule formation and no invasion of adjacent structures, surgical margin or serosa. The worst differentiation of the tumor is III with the major differentiation being II. Microscopically, the tumor is trabecular in type with hepatic cell appearance and no fatty change. The non-tumor liver pathology is micronodular cirrhosis. The report also mentions a separate specimen of the gallbladder without tumor, showing chronic cholecystitis.

The pathology report describes a liver specimen obtained from a patient who underwent subsegmentectomy and tumorectomy in segments 8 and 5. The liver exhibits two masses, both confirmed to be hepatocellular carcinoma. The first mass in segment 8 is multinodular and pale tan with focal hemorrhage and necrosis, while the second mass is smaller, pale green to tan, and has extensive necrosis and hemorrhage. The gallbladder removed during cholecystectomy shows chronic cholecystitis and cholesterolosis. The remaining parenchyme in the liver shows cirrhosis, with active fibrotic changes. Special stains are not reported, and there is evidence of inflammation in pleural and peritoneal fluids. No further treatment plan is outlined.

The patient has a known case of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), and a liver bissectionectomy was performed. The liver exhibited a poorly demarcated, multinodular confluent mass which measured 7.5 x 6.6 x 5.1 cm. The tumor was found to be confined within the capsule, and the resection margin was not involved. The remaining liver parenchyme showed cirrhosis, and no invasion of bile ducts or serosal surface was observed. Histopathological analysis revealed hepatocellular carcinoma with partial fibrous capsule formation and capsular infiltration, along with portal vein and vascular invasion. The gallbladder exhibited autolysis. Biopsy of tissues labeled as 'portal vein thrombi' showed the presence of tumor cells. Chronic gastritis and HBV-associated chronic hepatitis were also observed in the stomach and liver, respectively.

The pathology report describes a case of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) in a liver specimen from a patient who underwent right hemihepatectomy and cholecystectomy. The liver tissue showed two well-defined HCC masses with multinodular confluent growth and extensive necrosis and cirrhosis in the remaining parenchyma. The major and worst differentiation of the HCC was III/IV and II/IV, respectively, with trabecular histologic type and clear-cell and hepatic cell types. There was no invasion or metastasis, but a multicentric occurrence was observed. The gallbladder showed chronic cholecystitis, and the biopsy labeled as "parasite" revealed Clonorchis sinensis infestation. The non-tumor liver pathology showed minimal to mild lobular and portoperiportal-grade chronic hepatitis with septal fibrosis and no dysplastic nodule or ductal epithelial dysplasia.

The pathology report indicates a clinical diagnosis of hepatocellular carcinoma with no satellite nodules, portal vein invasion or intrahepatic metastasis. The lesion was a well-defined mass at segment 4 with a gross type of HCC: expanding nodular. Trabecular and solid histological type was observed with a maximum Edmondson-Steiner grade of III and no fibrous capsule formation, surgical resection margin invasion, capsular infiltration, serosal invasion, septum formation or microvessel invasion. The cirrhotic liver surrounding the tumor was also noted. Additionally, the report mentions chronic cholecystitis in the gallbladder. No other significant findings were reported, and the suggestion is to further analyze the gross photo provided.

The liver mass is a well-defined pale yellow to tan solid and firm mass without necrosis, suggesting hepatocellular carcinoma, with the worst differentiation grade II and major differentiation grade II, and a trabecular histologic type with hepatic cell type. There is mild steatosis in remaining parenchyma. The surgical resection margin, serosal invasion, portal vein invasion, microvessel invasion, intrahepatic metastasis, and multicentric occurrence are all not reported. In addition, there is also a report of adenocarcinoma arising in a tubular adenoma in the stomach's antrum, which is not relevant to the liver pathology.

The pathology report describes a case of papillary thyroid carcinoma in a patient who underwent total thyroidectomy. The tumor had a papillary growth pattern and measured 2.3 cm in the left lobe of the thyroid gland. There was no extra-capsular invasion or vascular invasion. A small satellite nodule was identified in block A13. The surgical margins were negative but close. One lymph node (block A14) showed metastatic thyroid carcinoma. The AJCC stage was pT2 pN1a pMx. The gross description of the specimen indicated a well-circumscribed lesion with scalloped borders in the left mid to inferior lobe, measuring 2.4 x 2.2 x 1.3 cm. The tumor was grossly confined to the thyroid gland and abutted the anterior and posterior margins. The thyroid gland away from the tumor appeared normal. No abnormalities were identified in the right thyroid lobe. A portion of the tumor was taken for special investigations. Lymph node dissection revealed metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in five out of ten lymph nodes in level 6 of the left cervical region, without extracapsular extension.

The patient's pathology report indicates the following diagnoses: A) the right inferior parathyroid biopsy shows negative findings for malignancy, with one lymph node also negative for malignancy; B) the right superior parathyroid biopsy exhibits benign normocellular parathyroid tissue and no malignancy; C) the left superior parathyroid biopsy presents benign normocellular parathyroid tissue and no malignancy; D) the muscle biopsy of the left cricoid thyroid displays metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma present in muscle and soft tissue, with dystrophic calcifications; E) the removal of lymph nodes in the left neck, Levels 2-4, demonstrates one of sixteen lymph nodes positive for metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma with extracapsular extension present; F) the lymph nodes in left neck, Level 6, biopsy reveal three of six lymph nodes positive for metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma with extracapsular extension present, benign normocellular parathyroid tissue, and no malignancy in ectopic thymic tissue; G) the total thyroidectomy shows the histologic tumor type is papillary thyroid carcinoma, with tumor size of 2.5 cm in greatest dimension, invasive growth pattern into extra-thyroidal soft tissues, intraoperative consultation diagnosis of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left lobe, and ectopic thymic tissue with no malignancy found. The report also states the lymph nodes and otherwise healthy tissue were submitted separately for special investigations and photography, as well as the size, weight, and dimensions of the specimens and containers.

The pathology report is for a fresh frozen tissue sample of a uterine mass located on the posterior wall. The sample was collected during surgical resection, and the histology revealed endometrioid adenocarcinoma, NOS with a grade/differentiation of III. The tumour size was 4.3 cm, and it was classified as Pathological T1b. No nodes were sampled, but 18 nodes were positive, and M0 was clinically confirmed.

Sample type: Tumour - Cervical Site of tissue: Cervix Year of sample collection: N/A Histology: Squamous cell carcinoma, nonkeratinizing Grade/Differentiation: N/A Pathological T: T1b Pathological N: N1 Number of Nodes Sampled: 1 Number of Nodes Positive: 23 Clinical M: M0 Histology Comments: Possible lymphovascular invasion is seen. Report states grade 3/3. All resection margins are clear.

Clinical History: Male patient underwent left side craniotomy for a brain tumor. Specimen A is a dome-shaped portion of edematous beige to gray-tan homogenous tissue measuring 3.2x2.5x2.0cm. Frozen section diagnosis of infiltrating glioma with features suspicious for anaplasia was made, and subsequent analysis led to the diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III). Specimen B is a 3.6 x 3.3 x 0.9 cm portion of homogenous beige to gray-tan soft tissue with focal areas of yellow to white softening that also showed anaplastic astrocytoma (WHO Grade III) upon analysis. The tumor cells display a gemistocytic appearance and a Ki-67 labeling index around 9% in highly cellular areas. The pathologist reviewed the gross description and specimen preparations and issued the report. The laboratory is certified to perform high complexity clinical laboratory testing.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis of a high-grade adenocarcinoma on the uterus, cervix, and endometrial bilateral fallopian tubes and ovaries. The tumor invades 3.0 mm of myometrial and 2.0 mm into the cervix, with the presence of lymphovascular invasion. No tumor was found on the left and right pelvic lymph nodes, the portion of omentum, right gonadal vessel, and paraaortic lymph nodes. A leiomyoma was found on the left ovary, and multiple small paratubal cysts were also present. The gross description reveals the characteristics of the uterus, cervix, bilateral tan-white external fallopian tubes, and ovaries. The left and right fallopian tubes showed hemorrhagic material within the lumen but no gross lesions. Multiple lymph nodes and adipose tissues were identified, but no tumor was found. The clinical history mentions endometrial cancer.

A male patient with a left thyroid nodule underwent FNA papillary and submitted two specimens for examination. The first specimen was a right paratracheal lymph node, and the second was a total thyroidectomy. The lymph node sample showed no metastatic disease, and the thyroidectomy sample exhibited papillary microcarcinoma with tall cell features and nodular hyperplasia of mild degree in non-neoplastic thyroid tissue. The tumor was well-differentiated with no mitotic activity, tumor necrosis, encapsulation, or extrathyroid extension detected, and surgical margins were free of tumor. A separate focus of papillary microcarcinoma was observed in the right lobe. One benign lymph node was identified. The report also includes gross descriptions of the specimens and a frozen section diagnosis of the lymph node as a benign lymph node.

The pathology report involves the examination of four specimens: right para-tracheal tissue biopsy, right superior mediastinal tissue biopsy, thyroid total thyroidectomy, and delphian lymph node biopsy. The biopsy results show that the right para-tracheal tissue is benign fibroadipose tissue, and the right superior mediastinal tissue has metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma consisting of a few psammoma bodies. The thyroid has multicentric papillary carcinoma, classical, tall and microcarcinoma variants. The psammoma bodies are present, and there is focal extra-thyroid extension into adipose tissue by the isthmic microcarcinoma. The surgical margins are free of tumor. One intrathyroidal parathyroid gland is involved in carcinoma, while one benign lymph node is present. The Delphian lymph node biopsy results show benign lymph nodes.

The patient has been diagnosed with thyroid papillary carcinoma of the tall cell variant. The tumor is located in the right lobe of the thyroid, with a diameter of 1.5 cm, and it has focal invasion of the perithyroidal fibradipose tissue and skeletal muscle. Sections through the remaining tissue reveal nodular hyperplasia with chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis but no neoplastic adenomas. The lymph nodes examined are benign, and metastatic carcinoma has not been identified. The diagnoses given during the intraoperative consultation are also benign.

A 1.5 cm left thyroid nodule was identified as papillary carcinoma of classical type with no necrosis and no identified mitotic activity. The tumor showed focal invasion but was completely encased in a capsule, and was present in the left lobe with an additional microcarcinoma present in the right lobe. Nodular hyperplasia was found in non-neoplastic thyroid tissue. Biopsy and excision of surrounding lymph nodes and tissue all indicated the presence of benign lymph nodes. A benign parathyroid gland was identified in the left lower parathyroid tissue. The report includes gross descriptions and summary of sections for each specimen. Intraoperative consultations also confirmed the benign nature of the parathyroid and lymph node tissue.

The pathology report describes a case of papillary thyroid carcinoma in a patient with a 7 mm nodule on the right thyroid. Several specimens were submitted including lymph nodes, a total thyroidectomy, a Delphian lymph node excision, and pretracheal tissue. The report indicates the presence of metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in three right paratracheal lymph nodes, one of which had a metastatic focus of 0.3 cm. The primary tumor, located in the right lobe of the thyroid, exhibited features of papillary carcinoma with tall cell variant and squamous metaplasia, measuring 1.5 cm in greatest diameter and partially surrounded by the thyroid capsule. Tumor markers were positive for TTF-1, PAX-8, CK7, thyroglobulin, and p63, with a proliferation index of 5-10%. The report also notes the presence of two foci of papillary thyroid microcarcinoma, nodular hyperplasia in non-neoplastic thyroid tissue, and mild chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. The surgical margins were free of tumor and there was no evidence of blood vessel invasion or extrathyrold extension. The report includes technical details about the specimens submitted and special stains used, but all diagnoses pertain to the presence or absence of cancerous cells.

The patient was diagnosed with Papillary carcinoma in the left lobe of the thyroid gland. Microcarcinomas were found in the left and right lobes as well. The tumor has a diameter of 1.2 cm and showed focal invasion but no blood vessel invasion, no extrathyroid extension, and completely surrounded the tumor. Surgical margins were free of the tumor. Nodular hyperplasia and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis were identified in the non-neoplastic thyroid. Two benign peri-thyroidal lymph nodes were identified. Pretracheal tissue was benign fibroadipose tissue. Delphian lymph node, Left lower parathyroid, and Left paratracheal tissue were submitted for frozen section consultation, all resulting in benign diagnoses confirmed in permanent diagnoses.

Clinical Diagnosis: Papillary thyroid cancer. Specimens Submitted: 1. SP: Pretracheal and superior mediastinal lymph nodes (fs). 2. SP: Total thyroidectomy. 3. SP: Delphian node. 4. SP: Right paratrachael node. Diagnosis: 1. SP: Pretracheal and superior mediastinal lymph nodes, excision (fs): -Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in 2/3 lymph nodes. -The largest node measures 0.5 cm, and the metastatic focus measures 0.45 cm. -No extranodal extension is identified. 2. SP: Total thyroidectomy: -Four foci of papillary thyroid carcinoma, follicular and microcarcinoma variants. -The largest nodule in the right lobe is encapsulated. The smaller nodules in the left lobe and isthmus are not encapsulated. -One of the microcarcinomas invades extra-thyroid fibroadipose tissue. -Surgical margins are free of tumor. -Exhibits nodular hyperplasia of mild degree. 3. SP: Delphian node, excision: Two benign lymph nodes (0/2). 4. SP: Right paratrachael node, excision: -Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in 2/2 lymph nodes. -The largest metastatic node is 0.18 cm, and the largest metastatic focus is 0.07 cm. -No extranodal extension is identified.

Clinical Diagnosis: Right thyroid nodule papillary FNA-thyroid cancer. Specimens Submitted: 1. Delphian nodes (fs). 2. Right para-tracheal lymph node (fs). 3. Pre-tracheal tissue midline (fs). 4. Rule out right lower para-thyroid gland (fs). 5. Total thyroidectomy. 6. Right paratracheal tissue. Diagnosis: 1. Delphian nodes (fs): Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in the form of psammoma body. Extranodal extension not identified. 2. Right para-tracheal lymph node (fs): Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma. Two lymph nodes examined, both with metastatic disease. Extranodal extension not identified. 3. Pre-tracheal tissue midline (fs): Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma. Two lymph nodes examined, both with metastatic disease. Extranodal extension not identified. 4. Rule out right lower para-thyroid gland (fs): Benign unremarkable parathyroid gland tissue. 5. Total thyroidectomy: Papillary carcinoma, diffuse sclerosing variant. Mitotic activity and tumor necrosis not identified. Extensive invasion of blood vessels and fibroadipose tissue. Surgical margins free of tumor. Chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis identified in non-neoplastic thyroid tissue. 6. Right paratracheal tissue excision: Benign unremarkable parathyroid gland. Intraoperative Consultation: 1. Delphian nodes (fs): Benign lymph node. Permanent diagnosis same. 2. Right para-tracheal lymph node (fs): 2 lymph nodes, both positive for metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma. Permanent diagnosis same. 3. Pre-tracheal tissue midline (fs): Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma involved one lymph node. Second lymph node cauterized with no definite tumor. Permanent diagnosis same. 4. Rule out right lower para-thyroid gland (fs): Parathyroid tissue. Permanent diagnosis same.

Summary: The pathology report relates to a patient with a history of muscle invasive HGTCC with micropapillary, signet ring, mucinous features. The report includes 9 specimens submitted, including lymph nodes, small intestine, bladder, urethra, and anterior vaginal wall. The report details the diagnosis of gastrointestinal stromal tumor, lymph node dissection with metastatic urothelial carcinoma, and the presence of benign lymph nodes, extranodal extension, and perineural invasion. The surgical margins were positive for tumor presence at the right and left ureteral margin. The bladder wall was diffusely involved by tumor, and there was perivesical soft tissue invasion. No perivesical lymph nodes were identified. The report concludes with mention of a spindle cell proliferation in the small intestine implant, and frozen section diagnosis.

Diagnosis: - Left lateral bladder wall, TURBT: Invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with muscularis propria invasion and no in situ carcinoma or vascular invasion. Some areas show extensive necrosis. - Depth of tumor, TURBT: Invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma with focal squamous differentiation, involving the muscularis propria and no in situ carcinoma or vascular invasion. - Base of tumor, TURBT: Invasive high-grade urothelial carcinoma involving the muscularis propria and no in situ carcinoma or vascular invasion. Gross Description: - Left lateral bladder wall: Multiple irregular tan-brown soft tissue fragments measuring 15x0.5x0.2cm, submitted in 5 cassettes. - Depth of tumor: Multiple irregular tan-brown soft tissue fragments measuring 13x0.5x0.4cm, submitted in 1 cassette. - Base of tumor: 2 irregular tan-brown soft tissue fragments measuring 12x0.5x0.5cm, submitted in 1 cassette.

The report describes a pT2 high-grade invasive urothelial carcinoma in a female patient who has undergone 2 rounds of BCG treatment. The specimen submitted includes various organs and lymph nodes, with the tumor infiltrating perivesical soft tissues but not the ureters. The left distal ureter presents with a benign appearance, while the right distal ureter shows mild atypia. Non-neoplastic mucosa exhibits chronic cystitis and foreign body reaction, and the female genital organs show endometrial polyp, mural leiomyomas, and hyperplasia in the ovaries. Perivesical lymph nodes do not show involvement, and the Pathologic Stage is pT3 (invasion of perivesicle soft tissue). Multiple sections are submitted for review.

The pathology report describes the results of a radical hysterectomy and lymph node dissection performed on a patient with invasive endocervical adenocarcinoma with mucinous features. The report indicates that there was no evidence of metastatic carcinoma in the lymph nodes, including the pelvic and common iliac lymph nodes, with only benign fibrofatty tissue present. The uterus and cervix showed moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with maximum dimensions of 3.5 cm, invading the anterior and posterior ectocervix and lower endocervix with equivocal lymphovascular invasion. The specimen margins were not involved by invasive carcinoma. The report mentions hyperplasia, squamous metaplasia, and Nabothian cysts, and proliferative endometrium. No gross tumor was seen in any of the lymph nodes. No other abnormalities were reported, and the report notes that the immunohistochemical tests used have not been approved by the FDA.

The reported specimen contains lymph nodes and uterine cervix. The lymph nodes are negative for cancer in A (right pelvic), B (right obturator), and C (left pelvic), but one of five lymph nodes is identified with metastatic carcinoma in D (left obturator). The uterine cervix is diagnosed with an invasive nonkeratinizing moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with lymphovascular invasion present and negative margins. The tumor measures 7.8 cm in size and the depth of invasion ranges from 1.1 cm in the cervix and approximately 2.0 cm in the lower uterine segment. Benign polyp partially involved by the tumor is also identified. Leiomyoma is found in the myometrium and fibrinous adhesions are present in the serosa. 15 lymph nodes are identified in the specimen and pN1 regional lymph node metastasis is confirmed in one lymph node. The tumor is staged as pT2a2 [IIA2].

PATHOLOGICAL DIAGNOSIS: A right parietal biopsy revealed an anaplastic astrocytoma with a loose, fibrillary background. The tumor cells tend to group together with occasional mitotic figures seen. Vascular proliferation and endothelial hyperplasia is present, but tumor necrosis is not identified. Ki67 is about 1-2%, MIB-1 is about 10-15%. Adjacent white matter and post-infiltrating white matter were also submitted for analysis, showing a transitional zone between uninvolved and involved cortex and white matter infiltrated by neoplastic cells with large, irregular nuclei.

Pathology report of a biopsy of the right temporal lobe shows the presence of an anaplastic glioma with a mix of astrocytoma and oligodendroglioma. Frozen section diagnosis confirmed glioma. The specimen shows multiple fragments of friable brain tissue with scattered calcification. Mitotic figures and vascular proliferation are present, more frequent in the astrocytoma component. The MIB-1 labeling index is about 15%. Tumor necrosis is not seen in the sections.

Filtered report: A pathology report from a brain excisional biopsy and right firm tumor excision showed a glioma with microcystic change, low histological grade, and an oligodendroglioma with atypical features and a high MIB-1 proliferation index. The tumor is diffuse, without necrosis or mitotic activity, with a fine fibrillary background, and reactive astrocytes observed in between neoplastic cells. The MIB-1 proliferation index ranges from 1% to 28%. The report suggests a low grade oligodendroglioma with areas of neovascularization and more cellular regions, which may indicate a more aggressive behavior. Immunoperoxidase stains for GFAP and MIB-1 were performed. The sample received was one fragment, 0.8 cm across, soft, grayish-white, and glistening.

Pathological diagnosis: Right temporal lobe biopsy shows an anaplastic astrocytoma, diffusely infiltrating, which was initially thought to be a small cell glioma. The neoplastic cells lack differentiation with multiple perivascular nests and infiltrates surrounding individual neurons. There is no evidence of coagulation necrosis or atypical mitosis. Additional sections were negative for lymphocytes, neuronal elements, or epithelial cells. In approximately 20% of neoplastic cells, GFAP, a protein expressed in astrocytes, was found. The electron microscope findings confirm that the cytoplasmic features and nuclei of the neoplastic cells are characteristic of a neoplastic astrocyte. The delay in issuing this report was due to the pathologist's absence and delivery of slides for consultation.

A man with a parietal-occipital tumor underwent brain mass biopsy and resection due to recent onset seizure. Pathological diagnosis for both specimens revealed a diffusely infiltrating, anaplastic astrocytoma with gemistocytic cells. Mitotic figures were found with difficulty, and no microvascular cellular proliferation or necrosis was present. The MIB-1 proliferation index was greater than 10%. Immunohistochemistry showed overexpression of p53 protein and a proliferation index greater than 10% in active areas, supporting the diagnosis of an aggressive astrocytoma.

Summary of Pathology Report: - Left frontal tumor - Pathological diagnosis: Anaplastic oligodendroglioma WHO grade III - Additional biopsy shows cerebral tissue with sparse infiltrating oligodendroglioma cells - Loss of Heterozygosity 1p, 19q assay: negative for allelic loss - Methylated MGMT promoter test: negative for evidence of methylation - Intra-operative consultation: glioma with oligodendroglial features, recommend collect blood for LOH studies - Frozen section and smears performed at and results reported to the Physician of Record - Gross description: multiple pieces of tumor biopsy in formalin fixative and residual tumor excision biopsy in formalin fixative - Histological stains performed for both biopsies including H/E, mGFAP-DA, LOH-curls, MGMT-curls, and MIB1-DA stains

The report pertains to a brain tumor located in the right parietal region of a male patient. The biopsy and excision biopsy both confirm an anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III. The tumor is moderately pleomorphic and infiltrating with irregular hyperchromatic nuclei, suggestive of a minor oligodendroglial component. There is increased mitotic activity in areas of high cellular density and a Ki-67 labeling index of approximately 10% overall, which approaches 45% focally. The R132H IDH1 mutation is positive, while the PCR for EGFR variant III mutation is negative. Loss of heterozygosity 1p, 19q assay shows allelic loss on the chromosome arm 19q and no allelic loss on chromosome arm 1p. MGMT promoter methylation is negative. The intraoperative consultation shows a high-grade glioma, and the gross description confirms the brain tumor's presence.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis of a left frontal brain tumor in a year-old man who had a new onset seizure and imaging study. Biopsies reveal that the tumor is an anaplastic oligodendroglioma with mixed cellularity and a proliferation index of 18%. The neoplasm has microvascular and cellular proliferation but no tumor necrosis. The tumor has 1p, 19q loss of heterozygosity and a positive methylated MGMT promoter. The report provides technical details of the testing and its limitations but does not include details such as patient or hospital information, treatment plan, or sample size and weight.

The pathology report describes a brain biopsy of a female patient with right frontal lobe abnormality and symptoms of headaches. The excised sample shows a moderate, cellular glial neoplasm with both atypical and elongated cells with a slight pleomorphism and diffuse infiltration of the cerebral cortex and white matter. Focally, there are hypercellular areas, perinuclear halos, and a zone of microcystic change. The MIB-1 proliferation index is about 4% in active areas. The neoplasm is a mixed oligoastrocytoma, predominantly oligodendrocytic, with intermediate mixed glioma. The MGMT promoter methylation test interpreted as negative for methylated MGMT promoter sequences. The GFAP stain suggests rather sparse glial fibrillogenesis, and the p53 protein overexpressed by about 20% of the neoplastic cells. The report provides no information on the size and weight of the samples, the patient's name, hospital, doctor, or treatment plan.

Pathological Diagnosis: A. Brain, excisional biopsy: High-grade glioma consistent with oligodendroglioma. B. Brain, recurrent tumor, excision: Anaplastic oligodendroglioma. C. Brain, recurrent tumor, excision: Anaplastic oligodendroglioma. Gross Pathology: A. Received fresh, one fragment of soft tannish-gray tissue, 0.5 cm in diameter. B. Received a 1.1 x 0.7 x 0.3 cm soft red-tan tissue fragment. C. Received a 2.5 x 2.4 x 1.0 cm aggregate of soft, red to gray-tan brain tissue. Microscopic: A. Brain fragments infiltrated by a glial neoplastic proliferation with prominent karyorrhexis, mitotic figures, and microvascular cellular proliferation. B. Portions of a solid glial neoplasm with large round nuclei, moderate pleomorphism, microvesicular change, and prominent endothelial and microvascular cellular proliferation. Mitotic figures found throughout the neoplasm. No necrosis. C. Brain extensively effaced by a glial neoplastic proliferation. Neoplasm appears to be growing in the leptomeningeal space and rarefying and gliotic the surrounding white matter. Immunohistochemistry: GFAP demonstrates numerous gliofibrillary oligodendrocytes and minigemistocytes. MIB-1 shows a proliferation index of 50% in the more active areas. Factor VIII depicts a high density of microvessels and prominent microvascular cellular proliferation. Comment: The neoplasm in the three specimens is an anaplastic oligodendroglioma with a high mitotic activity and microvascular cellular proliferation. The neoplasm appears to be growing in the leptomeninges. Tissue Committee Code: ICD9: 191.1.

The pathology report describes a case of renal cell carcinoma, papillary type I, in the right kidney of a patient with bilateral multifocal tumors. A partial nephrectomy was performed, and the excised tumor measured 5.5 X 4.2 X 2.3 cm with an adjacent incipient lesion. The tumor was limited to the kidney and invaded pT1b. No metastases were observed in regional lymph nodes or distant areas. The fat tissue overlying the tumor was found to be fibroadipose tissue with no tumor present. Two specimens were submitted for analysis - the right kidney mass and the fat overlying the tumor.

A 15 x 11.5 cm retroperitoneal mass adjacent to the left kidney was diagnosed as dedifferentiated liposarcoma. The tumor measures 25.0 cm in greatest dimension and is about 20% necrotic, involving kidney, adrenal gland, colon, spleen, and distal pancreas. The well-differentiated liposarcoma surrounds but does not invade the adrenal gland and involves colon serosa, while high-grade, nonlipogenic elements invade renal cortex. Soft tissue margins are involved by well-differentiated liposarcoma and high-grade elements, while colon margins are free of tumor. The spleen is histologically unremarkable. Immunostains performed on a block with epithelioid features are positive for CD10 and negative for AE1/AE3, CAM 5.2, EMA, and RCC. A representative section of the multilobulated mass, along with portions of the attached spleen, omentum, portion of pancreas, and a portion of colon, was subjected to processing and sectioning for further examination. The report concludes with a summary of sections submitted for analysis.

The pathology report describes the radical resection of a left upper retroperitoneal mass that includes the left kidney, left adrenal, spleen, portion of stomach, and three separate tumor nodules. The diagnosis is dedifferentiated liposarcoma, with three separate tumor nodules and a grossly estimated tumor necrosis of 20%. The tumor is composed of streaming fascicles of spindle cells and shows a divergent rhabdomyosarcomatous differentiation. The dedifferentiated component is predominantly a high-grade spindle cell sarcoma. The tumor involves the spleen, envelops around the kidney and adrenal, and extends up to the stomach. The well-differentiated liposarcoma component extends to the deep margin, and all other margins are uninvolved. The specimen is well-demarcated, with geographic necrosis and relationships identified with the margin, spleen, stomach, kidney, and adrenal. Photographs are taken, and representative tissue is submitted for permanent sections.

The pathology report is regarding a patient with a history of synovial sarcoma in the left ankle, who underwent left below the knee amputation. The report indicates that the tumor involved subcutaneous tissue, skeletal muscle, encased large nerve trunks, and invaded the talus bone. The tumor size measured 10.5 x 8.2 x 7.2 cm and was predominantly viable. However, bone and soft tissue margins were negative for the tumor. The report mentions some gross descriptions of the leg and foot, including measurements and the presence of a bulging mass at the medial aspect of the ankle. No further irrelevant information is present in the report, such as patient or doctor names, hospital name, or treatment plans. The report concludes with a summary of sections examined, including various blocks, sections, and sites.

The pathology report describes specimens received for analysis, including lymph nodes and breast tissues. The report confirms the presence of invasive lobular carcinoma in the left breast, with additional findings of columnar cell change, ductal hyperplasia, and fibroadenomatoid change, but no signs of cancer in the right breast. The report notes negative margins for carcinoma in the biopsied areas and that the sentinel lymph nodes tested negative for cancer. The report also includes immunohistochemistry results and mentions a correction to a previous error in the report.

The report describes multiple specimens and their diagnoses related to a left breast mass in a Caucasian female. The sentinal lymph nodes and margins are negative for tumor. The wide local excision pathology reveals an invasive ductal carcinoma with areas of necrosis, SBR grade III, measuring 4.0 x 3.0 x 0.9 cm. The tubular score, nuclear grade, and mitotic score are 3, and the margin is negative. ER and PR are negative with Allred score 0= proportion score 0+ intensity score 0. HER-2 is negative with intensity 1+ and 8% tumor staining. The lymph node status is 0/8, and there is no evidence of DCIS or lobular neoplasia.

The report describes specimens received for analysis, including two lymph nodes from the left axilla and a left breast lumpectomy. The lymph nodes were negative for metastases. In the left breast lumpectomy specimen, invasive ductal carcinoma and satellite invasive tumor were present, with an anterior surgical resection margin involved. In addition, intermediate nuclear grade, ductal carcinoma in situ was present. One of twelve axillary lymph nodes and one of two intramammary lymph nodes showed metastatic carcinoma. The largest confluent invasive tumor measured 2.5 cm and was located in the upper inner and lower inner quadrants. The report includes additional details about the lymph node status, DCIS and ER/PR/HER2 results. No clinical history or pre-operative diagnosis was provided.

The pathology report describes specimens received including four sentinel lymph nodes and left breast tissue. Sentinels lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. Left breast mastectomy specimens reveal multiple invasive and ductal carcinoma foci, with margins negative for tumor. The patient has an estimated 2% of ductal carcinoma in situ with intermediate nuclear grade and necrosis associated with invasive tumor. ER/PR positive, HER2 negative, with a recurrence score of 9 on the Oncotype DX breast cancer assay. Pathological staging is pT2N0. No further information is provided.

The pathology report pertains to a patient who underwent surgery for left breast invasive ductal carcinoma and right prophylactic mastectomy. The specimens removed during surgery included the sentinel lymph nodes, left axillary contents, left and right breast, left and right ovary, and fallopian tube. The intraoperative consultation diagnosis of sentinel lymph node 1 was negative, and sentinel lymph node 2 was positive for carcinoma. The left breast mastectomy showed invasive ductal carcinoma, nuclear grade 3, measuring 4.6 cm, with extensive lymphovascular invasion. The surgical resection margins were negative for tumor. No tumor was identified in the lymph nodes, left and right axillary contents, ovary and fallopian tube. The synoptic report showed that the tumor was ER positive, PR negative, and HER2 negative by FISH. The patient had a BRCA2 mutation.

The pathology report shows the specimens received for a left axilla sentinel lymph node biopsy, left breast mastectomy, an additional skin upper superior flap, and right prophylactic mastectomy. The sentinel lymph nodes #1-#4 from the left axilla are negative for tumor cells on touch prep. The left breast has invasive ductal carcinoma and ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with solid type, nuclear grade 3, necrosis, microcalcifications, and associated lymphoid infiltrate. The tumor size measures 3.5cm in greatest dimension and is located at the 12 o'clock position. There is no tumor seen in the skin and nipple region. The skin upper superior flap excision shows basal cell carcinoma superficial type, and the margins are free of tumor. The right breast has a small fibroadenoma, pseudolactational change, apocrine metaplasia, stromal fibrosis, and microcalcifications. The synoptic report shows the invasive tumor present, 0/5 lymph nodes, negative margins, tubular score 3, nuclear grade 3, mitotic score 3, modified Scarff Bloom Richardson grade, and presence of necrosis. The estrogen and progesterone receptor results are negative. The HER2 results are equivocal and confirmed as not amplified using the PathVysion HER-2 DNA Probe Kit. Biomarkers and lymphvascular invasion status will be reported in an addendum.

The pathology report describes four specimens, including three sentinel lymph nodes and the left breast, from a patient with left breast cancer. The report indicates that the lymph node excision revealed one lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma measuring 1.8mm and two negative nodes. The mastectomy specimen included a well-differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma measuring 1.5 cm and multifocal intermediate grade ductal carcinoma in situ, proliferative type fibrocystic changes, atypical ductal hyperplasia, and atypical lobular hyperplasia. Three additional lymph nodes were negative for tumor. Histological examination showed the presence of estrogen and progesterone receptors with a score of 8, indicating a positive result. The report concludes with recommendations for further testing and analysis.

The pathology report describes specimens of sentinel lymph nodes, breast tissue excisions, and a breast cyst, all from the right side. The lymph nodes are negative for tumor. The wide excision of the right breast reveals invasive poorly differentiated ductal carcinoma with lobular extension (SBR grade 3). The size of the tumor is 1.5x1.5x1.2cm, and its margins are free of tumor. The report also notes blunt duct adenosis, focal sclerosing adenosis, and focal duct ectasia. The breast cyst is consistent with a ruptured apocrine retention cyst with reactive atypia, periductal fibrosis, cystic and papillary apocrine change, and focal blunt duct adenosis. The re-excision of the inferior lateral margin shows ductal carcinoma in situ with lobular extension and high nuclear grade, stromal fibrosis, focal periductal mastitis, and cystic apocrine change with micro and coarse calcification. Notably, the invasive tumor is ductal, histologic grade 3, nuclear grade 3, with a Scarff Bloom Richardson grade of III, absent necrosis, and absent vascular/lymphatic invasion. The quantity of DCIS is less than 25%, solid type, high nuclear grade, with present necrosis. The report does not indicate any hormone receptor status or HER2 gene amplification.

The pathology report describes specimens received from a patient's right breast and axilla. The right breast had a simple mastectomy revealing a 1.8cm mass of invasive ductal carcinoma positioned in the lower outer quadrant. The carcinoma was SBR grade 3, intermediate nuclear grade, with tubular score 3, and mitotic score 3, with lobular extension and surrounding ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS). The lymph node samples taken from right axilla were negative for metastases (0/5). The left breast skin specimen had no tumor seen, and subareolar tissue had intraductal papilloma. Other findings included two radial scars, one area of usual ductal hyperplasia without atypia, lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS), biopsy site changes with fibrosis, and no evidence of vascular or lymphatic invasion. The surgical resection margins were negative for tumor. ER/PR results were negative. The report concludes with a detailed methodology of the tissue preparation, immunohistochemistry, and diagnostic dictation.

Breast tissue specimen obtained from a radical mastectomy with a grossly evident lesion of infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma, measuring 2.2 x 2.2 x 2.2 cm with no specification of tumor extent or margins. One of nine axillary lymph nodes was positive for metastasis, with no information on extracapsular invasion. Nottingham Histologic Score and additional pathologic findings were not determined. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or comments were noted.

Breast tissue checklist for excision of tumor shows a 3.5cm infiltrating ductal and lobular carcinoma lesion in the breast. One out of two axillary lymph nodes is positive for metastasis. Nottingham Histologic Score and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment cannot be determined. No further pathologic findings or comments mentioned.

Breast tissue checklist report for a mastectomy specimen indicates the presence of a grossly evident infiltrating ductal carcinoma tumor measuring 3.2cm in size without specified tumor extent, lymph node metastasis (0/5 positive), and outer quadrant tumor site. The report does not provide information on Histologic score, neo-adjuvant treatment, margins, additional pathologic findings, mitotic count, nuclear pleomorphism, and tubule formation. There are no comments in the report.

Summary: The pathology report describes a radical mastectomy specimen of the left breast with a centrally located tumor measuring 2.7 x 2.5 cm. Microscopic examination reveals infiltrating ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, with focal fibrosis and lipomatosis in ten examined lymph nodes. No venous invasion is observed, and margins are uninvolved. Total Nottingham Score cannot be determined. The report indicates no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment, and no additional pathologic findings are identified. Filtered report (excluding irrelevant information): Left breast tumor measuring 2.7 x 2.5 cm with infiltrating ductal carcinoma, moderately differentiated, and ten lymph nodes with focal fibrosis and lipomatosis. No venous invasion observed. Uninvolved margins. Total Nottingham Score cannot be determined. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings.

Mammary gland with a tumor of 1.8 x 1.5 cm. Microscopic examination revealed infiltrating duct and lobular carcinoma, G2. Five of the ten dissected lymph nodes showed metastases. Margins were uninvolved. Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined. Laterality was in the left upper outer quadrant.

The pathology report describes a tumor in the right, lower outer quadrant of a breast specimen, which was obtained from a radical mastectomy. The tumor is a moderately differentiated infiltrating ductal carcinoma, measuring 2.2 x 1.8 x 1.8 cm. There is evidence of a grossly evident lesion, but the extent of the tumor is not specified. There are 0/2 lymph nodes positive for metastasis with no mention of the presence of extracapsular invasion. The margins are not specified.
