There is no determination of the Total Nottingham Score, and there is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings. There are no comments included in the report.

The pathology report describes a radical mastectomy specimen of the right upper outer quadrant of the breast. The tumor, which was grossly evident, was found to be infiltrating ductal carcinoma and was moderately differentiated. The tumor size was 2.4 x 2.4 x 2.4 cm, and there was no lymph node involvement detected. Nottingham Histologic Score could not be determined. There was no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment, and no additional pathologic findings were reported.

Breast tissue lumpectomy from the left upper outer quadrant revealed a 2.4x0x2.8 cm moderately differentiated lobular carcinoma with grossly evident lesion. One out of ten axillary lymph nodes showed metastasis. Margins are uninvolved. The Nottingham Histologic Score cannot be determined, and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment was not specified. No additional pathologic findings were observed.

Left breast tissue mastectomy specimen shows a grossly evident medullary carcinoma measuring 2x2.5x2cm, moderately differentiated in histologic grade, without specification of tumor extent, lymph node involvement, extracapsular invasion, or margin status. Nottingham Histologic Score cannot be determined due to lack of information on tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, and mitotic count (25x and 40x). There is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings mentioned in the report. No comments were provided.

Summary of pathology report: - Squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix, non-keratinizing, G-2 with invasion of the entire endocervix and focal invasion into the upper third of the vagina - Tumor size: 3 x 4 x 6 cm, tumor thickness: 3 cm - Presence of serous cystadenoma, follicular cyst, luteal body with hemorrhages in the right ovary, and follicular cyst and fibrous bodies in the left ovary - Fallopian tubes are of normal structure - 4 out of 10 pelvic lymph nodes examined on the right show tumor metastases - Histologic grade: Moderately differentiated, Tumor extent: Lesion > 4 cm - Lymphatic invasion: Not specified, Venous invasion: Absent - Margins: Uninvolved, Evidence of neoadjuvant treatment: Not specified - Additional pathologic findings and comments: None

Summary: The pathology report describes a specimen obtained from a radical hysterectomy for a saucer-like tumor in the exocervix of the uterus. The tumor is identified as a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with superficial spread to the endocervix. The tumor measures 7 x 5.5 cm in size and 1.5 cm in thickness, and there is no evidence of venous invasion. The lymph nodes are not positive for metastasis, and the margins are uninvolved. Additional findings include small hyperemic cysts in the ovaries and hyperemia, lipomatosis, and fibrosis in examined lymph nodes. Formatted reports list the tumor extent as greater than 4.0 cm and provide no evidence of neoadjuvant treatment or lymphatic invasion.

The report describes a uterus with a tumor in the colli uteri, which is 8x4 cm and has invaded the serosa. The tumor is identified as squamous cell carcinoma, G2. Endometrial hyperplasia and leukoplakia of stratified squamous epithelium in the vaginal cuff are also noted. No pathological changes are observed in the right and left parametrium, and the examined lymph nodes demonstrate lipomatosis and sinus histiocytosis. The tumor size indicates stage T2a2 according to TNM-classification. Overall, the report suggests the presence of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with lymph nodes testing negative for metastasis and no evidence of any neo-adjuvant treatment.

Summarized pathology report for a skin tissue specimen: - Specimen type: Excision of tumor - Tumor site: Skin - Tumor size: 1.5x1x1cm - Tumor features: Ulcerated, Pigmented - Histologic type: Malignant melanoma - Histologic grade: Moderately differentiated

Pathology report for a skin tumor excision specimen indicates a moderately differentiated melanoma with Clark level III invasion. No specific tumor features or satellite nodules were mentioned. Lymph nodes, lymphatic invasion, venous invasion, margins, and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment were not specified. No additional pathologic findings were noted.

Skin tissue excision of a pigmented malignant melanoma specimen taken from the trunk area measuring 1.5cm x 0.4cm x 1.8cm with Breslow's depth of 3mm. Margin is uninvolved, and there was no evidence of lymphatic or venous invasion or neo-adjuvant treatment. No further additional pathologic findings were specified.

The pathology report describes a malignant melanoma lesion in the skin (hip area) that is 1x0x1.5cm in size, ulcerated, and pigmented. The lesion's Breslow thickness is 4.5mm, and there is evidence of tumor extent greater than 4mm, with or without ulceration. Satellite nodules, lymph nodes, and lymphatic invasion are not specified, but venous invasion is absent. Margins are uninvolved, and there is no evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment. The report indicates no other significant pathologic findings or comments.

Summary: The pathology report describes a malignant melanoma (spindle cell) with superficial ulceration on the facial skin. The tumor size is 1.2 x 0 x 2.5 cm with a Breslow's depth of 7 mm. There is no evidence of satellite nodules or venous invasion. The margins are uninvolved. The histologic grade, lymph nodes and lymphatic invasion status, and evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment are not specified.

A brownish-black, firm, invasive and ulcerated mass is found in the skin of the foot measuring about 5 x 4 x 1.5 cm. Microscopic examination shows the tumor composed of spindle or oval cells with abundant cytoplasm that often contains melanin pigment granules. The report confirms a diagnosis of poorly differentiated malignant melanoma which has metastasized to one out of the five inguinal lymph nodes. No other significant findings are reported.

Histopathological examination of a 18.6 cm segment of large intestine with a button-like tumor located in the mucosa (3.7 X 4.5 X I.2 cm) revealed adenocarcinoma tubulare (G2) and inflitrado carcinomatosa telae adiposae mesorecti. The tumor surrounds 90% of the intestine circumference, with a minimum margin of 2.1 cm. The incision lines were clear of neoplastic lesions and lymphonodulitis reactiva No XVI was present. The diagnosis is adenocarcinoma tubulare recti; tubular adenocarcinoma of the rectum. (G2, Dukes B, Astler-Coller B2, pT3, pNO, RO).

Summary: The pathology report describes a histopathological examination of a 26cm length of large intestine, mesentery and periintestinal tissue collected from a patient with clinical diagnosis of rectosigmoid junction cancer. The report confirms the presence of a 7.8cm flat tumor that infiltrates the whole thickness of the intestine and a 1.6cm tumor in the mesentery. Carcinoma infiltration is also observed in tunica muscularis and serosae flexure coli, adiposae mesenterii and mesorecti. Metastases carcinomatosae are seen in lymph nodes. The diagnosis is adenocarcinoma mucocellulare et mucinosum flexure sigmoideo-rectalis with metastases carcinomatosae in lymphonodis. The tumor is classified as G3, Dukes C, Atler-Coller C2, pT4, pN2b.

The pathology report includes three parts. In part 1, eleven right pelvic lymph nodes are removed and show no evidence of neoplasia. In part 2, seven left pelvic lymph nodes are removed and show no evidence of neoplasia. In part 3, a radical prostatectomy is performed and reveals prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+4=7. The carcinoma involves both the right and left prostate lobes with a greatest nodular diameter of 1.5 cm. Focal perineural invasion is identified but there is no evidence of extracapsular extension or angiolymphatic invasion. All surgical resection margins are free of neoplasia. Multifocal high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is identified. The patient's PSA value was 4.5 ng/mL. The T stage, pathologic, is pT2c, and the N and M stages, pathologic, are pNO and pMX, respectively. All lymph nodes examined are negative for neoplasia. The final diagnosis is prostate cancer.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a robotic-assisted radical prostatectomy. The prostate and bilateral seminal vesicles were examined and the report reveals the presence of invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 4+4=8 with tertiary Gleason patterns 3 and 5. The carcinoma involves both the right and left lobes and has a greatest nodular diameter of 1.4 cm, with extracapsular extension seen in the posterior right base region. Bilateral seminal vesicles are free of carcinoma and 10 benign lymph nodes were examined. The report notes the presence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, perineural invasion, and no angiolympathic invasion. The pathologic TNM stage is pT3a NO MX and the histologic grade is G3-4, poorly differentiated/undifferentiated. Benign prostatic hypertrophy and chronic moderately active prostatitis are also noted. The surgical margin involvement is widespread tumor involvement at margin.

Pathology report indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma, acinar type with a Gleason score of 3+4-7 involving both the right and left sides of the prostate with a 2.3 cm greatest nodular diameter. Approximately 15% of the examined prostate is affected with focal extraprostatic extension at the left anterior apex. Bilateral seminal vesicles are free of carcinoma, and all surgical margins are free of carcinoma. Multifocal perineural invasion and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia are present. The patient has a pathological TNM stage of pT3a Nx. The tumor is poorly differentiated/undifferentiated with a multifocal disease of 5-25%.

The pathology report pertains to a female patient who underwent total thyroidectomy due to papillary carcinoma of the right thyroid with follicular variant. The tumor measures 3.5 cm in maximum diameter and infiltrated the anterior soft tissue, involving the anterior and posterior margins. Four out of six lymph nodes in level IV and four out of eight lymph nodes in level IV are positive for metastatic papillary carcinoma. However, no tumor is identified in the right neck lymph nodes in levels II, III, and V. The gross description shows a 10.0 x 3.5 x 2.5 cm product of total thyroidectomy and right paratracheal node dissection, which includes the right lobe measuring 3.5 x 3.5 x 2.5 cm with nodular isthmus, a grossly unremarkable left lobe, and suspected lymph nodes in the cervical soft tissue. The lymph nodes in the neck dissection are submitted under different section codes. The patient has a history of thyroid cancer.

The pathology report describes a case of Papillary Thyroid Carcinoma. The report indicates that there is metastasis involving the cricothyroid membrane and left paratracheal and superior mediastinal tissue. The tumor is also present in the left lobe of the thyroid gland with extension through the thyroid capsule into peri-thyroidal connective tissue. There is no tumor present on the superior laryngeal nerve, right lobe of thyroid gland, or two left parathyroid glands. One lymph node is present in the thyroid nodule with no tumor detected. Three lymph nodes in Level III also have no tumor detected. Intra-thyroid lymph nodes present small nerve twigs, connective tissue, and skeletal muscle with no tumor. A frozen section of superior laryngeal nerve detects no tumor, and a frozen section of the nodule in the cricothyroid membrane indicates probable metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma with psammoma bodies involved in connective tissue with question progression onto a more aggressive form of thyroid carcinoma. A total thyroidectomy was performed, and the left thyroid lobe was replaced and expanded by the tumor. A rim of apparently normal thyroid is present with NO gross extension of the tumor outside the fibrous surrounding the mass. SNOMED codes were utilized in the consultation.

The pathology report pertains to a female patient who underwent completion thyroidectomy and right neck dissection for papillary thyroid carcinoma. The report identifies a focus of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left thyroid lobe, which may be continuous with the main tumor mass of papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right lobe extending into extrathyroidal soft tissues. Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma is noted in 10 of 23 lymph nodes with extracapsular extension. The report includes a detailed gross description of the resected tissues and lymph nodes. SNOMED codes for the diagnosis are M-80503 and T-B6000.

The pathology report describes the results of a specimen received from a patient who underwent total thyroidectomy with right neck dissection. The dominant tumor is a multifocal papillary carcinoma (2.3 cm, right, follicular variant) with a second smaller tumor (0.6 cm, right, classical variant). The report also shows the metastatic spread to several lymph nodes, including the right jugular, right posterior triangle, and right level 5A lymph nodes. The report indicates the absence of pathological diagnosis for the left lower parathyroid, thymus, and three lymph nodes. The report confirms no extrathyroidal extension present in the tumor. The report contains data on the histologic type, tumor size, and margins for the tumor. The report considers additional pathologic findings, including other papillary microcarcinomas in the isthmus. Finally, the report provides a detailed account of the specimen size, weight, and integrity, as well as ancillary studies that verified the primary tumor's identity.

The pathology report describes two specimens received: a right upper parathyroid biopsy with no pathological diagnosis and a right upper thyroid lobectomy specimen with papillary carcinoma, oncocytic variant, and follicular nodular disease diagnosed. The tumor is unifocal, encapsulated, and has minimal invasion. Lymphatic and perineural invasion is not identified, and there is no extrathyroidal extension. The primary tumor is classified as pT2, and no regional lymph nodes appear to be involved. Adenomatoid nodule(s) or nodular follicular disease, and focal thyroiditis are identified as additional pathologic findings. The gross description confirms the presence of two well delineated nodules in the upper lobe of the thyroid, with the tumor size measuring 2.9 cm in its greatest dimension. The remainder of the thyroid tissue is unremarkable, and a section of nodule and normal tissue is stored frozen.

The pathology report describes multiple findings from a thyroidectomy specimen and lymph node dissections of a patient. The thyroid gland had multifocal papillary carcinoma, with the left lobe having a dominant tumor measuring 3.2 cm and a right lobe having a smaller papillary carcinoma measuring 0.8 cm. The report also notes the presence of severe chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. No lymph node metastasis or extrathyroidal extension was identified. Multiple additional papillary microcarcinomas were also identified bilaterally. The report provides a detailed gross description of the specimens received, including their size, weight, and orientation.

Summary: The total thyroidectomy specimen showed multifocal papillary carcinoma with dominant mixed classical and follicular variant on the left lobe, with mild follicular nodular disease and chronic lymphocytic thyroiditis. Two additional papillary microcarcinomas were identified in the right lobe and isthmus. The tumor was partially encapsulated with minimal extent of invasion. Margins were uninvolved, and lymphovascular and perineural invasions were not identified. Pathologic staging showed pT1b, pNO. The adenomatoid nodule and nodular follicular disease were also present. No parathyroid glands or lymph nodes were identified. The upper and lower pole of the left lobe contained two well-delineated nodules. The rest of the thyroid tissue was unremarkable. Sections of left lower lobe nodule and normal tissue were stored frozen, and the remainder of the specimen was submitted for further analysis.

The pathology report describes a total thyroidectomy specimen with central neck dissection received for analysis, which weighs 23.2g and includes a thyroid gland with fibrous adhesions and silver nitrate paint. The left lobe contains the dominant tumor, a 3.0cm classical variant papillary carcinoma, with no evidence of extrathyroidal extension, lymphovascular invasion or perineural invasion. The right lobe contains the second dominant tumor, a 0.7cm widely invasive papillary carcinoma with evidence of capsular invasion and 2 of 7 regional lymph nodes involved by metastasis (pN1a). Additional pathologic findings include nodular follicular disease, focal thyroiditis, and a microcarcinoma in the right lobe. No parathyroid glands or lymph nodes are identified grossly. The report includes a description of the gross and microscopic features of the specimen and tumor characteristics such as laterality, tumor size, histologic type, and TNM staging.

The pathology report describes the findings of a specimen received from a patient with query right inferior parathyroid, total thyroid gland, and lymph nodes in the paratracheal and upper mediastinal regions. The report confirms the presence of widely-invasive papillary carcinoma with unusual features in the right lobe and isthmus of the thyroid gland. The report also describes the presence of lymph node metastases and cribriform and morular cells, which are characteristic of lesions associated with Familial Adenomatous Polyposis syndrome, though further clinical evaluation is recommended. Ancillary studies show positive results for thyroglobulin, TTF-1, HBME-1, and negative results for calcitonin, CD31, and CD5. The tumor is classified as a unifocal, partially encapsulated pT2 papillary carcinoma with widely invasive tumor capsule and lymph node metastases. Margins are uninvolved by the carcinoma. No extrathyroidal extension, perineural invasion, or lymph-vascular invasion is identified in the report. The report suggests additional clinical evaluation due to the presence of unusual features. The report also notes the absence of parathyroid glands or lymph nodes identified grossly. The report concludes with the quick section diagnosis, microscopic description, and staining results.

The pathology report describes multiple specimens received from the patient, including a left lower parathyroid biopsy, a total thyroid tie upper pole left lobe, and a left lower parathyroid specimen #2. The report identifies multifocal papillary carcinoma in the right thyroid lobe, follicular nodular disease with extensive degeneration and reactive atypia in the thyroid, and no pathological diagnosis in the lymph nodes, left superior parathyroid, and thymus. There is also a confirmed presence of parathyroid tissue in the frozen section slides. The report describes the tumor laterality, size, histologic type, and other descriptors of the two tumors found in the thyroid. Ancillary studies have also been conducted, including immunohistochemistry staining for calcitonin and monoclonal CEA and chromogranin, which showed positive staining for thyroglobulin in the dominant nodule. The report includes gross and microscopic descriptions and identifies additional pathologic findings, such as adenomatoid nodules and multiple papillary microcarcinomas.

Diagnosis: Metastatic papillary thyroid carcinoma in the left paratracheal lymph node (biopsy 1) and multifocal papillary carcinoma with dominant left 1.5 cm involvement including the resection margin in the thyroid (total thyroidectomy specimen). The tumor is unencapsulated with locally invasive capsular invasion, present V/L invasion, and no extrathyroidal extension. Papillary microcarcinoma is present in the left lobe (0.1 cm). There is also a benign lymph node in the right paratracheal area (biopsy 2). Pathologic staging is pT1 and pN1a with nodal metastases to Level VI lymph nodes. Tumor histologic type is classical papillary carcinoma and follicular variant.

The pathology report describes three specimens received. The first is a right hemithyroidectomy sample that weighs 24 g with a 4.7 cm dominant papillary carcinoma (follicular variant) and a 0.2 cm papillary microcarcinoma. The second is an inflamed seborrheic keratosis skin biopsy from the anterior neck. The third is a spindle cell lesion excisional biopsy from the right anterior chest, which is noted to be consistent with intravascular fasciitis variant of nodular fasciitis. The report also provides information on specimen size, weight, tumor focality, histologic type, histologic grade, margins, tumor capsule, lymph-vascular invasion, perineural invasion, and extrathyroidal extension. Regarding the spindle cell lesion of the anterior chest wall, further pathology studies will be completed. No additional pathologic findings were identified.

The pathology report describes three specimens received: left lower parathyroid, right paratracheal lymph nodes, and total thyroid. The parathyroid and lymph node biopsies did not yield any pathological diagnosis. The total thyroid specimen had a unifocal papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, 1.3 cm in size, in the left lobe. There was no lymphovascular or perineural invasion and no extrathyroidal extension. The tumor was encapsulated, with widely invasive tumor capsule invasion. The specimen weight was 7.8 g, with intact specimen integrity and tumor focality. Margins were uninvolved by carcinoma, and no lymph node metastasis was identified in 5 nodes examined. Thus, the TNM Descriptor was Not Applicable, and Pathologic Staging was based on AJCC/UICC TNM, 7th Edition. There were no additional pathologic findings.

Summary: The pathology report describes the findings from multiple lymph nodes and a hysterectomy specimen. The lymph nodes examined from various areas in the pelvis were negative for cancer. The hysterectomy revealed endometrial endometrioid adenocarcinoma with squamous differentiation and complex hyperplasia with atypia. Myometrial invasion was limited to the inner half, and the cervix had glandular involvement. Venous/lymphatic invasion was present, but no nodal involvement was noted. There were also findings of leiomyomata, epithelial inclusion cysts, and paratubal cysts. The synoptic data provided more specific information regarding the tumor size and involvement in the endocervix and myometrium. Gross descriptions of the specimens were also provided, and representative sections were submitted for further examination.

The pathology report describes a sample that includes lymph nodes from the right pelvic region and a total hysterectomy specimen with attached bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. The lymph nodes are negative for carcinoma. The uterine sample reveals endometrial adenocarcinoma of the endometrioid type, FIGO grade 3/3, with myometrial invasion present in the inner half but no lymphovascular invasion identified. The cervix is negative for carcinoma, but the tumor involves the lower uterine segment. Uterine leiomyomata are present, and the left fallopian tube has paratubal cysts, while the right fallopian tube and bilateral ovaries have no histopathologic abnormality. The TNM descriptors are not applicable, and the primary tumor is classified as pT1a (IA), with no regional lymph nodes involved. No distant metastasis is noted. The gross description of the uterine specimen reveals features consistent with the histopathologic findings, including the location and size of the tumor, which measures 7 cm in its greatest dimension and resides in the posterior endometrium.

Specimen type: Total thyroidectomy. Tumor site: Right and left lobes. Histologic type: Papillary carcinoma. Tumor size: 3.0 cm greatest dimension. Focality: Multifocal. Lymph nodes: Metastatic carcinoma in 6 of 7 lymph nodes. Extent of invasion: pT2. Regional lymph nodes: pN1a. Distant metastasis: pMx. Margins: Involved by invasive carcinoma. Venous/lymphatic invasion: Present. Additional pathologic findings: Lymphocytic Thyroiditis. Note: Parathyroid tissue found in right mid lobe.

Specimen type: Total thyroidectomy. Tumor site: Right lobe. Histologic type: Papillary carcinoma, follicular variant. Tumor size: 1.9 cm. Focality: Unifocal. Lymph nodes: None submitted. Extent of invasion: pT1 - Tumor size <2cm, limited to thyroid. Regional lymph nodes: pNx - Cannot be assessed. Distant metastasis: pMx - Cannot be assessed. Margins: Uninvolved with a distance of invasive carcinoma from nearest margin at 1mm. Venous/lymphatic invasion: Absent. Additional pathologic findings: Nodular hyperplasia, small solid cell nest (2mm), single attached histologically unremarkable parathyroid, right lobe. Left inferior para (excision): Parathyroid tissue (160mg) with attached histologically unremarkable thyroid.

Specimen type: Total thyroidectomy. Tumor site: Right lobe. Histologic type: Papillary carcinoma. Tumor size: 3 cm. Focality: Unifocal. No lymph nodes were submitted. The primary tumor was limited to the thyroid and its size was between 2 cm and 4 cm. Regional lymph node and distant metastasis cannot be assessed. Margins were uninvolved, and there was no venous or lymphatic invasion. Mild thyroiditis was observed.

The pathology report details the analysis of a right breast mass measuring 7.2 cm with a greatest dimension of 2.0 cm, later diagnosed as infiltrating ductal carcinoma, intermediate nuclear grade, with focal ductal carcinoma in situ, cribriform type, intermediate nuclear grade with necrosis. There is no evidence of lymphovascular invasion and the margins are free of tumor. Analysis of sentinel and non-sentinel lymph nodes did not reveal malignancy. Other areas of the breast showed fibrocystic changes with microcalcifications and changes from previous biopsy and therapy. The skeletal muscle showed no malignancy. Immunostains were in progress for certain samples. The report provides surgical and pathologic staging information, as well as gross descriptions of the samples.

The pathology report describes a right breast specimen from a total mastectomy, including sentinel lymph nodes and an axillary dissection. No carcinoma was seen in any of the sentinel lymph nodes, but immunohistochemistry for keratin was pending. There was invasive ductal carcinoma with a size of 2.0 cm and no lymphovascular invasion. Ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) was present and was high nuclear grade with expansive comedo necrosis, representing less than 5% of submitted tissue and with margins free of DCIS. Lobular carcinoma in situ was not identified. The tumor was Nottingham grade 2 with no response to presurgical therapy. There was no lymph-vascular invasion or dermal lymph-vascular invasion. A total of 11 lymph nodes were examined with no macrometastases, micrometastases, or isolated tumor cells. Immunohistochemistry was performed on estrogen and progesterone receptors, with positive results for estrogen (21%) and progesterone (1%) receptors. HER2 was negative. The extent of DCIS was estimated at least 5 cm with architectural patterns of solid and nuclear grade III. The histologic grade was Nottingham grade 2 with glandular/tubular differentiation score 2, nuclear pleomorphism score 3, and mitotic count score 2. Margins were free of invasive carcinoma, and the primary tumor was pT1c NO Mx with no distant metastases.

The pathology report describes a lumpectomy from the patient's right breast, axillary lymph node dissection, and additional tissue samples. The right breast mass measures 1.0 cm and contains poorly differentiated ductal carcinoma, with negative ER and PR and equivocal HER2. The additional right breast tissue inferolateral to the mass contains invasive ductal carcinoma less than 1.0 mm from the inked margin. There is no carcinoma seen in the fibroadipose tissue of the additional right breast tissue superficial to the mass. The right axillary contents show metastatic carcinoma to 19/21 lymph nodes with perinodal tumoral extension, with the largest metastatic node measuring 2.5 cm. The report provides details on tumor size, histologic type, Nottingham score, tubule formation, nuclear pleomorphism, mitotic count, margins, venous/lymphatic invasion, microcalcifications, and AJCC staging. The report also notes that the specimen and lymph nodes were inked and submitted in totality in multiple cassettes.

IGA-EW-A2FW-01A-PR. Pathologic Interpretation: A. SENTINEL NODE #1 COUNT: No malignancy seen in one lymph node (0/1). Keratin immunostain to follow. B. RIGHT BREAST, SHORT STITCH SUPERIOR LONG LATERAL: - Invasive ductal carcinoma, poorly differentiated, Nottingham grade 2 (3 + 2 + 1 = 6), papillary type, 2.8 cm in greatest dimension. - Resection margin is free of tumor; closest margin, 1.5 mm. - Lymphovascular invasion is not identified. - Ductal carcinoma in situ, high grade (DIN 3), with necrosis. - Margins are free of DCIS. - See tumor summary. TUMOR SUMMARY: Specimen: Partial breast. Procedure: Partial mastectomy. Lymph Node Sampling: Sentinel lymph node(s). Specimen Integrity: Single intact specimen (margins can be evaluated). Specimen Size: Greatest dimension: 11 cm. Additional dimension: 10 x 6 cm. Specimen Laterality: Right. Tumor Site: Invasive Carcinoma: Upper outer quadrant, Lower outer quadrant. Tumor Size: Size of Largest Invasive Carcinoma: Greatest dimension of largest focus of invasion over 0.1 cm: 2.8 cm. Tumor Focality: Single focus of invasive carcinoma. Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS): - DCIS is present. - Extensive intraductal component (EIC) negative. - Architectural Patterns: Comedo. - Nuclear Grade: Grade III (high). Glandular (Acinar)/Tubular Differentiation: Score 3: <10% of tumor area forming glandular/tubular structures. Nuclear Pleomorphism: Score 2: Cells larger than normal with open vesicular nuclei, visible nucleoli, and moderate variability in both size and shape. Mitotic Count Score 3. Overall Grade: Grade 3: score of 8. Margins: - Margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. - Distance from closest margin: 15 mm. - Margins uninvolved by DCIS. Treatment Effect: Response to Presurgical (Neoadjuvant) therapy: - In the Breast: No known presurgical therapy. - in the Lymph Nodes: No lymph node metastases and no prominent fibrous scarring in the nodes. Lymph-Vascular Invasion: Not identified. Dermal Lymph-Vascular Invasion: Not identified. Lymph Nodes: - Number of sentinel lymph nodes examined: 6. - Total number of lymph nodes examined (sentinel and nonsentinel): 6. - Number of lymph nodes with macrometastases (>0.2 cm): 0. Extranodal Extension: Not identified. Method of Evaluation of Sentinel Lymph Nodes: Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E), one level. Immunohistochemistry (PENDING). Pathologic Staging (pTNM): pT2 NO MX. Primary Tumor: pT2: Tumor >20 mm but <50 mm in greatest dimension. Regional Lymph Nodes (sn): Only sentinel node(s) evaluated. pNO: No regional lymph node metastasis identified histologically. Distant Metastasis: Not applicable. Ancillary Studies: Estrogen Receptor: Performed on another specimen. Results: Immunoreactive tumor cells present (1%). Progesterone Receptor: Performed on another specimen. Results: Immunoreactive tumor cells present (1%). Her2: Performed on another specimen. Results: Negative (Score 0). FISH for HER2/neu: NOT PERFORMED. Microcalcifications: Not identified. NOTE: Some immuno/astochesmical antibodies are analyte specific reagents (ASRs) validated by our laboratory. These ASRs are clinically useful indicators that do not regard FDA approval. These clones are used: ID5=ER, PgR 636=PR A485=HER2, H-11=ECFR. All stains used with formalin or molecular-fixed, paraffin-embedded tissue. Detection is by Emission Method. The results may be read by a pathologist as positive or negative. B: Suspicious lymph node right breast FS. C: Sentinel node #2 count FS. D: Sentinel node #3 count FS. E: Sentinel node #4 count FS. F: Sentinel node #5 count FS. G: Right breast, short stitch superior long lateral. Gross Description: A. Received fresh is one lymph node measuring 0.7 cm in diameter. Specimen was evaluated during frozen section and. submitted in one cassette. B. Received fresh is one tiny lymph node measuring 0.3 cm in greatest dimension. Submitted in toto in one cassette for frozen section. C. Received fresh is one lymph node measuring 1 cm in greatest dimension. Specimen was evaluated during frozen section and submitted in toto in one cassette. D. Received fresh is one lymph node measuring 1.2 cm in greatest dimension. Frozen section submitted in one cassette. Rest of adipose tissue measuring 1.5 x 1 x 0.5 cm, submitted in cassette 2. Both specimens submitted in toto in two cassettes. E. Received fresh is one lymph node, bisected, measuring 0.9 cm in greatest dimension. The specimen was evaluated during frozen section examination. Submitted in toto in one cassette. F. Received fresh is one lymph node, bisected, measuring 0.3 cm in greatest dimension. Frozen section submitted in one cassette. Rest of adipose tissue measuring 1 x 0.5 x 0.5 cm, submitted in cassette 2. G. Received in formalin is a 195-gram right partial mastectomy specimen measuring 11 x 10 x 6 cm. The specimen was already cut open when received. A very soft skin ellipse measuring 4.5 x 2 cm is present at the anterior surface. Nipple is present. An irregular-shaped tan-white fibrotic mass measuring 2.8 x 2.5 x 2.5 cm is present at the junction of the upper-outer and lower-outer quadrants. The mass is approximately 0.9 cm from the anterior skin margin and 2.5 cm from the posterior deep inked margin. A separate irregular-shaped tan-white nodular mass is present measuring 0.3 cm in greatest dimension, and 0.3 cm from the main tumor mass. Sections are as follows: 1. Deep margin. 2. Tumor with skin. 3. Tumor with anterior lateral and anterior inferior. 4 & 5. Composite sections of tumor. 6. Tumor. 7. Tumor with small nodule. 8. Upper outer quadrant. 9. Inner outer quadrant. 10. Lower inner quadrant. 11. Additional tumor.

The report includes two specimens: A) Paratubal cyst, excision, which shows a benign paratubal cyst and B) Cervix and uterus, radical hysterectomy, which shows a poorly differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with circumferential cervical involvement, except 0.6 cm area on posterior cervical lip, and anterior lower uterine segment involvement. The tumor size is 3.9 cm X 3.3 cm X 0.6 cm, with stromal invasion of 6 mm in 9 mm stromal wall thickness, or 67%. Lymphovascular space invasion and perineural invasion are absent. Vaginal cuff margin is negative with tumor extending to 2 mm from right anterolateral bladder flap margin. There is no parametrial involvement with six lymph nodes negative for metastatic carcinoma in both Left and Right BLN, respectively. AJCC Pathologic Stage is pT2a1 pNO. Other findings in the report indicate no specific pathologic abnormalities seen in the endometrium and myometrium.

The pathology report pertains to a 1B stage cervical cancer patient who underwent a radical hysterectomy. The report includes details about the lymph nodes in the right and left pelvic regions, the uterus, cervix, and parametrium. The histologic type is invasive non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, and the histologic grade is moderate to poorly differentiated. The tumor focality/site is in three quadrants (6-3 o'clock clockwise) of the cervix, and the size is 4.0 cm. The depth of invasion is 1.6 cm, and the horizontal extent is 2.7 cm. No lymphovascular space invasion is identified. The regional lymph nodes examined (26 in total) were negative for metastatic disease. The surgical margins were clear. The report includes additional pathologic findings related to the endometrium and myometrium. The AJCC Pathologic Stage is pT1b1 pNO pMx.

The revised pathology report states that the patient has endometrioid adenocarcinoma in the corpus and cervix, with histologic grade 2 and outer half myometrial invasion. The tumor is 1.5 cm deep and 1.8 cm thick, with 83% invasion. Lower uterine segment and cervical involvement are present, but adnexal involvement is not identified. The tumor is estrogen receptor-positive and weakly progesterone receptor-positive. The lymph nodes sampled during surgery do not show any malignancy, indicating a stage Il cancer based on the FIGO (2008 classification) Staging. The report also highlights the presence of intramural leiomyomata, atrophic right ovary, and serous cystadenoma in the left ovary. The cervix/vaginal margin status is reported to be 6 mm from the deep cervical stromal margin and anterior cervical/vaginal cuff margin. The report includes block summaries of the sections of tumor, lymph nodes, and other tissue samples that were examined. Immunohistochemical reagents were used, and appropriate internal and/or external positive and negative controls have been evaluated.

The pathology report describes excisions of several lymph nodes and a hysterectomy with bilateral salpingooophorectomy. The report reveals that the endometrium shows endometrioid adenocarcinoma with a histologic grade of III and invades the superficial myometrium up to the inner half to a depth of 2 mm. No evidence of carcinoma is identified in any of the lymph nodes examined. Immunohistochemistry results for tumor estrogen receptor and progesterone receptor are pending. The report also notes the presence of endometrial polyps and leiomyomata. No adnexal involvement is identified, and the cervical/vaginal margin and distance are free of carcinoma. The report includes detailed measurements and block summaries for each specimen received. An addendum reports the results of estrogen and progesterone receptor and p63 immunohistochemical studies, confirming the interpretation of grade 3 endometrioid adenocarcinoma.

The pathology report pertains to a patient who underwent a pancreaticoduodenectomy due to the presence of an adenocarcinoma in the pancreatic head. Biopsies from the bile duct margin, pancreatic duct margin, superior pancreatic lymph node, and aortocaval lymph node showed no malignancy identified. The tumor is moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma, with a size of 3.5 cm and peripancreatic soft tissue invasion, and perineural invasion. The surgical margins were negative except for the peripancreatic soft tissues. None of the eight total lymph nodes examined were found to have metastasis. The tumor is staged as pT3 pNO pMx. There were no remarkable findings in the gross description, and no special investigations were performed. Multiple lymph node candidates were identified, ranging in size from 0.5 to 2.0 cm, with the largest one being serially sectioned.

Summary: - Specimen type: Hemicolectomy. - Tumor site: Colon. - Tumor size: 9 X 8.5 X 8 cm. - Histologic type: Adenocarcinoma. - Histologic grade: Poorly differentiated. - Tumor extent: Pericolonic tissues.

Specimen type: Sigmoid colectomy. Tumor site: Sigmoid colon. Tumor size: 8.5 X 4.5 X 1.5 cm. Histologic type: Adenocarcinoma. Histologic grade: Moderately differentiated. Tumor extent: Pericolonic tissues. Lymph nodes: 0/8 positive for metastasis.

The specimen received for analysis is a large intestine tissue obtained from abdominal perineal resection with a tumor present at the rectosigmoid junction, which is ulcerated and identified as moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma. The tumor has not invaded the surrounding tissue, and none of the 12 lymph nodes analyzed show any signs of metastasis. The margins are found to be uninvolved, and there is no evidence of any neo-adjuvant treatment. There are no additional pathologic findings or comments related to the analysis.
Specimen type: Floor of mouth. Tumor size: 3 x 3 x 2 cm. Histologic type: Squamous cell carcinoma. Laterality: Midline.

Summary: The pathology report describes a fragment of tongue tissue containing a 4.5 cm gray-pink tumor located near the base of the tongue. Microscopic examination revealed a well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with ulceration. One of the four examined III level lymph nodes demonstrated metastasis. The tumor is of the keratinizing subtype of the oral cavity. Venous invasion is absent, and margins are uninvolved. No additional diagnosis details or comments were provided.

The pathology report describes a larynx specimen with an ulcerated white-gray dense tumor and a separate fragment of the thyroid gland that is within normal structure. The tumor is diagnosed as squamous carcinoma, keratinizing type, G-1, with no evidence of venous invasion or margin involvement. The report notes that endoscopies and figrolaryngoscopy show cancer of the larynx with the involvement of all parts of the organ.

The report describes hyperemic lymph nodes with a diameter of up to 3.5 cm in fatty tissue, which are diagnosed with diffuse large B-cell lymphoma through IHC staining. The lymphoma is found to have disseminated (multifocal) involvement and has spread to the liver and spleen. Venous invasion is absent, and margins are uninvolved. The lymph nodes in the axillary and inguinal regions are positive, with CD45 and CD20 showing a positive reaction, while CD3 is negative in the tumor cells, but positive in reactive cells. CD30 shows a positive reaction in some tumor cells.

The pathology report describes two lymph nodes with a morphological picture suggesting Non-Hodgkin's Large B-cell lymphoma. The report includes the size and characteristics of the tumor, absence of venous invasion, uninvolved margins, and immunohistochemistry data. The tumor is positive for CD 45 and CD 20cy, negative for cytokeratin pan, melanosome, chromogranin A, CD 3, and CD 10, and has up to 40% Ki67 protein in tumor cells. The diagnosis is diffuse large B-cell lymphoma of the lymph node.

The pathology report describes a Whipple specimen received, comprising a pancreas, duodenum, and gallbladder. A mass is present in the pancreas that measures 3 x 3 x 2.7cm, which is ill-defined, indurated, and likely invading the common bile duct. The mass is ductal adenocarcinoma of the head of the pancreas, moderately differentiated. Two lymph nodes are negative for malignancy out of two. The common bile duct, bile duct, and pancreatic neck margin are negative for malignancy. No significant microscopic findings and margins are specified.

The report outlines the findings of a pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple resection) procedure performed on an individual with invasive pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. The tumor, which is poorly differentiated and of the pancreatic head, measures 2.7 cm in its greatest dimension and focally infiltrates peripancreatic fat. The surgical margins are negative for malignancy, with the tumor being 0.1 cm from the nearest radial margin. While perineural invasion is present, no angiolymphatic invasion is identified. Of the eighteen regional lymph nodes examined, none are positive for malignancy. The pathological stage (AJCC 7th edition) is pT3 NO. The report also notes the absence of prior treatment and the presence of chronic pancreatitis, but does not mention any neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings beyond those outlined.

The pathology report pertains to a male patient with a right pelvic lymph node metastasis (4/11 lymph nodes) comprising both urothelial and small cell carcinoma components. The urinary bladder, prostate, and seminal vesicle exhibit high-grade conventional urothelial carcinoma (50%) intermixed with a small cell carcinoma (50%) component invading through the bladder wall and into the perivesical soft tissue, with extensive urothelial carcinoma in situ. The prostate exhibits prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 3+4=7, with focal extraprostatic extension. There is a metastatic urothelial carcinoma in one perivesical lymph node. The left distal ureter is tumor-free. The lymph nodes identified in the left pelvic region are negative for tumor. The total pTNM stage is pT3b, N2, MX for the bladder and pT3a, N0, MX for the prostate. The report includes additional details on the tumor type, grade, depth of infiltration, and distribution. The report also provides details of the specimens received and their gross description.

The biopsy sample labeled "left supraclavicular lymph node" consists of irregular pieces of fleshy tissue. The tumor cells are medium to large in size and display a diffuse pattern, with a high Ki-67/MIB1 activity. The immunoprofile shows that the lymphoma is a Diffuse large "B" cell lymphoma (DLBCL) with cells positive for CD20 and CD79a and negative for CD3, CD5, CD10, Cyclin D1, CD21, and CD23. The tumor cells are positive for BCL2 and BCL6, but negative for CD10. There is a suggestion of an adjacent follicular area with CD21 but no staining with CD10. The report notes areas of geographic necrosis, possibly due to fine needle biopsy.

Diagnosis: Glioma with loss of chromosomes 1p and 19q. Clinical history: Left frontal neoplasm. Specimens submitted: Multiple, pink-tan, soft tissue fragments, 1 x 0.4 x 0.2cm in aggregate. Representative sections submitted for frozen section and touch imprint. The remainder of the tissue submitted entirely for permanents. Cassette summary: 1 cassette for frozen section, 2 cassettes for permanents.

This pathology report pertains to a left frontal craniotomy with resection of a lesion. The specimens submitted are: A. Left frontal tumor; B. Left frontal lesion; C. Posterior margin frontal tumor. The final diagnosis for all three specimens is Anaplastic oligodendroglioma. Some portions of the tumor show a moderately cellular, round glial cells with a delicate capillary pattern, while other areas have increased nuclear pleomorphism and scattered mitoses infiltrating into the cortex, corresponding to a WHO grade III. Chromosome studies performed on paraffin blocks of the tumor showed Chromosome 1p loss and Chromosome 19q loss. The astrocytic marker p53 is negative, supporting the diagnosis. The report does not provide information about tumor size or margins. Frozen section diagnoses range from infiltrating glioma grade 2 or 3, possibly oligodendroglioma to negative for tumor seen. The report also includes macroscopic and microscopic descriptions as well as technical performing locations. Additional chromosome study results will be reported in an addendum.

Final Diagnosis: Low-grade mixed glioma (low-grade oligoastrocytoma), WHO grade II in the left frontal lobe excision. The tumor has geographically distinct areas resembling low-grade astrocytoma and low-grade oligodendroglioma. Ancillary tests including P53, IDH-1, and Ki-67 immunostains, and 1p/19q and EGFR FISH were ordered. FISH shows intact chromosomes 1p and 19q. EGFR amplification is not identified. The intraoperative diagnosis was low grade glioma, and the clinical diagnosis was left frontal brain tumor. No gross or microscopic findings were reported.

Summary: Liver biopsy negative for malignancy and intrinsic liver disease. Peripancreatic lymph node biopsy shows peritoneal cyst, benign. Stomach subtotal gastrectomy reveals adenocarcinoma, diffuse type, poorly differentiated, with 14 out of 30 perigastric lymph nodes involved by metastatic tumor (pT4aN3a). Omentum omentectomy is negative for malignancy. Tumor site is at the body, lesser curvature, measuring 6.8 cm, with tumor penetrating serosa and present lymphovascular invasion. No distant metastasis. Immunohistochemistry stains were performed with cytokeratin (MAK-6) on blocks highlighting metastatic tumor cells in lymph nodes. Tissue tested for ERPR by IHC, Her2 by IHC, and/or HER2 by FISH. ER, PR, Ki-67, p53 are reported as a semi-quantitative percentage of positively stained nuclei. Her-2/neu and EGFR are scored based on the degree of staining.

The pathology report describes the findings from a cholecystectomy, appendectomy, and total gastrectomy with proximal margin excision. The gallbladder showed benign glandular extension into the wall of the fundus consistent with an adenomyoma. The appendix was unremarkable with no dysplasia or malignancy identified. The stomach showed invasive adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated, arising just distal to the esophagogastric junction. The tumor invaded the submucosa with positive lymphovascular invasion and two of twenty-five lymph nodes showing metastasis. Margins were negative for malignancy, and there was no perineural invasion identified. Multiple fundic gland polyps and a few hyperplastic polyps were present, and the gastric antrum showed chemical gastritis with foveolar hyperplasia. The final esophageal margin showed benign esophageal wall without tumor involvement. The case was pathologic stage IIB, with the primary tumor being pT1b and regional lymph node involvement being pN1. No distant metastasis was identified.

The pathology report describes a partial resection surgery of a tumor in the right lobe of the liver, which was diagnosed as hepatocellular carcinoma with variable features, including solid and trabecular growth, desmoplastic stroma, and suggestion of glandular growth. The tumor was 4.0 cm in the greatest dimension, and the surgical margins were negative, except for a satellite nodule within 1 mm of the inked margin. The report also includes information about the gallbladder, which showed mild chronic cholecystitis, and a lymph node adjacent to the cystic duct. The report concludes with a list of immunostains used for the diagnosis and additional sections submitted for analysis.

Diagnosis: Hepatocellular carcinoma with tumor size of 18.0 cm in greatest dimension, located in the right lobe of the liver (regions 4 and 5). Tumor is Grade II (of III), unifocal, and confined to the liver with no lymphovascular space invasion. Surgical margin is negative. The neoplasm is positive for keratin CAM5.2 and Hepar, and negative for CK20. Clinical history includes a preoperative diagnosis of a right upper quadrant mass below the liver, and postoperative diagnosis of a liver mass. An 18.0 x 12.0 x 9.5 cm encapsulated, nodular mass that abuts the liver capsule is identified. Additional masses are not found. Surgical specimens consist of a 1.5 kilogram, 20.0 x 16.0 x 11.5 cm portion of liver, received with attached gallbladder. The gallbladder contains multiple yellow-tan multifaceted choleliths. Intra-operative consultation shows that the hepatocellular neoplasm is not identified on inked margin in representative sections.

The pathology report describes a total thyroidectomy specimen received for papillary thyroid carcinoma, classical type. The tumor is located in the right thyroid lobe, measures 4.2 cm in greatest dimension and extends into perithyroidal adipose tissue with focal superficial involvement of attached skeletal muscle. Resection margins are negative, and no lymphatic vascular invasion is identified. The left thyroid lobe is benign, with mild lymphocytic thyroiditis. Lymph nodes at right paratracheal lymph node level 6 are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The tumor is unifocal and the dominant tumor is on the right lobe. The tumor is a partially encapsulated, ill-defined rubbery nodule with heterogenous tan-yellow cut surface. There is no evidence of lymphatic vascular invasion. The final diagnosis is papillary thyroid carcinoma, classical type. The pathology stage is pT3, pNO, pMX. The report includes additional information on the gross description of the specimen and the microscopic examination.

A right thyroid lobectomy was performed on a patient with a right thyroid nodule. The specimen received was a portion of the thyroid weighing 10.3 g, with a 2.1 cm discrete nodule on the cut surface and additional small nodules up to 0.4 cm in diameter. Six cassettes were submitted with tissue specimens. Microscopic examination revealed a tiny incidental nodule of 0.5 cm with cytologic features worrisome for follicular variant of papillary thyroid microcarcinoma, confined to the thyroid and completely excised. There was also nodular hyperplasia, consistent with multinodular goiter, and one normocellular parathyroid gland. The case was sent out for consultation. An addendum report confirmed the incidental papillary thyroid microcarcinoma, follicular variant (confined to the thyroid and narrowly excised) and nodular hyperplasia, with one normocellular parathyroid gland present.

Diagnosis: Chronic hepatitis B with mild activity (Grade 2) and severe fibrosis (Stage 3) in the liver. Moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (3.0 cm) completely excised without evidence of endothelial-lined space invasion. No pathologic diagnosis for the gallbladder. Specimens received were an intact gallbladder measuring 7.5 x 4.0 x 3.0 cm with a patent cystic duct and a lymph node, and a portion of liver weighing 101.8 g measuring 10 x 6 x 5.4 cm with a 3.0 x 2.0 x 1.7 cm firm tan mass located 0.5 cm from the capsular surface and 1.0 cm from a blue painted resection margin. Grossly unremarkable liver parenchyma except for the mass. Sections submitted for study include the mass in relation to the capsular surface and closest blue painted margin, another section of the mass, and a section of grossly unremarkable liver parenchyma.

Sex: M. Specimen Description: A. Gallbladder at. B. Liver segment 6 at. Clinical Information: Cirrhosis secondary to ETOH with likely HCC. Diagnosis: A. Gallbladder: Cholelithiasis. B. Liver segment 6: Chronic hepatitis, mild. Cirrhosis, micronodular. Hepatocellular carcinoma, moderately differentiated, solid variant, 2.5 cm in the greatest dimension, with metastases to the portal veins and intrahepatic metastases. Tumor 0.3 cm away from the resection margin. Gross Description: A- Intact gallbladder with five irregular calculi and two palpable nodules within the adipose tissue. B- Liver segment containing a circumscribed green mass measuring 2.5 x 2.3 x 2.5 cm and a hemorrhagic mass measuring 1.0 x 1.0 x 1.0 cm, both with closeness to the surgical resection margin and liver capsule. Sectioning revealed a granular cut surface of the hemorrhagic mass.

The pathology report relates to a patient with hepatocellular carcinoma and chronic hepatitis with severe steatosis that underwent a partial hepatectomy. The resected gallbladder showed no sign of malignancy. The synoptic report shows the tumor in the liver to be well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 3.7 cm in its greatest dimension and confined to the liver without vascular invasion. The parenchymal margin was uninvolved by invasive carcinoma; however, the distance of invasive carcinoma from the closest margin was 0.1 min. The bile duct margin and other margins could not be assessed. The venous (large vessel) invasion was absent. No lymph nodes were identified. The report indicates that the surgical margin in the liver parenchyma was positive for the tumor and was ablated. The diagnosis confirms severe alcoholic hepatitis and fibrosis stage III.

The pathology report is about a female patient diagnosed with hepatocellular carcinoma. Samples were taken from multiple areas, including the gallbladder, lymph nodes, liver, and caudate lobe. The gallbladder showed cholesterolosis while the lymph nodes had no metastatic malignancy. The liver sample revealed a poorly differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma with multiple foci, a size of 15 cm, and lymphovascular invasion. There was no large vessel invasion, and the vascular margins were negative for the tumor. A caudate lobe sample showed the presence of tumor at the edge of the specimen and in small lymphovascular spaces, but the new cauterized margin was free of the tumor. The report notes that minor clear cell and multinucleated cell growth patterns were noted in the hepatocellular carcinoma.

The pathology report describes a case of colon cancer where an invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma was found in the cecum, arising from tubulovillous adenoma. The tumor had invaded the full muscle wall thickness and extended to subserosal fat with metastasis to two out of ten pericolonic lymph nodes. The proximal and distal margins of resection were negative for tumor. There was also metastasis of adenocarcinoma in liver biopsy consistent with metastasis from the cecal adenocarcinoma. The tumor size was 4 x 3.7 x 3.5 cm. The cancer was staged as pT3N1. The report recommends examining 7-14 lymph nodes for N2 staging. Grossly, the specimen consists of resected short segment of right colon measuring 15 cm in length with attached, adherent indurated adipose tissue. The tumor occludes cecal lumen and infiltrates entire colonic wall with apparent extension to subjacent adipose tissue. Multiple sections were submitted and labeled for examination.

The pathology report describes specimens received from the left kidney of a patient. Two biopsies from the left kidney showed no evidence of malignancy. The intact left kidney with perinephric fat weighed 301g and displayed a well-circumscribed, solid, white-tan mass with focal necrosis in the cortex, along with two additional masses, both well-circumscribed and solid without necrosis. A small white nodule and another solid nodule were present on the same and opposite side, respectively. Representative sections were submitted, and the diagnosis called for papillary renal cell carcinoma with multiple angiomyolipomata. The tumor did not invade the ureter, artery or vein, and surgical margins were uninvolved. Clinical investigation for a genetic disorder was advised due to the presence of multiple angiomyolipomas associated with renal carcinoma.

Specimens A, B, C, and D were received. Specimen A is a fragment of unoriented tan firm tissue measuring 1.1 x 0.9 x 0.3 cm and is negative for tumor. Specimen B contains eight lymph nodes, and Specimen C contains five lymph nodes, all negative for tumor. Specimen D is a resected prostate gland measuring 7.5-cm from right to left, 5-cm from anterior to posterior, and 4.5-cm from apex to base, weighing 91 g. The diagnosis is prostatic adenocarcinoma involving the right and left lobes of the prostate. The tumor involves the muscular wall of the left seminal vesicle and the inked left base with proximal urethral margin (multifocal). The perineural invasion is identified, but there is no definitive angiolymphatic invasion identified. The right seminal vesicle is negative for tumor, and the left is bisected to show beige tan cystic tissue. The right and left vas deferens are sectioned to show firm tan tube structure, and there is no tumor involvement. The clinical history is not given, and the pre-operative diagnosis is prostate carcinoma.

Summary: The report describes a radical prostatectomy specimen labeled A. PROSTATE, Received fresh, weighing 92 g and measuring 7 cm (right to left), 5 cm (anterior to posterior) and 4 cm (apex to base). The capsule is smooth and red. The right and left seminal vesicle and vas deferens show normal features. The diagnosis reveals the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma with Gleason score 4+3=7, involving approximately 4% of the examined gland and extending into the left seminal vesicle wall. Focal extraprostatic extension is identified as well as a margin of left posterior lateral being focally involved. Frozen performed and lymph nodes were not sampled. Pathological staging is T3b.

The pathology report describes the analysis of a prostate biopsy and two lymph node excisions. The prostate gland is 36 g and has adenocarcinoma with a Gleason grade of 5+5 involving approximately 35% of the examined tissue. Extraprostatic extensions are present at the anterior and mid base, and surgical margins at the apex, anterior, and base are positive for carcinoma. Four lymph nodes from the right pelvic and six lymph nodes from the left pelvic are negative for carcinoma. The gross description indicates the procurement of tissue samples at various levels and margins of the prostate gland, as well as the seminal vesicles, vas deferens, and lymph nodes. The clinical history and preoperative diagnosis are not provided.

The pathology report details the findings of a radical cystoprostatectomy surgical panel, with incidental foci of prostatic adenocarcinoma and invasive, high-grade urothelial carcinoma with a size of 7cm in the bladder. There was no malignancy found in ureter biopsies or pelvic lymph nodes. The bladder cancer stage was III, while the prostate cancer stage was I. No distant metastasis was identified. The pathologist examined the macroscopic and microscopic aspects of the specimen and surrounding tissues, which were submitted and labeled accordingly. Overall, the report only provides relevant medical information and excludes any patient or practitioner identifying information.

The pathology report indicates an invasive lobular carcinoma of the breast, with a well-differentiated modified Black's nuclear grade 1. The invasive lobular carcinoma measures 1.7 cm in maximum dimension. No tumor was present in three sentinel lymph nodes tested. Atypical lobular hyperplasia and fibrocystic changes were also present. In addition, a left breast excisional biopsy revealed lobular carcinoma in situ, classic type. Prognostic/predictive markers indicate that the patient is positive for estrogen receptor (90%) and progesterone receptor (80%), negative for HER-2/neu overexpression (0%), and has a high Ki-67 score (>35%, 65%). No other information is provided concerning patients, doctors, hospitals, or treatment plans.

The pathology report describes the biopsy results of multiple lymph nodes and a mastectomy specimen. The right axillary sentinel lymph node biopsies reveal metastatic carcinoma in two nodes with one measuring 2.5 mm and the other 5 mm. The third node is negative for metastatic carcinoma. The mastectomy specimen shows invasive lobular carcinoma of low to intermediate nuclear grade with an area of approximately 8 cm involved. The report also notes the presence of fibrocystic changes and atypical lobular hyperplasia in the breast tissue. One lymph node in the right axillary contents is positive for metastatic carcinoma, and additional lymph nodes require cytokeratin immunostain testing. The left breast mastectomy specimen reveals cysts and an ill-defined central fibrous area without any nodules. The report does not contain any information regarding the treatment plan. HER-2/neu FISH results are not included in this report.

The pathology report relates to an excised lymph node from the left neck of a female patient with atypical lymphocytes noted on fine needle aspiration and common variable immunodeficiency. The lymph node contains diffuse large B-cell non-GCB subtype lymphoma. The report includes flow cytometry data showing a population of mature B-cells expressing CD19, CD20, partial CD25, high-density CD38, and intermediate density lambda light chains. Immunoperoxidase markers indicate a B-cell phenotype consistent with non-GCB subtype. There is no evidence of EBERs. Clinical correlation and further classification studies are required. The report also includes a specimen request form and details of the lymphoma study protocol, which involves multiple tests.

A lymph node biopsy was received, measuring 3.5 x 3.5 x 2.8 cm. The biopsy shows diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, with CD20-positive large centroblastic cells, accompanied by lymphocytes, histiocytes, and plasma cells. The atypical cells are positive for CD20, BCL2, BCL6 and IgD, and negative for CD10 and MUM1, with Kappa light chain restriction. The small accompanying lymphocytes are CD3-positive. The Ki-67 proliferative index is 50-60%. PCR BCL2 is rearranged.

The pathology report describes a case of invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma with focal squamous differentiation in a urinary bladder specimen obtained via TURBT. The tumor has invaded the muscularis propria, and histology indicates high grade urothelial carcinoma with squamous differentiation. Lymph-vascular invasion is indeterminate, and there are additional findings of cautery artifact and necrosis. The gross specimen consists of multiple fragments of tan-pink rubbery soft tissue with a total weight of 8.1 grams, and it has been totally submitted in formalin.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent a total thyroidectomy due to papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, in the left lobe of the thyroid. A single ipsilateral focus of papillary microcarcinoma was also present. The right lobe had multinodular goiter, which appears to be benign. Central cervical nodes were negative for metastatic disease. The histologic type of the tumor is papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, and it is organ-confined and completely resected. The report also mentions a 0.3mm satellite focus of papillary microcarcinoma nearby. The margins of resection are negative, and there is no vascular invasion or distant metastasis. The specimen received for Tissue Procurement includes several nodules in the remaining parenchyma throughout the specimen, with the largest nodule measuring up to 0.8cm. Two lymph nodes and residual adipose tissue were recovered during the central cervical node dissection.

The pathology report describes a 1.5 cm papillary thyroid carcinoma in the right lobe of the thyroid, with Hashimoto's thyroiditis and multinodular goiter as background. The carcinoma is present at the peripheral resection margins. 2 out of 3 pretracheal lymph nodes are positive for microscopic papillary thyroid carcinoma. The left lobe of the thyroid shows benign thyroid parenchyma with Hashimoto's thyroiditis. The tumor is prominently calcified and has no tall cell or columnar cell features. No vascular invasion is identified, and distant metastasis is not evaluated. The report recommends clinical correlation due to focally present carcinoma at the inked resection margins. Grossly, a palpable 1 cm firm nodule is present in the thyroid, with a pink-tan irregular soft tissue fragment in the pretracheal lymph node, and a pink-tan irregular rubbery tissue fragment in the left thyroid lobe.

Prostatectomy was performed on an adenocarcinoma patient with a tumor size of 27 mm in the right posterior. The tumor has a Gleason score of 7 (primary pattern 3 with 95% and secondary pattern 4 with 5%), and there is no evidence of high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. The cancer has invaded the seminal vesicle, and the closest distance to the surgical margin is 1 mm in the right posterior. Lymph nodes were also sampled, and the pathologic stage is pT2c, NX, MX. Histologic type, variant histology, prostate size, and other histologic findings are not mentioned. The gross description includes the size, weight, and inked margins of the specimen, while the microscopic description is not provided in the report.

Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma, conventional type, involving both lobes of prostate, with focal extracapsular tumor extension present in left posterior region. High grade PIN is present, but perineural space invasion and lympho-vascular space invasion are absent. Surgical margins are negative. Lymph node dissection reveals three benign hyperplastic lymph nodes. Benign prostatic hyperplasia is also identified. PTNM stage is pT3aN0, MX. No metastatic carcinoma is found in lymph nodes.

Diagnosis: Benign hyperplasia in right and left pelvic lymph nodes. Carcinoma in radical prostatectomy specimen with adenocarcinoma, conventional type histologic type, Gleason grade of 7/10 (primary pattern 3/5, secondary pattern 4/5), involving both lobes, approximately 25% of the specimen, left seminal vesicle involvement, lympho-vascular and perineural space invasion, and high-grade PIN. Negative surgical margins at bladder neck, apical (inferior), and inked prostatic margin. Lymph node examination: 2 nodes examined, no metastatic carcinoma. pTNM stage: pT3b, NO, MX. Benign bladder neck tissue. Frozen section consultations confirmed all three diagnoses.

The pathology report is of an excision biopsy sample of a prostate gland and both right and left pelvic lymph nodes. The prostate gland weighs 35 grams and shows a moderately ill-defined firm area of pale discoloration measuring 1.5 cm in its mid aspect of the left posterior prostate, indicating prostatic adenocarcinoma with bilateral involvement of the seminal vesicle and vasa deferentia. The Gleason score is 4+3=7, and the percent of prostate involvement is estimated to be 25%. No lymphatic or venous invasion is seen. The right pelvic lymph node is benign, while the left pelvic lymph nodes are benign (x 2). The pathological stage is pT3b pNO. The tissue is taken for the Cancer Genome Atlas Project.

The pathology report concerns a case of prostate cancer in a male patient. The report indicates the presence of prostatic adenocarcinoma in the right lateral margin and in the main resection. The tumor occupies about 10-20% of the prostate volume and has a Gleason score of 7/10. Focal extraprostatic extension is present, and perineural invasion is also observed. No seminal vesicle involvement or lymphovascular space invasion is identified. The lymph nodes examined are negative for metastatic carcinoma. The staging of the tumor is pT2cN0. A total of five lymph nodes are examined, and four are identified as possible bisected lymph nodes. The report also describes the specimens submitted for examination, including yellow-tan fibrofatty soft tissue, pink-tan irregular soft tissue, and a 40.9-gram prostate. The report notes that a 2.5cm nodule suggestive of a lymph node is discovered and submitted for analysis. Additionally, genomic research is conducted on samples submitted in yellow, green, and blue cassettes.

The addendum report clarifies that no lymph nodes were identified in the specimen. The diagnosis is radical prostatectomy for prostate and pelvic lymph nodes, which reveals the presence of adenocarcinoma. The tumor involves both lobes and approximately 5% of the sampled tissue. It has a Total Gleason Score of 7/10. High-grade PIN, extraprostatic tumor extension, and perineural invasion are present. The surgical margin status indicates positivity at the apical/inferior site and at the right prostate adjacent to the right seminal vesicle. Lymphovascular space invasion is not identified, and TNM staging is T3b NX MX. The clinical history suggests preoperative diagnosis of prostate cancer with symptoms/radiologic findings. The specimen received is a 4.5 cm x 4.0 cm prostate gland with nodularity, and no lymph nodes are present. Additionally, benign prostatic hyperplasia, chronic prostatitis, and a focal organizing thrombus are identified. The overall comment is that there is extensive tumor in the section adjacent to the right seminal vesicle with extraprostatic extension in that section.

Filtered report: - Diagnosis: Bilateral prostatic adenocarcinoma with extensive capsular penetration, seminal vesicle invasion, and positive surgical margin. - Gleason sum score: 3+4=7/10. - Tumor characteristics: Largest tumor located on the left/posterior with estimated volume 3.5 x 2.0 x 1.0 cm. Proportion of prostate involved by tumor: 17%. - Pathologic stage: pT3b. - Pelvic lymph nodes: Bilateral excision shows one lymph node positive for metastatic prostatic adenocarcinoma (1/8). - Additional findings: Acute and chronic inflammation.

Prostate gland, radical prostatectomy. Histologic type is adenocarcinoma. Malignancy is identified in the left lobe only and accounts for less than 5% of the total prostate volume. Gleason grade is 6/10 (primary pattern=3/5, secondary pattern=3/5). Extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, and lymphovascular space invasion are not identified. High-grade PIN and treatment effect are not identified. Margins uninvolved. No lymph nodes received. pTNM stage is pT2a, NX. The prostate is received with attached bilateral adnexa and shows an ill-defined mass involving the posterior quadrants. The mass approaches the inked capsule and is present at the prostate/seminal vesicle junction. Gross extension of this lesion into the seminal vesicle is not appreciated. Additional masses or calculi are not identified. Representative sections are submitted in cassettes 1-18. Clinical history and symptoms/radiologic findings are not explicitly stated.

Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma of the prostate with 85% involvement. Gleason score of 8/10 (primary pattern: 4/5, secondary pattern: 4/5). Lymphovascular space invasion and high-grade PIN are present. Adenocarcinoma present at the inked margin of the base of the prostate gland. Bilateral pelvic lymph nodes examined, with one lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma measuring less than 0.1 cm confined to the subcapsular sinus. pTNM Stage: pT2c, N1, MX. Two specimens received: A) 51.3 g prostate gland with attached bilateral adnexa, B) aggregate of yellow-tan lobulated fibroadipose tissue containing multiple lymph nodes, which are entirely submitted for examination.

The pathology report indicates that the patient underwent surgical excision of the pelvic lymph nodes and prostate due to a preoperative diagnosis of prostate cancer. The lymph nodes were negative for metastatic disease, and the prostate exhibited features of prostatic adenocarcinoma with a total Gleason score of 7/10 and a tumor volume occupying roughly 15 to 20% of the prostate volume. No extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle involvement, lymphovascular space invasion, or high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia was identified. The surgical margin status was uninvolved, and nodular hyperplasia was also present. The pTNM stage was determined to be pT2c, NO. The pelvic lymph nodes and prostate were separately received in formalin-labeled containers, and representative sections were submitted for pathological analysis.

The pathology report describes a case of moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma that invades the right hemiglossectomy to a depth of 3 cm and extends to the inked deep margin. There is no definite angiolymphatic invasion found, and the posterior margin is greater than 2 cm from the tumor. However, the medial margin is 0.5 cm from the tumor. The new deep margin with OR consultation does not identify any tumor. Level 1b submandibular gland shows no evidence of metastatic carcinoma, but Level 1a, Level 2a, and Level 3 nodes show evidence of metastatic squamous cell carcinoma in one of the lymph nodes each. The tumor exhibits intranodal carcinoma with measurements ranging from approximately 0.2 to 0.5 cm in greatest dimension. The AJCC pathologic stage is T2,N2. The clinical information of the case is right tongue squamous cell carcinoma, and the frozen section diagnosis indicates that the hemiglossectomy's deep margin is focally involved by carcinoma, while the medial margin is free of tumor. A deep lateral ill-defined white mildly nodular area measuring 2 X 0.5 cm is also noted on the tongue's surface. The report also includes details of other specimens submitted for examination.

The pathology report confirms moderately-differentiated keratinizing invasive squamous cell carcinoma in the lateral floor of the mouth, with a tumor size of 5.3 cm in the greatest dimension that invades through the anterior mandible and into the subcutaneous soft tissue. All margins are negative for the tumor except inferior soft tissue with 0.8 cm distance. No tumor is identified in the lymph nodes except for the mentioned site. The gross description includes the size and inked margin of the specimen, and all necessary sections are submitted for examination. The frozen section diagnosis shows negative results for tumor on the submitted margins. Clinical information confirms oral cancer of the floor of the mouth, and there is an additional tissue requested for research purposes.

The pathology report describes a sample collection relating to a case of stomach cancer. The patient's age and sample size are not mentioned. The tumor is found on the stomach and is categorized as adenocarcinoma, mucinous type, with a pathological stage of T2b. The macroscopic tumor configuration is identified as Borrmann type I and type I (protruded and polypoid). Multiple nodules of the tumor are found within perigastric fat, and the cancer has spread to the lymph nodes with N3 staging. No mention of treatment is given. A slide URL is provided for further examination. The report does not include any patient or doctor identification and ends with histology comments.

The pathology report describes the sample collection and details of a tumor found in the GAST site, with information on the year, age of the patient, and number of days to the procedure. The primary tumor type is adenocarcinoma with a size of 6cm and histology grade of II. The report includes a URL for the histology slide image, but no other comments or information relevant to training a vision language model like CLIP.

The pathology report describes specimens obtained during surgery for a patient with cervical cancer, including lymph nodes and uterine tissue. The uterus and cervix specimen shows an 8cm squamous cell carcinoma with 1.5cm depth of invasion and involving the endometrium, with lymphatic invasion present. Margins were uninvolved by invasive carcinoma, but chronic endometriosis was noted. Lymph nodes were reactive in all regions evaluated. No parametrial or vaginal involvement was seen, and there were no non-lymph node metastases. The appendix had no abnormalities. The report also includes detailed descriptions of each specimen received for analysis.

The pathology report describes three specimens - left and right pelvic lymph nodes and prostate with seminal vesicles. No tumors were found in 5 out of 5 left pelvic lymph nodes and 2 out of 2 right pelvic lymph nodes. The prostate and seminal vesicles specimen showed prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason's score of 9 (5+4). The tumor involves both lobes, with the right side extending to surrounding muscles and nerves but with negative inked margins. No angiolymphatic invasion was identified, but perineural invasion and extracapsular extension were observed. The tumor was found to involve the right posterior inked margin, and both left and right seminal vesicles had positive results for tumors. The tumor involves 80% of the tissue examined and is classified as pT3b NO Mx.
