Additionally, there is a second sample type listed as BUFFY, but no further information is given regarding this sample.

Summary: The pathology report describes a glial neoplasm identified as Oligodendroglioma grade III. The MIB-1 labeling index, which measures tumor cell proliferation, is elevated up to 18.8%, indicating early anaplastic progression in an otherwise low-grade tumor. Microscopic examination shows a diffuse infiltration of gray and white matter by mildly to moderately hypercellular tumor with round mildly atypical nuclei, small nucleolus, prominent perinuclear halos, and perineural satellitosis. There is no microvascular proliferation or necrosis, and mitotic figures are not seen.

The pathology report describes a hypercellular astrocytic neoplasm infiltrating cortical grey matter with significant nuclear atypia and gemistocytic differentiation. Pervascular lymphocytes are occasionally present, but there is no evidence of microvascular proliferation or necrosis. The tumor is diagnosed as an anaplastic gemistocytic astrocytoma, grade III.

Summary: The pathology report describes a moderately hypercellular diffusely infiltrating glial neoplasm, diagnosed as an Oligodendroglioma, grade II. MIB-1 reactive cells are scattered throughout the sections, and a labeling index of 4.2% is calculated in the most proliferative areas. The tumor cells have moderate atypia and round nuclei, most with perinuclear halos. No mitotic figures are seen, and there is no microvascular proliferation or necrosis.

Diagnosis: Left temporal brain tumor. Anaplastic astrocytoma, grade 3. P53: focally positive. IDH1: Negative. MIB-1 LI: 13.3%. Discussion: The neoplastic cells are negative for IDH1 with a minority expressing p53. MIB-1 -. reactivity areas are seen within the tumor but in the most proliferative areas a labeling index of 13.3% is calculated, consistent with a high grade astrocytoma. Microscopic Description: Sections demonstrate a diffusely infiltrative astrocytic neoplasm. Atypia ranges from. mild to moderate. There is mild to moderate hypercellularity. The tumor cells resemble. fibrillary astrocytes. Some areas are suggestive for perinuclear halos. A rare mitotic figure is observed. There is no microvascular proliferation or necrosis.

A specimen of subtotal gastrectomy measuring 19.5cm and 12.0cm on the greater and lesser curvatures respectively was submitted for a patient diagnosed with adenocarcinoma. The tumor, located on the lower 1/3 of the stomach, was 4.0 x 3.5cm in size and classified as moderately differentiated AGC (Borrmann type) I+II. There was no gross serosal invasion. The tumor type was adenocarcinoma-tubular, moderately differentiated, with T3 depth of tumor invasion without involvement of adjacent structures. Lymphatic invasion was present, as was perineural invasion, and there was metastasis in 1-2 regional lymph nodes out of a total of 46. The special stain Cresyl Violet revealed many H. pylori. The final diagnosis is advanced gastric cancer.

Summary: The stomach specimen shows advanced gastric carcinoma in the lower third, center at the antrum, and lesser curvature. The gross type is Borrmann type 2 (ulcerofungating), and histologic type is adenocarcinoma, tubular moderately differentiated (tub2), with an intestinal growth pattern. The tumor size is 8.7x8.0cm and invades the subserosa (pT3), with mild venous invasion. No lymph node metastasis is present in 27 regional lymph nodes (pNO), and lymphatic and perineural invasion are not identified. The resection margin is free from carcinoma with adequate safety margins. CD10, MUC2, MUC5AC, MUC6, and cERB2 are evaluated with immunohistochemistry, and biopsy shows no tumor in the anvil ring.

SUMMARY: The report describes a specimen of a distal gastrectomy measuring 25.1 cm in the greater curvature and 17.4 cm in the lesser curvature, with a tumor located in the middle 1/3 of the stomach's posterior wall, measuring 2.5 x 2.4 cm. The tumor is classified as EGC I tubular moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with submucosal invasion. Lymphovascular invasion is present, while venous and perineural invasions are absent. The tumor is classified as being of the infiltrative type with an intestinal Lauren classification. No lymph node metastasis is detected, and several lymph nodes are characterized as having no tumor present. Cresyl Violet stain reveals no H. pylori.

Pathology report summary: A laparoscopic distal gastrectomy and cholecystectomy were performed on a patient diagnosed with stomach cancer. The tumor was located on the anterior wall side of the mid-antrum, measured 3.0 x 3.0 x 1.3 cm, and was classified as Adenocarcinoma, Diffuse type. Lymphatic metastasis was present in 5 out of 43 lymph nodes. The gallbladder had cholelithiasis and autolysis. No other relevant information was provided.

Diagnosis: Brain, left occipital lobe biopsy and resection revealed a diffuse astrocytoma, WHO grade II. The lesion primarily displays astrocytic features with labeling of fibrillary cytoplasmic processes. Mib-1 labeling index is less than 2%. The immunoexpression of R132H mutant IDH1 is present. The material will undergo further cytogenetic and molecular testing. The diagnoses given during intraoperative consultation were also glioma.

The pathology report describes two specimens labeled as "Right temporal brain tumor" and "Right temporal brain tumor #2", both of which are diagnosed as Diffuse Astrocytoma (WHO-II) with MIB-1 reactivity less than 3%. Intraoperative consultation confirms low-grade Astrocytoma on representative sections. No additional information such as patient name, doctor name, or hospital name is provided. The sample size, shape, and weight are excluded as requested. Special studies involving MIB-1 (Ki-67) are negative. The specimens are entirely submitted for frozen section and are entirely submitted for permanent diagnosis.

The pathology report indicates the diagnosis of invasive moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma in the head of pancreas, distal stomach, duodenum, gallbladder, pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple procedure), cholecystectomy, and appendectomy with a size of 2.8cm, mild dysplasia, and perineural and lymphovascular invasion. Four out of twenty-six lymph nodes have tested positive for metastasis. The final tumour staging summary reveals a primary tumour of pT2, pN1 regional lymph nodes, and pathologic stage IIB. Chronic pancreatitis, chronic cholecystitis, and PanIN-3 are other findings. Acute and chronic pancreatitis are present. The report lists additional pathologic findings such as islet cell hyperplasia. Margins were negative for invasive carcinoma except for mild dysplasia at the common bile duct margin.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: A. Gallbladder, chronic cholecystitis. B. Peri-portal lymph node, negative for metastatic disease. C. Perigastric lymph node, negative for metastatic disease. D. Distal margin of pancreas, severe chronic pancreatitis, malignancy not identified. E. Pancreas/duodenum, adenocarcinoma, moderately differentiated. Tumor site: pancreas with extension into ampulla. Tumor size: 2.8 x 2.2 x 1.7 CM. Lymphovascular space invasion and perineural invasion not identified. Surgical margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Lymph node status: p T3N1. Other significant findings: chronic pancreatitis.

Clinical Information: Cancer in the head of the pancreas with malignant-appearing structure of the common bile duct and a double duct sign. Diagnosis: A. Cholecystectomy: Chronic cholecystitis. B. Node Of Importance: One lymph node negative for carcinoma (0/1). C. Pancreaticoduodenectomy (Whipple resection), Partial Pancreatectomy: Ductal adenocarcinoma. Site: pancreatic head. Size: 2.4 cm. Grade 2. Tumor invades retropancreatic soft tissue. Margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma. Distance of invasive carcinoma from closest margin: 0.5 mm (nonperitonealized retropancreatic uncinate margin). Lymph-vascular invasion identified. Perineural invasion identified. Three out of 12 lymph nodes directly invaded by the tumor (3/12). Pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia (PanIN-2). Chronic pancreatitis. Gross Description: A. Gallbladder measuring 9.5 x 4.5 x 1.6 cm. The cystic duct is short. The gallbladder is closed. After opening, it is filled with green bile and no calculus. The wall thickness is 3 mm. B. Node of importance: One lymph node measuring 2.6 cm in diameter. C. Whipple's specimen: Duodenum measuring 19.0 cm in length and 5.0 to 6.0 cm in circumference, portion of gastric tissue 2.5 cm in length, common bile duct measures 5.3 cm in length and 1.6 cm in circumference. There is stenosis of the common bile duct 1.7 cm distal from the ampulla of Vater. The pancreas measures 5.0 x 2.5 x 2.0 cm, with a not well-demarcated tumor measuring 2.4 x 2.0 cm in the pancreatic head that invades retropancreatic soft tissue, and three out of twelve lymph nodes are directly invaded by the tumor.

The pathology report pertains to a patient with pancreatic cancer in the head of the pancreas, who underwent a Whipple's procedure. The report contains information on the resected lymph nodes, gallbladder, duodenum, pancreatic resection margin, common bile duct, and mesocolon lymph nodes. The pancreatic tumor was moderately differentiated invasive ductal adenocarcinoma with mucinous features, positive for perineural and lymph-vascular invasion, and with foci of pancreatic intraepithelial neoplasia. Common bile duct mucosa was also focally involved by carcinoma. Three out of fifteen peripancreatic lymph nodes were positive for metastatic carcinoma. The specimen was verified by a responsible resident, and a synoptic report was prepared. Frozen section diagnosis of retroperitoneal margin was negative for carcinoma. The final diagnosis was invasive moderately differentiated ductal carcinoma of the pancreas with involvement of the duodenal muscularis mucosae, ampulla of Vater and common bile duct. The cancer was present at the vascular bed resection margin and within 0.6 cm of the pancreatic resection margin, and 0.15 cm of the posterior resection margin. The distal common bile duct was denuded of epithelium, likely due to instrumentation.

Summary: The pathology report indicates an excision of a tumor from the esophagus. The tumor measured at 3 x 3 x 1.2 cm and was identified as a moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma. The tumor was found in the adventitia with no evidence of lymph node metastasis. Lymphatic and venous invasion, as well as neo-adjuvant treatment effects, were not specified or mentioned in the report. Margins were uninvolved, and there were no additional pathologic findings or comments provided.

The pathology report describes a resected tumor in the esophagus measuring 4x2x1.5cm, which is identified as moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma extending to the adventitia with involved margins. No lymphatic or venous invasion is specified. Of the two lymph nodes examined, none showed regional metastasis. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment or additional pathologic findings are noted. The tumor is located distally.

Summary: The pathology report describes a tissue specimen from the esophagus of a patient with a 6.5 cm grey-white tumor of the keratinizing subtype, which is well-differentiated with ulceration. The tumor extends to the muscularis propria without venous invasion, and margins are uninvolved. Two paraesophageal lymph nodes and eight lymph nodes along the a. gastrica sinistrae were examined, of which three showed metastasis. Other lymph nodes demonstrated anthracosis and follicular hyperplasia. No evidence of neo-adjuvant treatment was seen. Tumor location was lower third of esophagus.

The pathology report describes several excised specimens from a patient with invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, poorly differentiated/undifferentiated. Specifically, the report includes multiple lymph node excisions, a posterior vaginal margin excision, and a radical hysterectomy with bilateral tubes and ovaries excision. Among the lymph node excisions, there were benign lymph nodes identified, Lymph Node 1 and 2 involved endosalpingiosis, and all other lymph nodes were benign. The posterior vaginal margin excision showed invasive squamous cell carcinoma, poorly differentiated, with an ulcer in the proximal portions of the tissue. The radical hysterectomy revealed invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the uterine cervix, poorly differentiated/undifferentiated, with a tumor thickness of 8 mm out of 12 mm, and no evidence of tumor multicentricity, vascular or perineural invasion or parametrial involvement. Additionally, the surgical margins were free of tumor, and the lymph node status was benign. An incidental adrenal rest and occluded blood vessels were identified in the right parametrium.

DIAGNOSIS: 1) Uterus, cervix, bilateral tubes, and ovaries resection - high-grade leiomyosarcoma (10cm) involving the anterior uterine wall with vascular invasion. Uterine serosal surface is not involved by the tumor. Atrophic endometrium. Benign left ovary with serous cyst (2cm), left tube with benign paratubal cyst, and benign right ovary and tube. 2) Benign smooth muscle - biopsy of bladder posterior wall. 3) Benign smooth muscle - biopsy of left posterior bladder wall. 4) Benign fibroadipose tissue - biopsy of bladder dome.

Summary: The patient underwent a thyroidectomy and lymph node biopsies due to a papillary carcinoma of the thyroid. The tumor was unifocal and measured 6.5 cm in the greatest dimension. The cancer had metastasized to 12 lymph nodes out of 19 examined and had lymphovascular invasion present. There was no evidence of perineural invasion or extrathyroidal extension. Additionally, a diagnosis of lymphocytic thyroiditis was made in the right thyroid lobe. The left and right paratracheal tissue biopsies were inconclusive, and the left paratracheal lymph node biopsy had three lymph nodes with metastatic papillary carcinoma. Furthermore, there were four of seven lymph nodes in the central compartment and four of eight lymph nodes in the left lateral jugular that tested positive for metastatic papillary carcinoma. The report does not state any further information regarding the treatment plan or outcomes.

Microscopic diagnosis: uterine mass biopsy consistent with leiomyosarcoma, poorly differentiated (grade 3), with lymph-vascular invasion, present necrosis (extent approximately 15%). Margins not assessed due to unattached tumor fragments. Ancillary studies indicate smooth muscle actin, desmin, and Caldesmon immunoreactive for tumor cells, but no pankeratin immunoreactivity. The tumor invaded more than half of myometrial thickness and reached the serosa in multiple areas. Bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes were uninvolved by the tumor. The vermiform appendix shows no involvement of appendix proper by leiomyosarcoma, but with leiomyosarcoma present in blood coagulum adherent to the external surface of the appendix. No tumor identified in the adhesion of anterior abdominal wall peritoneum. The pathology stage was pT2b and pNo is 0/2, utilizing CAP soft tissue sarcoma scheme. The tumor is located in the uterine corpus with a size of 29.0 cm in greatest dimension, histologic grade of 3, and poor differentiation. Immunohistochemistry tests were performed with the result that the tumor cells were immunoreactive for desmin, smooth muscle actin, and Caldesmon, but not for pankeratin.

The pathology report describes three biopsies: an endometrial biopsy and two cervical biopsies. All three biopsies show invasive adenocarcinoma that has an endocervical origin, based on immunohistochemical stains. The report recommends clinical correlation. The patient has a medical history of abnormal uterine bleeding and an enlarged cervix. The biopsies are submitted in toto, and the gross description provides their size and color. The report mentions that an intradepartmental consultation was done and a staff pathologist reviewed the case. No treatment plan, patient or doctor's names, hospital name, or sample details are provided.

Final diagnosis: A. Left pelvic lymph nodes: No tumor seen in 9 of 9 lymph nodes. B. Right pelvic lymph nodes: Metastatic carcinoma seen in 1 of 5 lymph nodes. C. Bladder, prostate, seminal vesicles, vas deferens: Invasive carcinoma, high grade, left trigone, urinary bladder with squamous differentiation extensively present. Tumor size: 2cm. Histologic grade: 3/3. Extravesicular mass macroscopically present. TNM stage: pT3b, pN1, pMX. Additional findings: D. Left ureter margin is inked FS: Tumor present. E. Right ureter margin is inked FS: No tumor seen. F. Left ureter margin #2 FS: Dysplastic urothelium. G. Left ureter margin #3 FS: No tumor seen. Clinical information: Prepared for bladder cancer. Gross description: Radical cystectomy specimen with attached fat, bladder opened anteriorly, left trigone remarkable for a 2 x 1.5 x 1 cm deep ulcerated mass with invasive carcinoma. Procedure: Multiple H&E blocks prepared for each specimen.

The report indicates metastatic carcinoma in one left pelvic lymph node, with no tumor present in the other lymph nodes. The prostate gland contains a single focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma, with a Gleason score of 9 and tumor extending into extraprostatic tissue and the margin of resection. The right and left seminal vesicles and vasa deferentia are free of tumor. Further details are provided in the report, including gross description and section codes. The report also notes that some tests reported may not have been specifically cleared or approved by the FDA.

The pathology report pertains to a male patient diagnosed with prostate cancer. The report includes a gross description of left and right pelvic lymph nodes and a supplemental report on the prostate and seminal vesicles. The left and right pelvic lymph nodes examined respectively showed five and twelve lymph nodes, and no tumors were detected. The diagnosis for the prostate and seminal vesicles is prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 9 (4+5). The tumor is present in the peripheral and transition zone, and there is a second tumor focus of lower histologic grade confined to the prostate. The report indicates no tumor involvement in the segments of the right and left vasa deferentia, no lymphovascular invasion identified, and margins of resection are free of tumor.

The report contains information on a patient with prostate cancer. A metastatic adenocarcinoma was found in one of thirteen lymph nodes in the right and left pelvic area. The prostate and seminal vesicles have prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score 9 and tumor extending into extraprostatic tissue. There is perineural and lymphovascular invasion present. The margins of resection are free of tumor. The prostate gland contains two foci of prostatic adenocarcinoma, one in the peripheral zone and one in the transition zone. The second tumor is located in the right transition zone. The seminal vesicles and segments of the vasa deferentia are grossly free of tumor.

The pathology report indicates metastatic adenocarcinoma in both right and left pelvic lymph nodes, with extranodal extension and foci measuring less than 1.0 mm to 13.0 mm. The report also notes high grade prostatic adenocarcinoma involving smooth muscle at the anterior bladder neck margin. Further information regarding the prostate and seminal vesicles will be provided in a supplemental report. The addendum section reveals that the prostate gland contains a single focus of prostatic adenocarcinoma, with extensive multifocal extraprostatic extension and invasion of the right seminal vesicle. The tumor invades the margin of resection on the anterior and right apical region. The report provides no information about the patient's clinical history.

The report is an addendum to a pathology report, which provides a diagnosis of prostate adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 7 (4+3), extending focally into extraprostatic tissue, and extending to the margin of resection. The report notes that the prostate gland contains three foci of prostatic adenocarcinoma, one in the transition zone and two in the peripheral zone. The dominant tumor focus is in the right and left transition zone and measures 3.0 x 1.5 cm in the largest cross-sectional dimension. The report also mentions that the two peripheral zone foci are located in the left posterolateral and right lateral peripheral zone, and the non-dominant tumor foci are of lower histologic grade (Gleason score 6/3+3) and confined to the prostate with negative margins. Nineteen benign lymph nodes are identified in the bilateral pelvic lymph nodes. The report concludes by providing a gross description of the prostate and seminal vesicles.

The report pertains to a case with prostatic adenocarcinoma that has metastasized to one lymph node out of four in the left pelvic region. The tumor measures 2.3 x 1.5 cm in the largest cross-sectional dimension and extensively invades both right and left seminal vesicles including intra and extraprostatic portions. The tumor affects the left posterolateral surface of the prostate and left superior neurovascular bundle region. The extent of extraprostatic extension is 3.5 mm, extends into perivesicular soft tissue, and focally to the margin of resection up to 1.0 mm. The prostate gland measures 4.2 x 3.7 x 3.3 cm and has the usual shape. The seminal vesicles and segments of the vasa deferentia do not have any tumors. SNOMED codes were used in the report. A supplemental report is also expected for the prostate and seminal vesicles.

The patient presented with right pelvic pain and was found to have a solid renal mass. The right kidney was removed and diagnosed as chromophobe renal cell carcinoma with a tumor size of 5.2 cm, confined within the renal capsule, with no invasion of the renal vein or involvement of surgical margins. The non-neoplastic kidney showed a 1 cm diameter simple cyst. Three benign lymph nodes were excised from the paracaval area. The intraoperative consultation confirmed a renal cortical neoplasm favoring chromophobe renal cell carcinoma. No invasion of the ureter, renal vein, or adrenal gland was identified. The rest of the kidney parenchyma was unremarkable. The specimen was analyzed using various diagnostic procedures and stains, all showing negative results.

The left kidney received from radical nephrectomy is diagnosed with a high grade chromophobe type renal cell carcinoma with extensive necrosis. The tumor measures 12.5 cm in diameter and extends into renal pelvis and renal sinus fat. It also invades medium-sized veins in the region of the renal hilum. Renal vein invasion is identified. The surgical margins reveal a tumor presence of less than 1mm at the stapled renal vein resection margin and partial denuding of urothelium at the ureteral margin. Non-neoplastic kidney and benign adrenal gland are reported. Para-aortic lymph nodes excised show perinodal extension and metastasis, and a segment of vein excised is benign. The case is reviewed at GU pathology consensus conference for focal significant epithelial anaplasia and high nuclear grade.

The pathology report describes a case where a patient underwent a nephrectomy and adrenalectomy due to a large 12cm right renal mass. The histologic diagnosis of the tumor was chromophobe renal carcinoma with a Fuhrman nuclear grade III. The tumor infiltrated the capsule but did not involve the inked margin and there was no evidence of the tumor in the lymph nodes. The adrenal gland was also found to be free of a tumor. Two lymph nodes were removed from interaortocaval and found to be free of the tumor. The report contains a gross description of the specimen and outlines all the sections submitted for analysis in the laboratory.

The pathology report describes three specimens labeled "10th rib", "right kidney" and "regional lymph nodes". The bone marrow specimen showed normal hematopoiesis with no evidence of malignancy. The kidney specimen contained a 10 cm renal cell carcinoma, of chromophobe type with a Fuhrman nuclear grade III/IV and lymphovascular invasion identified near the renal vein. However, margins were free of tumor. The lymph nodes were negative for tumor. Immunohistochemistry supported the diagnosis of chromophobe type. The adrenal gland was not identified. The report also includes details about the specimens received for each label and their respective sizes.

Summary: The pathology report describes a radical nephrectomy performed on the left kidney due to a 12.8 cm renal cell carcinoma with Fuhrman nuclear grade 3 of 4, chromophobe type. The tumor is confined to the renal parenchyma and shows no lymphatic vascular invasion, while two lymph nodes are free of tumor. The renal parenchyma away from the tumor shows no specific abnormalities. Microscopic examination reveals normal glomeruli, tubules, and interstitium, with focal tubular atrophy and interstitial fibrosis in approximately 10% of the sample. No adrenal gland is noted, and the perinephric adipose tissue is freely mobile. Representative sections of the tumor, cortex, medulla, and possible lymph nodes have been submitted for cytogenetics and further examination. AJCC (1997) stage is T2 NO MX.

The report describes a right radical nephrectomy specimen received from a patient with a right kidney mass. The tumor measures 13.8 cm and is characterized as an oncocytic neoplasm most consistent with chromophobe renal cell carcinoma. The tumor is limited to the kidney, but there are foci that are suspicious for vascular invasion. Venous invasion is present, but the margins are uninvolved. The regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed, and there are no distant metastases. No invasion into the perinephric adipose tissue is identified. The ureter and pelvis mucosa are unremarkable. Additionally, tumor stains positively for PAX-2, C-kit, and CK7.

The pathology report describes a left partial nephrectomy specimen that includes a chromophobe renal cell carcinoma with a Fuhrman's nuclear grade of 3 that measures 4.5 cm in maximum dimension and shows local infiltration into perinephric adipose tissue. However, after resection, the parenchymal and soft tissue margins are free of tumor. The report also notes that the tumor is predominantly composed of cells with eosinophilic, granular cytoplasm and perinuclear halos. The immunohistochemical stains demonstrate positive staining for Cytokeratin 7 and negative staining for Vimentin. Electron microscopic examination shows the presence of a large number of intracytoplasmic vesicles with few occasional mitochondria with tubular cristae, which is consistent with chromophobe renal cell carcinoma. The left adrenal gland and periaortic lymph nodes show no signs of tumor, and the gross inspection of a portion of the 11th rib is reported for gross inspection only. SNOMED codes are also provided.

The pathology report describes a nephrectomy specimen including a left kidney and adrenal gland with a well-circumscribed tumor measuring 18.0 x 16.0 x 8.5 cm, which is confirmed to be chromophobe renal cell carcinoma with Furhman's nuclear grade 3. The tumor is confined to the kidney and has lymphatic/vascular invasion present, but margins of resection are free of tumor and there is no tumor present in the adrenal gland or para-aortic lymph nodes. The gross description includes extensive areas of hemorrhage and necrosis within the tumor. Portions of the tumor have been submitted for possible electron microscopy and sections of tumor and normal kidney have been submitted to the tumor bank. The clinical history is left renal mass.

The pathology report relates to a patient with a right thyroid mass and shortness of breath. The chest CT showed bilateral LAD, suspicious for sarcoidosis or lymphoma. The operative procedure carried out included right total thyroidectomy and mediastinoscopy. The report mentions several lymph nodes extracts from the mediastinum, delphian region, and level IV R, with no evidence of neoplasm, but non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation present. The right thyroid lobe weighed 14.4g with the presence of a 2.0 x 1.5 x 1.0 cm and a 1.0 x 0.6 x 0.6 cm well-defined, somewhat lobular nodule. The report showed two additional tan, poorly-defined areas, and no discrete nodules in the left lobe thyroid. The frozen section report indicated non-necrotizing granulomatous inflammation and negative for neoplasm. Permanent sections confirmed papillary carcinoma, follicular variant, and lymphocytic thyroiditis in the right lobe only.

DATE OBTAINED: DATE RECEIVED: DIAGNOSIS #1 - EXCISION, FAT (PERINEPHRIC): FAT (NO TUMOR PRESENT) #2 - RESECTION, (PARTIAL), KIDNEY (RIGHT): RENAL PAPILLARY CARCINOMA - Histologic type: Renal papillary carcinoma, type 2 Sarcomatoid features: Not identified Tumor Necrosis: Focally present Tumor size: 2.5 cm Fuhrman nuclear grade: NA (ISUP nucleolar grade 2) Tumor site: Right kidney Tumor focality: Unifocal Macroscopic extent of tumor: Confined to kidney Microscopic extent of tumor: Confined to kidney Lymphatic/vascular invasion: Absent Margins: Renal parenchymal margin - negative Perinephric fat/capsular margin - negative (specimens #1, #2) Non-neoplastic kidney: No significant findings Adrenal gland: Not present Lymph nodes: Not present pTNM: pT1a AJCC STAGE: Stage I (assumes cNO CMO) COMMENT 88307 Clinical Diagnosis and History: Right renal mass Tissue(s) Submitted: 1: PERINEPHRIC FAT 2: RIGHT RENAL MASS AND SURROUNDING FAT Gross Description: Specimen #1 is received in formalin labeled perinephric fat and consists of a 5.0 x 5.0 x 1.5 cm aggregate of tan-yellow, soft to lobulated fibroadipose tissue. The specimen is serially sectioned, and no gross lesions are identified. Representative sections are submitted labeled 1A-1B. Specimen #2 is received fresh for intraoperative consultation labeled right renal mass and surrounding fat and consists of a 9 gram, 3.6 x 3.0 x 3.0 cm partial nephrectomy specimen. The parenchymal margin is inked in blue, the capsule is inked in black. The parenchymal margin appears intact, and the capsule margin appears smooth and intact. The specimen is serially sectioned to identify a 2.5 x 2.2 x 1.6 cm tan-pink, focally hemorrhagic mass measuring 0.2 cm from the nearest parenchymal margin and abutting the capsule. The adjacent renal parenchyma is tan-brown, soft. A representative portion of the normal and mass is submitted for TCGA study. Representative sections are submitted labeled as follows: 2A-2F: tumor to adjacent parenchyma and capsule (2A closest parenchymal margin) 2G: uninvolved parenchyma 2H: surrounding adipose tissue Intraoperative Consult Diagnosis: 2A/GDX: TUMOR MEASURES - ~2MM AWAY FROM THE CLOSEST PARENCHYMAL MARGIN

DIAGNOSIS: Resection, Liver (Segment 3): Hepatocellular Carcinoma, moderately differentiated grade (II), 8.5cm size, unifocal multifocality, microvascular invasion (focal), and confined to the liver with micronodular cirrhosis. P2 NX AJCC stage II. COMMENT: No lymph nodes present. Gross description includes an intact segment of liver with a single stapled margin, red-brown cap surface, serially sectioned soft tan-brown well-defined mass measuring 1.5cm from the stapled margin, surrounding dark red subcapsular hemorrhage, and no other discrete lesions identified. Intraoperative Consult Diagnosis: Resection margin negative for Hepatocellular Carcinoma (1.8cm tumor to margin).

The pathology report is for a patient who underwent a modified radical mastectomy due to multifocal invasive ductal carcinoma in the right breast, with the largest tumor measuring 4 cm and a grade 2 Nottingham histologic score. Angiolymphatic invasion and metastatic carcinoma in 7 of 18 axillary lymph nodes were detected, with focal extracapsular extension. The tumor is positive for E-cadherin and negative for ductal carcinoma in situ. Margins are uninvolved, and the skin is directly invaded by the carcinoma. The lymph nodes are positive for macrometastasis and micrometastasis. ER, PR, and HER2/neu expression levels are positive, except for Ki-67, which is high. A couple of lymph nodes were evaluated with PanKeratin stain. The report provides sample sizes and weights, cassette summaries, and microscopic descriptions, and mentions intraoperative consultation.
