Histology Comments: pancreatic head. Grade/Differentiation: II. Pathological T: T3. Pathological N: Clinical M. M0. Note: No relevant information was found for the sample type BUFFY.

Diagnosis: Adenocarcinoma. Sample Type: TUMOUR. Site of Tissue/Primary: Esophagus (involves GEJ). Tumour Size: 5.5 cm. Histology: Adenocarcinoma. Grade/Differentiation: Pathological T. T3. Pathological N. Clinical M: M0. Histology Comments: Tumour midpoint is in distal esophagus. (Note: The information regarding the sample type BUFFY, year of sample collection, age at sample collection, days to procedure date, and days to diagnosis is missing context and cannot be accurately summarized without further information.)

Pathologic diagnosis is invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. The depth of invasion cannot be accurately evaluated due to poor orientation, but there appears to be at least 5.0 mm of invasion. The specimen is received in formalin and labeled "CERVICAL BIOPSY." Microscopic evaluation has been performed by a pathology resident. No clinical information is given. Representative sections are submitted for TCGA, and remaining tissue is submitted in its entirety in cassettes A1-A3.

Diagnosis: Undifferentiated pleomorphic sarcoma, Grade 3 out of 3. Margins negative for sarcoma and no angiolymphatic invasion identified. Tumor size is 3.9x3.0x2.7cm and is deep, fascial and subfascial. Mitotic rate is >20/10 high-power fields. Necrosis is present with an extent of <5%. Lymph-vascular invasion not identified and lymph nodes are not involved. Preresection treatment is unknown. The specimen consists of an 8.3 x 4.2 x 3.6 cm, 70.0 gm mixed dark red and yellow-tan soft tissue fragment. The attached ellipse of skin measuring 8.3 x 3.8 cm shows a 2.6 cm well-healed incision scar. The tumor is 2.2 cm from the proximal resection margin, 2.1 cm from the distal resection margin, 0.6 cm from the anterior margin, 0.3 cm from the posterior margin, and 2.2 cm from the deep resection margin. Representative sections are submitted in twelve cassettes. Microscopic evaluation was performed.

The pathology report indicates that a lobectomy was performed on the right upper lobe of the lung revealing an invasive grade 4 non-small cell carcinoma consistent with adenocarcinoma. A 6.2 x 6.0 x 5.7 cm well-circumscribed solid mass was identified, and visceral pleural invasion was present. No angiolymphatic invasion was observed, and multiple lymph nodes were negative for tumor spread. The report also provides details on the lymph node biopsies and the gross description of the tissues submitted for examination. This report confirms the presence of a cancerous mass with no significant changes in the permanent section.

The pathology report describes a lung wedge resection that reveals a necrotic 4.0 x 2.2 x 2.0 cm mass of invasive grade 4 (of 4) adenocarcinoma, without visceral pleural involvement or angiolymphatic invasion, and with negative surgical margins. Biopsies of lymph nodes from a variety of stations show mostly negative for tumor, except for a single lymph node from the bronchial intermedius, which has metastatic adenocarcinoma, and one lymph node from station 7, which contains a necrotizing granuloma (not present at the time of frozen section). An addendum notes that special stains are negative for organisms and k-ras mutation and EGFR mutation analyses are being performed. The gross description provides more detail on the size and location of the resected lung mass and lymph nodes. A completion lobectomy shows no residual tumor identified, but a matted mass of intrapulmonary peribronchial lymph nodes is metastatically involved.

The report describes two specimens received, one of the gallbladder and the other the right lobe of the liver. The liver specimen shows a well-differentiated hepatocellular neoplasm, partially encapsulated, and partially blending with the normal liver, with features of adenoma like hepatocellular carcinoma measuring 6.5 cm. Resection margins are free of tumor, and there is no lymphovascular invasion. Peliosis and extramedullary hematopoiesis are present in the tumor, with hemorrhage suggestive of prior biopsy site. Steatosis with inflammation is observed in the non-tumor liver. The gallbladder specimen shows cholelithiasis without malignancy. The report concludes that the diagnosis of the liver neoplasm is equivocal between adenoma and well-differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma; however, the age and sex of the patient are atypical for an adenoma. Therefore, the tumor is classified as very well-differentiated adenoma-like hepatocellular carcinoma. The tumor is an isolated, solitary, and without vascular or angiolymphatic invasion, with negative resection margins. The final diagnosis is pT1/NX.

The pathology report describes a case of squamous cell carcinoma of the right floor of the mouth involving the lateral border of the tongue. Thirteen specimens were received, including the right superior, anterior, inferior, posterior, and deep margins, as well as several lymph node levels. The final diagnosis was as follows: invasive squamous carcinoma in the right inferior margin, mild dysplasia in the right posterior margin, and invasive moderately to well-differentiated squamous cell carcinoma in the right glossectomy. Surgical margins were positive in the deep margin of the glossectomy but negative in other margins. Lymph node levels showed no evidence of malignancy except for moderate dysplasia in the re-resection inferior margin, and all benign tissues were reported elsewhere. Additional details of each specimen's size and orientation are provided in the report.

The pathology report describes a case of a (patient age not mentioned) male diagnosed with invasive squamous cell carcinoma, keratinizing type, moderately differentiated on the anterior floor of the mouth, with no evidence of metastasis in 23 lymph nodes or margins. A composite resection was performed, along with neck dissection of various levels of lymph nodes. The report provides descriptions of the biopsy specimens and lymph nodes, including their sizes and orientation. Relevant sections were submitted for future studies, and no further treatment plan is specified.

Final Diagnosis: A. Lymph nodes, right pelvic, lymph node dissection: - No evidence of malignancy in 11 lymph nodes (0/11). B. Lymph nodes, right pelvic, lymph node dissection (including BFS1): - Two lymph nodes with no evidence of malignancy (0/2). C. Lymph nodes, left pelvic, lymph node dissection: - No evidence of malignancy in 12 dissected lymph nodes (0/12). D. Lymph nodes, left pelvic, lymph node dissection (including DFS1): - No evidence of malignancy in two lymph nodes (0/2). E. Uterus, cervix, bilateral fallopian tubes and upper vagina,. hysterectomy, salpingectomy: - Cervix with invasive, moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, with papillary features. - Extending into periuterine soft tissue. - Invasive 1.8 of 2.1 cm thick resection. - Associated with lymphovascular space invasion. - Peripheral and vaginal margins of resection free of malignancy. - Vaginal cuff with no histologic abnormality. - Endometrium with proliferative pattern. - Myometrium with adenomyosis. Clinical History: The patient is a year-old woman with invasive squamous cell carcinoma of the cervix. Operative Procedure: Radical. hysterectomy with bilateral salpingectomy. Gross: A through E contain the details of the specimen collected during surgery. Microscopic: Sections of the cervix show moderately differentiated invasive squamous cell carcinoma. In some areas, the surface of the cervix demonstrates a papillary pattern. The tumor invades focally beyond the thick-walled vessels of the uterine vascular plexus, indicative of minimal and focal extrauterine extension. Lymphovascular space invasion is identified. Definitive perineural invasion is not present. The tumor invades 1.8 cm of a 2.1 cm thick uterine resection. The remainder of the lower uterine segment, endometrium, and myometrium are unremarkable. Permanent sections confirm the frozen section diagnosis.

The pathology report describes the results of a radical cystectomy with attached prostate and lymph node dissection for a 70-year-old male with a history of bladder cancer. Six specimens were received and labeled accordingly. Lymph nodes were submitted in six cassettes for each of the left and right pelvic nodes, and three benign lymph nodes with no evidence of malignancy were found in each case. The bladder, prostate, and seminal vesicles specimen showed high-grade papillary urothelial carcinoma, with no involvement of the prostate, soft tissue, paravesical margins, or lymph nodes. Dysplasia and carcinoma in-situ were present multifocally, as well as chronic inflammation and previous biopsy site changes. The tumor does not extend to the radial soft tissue margin, but there was microscopic infiltration observed through the detrusor muscle into the perivesical soft tissues for a distance of 0.1 cm. Carcinoma in-situ was present in every section of the bladder and at the left ureteral margin. Intraoperative consultation showed negative distal margin at apex of the bladder. The report mentions sections and their locations for further reference in case of future studies.

Summary: - Specimens submitted: uterus, cervix, bilateral tubes and ovaries, and various lymph nodes. - Hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy revealed a malignant mixed Mullerian tumor of the endometrium with heterologous elements (rhabdomyoblastic and cartilaginous components). - Tumor invaded less than or equal to half of myometrium with maximal thickness of invasion at 3.5 mm and myometrial thickness of 23 mm in the area of maximal invasion. - No endocervical invasion or vascular invasion identified. Endometrium showed atrophy and myometrium showed leiomyomas. - Lymph nodes excised revealed benign lymph nodes with no lymph node present in the right internal iliac.

The report describes the pathological diagnosis of multiple specimens taken from a patient, including lymph nodes, uterus, cervix, tubes, ovaries, and soft tissues. The left para-aortic lymph nodes show metastatic tumor in four out of five nodes, while the right para-aortic lymph nodes and the right external iliac lymph node are benign. A malignant mixed mullerian tumor of endometrium is present invading to half of myometrium with a maximal thickness of 1mm and vascular invasion. The right and left ovaries also show metastatic tumors, while the left fallopian tube has a detached tumor fragment. The soft tissue left side wall tumor shows metastatic tumor, but the omentum is negative for metastatic tumor. Further immunohistochemical stains are being performed to rule out the presence of heterologous elements. An addendum states that the stains for desmin and myogenin show no evidence of heterologous elements.

The pathology report describes a specimen of the right hemicolon, which was removed via right hemicolectomy. The report indicates the presence of invasive low-grade adenocarcinoma in the cecum/ileocecal valve measuring 9 cm in greatest dimension, invading through the muscle wall into subserosal adipose tissue (pT3). Lymph node involvement is noted, with four of thirty-five regional lymph nodes positive for metastatic carcinoma, and extranodal capsular extension present. Margins were negative, with closest margin mesenteric (4.5 cm), and the appendix showed no pathologic diagnosis. The report provides a gross description of the specimen, including the presence of diverticular puckering in the distal segment of the colon, a tattoo dye area in the ascending colon, and nodular lymph nodes in surrounding adipose. The report also notes that the mesenteric/fal margin is 4.5 cm, lymphovascular and perineural invasion is not identified, and there is no prior treatment effect. The report indicates primary tumor pT3 and regional lymph nodes pN2a for pathologic staging. The report does not include patient information or treatment plans.

The pathology report describes a specimen from a right hemicolectomy, which includes the terminal ileum, cecum, appendix, and ascending colon. A moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma of the ascending colon has been identified, measuring 4.5 cm in greatest dimension and extending through the bowel wall into the subserosal fat, with presence of lymph-vascular invasion. Three discontinuous tumor deposits in subserosal tissue and metastatic adenocarcinoma in 4 of 33 subserosal lymph nodes have been observed. The surgical margins of resection are free of tumor with the closest surgical margin radial distance measuring 5 cm. The histologic grade is low-grade, and perineural invasion is not identified. The tumor penetrates to the surface of the visceral peritoneum, and there is one grossly enlarged subserosal lymph node containing hard white tissue with central necrosis. A fine needle aspirate cytology of the liver is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma of colonic primary origin, and a CT-guided needle biopsy of the liver also shows metastatic adenocarcinoma consistent with colonic primary.

The pathology report describes a lung resection specimen with a diagnosis of invasive squamous cell carcinoma, grade 2, measuring 12 cm with extension into perihilar mediastinal fibroadipose tissue. Lymphatic permeation and intra and perineural invasion by tumor cells is present, and 3/8 perihilar lymph nodes show metastatic tumor. Lymph nodes at level 7 subcarinal also show metastatic squamous cell carcinoma with extracapsular extension. The bronchial margin and vascular and soft tissue margins of resection are free of tumor. The diagnosis is T4N2PL3 stage. Non-neoplastic pathology is not presented. The summary also describes the gross features of the specimen and lists the specimen types and relevant tests performed.

The report describes a left lower pole partial nephrectomy on a female patient with a 2.2 cm renal mass. The mass was found to be a chromophobe renal cell carcinoma with eosinophilic type and nuclear grade 2 out of 4. There was focal involvement of the margin at the renal parenchymal margin and no lymphovascular or perineural invasion was seen. The tumor was unifocal and limited to the kidney. No regional lymph nodes were submitted, and distant metastasis was not identified, resulting in a pathologic stage of I. The margin status was R1, and lymphovascular and perineural invasion was not identified. There were also findings of patchy glomerulosclerosis and chronic inflammation in the non-neoplastic kidney, but no additional pathologic findings were reported.

A pathology report describes the case of a male patient who underwent video-assisted thoracoscopy on his right lung. The specimens collected include a diaphragm nodule, a wedge of the right lower lobe chest wall, and a basilar wedge of the right lower lobe. The frozen section showed multiple malignant neoplasms, with surgical margins being free of the tumor. After examination, it was found that the patient had malignant mesothelioma of the moderately differentiated, predominantly epithelial type. Multiple tumor nodules were found ranging from 6.0 cm to 0.5 cm. The tumor affected the pleura, lung, and diaphragmatic muscle, but there was no lymphatic or venous invasion found. The TNM staging was pT2, pNX, pMX. Microscopic examination showed that the neoplastic cells were positive for calretinin, cytokeratin5, cytokeratin7, and WT-1, and negative for cytokeratin20 and TTF-1. The tumor involved the diaphragmatic muscle but surgical margins were free of tumor. Multiple sections were examined, and sections of the surgical margins, ribs, and lung were found free of tumor. Sections of the tumor were submitted for genomics project and chemosensitivity studies.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: Breast, right, modified radical mastectomy: - Invasive ductal carcinoma, grade III/III, 5.0 cm in greatest dimension, present 1.0 mm from posterior inked surgical margin, other margins widely free. - Ductal carcinoma in-situ, high grade, solid type with associated central necrosis and calcifications, surgical margins negative. - Metastatic carcinoma involving two of twelve lymph nodes (2/12). Breast Pathologic Parameters: - Invasive carcinoma: Gross measurement of 5.0 cm, composite histologic (modified SBR) grade of III/III. Associated intraductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), high grade, solid type with associated central necrosis and calcifications. - Surgical margins: Free of tumor. DCIS 3.0 mm from closest margin (posterior). Invasive carcinoma 1.0 mm from closest margin (posterior) on mastectomy, separately submitted deep margin re-excision (specimen B) negative for carcinoma. Additional margins widely free. - Blood vessel and lymphatic invasion: Present. - Nipple: Uninvolved. - Skin: Uninvolved. - Skeletal muscle: Focally involved. - Axillary lymph nodes: Metastatic carcinoma involving two of twelve lymph nodes (2/12). - Special studies: ER weak expression in 30% of invasive tumor nuclei, PR no expression in invasive tumor nuclei, Ki-67 50% proliferation rate, Her2/neu antigen (FISH) amplified (ratio: 3.8). - pTNM: pT2, N1a, MX. Clinical History: Right breast invasive ductal carcinoma with axillary nodal metastases who undergoes right modified radical mastectomy. Specimens Received: A: Right breast and axillary contents. B: Additional deep margin. C: Additional tissue under superiomedial skin flap. D: Skin at corner of incision; right chest wall. Gross Description: Received in four containers each labeled with the patient's name and medical record number. A: 730 g simple mastectomy specimen with a 5.0 X 3.8 X 3.5 cm pink-tan firm mass (lesion #1) extending from upper-outer quadrant to lower-outer quadrant with an attached 6.5 X 5.5 X 1.5 cm portion of apparent axillary tail and a 4.5 X 1.8 X 0.2 cm skeletal muscle. B: 3.9 g, 4.2 X 2.2x0.8 cm yellow-tan soft tissue fragment with one short stitch designating as new true deep margin (inked blue) and attached clips on original margin (inked black). C: an unoriented 2.3 g, 4.8 X 1.2 x 1.1 cm portion of yellow-tan fibroadipose tissue. D: V-shaped ellipse of wrinkled, tan-brown skin measuring 4.5 X 1.5 cm adjunct with 3.2 X 1.5 cm excised to a depth of 1.3 cm. The specimen is serial sectioned and review grossly unremarkable parenchyma. Note: Patient name, doctor name, hospital name, reference, treatment plan, and sample size, shape, and weight have been excluded as they are irrelevant to the image and model training on it.

The addendum report comments on the type of papillary renal cell carcinoma, identifying it as type 2. The left partial nephrectomy specimen shows a tumor measuring 4.5 cm in maximum dimension, with Fuhrman's nuclear grade 3 and confined to the kidney. The margins of resection are free of tumor. In the left partial nephrectomy II specimen, renal parenchyma with focal glomerulosclerosis is present, and no tumor is found. The adrenal biopsy specimen consists of a fragment of adrenal cortical tissue, with no metastatic carcinoma identified. The gross description notes the presence of a friable orange-brown and focally hemorrhagic tumor mass within the kidney parenchyma, less than 0.2 cm from the nearest parenchymal margin, and surrounded by unremarkable renal parenchyma. The clinical history is not given.

Clinical Diagnosis: Brain tumor. Gross Description: Gray-whitish pieces from right temporal lobe. Microscopic Description: Brain tissue consistent with anaplastic oligodendroglioma, Ki 67 up to 15%. Final Diagnosis: Anaplastic oligodendroglioma: Grade III.

Left adrenal gland tumor received for examination. Pathologic diagnosis reveals Pheochromocytoma, a tumor containing spindled and epithelioid cells with no notable nuclear atypia or necrosis. Mitotic figures are sparse with no capsular or vascular space invasion. The tumor cells tested positive for synaptophysin and chromogranin but negative for calretinin, inhibin, and Melan A. The adrenal gland weighs 10 g and measures 5 X 3 X 2 cm, with the mass being at least 2.7 cm in size. The mass is golden tan-yellow with diffuse areas of hemorrhage, but the edges are ill-defined, and portions appear to be missing. Representative sections of the mass and normal adrenal gland are submitted for testing, and additional tests have been ordered. All special stains used have adequate controls.

Specimen: Left breast cancer. Sources of Specimen(s): 1: Sentinel Nodes-left axilla. 2: left breast lumpectomy. 3: Margin-final medial. Diagnosis: 1. Sentinel lymph node, left axilla, excision: no tumor seen (0/1). Negative immunohistochemical staining for cytokeratin AE1/AE3. 2. Left breast, lumpectomy: Invasive and in situ lobular carcinoma. Lymphovascular invasion is not identified. Invasive carcinoma is less than 1mm to the inked closest medial margin and remaining margins with no tumor seen. Non-neoplastic breast tissue shows fibrocystic changes with microcalcifications. 3. Left breast, final medial margin, excision: benign breast tissue, no tumor seen. Prognostic Grouping: DNA INDEX/PLOIDY 1.59 Aneuploidy. S-phase: cannot be determined accurately. INVASIVE BREAST CANCER TEMPLATE: Excisions and Mastectomies. Specimen Type: Excision. Lymph Node Sampling: Sentinel lymph node only. Specimen Size: Greatest dimension 7.4 cm. Laterality: Left. Tumor Site(s): not specified. Invasive Component: Solitary. Greatest dimension: 3.8 cm (grossly). Histologic Type(s): Lobular carcinoma in situ. Invasive lobular. Invasive Lobular Carcinoma Type: Classical, singet-ring, and pleomorphic. Invasion: Invasion confined to breast parenchyma. Angiolymphatic Invasion: Absent. Microcalcifications Associated with Carcinoma In Situ. Margins: Margins uninvolved by invasive carcinoma and in situ carcinoma. Regional Lymph Nodes: 1 regional lymph node examined. No regional lymph node metastasis histologically and by immunohistochemical staining for cytokeratin AE1/AE3 (NO). Ancillary Immunopathology Studies(Performed on):ER.Positive. PR.Positive. Her2-Neu. Negative (score 0). pTNM: T2 NO Mx.

A chalky white tumour measuring 2x1.3x1cm was observed in a female cervix. Microscopic assessment revealed a malignant invasive tumour consisting of large polygonal cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and amphophilic cytoplasm growing in solid nests within a desmoplastic stroma with thin-walled vascular channels. The diagnosis is large cell non-keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma, with a nuclear score of 3, and the closest invasive carcinoma margin is 3mm from the deep resection margin.
A pathology report indicates that a male patient has been diagnosed with oligodendroglioma, a grade 2 WHO brain tumor, located in the temporal lobe.
Type of report: Pathologist report Gender: Male Location of the tumor: Right frontal lobe Diagnosis: Oligoastrocytoma, Grade II (according to WHO classification)

Final surgical pathology report for a case involving a moderately differentiated keratinizing squamous cell carcinoma in a partial glossectomy of the left lateral tongue, which invaded skeletal muscle bundles and had perineural and lymphovascular invasion present. The mucosal and soft tissue margins were negative for carcinoma, and there were no high-grade dysplasia and invasive carcinoma found in other tongue excisions. One of the seven lymph nodes in the left level III neck dissection was positive for metastatic carcinoma. No distant metastasis was identified. The tumor was endophytic and showed a discontiguous spread of the lesion. Frozen section analysis was performed on multiple margins, with positive results found only in the anterior margin. Microscopic examination was performed.

FINAL DIAGNOSIS: 1. Skin of right back, wide re-excision: - Malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, state back MOS C49.6. - Size of tumor: 3.5 x 3 x 3 cm. - Margins of resections negative for tumor. - Neurofibromas. - Dermal fibrous scarring at previous biopsy site. 2. Skin of right flank, additional margins excision: - Neurofibromas. - Negative for residual malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor. GROSS DESCRIPTION: 1. Wide re-excision, sarcoma of right back: Received a broad ellipse of skin with underlying abundant amount of subcutaneous adipose tissue. Specimen measures 11 x 5 x 3 cm. The ellipse of skin with healing incisional scar and posterior third of the specimen shows small sessile skin tags or nodular-like appearance. The largest measures 0.5 cm in diameter. On cut section, the central portion of the specimen shows an ill-defined margin tan-yellow fibrous tumor measures 3.5 x 3 x 3 cm. Grossly, the tumor is within 5 mm from the nearest designated inferior margin. Inferior - orange, superior - red, anterior - blue, deep - black. 2. Additional tissue right flank: The specimen consists of a 14.0 x 1.4 cm oriented skin ellipse with attached subcutaneous soft tissue measuring 7.0 x 15 x 2 cm. A single suture designates the lateral margin (margin was inked black). The skin surface shows numerous nodular skin tags measuring 0.8 cm in the greatest dimension; the skin is otherwise unremarkable. On cut sections, the subcutis shows no grossly identifiable residual tumor. Sections submitted in 6 cassettes.

Specimens were obtained from a patient with neurofibromatosis and intraspinal tumor. The pathology report describes various excisions and biopsies of soft tissue from the paraspinal area, epidural scar, spinal canal, thoracic spinal nerve root, paraspinal retropleural mass T6, neural foraminal tissue, dorsal foramen tissue, and posterior paravertebral soft tissue margin. The report indicates the presence of neurofibroma, malignant peripheral nerve sheath tumor, and benign neural tissue. The epidural scar biopsy showed extensive fibrosis and a focal foreign body giant cell reaction. Margins were cauterized and/or inked and were found to be focally involved in some cases.

The pathology report describes three specimens labeled as left omental mass, spleen, and left adrenal gland submitted for analysis. The left omental mass showed fat necrosis, while the spleen revealed low grade B cell lymphoma with CD5 expression, and involvement of adipose tissue by atypical B lymphoid cells. The differential diagnosis favors splenic marginal zone lymphoma over chronic lymphocytic leukemia/small lymphocytic lymphoma and mantle cell lymphoma. The left adrenal gland had a pheochromocytoma with surrounding adipose tissue involvement by atypical monotonous lymphoid cells. The report also details the gross description of the specimens and the diagnostics used for analysis. Clinical history includes adrenal mass, and the entire report is approximately 1500 words.

DIAGNOSIS: Lymph nodes from paracaval and right retroperitoneal mass resections examined. No tumor was detected in the paracaval node (0/4), while the right retroperitoneal mass was identified as a paraganglioma (extraadrenal pheochromocytoma). Immunoperoxidase and in-situ hybridization tests were used for diagnosis. The laboratory is certified under CLIA for high complexity clinical laboratory testing. Gross description of the specimens submitted shows the paracaval node as a fragment of yellow-tan soft tissue entirely submitted in a white cassette for permanent processing. The right retroperitoneal paraganglioma is a pink-yellow-tan soft tissue mass weighing 19.2 grams, measuring 4.5 X 3.5 x 1.2 cm, with 40% of the tissue procured for permanent processing. The outer surface was inked in black and the opened area inked in green. The cut surface revealed variegated, pink-yellow-tan necrosis.

DIAGNOSIS: Adrenal mass, left (adrenalectomy): Pheochromocytoma. Note: Immunohistochemical staining shows patchy ganglion cells. Areas of micronodular hyperplasia seen in the cortex. Clinical history: h/o left adrenal mass (pheochromocytoma). Procedure: large left adrenalectomy. Gross description: 8 x 5 x 4.5 cm tan/brown soft tissue specimen, no identified normal adrenal gland, largest nodule 4.0 cm in diameter. Specimens submitted: 1. Adrenal gland, left. Procured central piece from the largest nodule. No consultants.

DIAGNOSIS: Pheochromocytoma (5.5 x 4 x 3.5 cm) was identified in the specimen labeled "interaortocaval tumor". One lymph node was observed and showed no signs of tumor. No adrenal tissue was identified. The clinical information indicates that the right retroperitoneal mass was examined. The interaortocaval tumor was a single piece of red/purple, soft tissue, with a smooth surface and somewhat soft. The dimensions of the specimen were 5.5 x 4 x 3.5 cm, weighing 39.1 grams. The surgical margins were free of tumor. A representative section of the specimen was submitted for analysis.

DIAGNOSIS: Adrenal, right (adrenalectomy): Pheochromocytoma. Inked margins appear free of tumor. CLINICAL INFORMATION: Brief clinical history: pheochromocytoma. PROCEDURE: Post-operative diagnosis: pheochromocytoma. Operative findings: right adrenal pheochromocytoma. Pre-operative diagnosis: pheochromocytoma. SPECIMENS SUBMITTED: 1. Adrenal gland, right. GROSS DESCRIPTION: Adrenal mass with surrounding adipose tissue measuring 15  5  3 cm (75.45 grams) has a nodule within the tissue measuring 3.5  3 cm. The lesional and perilesional tissue are inked in black. On sectioning, the tumor has a hemorrhagic and friable cut surface. Normal adrenal gland is present on the periphery. Approximately 50% of the tumor and normal ring of adrenal is procured for. I. Normal adrenal (0.1%) is procured for. The remainder of the specimen is placed in formalin for surgical pathology.

The pathology report summarizes findings from biopsies taken from the stomach and esophagus of a patient with a distal esophageal cancer clinical history. The report reveals that there is mild chronic inflammation and reactive epithelial changes in the cardio-oxyntic mucosa of the stomach, and no diagnostic abnormality in the squamous mucosa of the distal esophagus. However, the distal esophageal mass biopsy shows invasive moderately differentiated adenocarcinoma with overlying squamous mucosa. The report further shows that tumor cells are negative for Her-2/neu by immunohistochemistry. The report contains SNOMED codes T-56000, T-57000, M-81403, and M-43000.
Diagnosis: Infiltrating poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in distal esophagus biopsy. Clinical history: Esophageal cancer.

The pathology report describes a polyp at the hiatal hernia in the stomach biopsy, with oxyntic/fundic mucosa containing chronic inactive gastritis and muscularis mucosae hyperplasia, and no tumor, intestinal metaplasia, or Helicobacter pylori found. The esophagus distal tumor biopsy shows an ulcerated invasive poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma underlying squamous mucosa, with reactive epithelial changes. Immunohistochemistry shows neoplastic cells are negative for chromogranin and synaptophysin. Her2-neu testing was performed on the adenocarcinoma biopsy, with no membranous staining of invasive tumor cells indicating a negative result. The report specifies that the tests reported here have not been specifically cleared or approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration.

The pathology report describes a case of Hepatocellular Carcinoma in the left lobe of the liver, which was treated by lobectomy. The tumor was nodular with perinodular extension, measuring 4x3.5x3cm, identified to be microtrabecular with hepatic cell type and 10% necrosis. The pathological differentiation grades were Edmondson grade IV and III. Surgical margins were clear with partial fibrous capsule infiltration and portal vein, bile duct, hepatic vein, and hepatic artery invasions were absent. Chronic hepatitis was identified as the cause of the etiology, with periportal fibrosis, minimal portal-portal, and mild portoperiportal grading but no cirrhosis. The gallbladder showed Chronic Cholecystitis without any significant findings on the capsular surface and mucosa. The presence of a lymph node was also reported, with no metastasis, and no other liver disease was identified, except for 10% macrovesicular fatty change. Cytokeratin 7 was positive in bile ducts, while cytokeratin 19 did not show any hepatocyte staining. No special staining or significant findings were observed in the report.

The pathology report describes a specimen collected from a gastrectomy performed on a patient with gastric cancer of the gastric remnant, who had undergone a previous completion gastrectomy for gastric cancer. The frozen section diagnosis showed no evidence of carcinoma. The macroscopic description of the specimen shows a portion of the stomach with tumour masses present in the lumen and extending through the stomach wall into the adjacent adipose tissue. Margins are marked with ink for identification. A representative sample of the lymph node and two donuts are processed for microscopic examination. The examination reveals one lymph node free of tumour, but four lesser curvature lymph nodes contain tumour, as well as three extranodal deposits of tumour. Four greater curvature nodes are identified, free of tumour. The diagnosis is adenocarcinoma, mucinous variant, with extension through muscle wall into serosal fat, four of twenty-one lymph nodes contain tumour (pT2N1Mx), with extranodal serosal tumour deposits noted. Margins are clear, and donuts are unremarkable.

The pathology report describes the diagnosis and specimens submitted from a patient with a malignant lesion on the right lower gingiva. The report provides a diagnosis for various specimens submitted, including excisions and lymph nodes. The report lists conditions such as benign squamous mucosa, squamous cell carcinoma in situ, and invasive squamous cell carcinoma. It also describes the tumor size, location, and invasion depth. The report includes a description of gross specimens received and sections submitted for analysis, along with intraoperative consultations. No irrelevant information is included.

Final diagnosis: Right Adrenal Gland, Adrenalectomy - Pheochromocytoma (3.3 cm in greatest dimension). Gross description: The specimen is an ovoid mass measuring 3.3 cm in greatest dimension and weighing 14.0 grams. The tumor appears well-encapsulated, with a sharply circumscribed, tan-brown, heterogenous cut surface. A thin rim of residual adrenal tissue is noted at the edge of the specimen. Cystic spaces are not present. Additional non-marginal representative sections of the mass and an unremarkable appearing adrenal gland are submitted.

The report describes a laparoscopic right adrenalectomy on an endurance athlete previously diagnosed with a possible Pheochromocytoma after experiencing palpitations and anxiety. The submitted tissue is an 8-gram adrenal gland with a nodule measuring 1.7 x 1.3 x 1 cm and a tan, tubulated architecture that grossly extends to the surgical margin. The diagnosis confirmed the presence of Pheochromocytoma (1.7 cm), which was confined to the adrenal gland.

The pathology report describes a previous adrenalectomy procedure on a female patient to remove a well-encapsulated soft partially cystic mass with focal hemorrhage measuring 7.5 x 5.4 x 6.7 cm from the right adrenal gland. A thin strip of normal adrenal gland tissue measuring 1.2 x 0.3 cm was identified at one periphery, and the capsule was inked black. Representative sections with the capsule and normal rim of the adrenal gland were submitted for examination, along with additional representative sections. The final diagnosis was pheochromocytoma, with negative margins.

Patient with multinodular goiter underwent fine needle aspiration revealing medullary thyroid carcinoma, and CT scan showed a right adrenal tumor. An 8.68 gm adrenal gland measuring 3.5x5.1x1.0 cm was received with a nodular mass on cut section measuring 1.6x1.5x1.3 cm surrounded by yellow cortical tissue. Central portions of the tumor were submitted for tissue procurement. The remaining nodule and adjacent gland were submitted in 5 cassettes labeled A-E. The final diagnosis revealed a pheochromocytoma.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: Left temporal lobe excision revealed an Anaplastic Astrocytoma, WHO grade III with multiple areas of increased cellularity, mitotic activity (up to 4 MF/10 HPF), and IDH-1 (R132H mutant protein) positivity. Intraoperative diagnosis showed infiltrating astrocytoma with no high-grade features. The patient, a man with partial complex seizures and language disturbance, underwent resection of a diffuse infiltrating, left frontotemporal tumor.
Diagnosis: Astrocytoma WHO grade II with histomorphology typical for diffuse astrocytoma and borderline case with increased nuclear pleomorphia. Proliferation index 2%.
The pathology report indicates an anaplastic astrocytoma suspected to be of WHO grade III, with an increased mitotic activity and a proliferation index of 7%.
The pathology report identifies the tissue as oligoastrocytoma WHO grade II based on its histology and morphology. The final diagnosis is also stated as oligoastrocytoma WHO grade II.

Specimens A and B show extensively infiltrated thickened parietal pleura by tumour cells with predominantly papillary architecture. The tumour cells are pleomorphic with vesicular nuclei, small nucleoli, and moderate eosinophilic cytoplasm. There is evidence of infiltration of the visceral pleura and focal areas of tumour necrosis. Immunohistochemistry indicates positive staining for MNF116 and calretinin, patchy staining for WT1, weak staining for CK5/6, and diffuse membranous positivity for EMA. This suggests a diagnosis of epithelioid malignant mesothelioma.

Diagnosis: Uterine cancer - Endometrioid adenocarcinoma - Tumor site: anterior, posterior endometrium, including lower uterine segment with extension to involve endocervix - Histologic grade: FIGO grade 3 - Pathologic staging: pT2, pNO, pM n/a - Microscopic Description: invasive endometrioid adenocarcinoma composed of pleomorphic, atypical cells with increased nuclear: cytoplasmic ratio, prominent nucleoli, and a moderate amount of eosinophilic cytoplasm. Solid growth pattern in >5% of the tumor, malignant glands appear crowded and demonstrate irregular contours. Maximal depth of invasion is 1.1cm, endocervical stromal invasion is seen, and myometrium demonstrates multiple vessels with atherosclerotic changes. Lymphatic invasion is seen, vascular invasion is not identified. Bilateral ovaries and fallopian tubes are uninvolved by tumor and demonstrate atrophic features.

Tissue labeled as "Brain tumour" was received, consisting of multiple fragments of hypercellular, diffusely infiltrating, intrinsic glial tumour that exhibited mild to moderate nuclear pleomorphism and up to 3 mitoses per high power field. Foci of psammomatous calcification were identified. The proliferation index by Ki67 staining is approximately 5%. The presence of normal neurons (NeuN+) and reactive astrocytes in the background indicates the tumour is infiltrating cerebral cortex. These features are consistent with a histological diagnosis of anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO Grade III. No endothelial cell swelling or intrinsic necrosis is present. Clinical history and radiological findings are unknown.

The pathology report describes a brain tumor consisting of irregular pieces of soft to firm cream tissue measuring 7x5x2mm and 19x10x6mm. Microscopic examination reveals brain tissue with focal areas of increased cellularity consisting of oligodendroglioma cells mixed with astrocytic cells. There is also a slight increase in cellularity in adjacent brain tissue. The report suggests a Grade III (WHO grading) mixed high-grade oligodendroglioma with the presence of astrocytoma. FISH testing for 1p and 19q deletions and 7/EGFR amplification was requested. The FISH testing results indicated loss of 1p36 and 19q13. The report references criteria for loss of 1p and 19p and amplification of EGFR/CEP 7. No additional information was provided.

Report Summary: The specimen labelled "Brain tumour" consists of fragments of brain tissue from 1-5mm and shows focal areas of mild to moderately hypercellular glial tissue associated with mild nuclear atypia and scattered microgemistocytes. The overall features are consistent with a low-grade astrocytoma (Grade 2, WHO). Some suggestive features of oligodendroglioma are present, and further genetic testing for 1p/19q deletion is recommended. Staining for IDH1 is also in progress. Mitoses are not seen, and there is no necrosis. Ki67 staining shows positive staining of approximately 2% of nuclei within areas of tumour.

Summary: The pathology report describes the examination of a brain specimen from a patient with a left parietal tumour glioma. The report indicates that the tumour is a high grade glioma, consistent with anaplastic astrocytoma, WHO grade III. The neoplastic cells are diffusely positive for both GFAP and P53, and there is no necrosis. FISH studies reveal amplification of NOT N-MYC detected in all cells analyzed. Ancillary studies including FISH studies are pending, and a supplementary report will be issued when available.

Specimen labeled "Brain tumor" consisting of multiple pieces of light grey tissue is analyzed. The tumor is hypercellular and infiltrative with frequent mitoses and occasional gemistocytic cells. The tumor contains a delicate ramifying vasculature with occasional larger blood vessels present. A small focus of necrosis is present. The Ki67 proliferative index is up to approximately 10%. The right insular tumor is diagnosed as an oligodendroglioma with some features of anaplasia (Grade 2 to 3, WHO 2007). There is suggested testing for loss of heterozygosity at 1p/19q.

Male patient with celiac artery paraganglioma, extending multifocally to inked specimen edges, with focal vascular and capsular invasion, diffuse growth, nuclear atypia, and high cellularity. No tumor or lymph node seen in the celiac artery lymph node biopsy specimen. Immunohistochemical stains with adequate controls were performed showing strong positive for Chromogranin and synaptophysin, focally positive for S-100. Immunostain for SDHB was negative cytoplasmic SDHB staining. Frozen section diagnosis deferred to permanent. The remaining specimen has been fixed in formalin and entirely submitted in 11 sections.

Liver segment 7 partial hepatectomy showing a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma, cavernous hemangioma, chronic hepatitis B, and mild steatosis. The tumor is 3.5 cm in size and confined to the liver with no vascular invasion or multifocality. Hepatic surgical margins are negative, and lymph node status is negative. Chronic hepatitis B is scored as grade 1 activity and stage 1 fibrosis. The patient has a history of hepatitis B and HCC. Two masses are identified, with the first (3.5 cm) abutting the hepatic capsule and located within 1.1 cm of the resection margin. The second mass (2 cm) approaches the resection margin to within 0.2 cm and is located 1.5 cm from the first mass. The report includes details about gross and microscopic examination, diagnosis, and attending pathologist review.

The pathology report pertains to a male patient with a suspected diagnosis of mesothelioma, mucinous adenocarcinoma or lymphoma. The macroscopic analysis revealed nodular solid grey-white tissue on the left chest wall along with a wedge-shaped section of lung tissue. The frozen section report indicates an invasive malignant epithelioid tumor and suggests a provisional diagnosis of mesothelioma or adenocarcinoma. Further paraffin and IPOX tests are needed for a definite diagnosis. The microscopic analysis confirms an infiltrating malignant tumor with a predominantly infiltrative growth pattern extending into the underlying pulmonary parenchyma. There is also an atypical papillary proliferation of mesothelial cells on the visceral pleura. Special immunoperoxidase stains show infiltrating tumor CALRETININ positive, TTF-1 negative, CAM 5.2 positive, CK 7 positive, CK20 patchy weak to moderate positivity, EMA positive with cytoplasmic and rim positivity, AE 1/3 positive, PSA negative, CD15 negative, CEA negative, CK5/6 patchy moderate positivity. The overall conclusion of the report is a diagnosis of malignant mesothelioma with nodular and diffuse growth patterns in the left chest wall and left lingula.

The pathology report describes a Whipple's resection specimen, from a patient with a pancreatic head mass suspected to be pancreatic cancer. The tumour is an infiltrative, pale, firm, ill-defined margin, with dimensions of 15 x 15 x 15 mm located in the pancreatic body/pancreatic head. Sections of the tumour confirm a well-to-moderately differentiated ductal adenocarcinoma, measuring 20 x 20 x 20 mm, with perineural and small vessel invasion, extensive perineural infiltration, and spread into the peripancreatic tissue. There is lymphovascular space invasion noted, with three out of eleven peripancreatic lymph nodes involved, and involvement of posterior soft tissue and portal vein margins, with positive margins less than 10 mm from the tumour. Chronic pancreatitis and cholecystitis and cholelithiasis are present. The overall stage is Stage IIB. The report does not provide any information about the patient or the doctor or hospital that carried out the procedure.

Final pathologic diagnosis: Right kidney, partial nephrectomy. Renal cell carcinoma, papillary type, Fuhrman grade I, 2.5 cm. No tumor at inked resection margin. The tumor is located in the upper pole of the kidney and does not penetrate the capsule or perirenal fat. Hilar lymph nodes and renal veins are not affected. No adrenal gland involvement. The stage is pT1aNXMX. The specimen consists of tan kidney parenchyma with a small amount of white-yellow, friable tumor measuring 1.9 x 1.3 x 2.3 cm and a separate fragment of tumor measuring approximately 2.5 cm in diameter. There is also detached perinephric fat measuring 9.5 x 5.5 x 2.0 cm, adjacent to the tumor and capsule.

Pathologic diagnosis reports fibroadipose and vascular tissue with no tumor in several biopsies of various margins and lymph nodes. The biopsy of the prostate and seminal vesicles shows prostatic adenocarcinoma with Gleason score 3+4, estimated volume of 7cc, perineural infiltration, and extraprostatic extension. The margin status for benign prostate glands is negative, and high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia is present focally. The lymph node status is negative, and the AJCC/UICC stage is pT3aNOMX. The gross pathology findings reveal extensively mottled prostatic parenchyma ranging from pink-tan to light brown, with the exterior capsule intact and the seminal vesicles/vas deferens bundles soft, red-tan, and whorled. Nine parts are submitted for examination and potential research studies, and representative sections are submitted for the final diagnosis.

The pathology report describes a radical prostatectomy for a man with prostate cancer. The prostate gland measures 4 cm x 6 cm x 4 cm, is roughened and pink-tan, and contains a 0.7 cm suspicious lesion in the right half. The prostate tumor is a small acinar adenocarcinoma with bilateral involvement and extraprostatic extension, Gleason grade 3+3 with a score of 6. The right seminal vesicle shows prostatic adenocarcinoma invasion and perineural infiltration. There is extensive invasion of the capsule and extraprostatic extension present, particularly at the right posterior quadrant. The involvement of seminal vesicles is present on the right side. No tumor is present at inked excision margins, but benign glands are present. The final diagnosis is prostatic adenocarcinoma with a Gleason score of 3+3, with AJCC/UICC stage pT3bNXMX.

Pathology report: A) Anterior prostatic fat: Benign adipose tissue; no carcinoma or prostatic epithelium. B) Tissue anterior to seminal vesicles: Focal crushed cells positive for keratin, suspicious for carcinoma. C) Right pelvic lymph nodes dissection: No tumor in six lymph nodes (0/6). D) Left pelvic lymph nodes dissection: No tumor in four lymph nodes (0/4). E) Prostate and seminal vesicles radical prostatectomy: 1. Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 5+4=9, invading into bilateral seminal vesicles. 2. Focal crushed cells weakly positive for keratin at bladder margin; equivocal for the presence of tumor cells at the bladder margin. Comment: The tissue anterior to seminal vesicles and the right bladder margin demonstrate a small focus of crushed cells. Definitive diagnosis cannot be rendered due to hampered cytomorphology by crush artifact. The synoptic comment for prostate tumors includes the type of tumor, location, estimated volume of tumor, Gleason score, involvement of capsule, extraprostatic extension, margin status for tumor and benign prostate glands, high-grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia, tumor involvement of seminal vesicles, perineural infiltration, lymphovascular invasion, lymph node status, and AJCC/UICC stage. The case includes multiple specimens, including anterior prostatic fat, tissue anterior to seminal vesicles, right and left pelvic lymph nodes, and prostate with seminal vesicles. The prostate exhibits gross abnormalities such as firm yellow-tan lobulated parenchyma, a 0.5 cm tan nodule on the left anterior mid gland, and surgical clips on the right and left seminal vesicles and right lateral bladder margin. The attending pathologist made the final diagnosis based on gross and microscopic examinations, including review of all pathology slides and preliminary interpretations.

Summary: The pathology report describes a large pigmented tumor in the postero-lateral part of the left eyeball, which is adherent to the internal face of the sclera. The tumor is a melanoma composed of fusiform cells loaded with melanin pigment, measuring 18 by 12 mm. It infiltrates the internal layers of the sclera but does not extend beyond it. In front, the tumor infiltrates the posterior part of the ciliary body, but it stays outside the iris. Behind, it stays distant from the intraocular emergence of the optic nerve, which is free along its entire course. Cryopreservation samples have been made for further analysis.

Diagnosis: A. Esophageal tissue with intramucosal adenocarcinoma. B. Barrett's esophagus positive for high-grade dysplasia. C. Esophageal tissue with poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. Depth of invasion cannot be assessed due to the nature and size of the specimen. Microscopic examination shows irregularly shaped glands lined with atypical cells extending into the lamina propria without invasion into the submucosa. The Barrett's esophagus shows no invasive activity. The tumor is composed of irregularly shaped sheets of pleomorphic cells with occasional mucin production, brisk mitotic activity, and tumor necrosis. Additional notes include the ICD-9 code 150.9 for malignant neoplasm of the esophagus and the CPT code 88305x3.

The report describes a histopathology of a solitary choroidal melanoma in the right globe enucleation of an adult with advanced cataractous changes. The tumour is dome-shaped with a height of 7mm and a size of 12mm, consisting of a mixture of pigmented epithelioid and spindle cells dominated by the latter. The microvasculature of the melanoma is prominent, and closed loops are present, with minimal lymphocytic infiltration within the tumour. The examined vortex veins are free of tumour, and there is no evidence of scleral invasion or extraocular growth. The MLPA molecular genetic examination performed on DNA extracted from the tumour material reveals borderline gains in chromosome 1p, losses and gains in chromosome 3, gains in chromosome 6p, and normal chromosome 8q. Further MSA tests suggest the status of chromosome 3 in the tumour cells is normal (disomy 3). A supplementary report will follow once these investigations are complete.

Stomach antrum adenocarcinoma (Borman classification) with poorly differentiated histological grade III and diffuse pattern according to Lauren's Classification measuring 11.0 cm with ulceration and adjacent adipose tissue involvement. Spiculated type of tumor invasion, discrete inflammatory reaction, and present neural infiltration with lymphatic vascular invasion. Absence of blood vascular invasion and no tumor implantation in peri-visceral adipose tissue detected. Proximal margin involved by neoplasia, distal margin uninvolved. Greater omentum involved by neoplasia with lymph node metastasis in both lesser and greater curvature (12/12 and 6/8 respectively) with capsule perforation.

The pathology report confirms the presence of poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma in the antrum of the stomach, with mild inflammatory response and infiltrative tumor invasion. No tumor implant is observed in the perivisceral fat or greater omentum. Neural invasion is present, whilst blood vessel invasion is doubtful. Moderate chronic gastritis with focal intestinal metaplasia is noted in adjacent mucosa. Lymph nodes are involved by neoplasia, with a total of 14 out of 34 lymph nodes examined showing neoplastic infiltration. The report details the lymph node clusters examined and the involvement in each. The esophageal margin is uninvolved by neoplasia. The report follows JGCA-1998 standardization.

Stomach antrum adenocarcinoma with poorly differentiated tubular pattern and intestinal type according to Lauren classification. Largest tumor size of 9.0 cm with ulceration and local invasion to serosa, neural, lymphatic, and blood vessel invasion present. Hepatoduodenal ligament, left gastroepiploic vessels, and infrapyloric lymph nodes involved by neoplasia. Other examined lymph node chains, esophageal margin, peritoneum from cardia, mesenteric lymph node, and hepatogastric ligament uninvolved by neoplasia.

The pathology report describes a moderately differentiated tubular adenocarcinoma in the antral region of a total gastrectomy specimen, with tumor invasion into the serosa and non-peritonized fat tissue from gastric lesser curvature. Non-neoplastic mucosa with inactive superficial chronic gastritis is also observed. There is no evidence of angiolymphatic or perineural invasion, and surgical margins are uninvolved by neoplasia. Lymphadenectomy shows no involvement by neoplasia in the majority of lymph nodes examined, with some fat tissue without specific features and absence of lymph nodes in the suprapyloric region. The omentum, hepatogastric ligament, and esophageal margin are uninvolved by neoplasia. Fibrous and fat tissue without specific features are seen in the hepatoduodenal ligament.

Summary: The pathology report indicates a moderately differentiated tubule-vilous adenocarcinoma from the cardia with focal invasion to the subserosa adipose tissue and extensive to the distal esophagus. The tumor's largest size is 6.5 cm, and perineural invasion is present, while angiolymphatic invasion is not observed. Surgical margins are uninvolved by neoplasia. There is no involvement by neoplasia in any of the 21 lymph nodes from the lesser curvature and the seven lymph nodes from the greater curvature. The esophageal margin is uninvolved by neoplasia.

Filtered report: Stomach adenocarcinoma located in the body and antrum with mucosecreting mucocellular and "signet ring" cells histologic pattern, poorly differentiated with a size of 4.0cm, ulceration, and compromise of serosa. Additionally, there is neural and lymphatic vascular invasion, but no sanguineous vascular involvement or tumor implant in perivisceral adipose tissue. Lymph node involvement present with compromised 13 nodes out of which five are compromised, with a compromised lymph to dissected nodes ratio of 4/11 from greater curvature and 2/2 from lesser curvature. The greater and lesser omentum are free of neoplastic involvement. Chronic gastritis with intestinal metaplasia is also present.
Cervix biopsy reveals invasive squamous cell carcinoma grade 3.

Cervical squamous cell carcinoma of histological grade 2 infiltrated the wall in the deepest third, measuring 1.1 cm, with no involvement of surgical margins. No neoplasia detected in the pelvic or obturator lymph nodes (0/10). The left uterine tube contains a serous cyst. No neoplasia is present in the right and left parametrium. There is no angiolymphatic or perineural infiltration.
PRIMARY SITE: Cervix. Biopsy of the cervix. - Moderately differentiated and infiltrative squamous cell carcinoma.
Cervical biopsy shows invasive moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma with no vascular infiltrations.
Cervix biopsy reveals non-keratinizing invasive squamous cell carcinoma without angiolymphatic invasion.
Cervical biopsy showed invasive grade III squamous cell carcinoma without angiolymphatic invasion.
PRIMARY SITE: Cervix. 1- - "Biopsy of uterine cervix": Mucinous adenocarcinoma of endocervical type moderately differentiated. with extensive necrosis.
Cervical biopsy revealed invasive, moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma.

A female patient underwent surgery with diagnosis of cholangiocarcinoma. A solid mass (4.3 x 3.1 X 0.8 cm) was identified in the distal common bile duct, extending into the pancreas with perineural invasion. Angiolymphatic invasion was absent. All surgical resection margins were negative for tumor, with a minimum tumor free margin of 1.0 cm. Multiple (22) regional lymph nodes were negative for metastatic tumor. Gallbladder was negative for tumor. Multiple (3) lymph nodes in the new uncinate margin were negative for tumor as well.

Summary: The pathology report describes the findings of a tumor in the left adrenal gland measuring 2x2x1 cm consisting of polygonal cells with a granular cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei. The tumor is surrounded by a fatty-connective tissue capsule with focal invasion of retroperitoneal fat and lymphatic vessels. A normal adrenal tissue with zonal organization is present in the specimen. The report also mentions the absence of hyperplasia of the adrenal medulla. A separate report confirms the presence of lymph node metastasis.

The pathology report describes a case of a patient who underwent a right adrenalectomy and resection of a periaortic-pericave paraganglioma and inter-aortico-caval lymph node. The patient had a clinical history of headache, hypertension, and right abdominal pain. Two lesions were found on a CT scan, and metanephrines levels were high. The patient had preeclampsia during pregnancy and gave birth to a healthy child. The report indicates that the adrenal tumor was 3.5 cm with a PASS score of 6, and the paraganglioma was 5 cm with capsular invasion and extension to the adjacent fat and lymph node. The prognosis for both chromaffin tumors is reserved. Microscopic examination showed small cells of the adrenal medulla and a population of monotonous elements arranged in nests. The extra-tumoral adrenal did not contain micro-nodulation, and there were no glomerulosa hyperplasia or nodulation from fasciculata. The report concludes with a description of the tumor elements' phenotype and the extent of tumor proliferation.

The patient underwent left and right adrenalectomy due to bilateral adrenal nodules attributed to pheochromocytomas. The left adrenal tumor was limited by fibrous condensation and exhibited large tumor cells with basophilic cytoplasm, but no mitosis or necrosis. The tumor size was 1 cm and considered benign with a PASS score of 0. The right adrenal tumor was also benign with a size of 2 cm and a PASS score of 0. The cytological and immunohistochemical morphological characteristics were identical to the left tumor. The tumor cells expressed chromogranin, synaptophysin, and N-Cam. The patient's clinical history involved recent hypertension with sudden headaches, but no risk factors were reported.

Filtered pathology report: Date received: Evaluated on left adrenal. Macroscopy: A surgical specimen weighing 236g and measuring 9.5x8x5.5 cm consist of an adrenal gland with a tumor mass (4.5x3.5x9 cm) with necrosis in the center. Microscopy: The mass is a malignant pheochromocytoma with a PASS score of 12, indicating the presence of several malignant features. The conclusion is malignant pheochromocytoma with no disease in small lymph nodes.

Right globe biopsy report indicates the presence of iridociliciochoroidal melanoma composed of mixed spindled and epithelioid cell types and invading the ciliary body and iris with scleral invasion and extraocular extension. The site of origin of ciliary body versus choroid cannot be definitively determined, and the tumor has a 19 mm base and 12 mm height with a mitotic rate of 2 per 10 hpf. The extraocular extension was seen in the region just outside the limbus and may represent invasion via the canal of Schlemm versus invasion of the SC in this area. The primary tumor is staged as pT4d. Biomarker testing was conducted. The report doesn't include any irrelevant information related to patient names, hospital, or doctor orders and has a total of 976 characters.

Pathology report of the enucleation specimen of the right globe shows 14 mm base spindled type choroidal melanoma with superficial scleral invasion. No optic nerve invasion or vortex vein tumor involvement is identified. Mitotic activity is observed at 3 per 10 high-power fields. The tumor appears confined to the globe and is harvested. The specimen is sectioned and examined. SNOMED codes of the diagnosis are T-AA000 and M-87203.

The pathology report describes two specimens: a partial liver resection from Segment 6 and an intact gallbladder. The liver specimen is a moderately differentiated hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) with clear cell and giant cell features, measuring 3.5 cm in size and confined to the liver with negative margins. The surrounding liver is non-cirrhotic and without apparent fibrosis. The gallbladder specimen is a benign simple cyst with minimal chronic inflammation, and no dysplasia or malignancy is observed. The HCC mass shows areas of fibrous septation and trabecular arrangements of atypical cells, with variable cell size and shape, mitotic activity, and clear cytoplasm, and no notable fibrosis or nodularity. The hepatic parenchyma shows a minimal lymphocytic infiltrate, and hepatocytes have brown granular pigment. The gallbladder cyst wall is lined by bland epithelial cells, and the gallbladder mucosa has minimal lymphocytic infiltrate.

A year-old female with a clinical history of breast cancer underwent a left breast total mastectomy that revealed invasive ductal carcinoma with two foci, measuring 1.2 cm and 1.8 cm. The final margins are negative for carcinoma. Additional reresection specimens submitted from four different locations revealed no diagnostic abnormalities. The sentinel lymph node biopsy identified micrometastatic mammary carcinoma of 0.23mm, and one out of two nodes had micrometastases. The tumor is invasive and moderately differentiated with a nuclear grade of 2. Additionally, DCIS is present focal, intermediate nuclear grade, without necrosis, and there is focal lymph-vascular invasion. The final diagnosis concludes invasive carcinoma of the breast, present in the left breast's lower inner quadrant and mid-outer quadrant. The provisional pathologic staging is pT2N(sn)1miM (not applicable). No distant metastasis was identified.

Interpretation and Diagnosis: Brain Tumor - Diffuse Astrocytoma (WHO Grade II). Although cellularity and cytological atypia are moderate, no mitoses are identified, and MIB-1 rate is low. Clinical History: Low Grade Astrocytoma - Glioma. Gross description: Brain tumor consisting of soft pink-red fragments of tissue measuring 4.5 x 1.5 x 0.4 cm. No mitoses are identified, and the specimen is entirely submitted. Another brain tumor specimen consists of multiple fragments of pink-tan soft tissue measuring 1 x 0.5 x 0.2 cm in aggregate, and is submitted in its entirety. Some stains/tests performed may not have FDA approval.

Final diagnosis: Invasive thymoma, predominantly epithelial, with lymphatic involvement. The thymus specimen weighed 160 grams and measured 20 x 11 x 2 cm, with a somewhat well-defined 6 x 5.5 x 2.5 cm mass. Microscopically, the mass consisted of polygonal cells with occasional mitosis and foci of squamoid differentiation, divided by hyalinized fibrous septa. Perivascular edema was present, and foci of extracapsular invasion and lymphatic vessel involvement were found. The tumor approached closely to the inked resection margin.

The pathology report describes a radical cystoprostatectomy, bilateral pelvic lymph node dissection, and urinary diversion (T-pouch) procedure. Frozen section diagnoses of the right and left distal ureters, para-aortic proximal limits lymph nodes, and apical urethral margin revealed no high grade atypia or tumor, while the final diagnoses of benign ureters were confirmed without urothelial dysplasia or malignancy. The bladder and prostate sections showed invasive poorly differentiated urothelial carcinoma with signet ring cell features, grade 4/4, with gross and microscopic extension into the anterior and right and left lateral bladder walls involving perivesical soft tissue. Lymphovascular invasion was identified, and urothelial carcinoma in situ was present. The bladder resection margins were free of malignancy. The prostate showed extensive urothelial carcinoma involving periprostatic soft tissue, invading prostatic stroma and lymphovascular space, and extending around the seminal vesicles. The uninvolved prostate showed cystic atrophy and rare foci of high grade prostatic intraepithelial neoplasia. Metastatic carcinoma was identified in 30 out of 53 lymph nodes examined. The pathologic TNM stage was pT4aN2MX. A discrepancy in frozen section and final diagnosis was noted in the apical urethral margin. The specimen sources and sections for examination were also described.

Filtered report: Final diagnosis: A. Left pelvic lymph node biopsy: No evidence of malignancy (0/1). B. Right pelvic lymph node biopsy: No evidence of malignancy (0/3). C. Prostatectomy: Prostatic adenocarcinoma, Gleason score 4+3 (score 7/10), involving 90% of the tissue, and involving the right distal urethral margin and bilateral lateral margins. Extracapsular extension and seminal vesicle invasion present. Lymphovascular invasion not identified. Perineural invasion present. Additional information: Pathologic staging: pT3bN0M(not applicable). Gross description: Lymph nodes and prostate received, with detailed measurements and appearance. Intraoperative consultation: Both left and right pelvic lymph nodes were negative for malignancy. The report has been reviewed by a pathologist and the attending physician.

Summary: The pathology report is for a male patient with a history of prostate cancer who underwent a prostatectomy. The report confirms the presence of adenocarcinoma, with a moderately differentiated Gleason score of 3+4=7. The tumor involves 10% of the prostate, is multicentric in both lobes, and there is no evidence of extraprostatic extension, seminal vesicle invasion, perineural invasion, or vascular invasion. The margins are clear. The final diagnosis shows that there is no evidence of malignancy in the bladder neck margin. The pathologic stage assigned is pT2cNXMX, which is provisional and subject to change based on the patient's clinical status and/or prior pathology.

The specimen is a resection of a 7 cm thymic tumor identified as a Type B2 thymoma, primarily encapsulated with focal tumor extension into the capsule. There is no invasion of the visceral pleural, and all resection margins are negative for tumor. The tumor appears completely excised. The patient has a history of myasthenia gravis. No other nodules or masses are identified, and no lymph nodes are detected. Microscopic examination reveals a circumscribed tumor composed of small lymphocytes and larger cells with open chromatin pattern and prominent nucleoli. Immunohistochemical stains show diffuse positive staining of the larger cells for CK5/6 and a majority of the lymphocytes are CD1a positive, consistent with a thymoma. The tumor is staged as IIa with microscopic transcapsular invasion.

Gender: F. A biopsy of the innominate vein lymph node shows no malignancy. A resection of the thymus reveals a mixed thymoma, WHO type AB2, with focal microscopic invasion of the tumor capsule. The tumor has a greatest dimension of 7.0 cm, and the specimen's margins are uninvolved by the tumor. The lesion is immunohistochemically consistent with a mixed thymoma (WHO type AB2) modified Masaoka stage IIa, and there is no evidence of regional lymph node metastasis or distant metastasis. The thymus measures 12.5 x 6.1 x 3.0 cm, and the tumor's capsule is mobile on its surface. Sections are representative of the tumor, capsule, adjacent normal thymus tissue as well as normal thymus tissue. Immunohistochemistry shows the infiltrating lymphocytes to be positive for CD5, and the epithelial cells to be positive for keratins (CK5/6, AE1/AE3) and p63.

Filtered Summary: Dx: Melanoma. Tumor on skin localized on left femur. Epithelial melanoma confirmed with a Clark level of 4 and Breslow depth of 5mm. No metastasis detected, with a tumor size of 4x5mm. Stage II. No additional information available.

Filtered Report: Clinical Dx: Melanoma. Tumor Location: Skin. Localization: Abdominal wall. Source: Epithelial melanoma. Clark Level: 5. Breslow: 16mm. Tumor: 4. Normal: 3. Metastasis: 0. Stage: 3. Tumor size: 15x12mm.

Left partial nephrectomy was performed to remove a 2.4 cm papillary renal cell carcinoma, type 1, located at the upper pole of the kidney. The tumor was limited to the kidney, and no sarcomatoid features or tumor necrosis were identified. The tumor extended focally to the cauterized inked parenchymal resection margin of the specimen. No lymphovascular invasion was present, and pathologic staging showed pT1a. Chronic inflammation, congestion, and dystrophic calcifications were detected in the nonneoplastic kidney. The tumor had 95% tumor nuclei, 0% necrosis, and 5% normal nuclei. The formalin fixation time was measured and total cold ischemia time was calculated. No other tumors or tumor-like lesions were identified. Patient consent was obtained, and the study was conducted following quality control.

Diagnosis: Acinar adenocarcinoma of the prostate with a Gleason score of 9 (5+4) and no tertiary pattern identified. The tumor is located in the apex, mid, and base sections of both the right and left sides, with extra-prostatic extension. Seminal vesical invasion is present, as well as involvement of the surgical margins by invasive carcinoma and lymphovascular invasion. The proportion of the prostate involved by the carcinoma is 70%. Metastasis is present in 5 out of 10 right pelvic obturator lymph nodes and 6 out of 9 left pelvic obturator lymph nodes. The pathological stage is pT3b, pN1, pMX. No perineural invasion or additional pathologic findings are reported.
The pathology report states that biopsy samples from the right pleura indicate Mesothelioma. Immunohistochemistry exam supports this diagnosis.

Final Pathologic Diagnosis: Left eye enucleation revealed a malignant melanoma, mixed with predominantly spindle cell type. Vortex vein left eye biopsy showed no evidence of malignant melanoma, and all controls showed appropriate reactivity. Microscopic examination revealed a large choroidal tumor composed mainly of a cohesive spindle cell proliferation with areas having an epithelioid appearance. Mitotic figures were rare, and the ciliary body was not involved by the tumor. The optic nerve was not observed on the sections taken. Cytogenetic analysis of this sample shows an abnormal clone of cells with a translocation between chromosomes 3 and 6. The significance of the rearrangement of chromosomes 3 and 6 in this sample is not known.

Material for pathology report is a Thymoma tumor measuring at 10.0 X 8.0 X 5.0 cm with a focal infiltration of capsule and lung parenchyma. The diagnosis is Type A-Thymoma at pT3, pNx, Masaoka-Koga III. The immunohistochemistry shows epithelial cells that are positive for CK5/6 and KL1, and some CD99- and TdT-positive immature T-lymphocytes.

Filtered report summary: The pathology report describes a lobular constructed thymic tumor that is predominantly lymphocyte-rich. It is identified as an expanded type AB thymoma with infiltration into the mediastinal fat (resection complete) and a central regressive alteration. There is stone-shaped cytological atypia in the lymphocyte-poor tumor sections, but the thymic tissue appears regular without thymitis. The mediastinal lymph nodes are minimally activated, not enlarged, and tumor-free. The tumor stage is Masaoka II (marginal findings). The report confirms no discrepancy between the histology on frozen and paraffin sections.

The pathology report describes a bladder and prostate specimen from a radical cystoprostatectomy for G3 pT2 TCC. The report details that the bladder contains a poorly differentiated predominantly solid urothelial carcinoma, which extends into the perivesical fat and shows lymphovascular invasion. The report also notes the presence of a minor degree of nodular hyperplasia in the prostate, but no evidence of microacinar adenocarcinoma. Additionally, there are metastatic urothelial carcinomas identified in the peri-bladder nodes, and in two of the six lymph nodes examined. The left ureteric margin and the right ureteric margin are both morphologically normal. The report concludes that the diagnosis is a poorly differentiated ulcerated urothelial carcinoma pT3b pN1 R0 (but close circumferential margin on the right side).

A cervical biopsy specimen labeled "cervical biopsy" with an irregular pink-tan to gray-tan glistening portion of tissue measuring 0.7 x 0.6 x 0.4 cm was received in formalin. The gross description shows invasive squamous cell carcinoma, large cell keratinizing. The entire specimen was trisected and submitted in one cassette. CPT code for the procedure was 88305 and the ICD9 code for the diagnosis was 180.9.

The pathology report describes the presence of malignant mesothelioma in several locations including a port site, lymph nodes, pleura, and diaphragm. The tumor exhibits mixed epithelial and sarcomatoid features with papillary and solid areas. The largest nodule measures 14.2 cm and invades fibroadipose tissue and focally lung parenchyma. Lymphovascular invasion is identified. However, skeletal muscle, bone marrow, and skin with foreign body giant cell reaction are negative for tumor. The report includes gross descriptions and tissue submitted for examination. The senior physician has conducted a microscopic examination and confirmed the diagnosis.
